Boston went 2-0 against Dallas during the regular season. The Celtics won the last regular season matchup 138-110 on March 2 led by 32 points from Jayson Tatum, while Luka Doncic scored 37 points for the Mavericks.\n\nThe Celtics have gone 37-4 at home. Boston is the NBA leader with 35.6 defensive rebounds per game led by Tatum averaging 7.2.\n\nThe Mavericks have gone 25-16 away from home. Dallas ranks ninth in the Western Conference shooting 36.9% from 3-point range.\n\nThe 120.6 points per game the Celtics average are 5.0 more points than the Mavericks allow (115.6). The Mavericks are shooting 48.1% from the field, 2.8% higher than the 45.3% the Celtics' opponents have shot this season.\n\nTOP PERFORMERS: Tatum is shooting 47.1% and averaging 26.9 points for the Celtics. Derrick White is averaging 3.2 made 3-pointers over the last 10 games.\n\nDaniel Gafford is scoring 11.0 points per game and averaging 7.6 rebounds for the Mavericks. Doncic is averaging 29.1 points and 10.5 rebounds over the last 10 games.\n\nLAST 10 GAMES: Celtics: 9-1, averaging 113.8 points, 44.0 rebounds, 24.0 assists, 6.4 steals and 5.2 blocks per game while shooting 48.9% from the field. Their opponents have averaged 104.1 points per game.\n\nMavericks: 8-2, averaging 109.8 points, 43.9 rebounds, 23.5 assists, 6.1 steals and 5.9 blocks per game while shooting 48.3% from the field. {"uri": "8164313316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:57:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:57:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:56:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/nba-finals-key-storylines-full-schedule-and-how-to-watch/article_b1d8ab6e-31b9-567c-9a84-86b123abc411.html", "title": "NBA Finals: Key storylines, full schedule and how to watch", "body": "(CNN) -- After eight months of grueling competition, 30 teams have been whittled down to just two.\n\nThe Boston Celtics and the Dallas Mavericks are the last teams standing and will face off in the 2024 NBA Finals, which begin at TD Garden on Thursday, for a chance to etch their names into the history books.\n\nHow to watch\n\nThe NBA Finals will be broadcast exclusively on ABC in the United States.\n\nIn the UK, BBC One and TNT Sports will air the Finals, but international fans can also watch the best-of-seven series on NBA League Pass.\n\nCeltics juggernaut?\n\nWith 64 wins, the Celtics were by far the most dominant team throughout the regular season and have continued that impressive run into the playoffs, losing just two games all postseason.\n\nHowever, those wins come with the slight caveat of the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers and Indiana Pacers missing key players - Jimmy Butler, Donovan Mitchell and Tyrese Haliburton, respectively - for all or part of those series.\n\nRegardless, the Celtics have taken care of business in a supremely efficient manner this postseason and will be hoping that second-year head coach Joe Mazzulla can finally push the team over the top.\n\nThe Celtics have enjoyed incredible playoff consistency in recent seasons. This is the sixth time in eight years the franchise has reached at least the Conference Finals and the second time in three years Boston has reached the Finals. The coveted Larry O'Brien Trophy, however, has so far eluded them.\n\nVictory in this year's Finals would give the Celtics a record-breaking 18th NBA title, taking them past the Los Angeles Lakers as the most successful franchise in the league.\n\nCritics and opponents have at times maligned the Celtics as having a soft underbelly, with key players or the team as a whole struggling in the biggest moments; both last year's shock loss to the No. 8 seed Miami Heat in the Eastern Conference Finals and Jayson Tatum's performances in the 2022 NBA Finals being examples of these concerns.\n\n\"There's a lot that myself and we can learn from that experience, being in the Finals,\" Tatum told reporters. \"This go-around is a lot different. Obviously, we've been there before and we came up short. It's a great opportunity to make it to Finals again, you don't always get a second chance.\n\n\"I'm really just looking at it as a second chance, trying to simplify things as much as we can. It's another series that we gotta win.\n\n\"Having nine days off [before the Finals] is good for your body and for everybody to get healthy, but we're in the NBA Finals and we're all so anxious and excited to play. I wish it did start a little bit earlier, so we could get after it, but we have a lot of guys of who been here before and we understand the magnitude of this moment and saying sharp, fresh and staying ready.\"\n\nBut the team has shown impressive mettle this postseason, in particular in the Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers. Three times in that series, the Celtics found themselves down late but turned each of the games around to earn a sweep, thanks largely to series MVP Jaylen Brown.\n\nAccording to ESPN Stats and Info, the Pacers had at least a 90% win probability during the fourth quarters of Games 1, 3 and 4.\n\nCan Luka emulate Dirk?\n\nWhile the Celtics have been on a roll since day one, the Dallas Mavericks didn't really turn their season around until February's trade deadline.\n\nThe addition of more size and length in Daniel Gafford and PJ Washington has perfectly complimented the superstar backcourt of Luka Don\u010di\u0107 and Kyrie Irving, who have taken turns carrying the team throughout this playoff run.\n\nMeanwhile, Dereck Lively II is capping off a mightily impressive rookie season by becoming a valuable rotation piece for the Mavericks this playoff run, while Derrick Jones Jr. has grown as a player and made some huge buckets in the postseason.\n\nThough Don\u010di\u0107, who finished third in MVP voting, is still performing at a high level, a knee injury means he has struggled at times to reach the heights of the regular season; so much of Dallas' success will rest on the Slovenian's fitness and form.\n\nHead coach Jason Kidd could further cement his place in Mavericks history by leading the team to the title. It has been 13 years since Kidd helped bring the franchise its first and only Larry O'Brien trophy as a player, assisting Dirk Nowitzki in a stunning Finals win over the Miami Heat.\n\n\"It was a tough road to get back here [the Finals],\" Irving told reporters. \"So I'm just appreciating all of the little steps that it took, appreciating all the people who helped me grow. It was a great reflection period the last couple of days just thinking about not only the past few years, but what we were able to accomplish this year in such a short period of time.\n\n\"How we galvanized the city of Dallas and our fans, and it just feels like we've got the whole world supporting us throughout this endeavor, so I'm appreciative and grateful for everything that I had to go through and everything my teammates had to go through in order to get here with me.\"\n\nFull schedule\n\nAll games are away vs. home\n\n* Game 1: Mavericks vs. Celtics, June 6 - 8:30 p.m. ET\n\n* Game 2: Mavericks vs. Celtics, June 9 - 8:00 p.m. ET\n\n* Game 3: Celtics vs. Mavericks, June 12 - 8:30 p.m. ET\n\n* Game 4: Celtics vs. Mavericks, June 14 - 8:30 p.m. ET\n\n* *Game 5: Mavericks vs. Celtics, June 17 - 8:30 p.m. ET\n\n* *Game 6: Celtics vs. Mavericks, June 20 - 8:30 p.m. ET\n\n* *Game 7: Mavericks vs. Celtics, June 23 - 8:00 p.m. ET\n\n* If needed\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. They've got two of the best ever,\" he told Rachel Nichols and DeMarcus Cousins. \"Obviously, Jayson Tatum and those guys are really good. Jaylen Brown is really good. But Luka (Doncic) and Kyrie (Irving) are something we haven't seen. They are the best duo (in the Finals). They don't just have the best player.\"\n\nIrving is the only one out of Doncic, Brown and Tatum to have won an NBA title. It's been eight years since he last did so, but the 32-year-old has found new life in Dallas and elevated his game his game in the regular season. But he's seen a small dip in the playoffs averaging 22.8 points, 3.9 rebounds, 5.2 assists and 1.2 steals per game.\n\nThe eight-time All-Star has championship experience and has been able to be consistent throughout. In 13 Finals games, Irving averaged 27.7 points, 4.2 assists and as many rebounds.\n\nDoncic has also been a force for Dallas en route to the NBA Finals averaging 28.8 points, 9.6 assists and 8.8 rebounds.\n\nAfter Doncic and Irving, though, Thomas isn't sold on the rest of the Mavs' roster, noting \"the difference\" between the two teams is the Celtics' starting five \"is amazing.\" Because of the roster as a whole, Thomas believes his former Celtics team will take care of the Mavericks and win Banner 18.\n\nThe Mavericks will likely pose the tallest task for the Celtics. Despite only losing two games in their playoff run, their opponents have been without some of their star players due to injuries, causing some to believe they had an easy route to the Finals.\n\nBut Brown and Tatum have done everything right thus far. If Tatum had a down game, Brown, Al Horford and Derrick White were there to put up points.\n\nThere's already plenty of noise surrounding the series with Irving and Kristaps Porzingis playing their former teams. Celtics fans have never quite forgiven Irving for how he departed Boston, and there's reportedly \"real beef\" with Mavericks fans and Porzingis.\n\nThe NBA Finals begin Thursday night at TD Garden at {"uri": "8162817714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "11:50:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T11:50:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T11:49:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/celtics-mavericks-nba-finals-tatum-brown-doncic-irving-porzingis-defense-threes/", "title": "What to watch for when the Celtics and the Mavericks battle in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- After a grueling wait that has felt like months, the NBA Finals will finally tip off in Boston on Thursday night. The Celtics and the Mavericks should treat us to quite the battle, with a lot of star power ready to leave it all out there for a championship.\n\nJayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have led the Celtics to the biggest stage for the second time in the last three years, and are determined to bring a banner (the organization's 18th) back to Boston. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are standing in their way, as the Mavs look to finish off their mid-season turnaround with Dallas' second title.\n\nThe top-seeded Celtics were the best team in basketball throughout the season and are well-rested heading into the NBA Finals after a lengthy break following their Eastern Conference Finals sweep of the Indiana Pacers. The Mavericks enjoyed a long break too after finishing off the Minnesota Timberwolves in the Western Conference Finals in five games. They are just the second fifth seed to make it to the NBA Finals.\n\nDallas will be the best team the Celtics face this postseason, with a two-headed monster in Doncic and Irving leading a talented and deadly offensive attack. The Mavs are battle-tested too, beating a trio of 50-plus win teams to get to the Finals.\n\nWhile the Celtics have pretty much rolled to their 76 wins this season (64 in the regular season before 12 more in the playoffs), the Mavericks morphed into a new team in the weeks following the trade deadline. Acquiring P.J. Washington and Daniel Gafford gave Dallas backbone on defense, and the Mavs have made incredible strides toward becoming a complete team.\n\nBut the Celtics are the better team from top to bottom, and their defense will likely be the difference in this matchup. Here's what we'll be watching for throughout the NBA Finals.\n\nWe'll start with the main attraction with this showdown, which is the star power on both sides. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown vs. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving is a pretty sweet Finals matchup.\n\nLuka and Kyrie are both insanely talented scorers who can put the ball in the hoop in a number of ways from just about anywhere on the floor. Tatum and Brown may not have the scoring prowess of those two but they are also pretty good at racking up points and setting up others. And the Jays are two-way stars who bring a big impact on the defensive end as well.\n\nDoncic is the best player in this series. He can sink shots from anywhere with just about anyone on him, and he does so in an incredibly crafty and unpredictable way. He is in no way the most athletic player on the floor, but he can pick apart just about any defense. It's in his DNA to want to rip out the hearts of his opposition. He logged a triple-double in both regular-season meetings with the Celtics.\n\nWith Irving and his three-level attack in the same backcourt as Doncic and his creativity, the Boston defense is in for a massive challenge this series. But the Celtics have the bodies to make life difficult on both of the Mavs stars, and Tatum and Brown will be part of that equation along with Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, and Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nOffensively, Tatum and Brown will have to have an efficient series for Boston to be at its best. And they were both excellent against the Mavs during the regular season, with Tatum averaging 35.5 points off 52.5 percent shooting and 41.2 percent from three. This matchup could be what he needs to get out of his shooting slump, and we could finally get one of the Tatum takeover games we've been clamoring for.\n\nBrown averaged just under 30 points over his two games against Dallas, hitting 57 percent from the floor. He's been incredible this postseason on both ends of the floor, and will have to keep that going against the Mavs. Brown will likely be spending a lot of time on Doncic on the defensive end, so his offense may dip a bit with that tough assignment.\n\nBut if Tatum and Brown have the likes of P.J. Washington, Derrick Jones Jr., or Josh Green guarding them, they should put up some Luka-Kryie-like stat lines for the Celtics.\n\nIf you like star power, this NBA Finals matchup will provide plenty.\n\nTatum and Brown should be hunting out Luka or Kyrie every time they have the ball in their hands, at least as much as they can without throwing off the flow and rhythm of the Boston offense. It will be a balancing act, but one the Celtics should try to work to their advantage.\n\nDoncic and Irving put in the work to become better defensive players down the stretch, but they are still liabilities on that end of the floor. The Celtics should test them 1-on-1 or make them run through a sea of screens, anything to make them work on defense. Make Luka run around on defense as much as possible, and take it to Kyrie in the post.\n\nThe more energy that duo expends on the defensive end, the less juice they'll have on the offensive end. Make them work on defense and they won't be energizer bunnies on offense. (In theory, at least. Even making Luka work on defense doesn't guarantee that he won't drop a triple-double on Boston.)\n\nOne of Doncic and Irving will go off on a given night. The goal for the Celtics is making sure it's not both of them, as the Mavs are 5-0 this postseason when both Doncic and Irving score 30 points. Making them both work on defense will go a long way toward accomplishing that goal.\n\nKristaps Porzingis is set to return and make the Celtics whole again in Game 1. The Celtics didn't miss him too much against the Heat, the Cavaliers, or the Pacers, but they'll need his floor-stretching and rim-protecting services against the Mavericks. He'll be a matchup nightmare for Dallas in the paint too, with the ability to post up or shoot over Mavs centers Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II.\n\nBut he's coming off a calf injury that forced him to miss 10 games and weeks of practice. The most work Porzingis has done over the last 37 days was taking part in scrimmages at practice. That is nowhere near the intensity he'll see in Game 1 of the NBA Finals.\n\nWe'll see how much rust Porzingis has to shake off and if he's on a minutes restriction his first few games back. It's almost a certainty that the Mavericks are going to test him early and often, so we'll see if he's ready for all that attention.\n\nRemember all that star power we talked about? Don't forget about that next tier of stars, which could be the difference in this series.\n\nAnd that benefits Boston, with Holiday and White forming a backcourt that is almost unfair. Both are defensive wizards and will go a long way in helping the Celtics \"contain\" Doncic and Irving. And with Luka and Kyrie likely combining for at least 70 points per game (that's what \"containing\" those two means, and that number could easily flirt with the 80s on some nights), both will have to drop some points of their own.\n\nQuality is more important than quantity for Holiday and White. Neither has to score 20 every night for Boston to win, but they have to be ready to make big shots when the time comes. Tatum and Brown are going to command a ton of defensive attention, which will leave Holiday and White with good looks.\n\nHoliday was the late-game hero in Game 3 against the Pacers with a clutch three-point play and steal on the defensive end. White wore the cape for Boston in Game 4 with the game-winning/series-sealing corner three in the final seconds. So in addition to being a game-changing defensive duo, they can also pack an offensive punch out of the backcourt.\n\nWashington was a solid deadline pickup for Dallas, giving the Mavs a versatile defender and scorer. He can defend multiple positions and will likely find himself spending a lot of time on Tatum during the Finals. He's also a talent scorer that can knock down threes and has a real solid floater.\n\nDerrick Jones Jr. can fly and send down some wild dunks, and rookie center Derek Lively II brings some size and defense off the bench.\n\nBoth teams are going to let it fly from downtown this series. Boston led the NBA in three-point attempts and makes during the regular season, and that has carried over to the playoffs, with the C's averaging 39.8 attempts and 14.6 makes from three-point and. Nearly half of Boston's shots this postseason have come from downtown, with 47.4 percent of their shot attempts coming from three.\n\nThe Mavs ranked second and third, respectively, in three-point attempts and makes in the regular season. They have taken the fifth-most three-point shots (33.9) and own the third-most makes (12.6) in the playoffs.\n\nThe corner three is a weapon for both teams, as the C's led the league by connecting on 43.6 percent of their shots from the corners. They did a great job taking that away from opponents, holding teams to a league-worst 35.2 percent on corner threes in the regular season and an NBA-low 23.5 percent in the playoffs, via ESPN.\n\nThe Celtics should be able to take away a big part of Dallas' drive-and-kick offense if they continue to defend those corners.\n\nSeriously, Celtics. You're in the NBA Finals. Now is not the time to lose any home games.\n\nBoth of Boston's losses this postseason were at TD Garden. The Celtics would have lost Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals if it weren't for Brown's heroics in the final seconds. Back in the 2022 NBA Finals, the Celtics lost two of their three home games to the Warriors, and were 6-6 at home that postseason.\n\nThe Celtics fought hard for the top seed to land home-court advantage throughout the playoffs. Don't let all that hard work go to waste by dropping one of the first two games of the NBA Finals.", "source": {"uri": "cbsnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS News"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8164637290", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:09:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:09:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:09:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2024/06/06/preview-celtics-take-on-dallasin-2024-nba-finals-game-1/", "title": "Preview: Celtics take on Dallas In 2024 NBA Finals' Game 1", "body": "NAIROBI, Kenya, Jun 6 - Five-time NBA All-Star Jayson Tatum, three-time NBA All-Star Jaylen Brown and the Boston Celtics will host five-time NBA All-Star Luka Doncic, eight-time NBA All-Star Kyrie Irving and the Dallas Mavericks when the 2024 NBA Finals presented by YouTube tips off at Boston's TD Garden at 3:30 a.m. EAT in the early hours of Friday morning.\n\nThis is the first time the Celtics and the Mavericks meet in the NBA Finals.\n\nThis also marks the sixth consecutive season in which the NBA will crown a different champion. The Celtics or Mavericks will follow the Raptors (2018-19), Lakers (2019-20), Bucks (2020-21), Warriors (2021-22) and Nuggets (2022-23) as the most recent NBA champions.\n\nThe only other time in league history with six different champions in a six-season span was 1974-75 - 1979-1980.\n\nThe Celtics finished the regular season on top of the Eastern Conference, with the league's best 64-18, and have dropped only two games in this year's playoff campaign.\n\nThey are coming in fresh, with their last game played on 27 May, when they completed the sweep of the Indiana Pacers in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nJayson Tatum is leading the team in points (26 per game), rebounds (10.4 per game) and assists (5.9 per game) this postseason, and will look to take care of business once again when the battle for the Larry O'Brien Trophy begins in Boston tonight.\n\nHe realizes the enormity of the task at hand though.\n\n\"We only hang NBA championship banners, right? 17 of them. Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. All of us are honored to follow in their footsteps, the way they paved for us to live out our dream,\" he said during yesterday's media day.\n\nFor the Mavs, it is their first trip to the NBA Finals since their 2011 championship season. They can't ask for more of Doncic who has been dominating their playoffs campaign on both sides of the floor with 28.8 points, 9.6 rebounds, 8.8 assists and 1.6 steals per game.\n\nDoncic is the 2023-24 NBA scoring leader and his career playoff scoring average of 31.1 points per game is the second highest in NBA history, behind Michael Jordan (33.4 ppg).\n\n\"First time here. Hopefully it's not the last game. But never take it for granted. You never know if you are going to come back, so just enjoy the experience,\" he said yesterday.\n\nThe Celtics and Mavericks have both thrived on the road in the playoffs. Boston is unbeaten on the road (6-0), while Dallas has won five straight road playoff games and is 7-2 on the road this postseason.\n\nThe Celtics beat the Mavericks twice in the regular season, winning 119-110 on 22 Januaryin Dallas, and 138-110 on 1 March in Boston.\n\nThe 2024 NBA Finals presented by YouTube will air on ESPN (live), NBA League Pass live and on demand) and NTV (delayed) in {"uri": "2024-06-380134747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:28:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:28:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:11:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/who-will-win-nba-finals-writers-from-dallas-boston-make-their-mavs-celtics-predictions/article_9d8a12fb-6813-59d5-812b-a8ce09fdf9b5.html", "title": "Who will win NBA Finals? Writers from Dallas, Boston make their Mavs-Celtics predictions.", "body": "Brad Townsend, Tim Cowlishaw, Kevin Sherrington, Mike Curtis and Shawn McFarland - The Dallas Morning News (TNS)\n\nAhead of the NBA Finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, columnists and beat writers from The Dallas Morning News and The Boston Globe collaborated to answer several questions and predict an outcome for the series, which starts Thursday in Boston.\n\nHere are their predictions:\n\nMike Curtis\n\nI've been 3 for 3 in predictions over the last three series, even though I was off by one game in the second and third rounds. The Celtics will be the toughest opponent the Mavs have faced during these playoffs, and the same can be said for Boston because of Dallas' superstar backcourt and versatility on both ends of the floor. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are in a good rhythm, and if their offense is taken away, they can resort to a potent lob game with their two big men, Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II.\n\nI don't foresee many blowouts, and I think almost every game will go the distance, but I'm choosing the Mavericks in six games.\n\nTim Cowlishaw\n\nDallas goes where Luka goes, and Luka is the best player in the league today. Certainly he's the best player in the league still active. I think the Celtics can do a better job on Kyrie Irving than the Wolves did -- probably with Jrue Holiday guarding him -- but there's not that much to be done against Luka.\n\nThe teams have had a week or more to rest, and there's an extra off day in the Finals between all games except 3 and 4 here in Dallas. That's to Luka's benefit more than anyone's. The Celtics have had a soft playoff run against Miami without Jimmy Butler and others, Cleveland without Donovan Mitchell and an Indiana team that's new to the playoff hunt.\n\nBoston has been just as good as Dallas (maybe better) at closing out games, but I'll still take Doncic with the ball in his hands for the final shot over Tatum, Brown and the rest. Sometimes teams just get on a roll, and Dallas is on one. Mavericks in five.\n\nShawn McFarland\n\nCeltics in seven games. That's no disrespect to the Mavericks, either. The Celtics had the best net rating in the regular season and postseason, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are playoff-tested, and Boston has lost just twice in three rounds.\n\nThis clearly isn't the same Mavericks team that Boston beat twice in the regular season, of course, which sets up a competitive series. Don't be surprised if Dallas takes one of the first two road games, though, to create a pivotal stretch at American Airlines Center.\n\nKevin Sherrington\n\nPicking the Mavs to beat the Celtics feels like an affront to logic. Boston was, by record, the league's best team and has been one of the best three years running. Some of us can still remember when the Mavs lost five of six after the deadline and Kidd's job seemed in jeopardy. Still like to know what all went down in that famous team meeting.\n\nEven as well as they played against Oklahoma City and Minnesota, the Mavs benefited from facing unseasoned players. Boston is a different story. But, these days, so is Dallas. I don't think the Mavs will beat the Celtics, but I'm tired of being wrong. Mavs in seven.\n\nBrad Townsend\n\nBoston was the best NBA team over the course of the season, but Dallas has been the best team of the past 2.5 months.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThe Celtics' 10-day layover between games, and [Kristaps] Porzingis not having played in two months, will be factors early in the series -- along with the fact that Boston hasn't faced competition of Dallas' caliber since the regular season, as the Celtics' playoff path has been paved against injury-racked opponents.\n\nThose factors will help Dallas win one of the first two games in Boston. After that, the series will come down to the Mavericks having the series' best player, Doncic, and the series' best two closers, Doncic and Irving. Mavericks in six.\n\nChad Finn\n\nCeltics in 6. The Mavericks have the best player in the series in Luka Doncic, and the biggest wild-card in Kyrie Irving, who has been playing magnificent basketball but has some, uh, baggage with the Celtics. They are a duo to be reckoned with, capable of stealing games on their own. But they will not steal the series, because the Celtics are the better team. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are a dynamic duo, but it's the depth and versatility of the Celtics' top six that will deliver Banner 18 to Boston, particularly the selfless backcourt duo of Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nAdam Himmelsbach\n\nCeltics in 5. I think this is the first time I've ever picked the Celtics to win a title. But it's going to happen. There's a reason they won 14 more games than the Mavericks during the regular season, and even though they've traveled a smoother road during these playoffs, they've mostly dismantled their competition.\n\nEveryone will be watching Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving and their wizardry with the basketball, but the other end of the floor will be most important, as the Celtics relentlessly hunt mismatches against both players, tiring them out in the process.\n\nChristopher L. Gasper\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics finally face a team with its full complement of talent. The dynamic duos of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown and Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving cross each other out. But Boston's path to Banner 18 is strength in numbers. The Celtics have multiple players who can form a Big Three with The Jays any given night -- Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, Al Horford, and a returning Kristaps Porzingis, who like Irving is seeking Finals redemption against a former team. The Celtics margin for error and victory is simply greater than that of the peaking Mavs.\n\nDan Shaughnessy\n\nMavericks in 7. Please don't be offended. It's Jayson Tatum's time. It's Jaylen Brown's time. The Celtics have the best roster, won the most games, and are 12-2 in the playoffs. But I still don't trust them and have nightmares about Kyrie Irving winning it here.\n\nKhari Thompson\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics have too much depth on both ends of the floor for Dallas to match. All five starters, plus Al Horford, have shown that they can take over a game offensively. They've rolled through the first three rounds without Kristaps Porzingis. Jayson Tatum's 3-point shot isn't falling, but his game is so well-rounded that it hasn't mattered much. Stopping Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving will be a tall task, but there's arguably no team better equipped to contain them than the Celtics, who have one of the league's best defensive backcourts in Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nGary Washburn\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics have a deeper team, have had more than a week to prepare and appear ready for this moment. There are no excuses. They are healthy with Kristaps Porzingis returning, rested, and motivated. The Mavericks will be their biggest challenge and it will take more than this team has ever given to win a playoff series, but they are capable and it's their time.\n\n\u00a92024 The Dallas Morning News. {"uri": "8163319685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:15:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:15:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:14:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/mavericks/2024/06/05/whats-the-biggest-storyline-in-this-years-nba-finals-battle-between-mavericks-celtics/", "title": "What's the biggest storyline in this year's NBA Finals battle between Mavericks, Celtics?", "body": "Ahead of the NBA Finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, columnists and beat writers from The Dallas Morning News and The Boston Globe collaborated to answer a series of questions and predict an outcome before Game 1 on Thursday in Boston.\n\nHere are their answers regarding the Finals' biggest storyline, besides Kyrie Irving returning to Boston?\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMike Curtis: The opportunity for Luka Doncic to win his first championship. At 25, Doncic can add to his impressive basketball r\u00e9sum\u00e9 by capturing that elusive first title. A championship this early in his career would put him ahead of some of the greatest to play the game, including Michael Jordan (28), LeBron James (27), Stephen Curry (28) and Shaquille O'Neal (28). Despite a historic season, he finished third in voting for the regular season MVP award. He now has a chance to win a Finals MVP -- which he'd probably appreciate more.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTim Cowlishaw: I don't know how Luka Doncic isn't the biggest storyline in everything he does. He already has set new regular-season statistical standards, and he has been dominant in the playoffs. In the conference finals, he badly outplayed Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, and few players have enjoyed hitting big shots or winning on the road stage quite like Luka.\n\nMavericks\n\nBe the smartest Mavericks fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nWell, a Finals in the Garden against the team with 17 championship banners is about as large as it's going to get. The accolades keep pouring in from national TV analysts, coaches, players. This series isn't quite Luka vs. the Celtics, but it's close to that, and he loves it. The extra days off in the Finals will allow Jason Kidd to play Luka close to 48 minutes a night.\n\nShawn McFarland: The impact a title could have on each team's star(s). Just consider the company of 1A players who have led teams to recent titles that either Doncic or Jayson Tatum could join: Nikola Jokic, Steph Curry, Giannis Antetokounmpo, LeBron James and Kawhi Leonard.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA Dallas win would cement Doncic and Dirk Nowitzki as the only two superstars to lead the Mavericks to a championship. An 18th banner for Boston would officially ensure that the Tatum-Jaylen Brown era is successful beyond deep-yet-ringless playoff runs, and it'd squash any leftover narrative that the two can't coexist. The NBA is a star-driven league, and this series has massive ramifications for those on both sides.\n\nKevin Sherrington: Kristaps Porzingis' return to Dallas will undoubtedly become a subtext, especially after Chandler Parsons' contention that Doncic didn't like playing next to him and that there's a \"beef\" there. Luka says there's nothing there.\n\nUnless KP goes off against the Mavs, the dominant storyline will be whether Luka carries the Mavs to a title. Boston has a better team, or at least more star-caliber players, but, all apologies to Tatum, none so bright as Luka. If he doesn't play at a superstar level in the Finals, it won't be because he shrank from the spotlight. He might be the most unflappable player in the league, if not all sports.\n\nAdvertisementAdvertisement\n\nBrad Townsend: It's Porzingis because there are so many layers to his expected return to the court. He hasn't played a game since April 11. How rusty will he be? How quickly will he and his teammates reacclimate to one another? There's no worse time than the NBA Finals for Porzingis and the Celtics to confront these unknowns and have, in effect, a breaking-in period.\n\nThen, let's say the transition goes smoothly and the Celtics win the first two games in Boston, Porzingis faces the hurdle of playing his first game in Dallas since the Mavericks traded him to Washington in February 2022.\n\nChad Finn: I think the most overlooked storyline in all of the analysis about this series is how the Mavericks intend to defend the Celtics. Dallas's defense has been terrific pretty much since the trade deadline, but it has also been lucky (catching an Oklahoma City team that went frigid from 3). Doncic and Irving are average defenders at best, and the Celtics are going to expose weaknesses that have been hidden so far.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdam Himmelsbach: This is an obvious one, but it's the health of Celtics center Kristaps Porzingis, who is expected to return for Game 1 after being sidelined since suffering a calf sprain against the Heat on April 28.\n\nWhen Porzingis was asked Tuesday whether he is running without pain, he had a long, long pause before finally answering yes. Maybe this was just a smokescreen, or maybe there is something there. The Celtics will welcome 3-point shooting to space the floor, along with his rim protection against the Mavericks' array of high-flying finishers.\n\nGary Washburn: How the Celtics defend Luka Doncic and approach one of the league's most talented and ball-dominant players. Do they allow Doncic to score but try to shut down his options for distributing the ball? Doncic has arguably been the best player in the playoffs and the Celtics have to devise a plan to slow him down so he doesn't turn into a scorer and distributor. If Doncic takes full control of this series, hits shots, gets to the free-throw line and is allowed to toss easy lobs to the Dallas big men, it could be a long series for the Celtics.\n\nAdvertisementRelated StoriesView MoreWhich players will step up for Mavs, Celtics? "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-11", "textStart": 3377, "textEnd": {"uri": "8164752830", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:19:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:19:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:18:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/boston/news/celtics-mavericks-nba-finals-predictions-tatum-brown-doncic-irving-mvp/", "title": "Celtics-Mavericks NBA Finals predictions", "body": "BOSTON -- The NBA Finals are finally tipping off in Boston, and a week or two from now, the Boston Celtics or the Dallas Mavericks will be crowned champions.\n\nIs it finally time for Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown to add their own banner to Celtics' vast collection, or will Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving play spoiler for Boston? The WBZ-TV and CBS Boston sports team makes their picks, and everyone is going Green with their predictions.\n\nDan Roche, WBZ-TV Sports\n\nI think THIS Celtics team has answered every question/situation thrown their way this postseason. It's their time.\n\nBoth of their losses -- Game 2 against Miami and Game 2 against Cleveland -- resulted in bounce back Game 3 victories on the road.\n\nNeed a big shot from your two best players? Game 1 against Indiana it was Jaylen Brown with a huge three to send it into overtime. Then Jayson Tatum delivered a three-point play followed by a dagger three with 43 seconds left in the extra session. Your two superstars delivered when it was needed most.\n\nGame 3 in Indiana was Jrue Holiday's turn to step up, and he did so on both ends of the floor in the final seconds. The ageless Al Horford also buried seven threes in that road victory.\n\nGame 4 was Derrick White, who came up with the clinching three late in the corner.\n\nThis is a t-e-a-m at its finest, and Joe Mazzulla has a team that listens and understands exactly what their head coach wants from them.\n\nBoston is also 12-2 in the postseason, a perfect 6-0 on the road and 6-2 at home. They're also 3-for-3 in series clinching opportunities.\n\nAnd now - Kristaps Porzingis is ready to return from a calf strain. Yet another weapon on both ends of the floor.\n\nLuka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are superstar players leading a Dallas team that learned to play championship defense the final months of the season. They deserve to be here.\n\nBut Boston has more weapons on offense and plays quality defense. It should be a battle, but I'll take the Celtics in six with Jayson Tatum earning MVP honors.\n\nNick Giovani, WBZ-TV Sports\n\nIt's been a postseason of gentlemen's sweeps and a complete sweep for the Celtics. That trend may not continue against the Mavericks, but with Kristaps Porzingis back I think it's only a matter of time before Banner 18 is in place.\n\nIt just comes down to how healthy KP really is. His 10-second pause when asked if he's still playing through some pain makes one wonder how close to 100 percent he really is. But his mere presence out on the Parquet is enough to make the Mavs think twice about trying to find their points in the paint.\n\nAs far as solving the problem of Luka and Kyrie, that's no small task. Just ask the Nuggets and Timberwolves. But, I think the Celtics collectively can keep both from going off with their NBA all-defensive second team backcourt of White and Holiday with some help from Jaylen Brown.\n\nIt's time for the Celtics to finish the job. This has been building for Tatum and Brown for years, and Brad Stevens gave Joe Mazzulla and company the missing pieces this offseason in Porzingis and Holiday. Now they're in the Finals after a dominant regular season and mostly dominant run in the playoffs. Having to win three close games against the Pacers in the Conference Finals proved the Celtics can come through in the clutch.\n\nThe Mavericks will be Boston's biggest test this postseason, and there's a good chance most of these games are going to be tight contests. That's a scary thought, considering Luka has made the Celtics pay late in games before. (Remember when he spoiled Kevin Garnett's special day at the Garden a few years ago? Yeah, I blacked that out of my brain too.)\n\nWhile the Mavs have the best player in the series, the Celtics have the better team from top to bottom and a much, much better defense. In the end, that will lead Boston to Banner 18.\n\nLuka is going to score a lot and Kyrie will get his points too. But I believe we're going to get at least one Tatum takeover game, another game-winner for D-White, a lot more ridiculous defense from Holiday, and Brown will break some more ankles on his way to adding another MVP trophy to his growing collection. Celtics in 6.\n\nJoe Weil, CBS Boston\n\nThe Celtics are 76-20 this season. I repeat...THE CELTICS ARE 76-20 THIS SEASON.\n\nLuka Don\u010di\u0107, Kyrie Irving, and this remade Mavericks defense are going to be a tough challenge, but I think it's important to put into context the historical uphill battle that Dallas is trying to climb. The last NBA Finals winner that was lower than a three seed was the 1995 Houston Rockets (and while they were a six seed that year, they won the championship the year before, they played a young Orlando Magic team in the 1995 Finals, and they added Hall-of-Famer Clyde Drexler via a midseason trade that year). And as C's aficionado Bill Simmons noted, there have been 10 teams over the last 50 years that had 20 losses or less by the time they made the Finals, and the 2015-16 Golden State Warriors are the only one in that group to lose the Finals.\n\nThe Celtics were the best team in the regular season. They posted the fifth-best regular season point differential ever. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are playing the most complete basketball of their careers, Jrue Holiday and Derrick White are perfect role players for this team, Kristaps Porzingis appears healthy now, and Al Horford is somehow still a very useful player at age 38.\n\nThe C's playoff path has been easy, but that's the benefit of having the one seed. And even without Porzingis for most of the playoffs, the C's are still 12-2 this postseason. {"uri": "8164141834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:04:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:04:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:03:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/06/sports/nba-finals-predictions-celtics-mavericks/", "title": "NBA Finals predictions from the staffs of the Globe and the Dallas Morning News - The Boston Globe", "body": "Celtics in six. The Mavericks have the best player in the series in Luka Doncic, and the biggest wild card in Kyrie Irving, who has been playing magnificent basketball but has some, uh, baggage with the Celtics. They are a duo to be reckoned with, capable of stealing games on their own. But they will not steal the series, because the Celtics are the better team. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are a dynamic duo, but it's the depth and versatility of the Celtics' top six that will deliver Banner 18 to Boston, particularly the selfless backcourt duo of Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nCeltics in five. I think this is the first time I've ever picked the Celtics to win a title. But it's going to happen. There's a reason they won 14 more games than the Mavericks during the regular season, and even though they've traveled a smoother road during these playoffs, they've mostly dismantled their competition. Everyone will be watching Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving and their wizardry with the basketball, but the other end of the floor will be most important, as the Celtics relentlessly hunt mismatches against both players, tiring them out in the process.\n\nCeltics in six. The Celtics finally face a team with its full complement of talent. The dynamic duos of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown and Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving cross each other out. But the Celtics' path to Banner 18 is strength in numbers. They have multiple players who can form a Big Three with The Jays any given night -- Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, Al Horford, and the returning Kristaps Porzingis, who like Irving is seeking Finals redemption against a former team. The Celtics' margin for error and victory is simply greater than that of the peaking Mavericks.\n\nMavericks in seven. Please don't be offended. It's Jayson Tatum's time. It's Jaylen Brown's time. The Celtics have the best roster, won the most games, and are 12-2 in the playoffs. But I still don't trust them and have nightmares about Kyrie Irving winning it here.\n\nCeltics in six. The Celtics have too much depth on both ends of the floor for Dallas to match. All five starters, plus Al Horford, have shown that they can take over a game offensively. They've rolled through the first three rounds without Kristaps Porzingis. Jayson Tatum's 3-point shot isn't falling, but his game is so well-rounded that it hasn't mattered much. Stopping Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving will be a tall task, but there's arguably no team better equipped to contain them than the Celtics, who have one of the league's best defensive backcourts in Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nCeltics in six. The Celtics have a deeper team, have had more than a week to prepare, and appear ready for this moment. There are no excuses. They are healthy with Kristaps Porzingis returning, rested, and motivated. The Mavericks will be their biggest challenge, and it will take more than this team has ever given to win a playoff series, but they are capable and it's their time.\n\nMavericks in six. I am 3 for 3 in predictions over the last three series, even though I was off by one game in the second and third rounds. The Celtics will be the toughest opponent the Mavericks have faced during these playoffs, and the same can be said for Boston because of Dallas's superstar backcourt and versatility on both ends of the floor. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are in a good rhythm, and if their offense is taken away, they can resort to a potent lob game with their two big men, Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II. I don't foresee many blowouts, and I think almost every game will go the distance.\n\nMavericks in five. Dallas goes where Luka goes, and Luka is the best player in the league today. Certainly he's the best in the league still playing. I think the Celtics can do a better job on Kyrie Irving than the Wolves did -- probably with Jrue Holiday guarding him -- but there's not that much to be done against Luka. The teams have had a week to rest, and there's an extra off day in the Finals between all games except 3 and 4. That's to Luka's benefit more than anyone else's. The Celtics have had a soft playoff run. Boston has been just as good as Dallas (maybe better) at closing out games, but I'll still take Doncic with the ball in his hands for the final shot over Tatum, Brown, and the rest. Sometimes teams just get on a roll, and Dallas is on one.\n\nCeltics in seven. That's no disrespect to the Mavericks. The Celtics had the best net rating in the regular season and postseason, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are playoff-tested, and Boston has lost just twice in three rounds. This clearly isn't the same Mavericks team that Boston beat twice in the regular season, of course, which sets up a competitive series. Don't be surprised if Dallas takes one of the first two road games, though, to create a pivotal stretch at American Airlines Center.\n\nMavericks in seven. Picking the Mavericks to beat the Celtics feels like an affront to logic. Boston was, by record, the league's best team and has been one of the best three years running. Some of us can still remember when the Mavericks lost five of six after the deadline and Jason Kidd's job seemed in jeopardy. Still like to know what all went down in that famous team meeting. Even as well as they played against Oklahoma City and Minnesota, the Mavericks benefited from facing unseasoned players. Boston is a different story. But, these days, so is Dallas. I don't think the Mavericks will beat the Celtics, but I'm tired of being wrong.\n\nMavericks in six. Boston was the best team over the course of the season, but Dallas has been the best team of the past 2\u00bd months. The Celtics' 10-day layover between games and Porzingis not having played will be factors early in the series -- along with the fact that Boston hasn't faced competition of Dallas's caliber since the regular season, as the Celtics' playoff path has been paved with injury-racked opponents. Those factors will help Dallas win one of the first two games in Boston. After that, the series will come down to the Mavericks having the series' best player, Doncic, and the series' best two closers, Doncic and Irving.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8164862633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:26:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:26:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:25:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://nesn.com/2024/06/nba-finals-picks-staff-predictions-ahead-of-celtics-mavericks-series/", "title": "NBA Finals Picks: Staff Predictions Ahead Of Celtics-Mavs Series", "body": "The Celtics are back in the NBA Finals, taking their third swing at Banner 18 with arch-nemesis Kyrie Irving and the Mavericks standing in Boston's way.\n\nJayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have endured plenty of defeat during their previous four shared trips to the Eastern Conference finals. Boston's co-stars still recall the gut-wrenching ending of walking off the TD Garden's parquet as the Warriors celebrated, covered in confetti and champagne. Therefore, after a blockbuster-filled offseason, a league-best 64-win regular season, and a 12-2 run this postseason, it's up to the Celtics to rise to the occasion.\n\nWith Game 1 just hours away from its 8:30 p.m. ET scheduled tip-off at TD Garden, it's time to take a pre-Finals stance. Which team will come out victorious, hosting a Larry O'Brien Trophy, and who will win Finals MVP?\n\nHere are the official NESN Digital staff predictions before the Celtics and Mavericks square off in Game 1:\n\nGreg Dudek: Celtics over Mavericks in five games\n\nJust don't see how the Mavericks can consistently defend Boston's multitude of options who can all splash in 3-pointers. Plus, the Celtics are well-suited to match up with Kyrie Irving and Luka Doncic thanks to a strong defensive backcourt tandem in Derrick White and Jrue Holiday.\n\nJayson Tatum came up short in the Finals two years ago, but it won't be a repeat performance this time around for the Celtics star. Tatum has to be taking all the playoff criticism personally and with an all-around showing against the Mavs, will hold the trump card with Finals MVP in tow.\n\nGio Rivera: Celtics over Mavericks in five games\n\nSometimes destiny overrules all else, and there's no team more overdue than the Celtics this postseason. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have fended off the outside noise from Opening Night in October, the blockbuster additions of Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday have been (chefs kiss) spotless, and coming full circle with Boston enemy Kyrie Irving is Hollywoodesque.\n\nTatum coming up short of a second-career Eastern Conference finals MVP honor, Brown being questioned after signing a record-setting contract in the offseason, and 16 years without raising a banner at TD Garden should spark enough motivation. And with all that (presumed) hunger for redemption, Tatum is perfectly positioned to emerge as the MVP of the Finals.\n\nGayle Troiani: Celtics over Mavericks in six games\n\nI believe the Celtics will capture Banner No. 18 in six games. Boston has a lot more depth than Dallas on offense and defense, especially with Kristaps Porzingis reportedly returning. The MVP with be Jaylen Brown.\n\nKeagan Stiefel: Celtics over Mavericks in six games\n\nIt's always difficult picking against the best player in the series (Luka Doncic), but I haven't seen anything from the Celtics that leads me to believe they can't wipe the floor with this Mavericks team. I'm not sure it will be as close as a six-game series would indicate. Doncic will steal one or two games, but Boston is a better team.\n\nTim Crowley: Celtics over Mavericks in six games\n\nDallas can compete and has the talent to challenge Boston. Luka's late-game shot-making could steal at least a game and the Mavericks are going to make this a series. Ultimately, the Celtics went 12-2 this postseason and now get as good of a late-postseason addition as possible with Porzingis returning. {"uri": "2024-06-380986984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:21:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:21:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:02:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/2024-nba-finals-series-prediction-pick", "title": "2024 NBA Finals Series Prediction & Pick", "body": "The Mavericks overcame the Los Angeles Clippers in six games in the first round of the playoffs to start their journey. Then, they took down the Oklahoma City Thunder in six games. The Mavs finished their quest for the finals by beating the Minnesota Timberwolves in five games to seal their ticket.\n\nThe Celtics defeated the Miami Heat in five games in the first round. Next, they routed the Cleveland Cavaliers in five games in the Eastern Conference Semifinals. Boston swept the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference Finals to seal their spot in the NBA Finals.\n\nThe Mavericks will be making their second appearance in the NBA Finals and first since 2011, when they won their only championship. Meanwhile, the Celtics will make their 23rd appearance in the NBA Finals. The Celtics are 17-5 in the NBA Finals, including a series loss to the Golden State Warriors two seasons ago.\n\nThe Celtics swept the season series against the Mavericks. Significantly, they destroyed the Mavs 138-110 at home and beat them 119-110 in Dallas. The Celtics have won four in a row, and gone 6-4 over the past 10 games against the Mavericks.\n\nThe Mavericks are heavy underdogs, but no one should count them out. Their great coaching staff has done everything to get the best out of their players. Now, Jason Kidd hopes to lead the Mavericks to their second championship as their head coach after leading them to their first title as the starting point guard.\n\nThere are many similarities to that series. First, Kidd overcame a heavily favored Miami Heat team, teaming up with Dirk Nowitzki to overcome a team that included LeBron James, Dwayne Wade, and Chris Bosh. Now, he will coach up stars Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving as they try and overcome a heavily favored Celtics team that includes Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, Kristaps Porzingis, and Jrue Holiday.\n\nDoncic has been excellent in these playoffs, averaging 28.8 points per game. Furthermore, he averaged 32.4 points per game in the Western Conference Finals. Irving has also been good in the playoffs, averaging 22.8 points per game. Likewise, he turned it up a notch in the Western Conference Finals by averaging 27 points per game.\n\nBut PJ Washington is a player to keep an eye on. Ultimately, he has averaged 13.6 points per game in the postseason but has shown he was capable of putting up 25-30 points. Derrick Jones Jr. has been solid, averaging 9.8 points per game. Also, Daniel Gafford has contributed to the effort, averaging 9.2 points per game.\n\nThe Mavericks will cover the spread if Doncic and Irving can continue to play at a high level on offense and supporting players contribute with solid shots. Then, the defense must close out and force the Celtics to take bad shots.\n\nWhy The Celtics Could Win The Series\n\nWhile the Mavericks feel like heavy underdogs, the Celtics feel like they are attempting to finish their story. Unfortunately, they fell apart two seasons ago when they ran into the Warriors. The Celtics would like to remedy that defeat and take the lead for most championships in the NBA.\n\nTatum has been great in the playoffs, averaging 26 points per game. Yet, he likely needs to do more this time around than he did two years ago when he averaged 21.5 points, seven assists, and 6.8 assists per game in six games. Brown has averaged 25 points per game in the playoffs and 29.75 points per game in the Eastern Conference Finals. Additionally, he would like to improve on his stats from two seasons ago, when he averaged 23.5 points, 7.3 rebounds, and 3.7 assists per game in the NBA Finals.\n\nKristaps Porzingis wants revenge on his former team and is back after missing the last two rounds. Ultimately, his calf injury will be something to watch. Holiday was the other addition in the offseason, as the Celtics aimed to fix any issues they had. Meanwhile, Derrick White will hope to show he is ready to bounce back.\n\nThe Celtics will win this series if Tatum and Brown can take their game to the next level while Porzingis and Holiday produce. Then, they need to hit their shots from beyond the arc.\n\nThe Mavericks are the heavy underdogs. However, when looking at this series, you have to consider the player matchups and what the elite players will do. In this case, there are four elite players: Doncic, Irving, Tatum, and Brown. Porzingis can certainly make a difference. Yet, there are questions as to how his calf will hold up. While Porzingis is saying all the right things, his return may hinder the team if he is not at 100 percent. The Mavericks already overcame the two best teams in the Western Conference, dispatching the Thunder in six games and the Wolves in five games. It's certainly not a stretch to see them do it again, toppling the best team in the Eastern Conference to win their second title.\n\nClick here for more betting news and predictions", "source": {"uri": "8163101517", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "14:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T14:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:43:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/mavericks/2024/06/05/who-will-win-nba-finals-writers-from-dallas-boston-make-their-mavs-celtics-predictions/", "title": "Who will win NBA Finals? Writers from Dallas, Boston make their Mavs-Celtics predictions", "body": "Ahead of the NBA Finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, columnists and beat writers from The Dallas Morning News and The Boston Globe collaborated to answer several questions and predict an outcome for the series, which starts Thursday in Boston.\n\nHere are their predictions:\n\nAdvertisementMike Curtis\n\nI've been 3-for-3 in predictions over the last three series, even though I was off by one game in the second and third rounds. The Celtics will be the toughest opponent the Mavs have faced during these playoffs, and the same can be said for Boston because of Dallas' superstar backcourt and versatility on both ends of the floor. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are in a good rhythm, and if their offense is taken away, they can resort to a potent lob game with their two big men, Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nI don't foresee many blowouts, and I think almost every game will go the distance, but I'm choosing the Mavericks in six games.\n\nMavericks\n\nBe the smartest Mavericks fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nTim Cowlishaw\n\nDallas goes where Luka goes, and Luka is the best player in the league today. Certainly he's the best player in the league still active. I think the Celtics can do a better job on Kyrie Irving than the Wolves did -- probably with Jrue Holiday guarding him -- but there's not that much to be done against Luka.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe teams have had a week or more to rest, and there's an extra off day in the Finals between all games except 3 and 4 here in Dallas. That's to Luka's benefit more than anyone's. The Celtics have had a soft playoff run against Miami without Jimmy Butler and others, Cleveland without Donovan Mitchell and an Indiana team that's new to the playoff hunt.\n\nBoston has been just as good as Dallas (maybe better) at closing out games, but I'll still take Doncic with the ball in his hands for the final shot over Tatum, Brown and the rest. Sometimes teams just get on a roll, and Dallas is on one. Mavericks in five.\n\nShawn McFarland\n\nCeltics in seven games. That's no disrespect to the Mavericks, either. The Celtics had the best net rating in the regular season and postseason, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are playoff-tested, and Boston has lost just twice in three rounds.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThis clearly isn't the same Mavericks team that Boston beat twice in the regular season, of course, which sets up a competitive series. Don't be surprised if Dallas takes one of the first two road games, though, to create a pivotal stretch at American Airlines Center.\n\nAdvertisementKevin Sherrington\n\nPicking the Mavs to beat the Celtics feels like an affront to logic. Boston was, by record, the league's best team and has been one of the best three years running. Some of us can still remember when the Mavs lost five of six after the deadline and Kidd's job seemed in jeopardy. Still like to know what all went down in that famous team meeting.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nEven as well as they played against Oklahoma City and Minnesota, the Mavs benefited from facing unseasoned players. Boston is a different story. But, these days, so is Dallas. I don't think the Mavs will beat the Celtics, but I'm tired of being wrong. Mavs in seven.\n\nBrad Townsend\n\nBoston was the best NBA team over the course of the season, but Dallas has been the best team of the past 2.5 months.\n\nThe Celtics' 10-day layover between games, and [Kristaps] Porzingis not having played in two months, will be factors early in the series -- along with the fact that Boston hasn't faced competition of Dallas' caliber since the regular season, as the Celtics' playoff path has been paved against injury-racked opponents.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThose factors will help Dallas win one of the first two games in Boston. After that, the series will come down to the Mavericks having the series' best player, Doncic, and the series' best two closers, Doncic and Irving. Mavericks in six.\n\nChad Finn\n\nCeltics in 6. The Mavericks have the best player in the series in Luka Doncic, and the biggest wild-card in Kyrie Irving, who has been playing magnificent basketball but has some, uh, baggage with the Celtics. They are a duo to be reckoned with, capable of stealing games on their own. But they will not steal the series, because the Celtics are the better team. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are a dynamic duo, but it's the depth and versatility of the Celtics' top six that will deliver Banner 18 to Boston, particularly the selfless backcourt duo of Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nAdam Himmelsbach\n\nCeltics in 5. I think this is the first time I've ever picked the Celtics to win a title. But it's going to happen. There's a reason they won 14 more games than the Mavericks during the regular season, and even though they've traveled a smoother road during these playoffs, they've mostly dismantled their competition.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nEveryone will be watching Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving and their wizardry with the basketball, but the other end of the floor will be most important, as the Celtics relentlessly hunt mismatches against both players, tiring them out in the process.\n\nChristopher L. Gasper\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics finally face a team with its full complement of talent. The dynamic duos of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown and Luka Don\u010di\u0107 and Kyrie Irving cross each other out. But Boston's path to Banner 18 is strength in numbers. The Celtics have multiple players who can form a Big Three with The Jays any given night -- Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, Al Horford, and a returning Kristaps Porzi\u0146\u0123is, who like Irving is seeking Finals redemption against a former team. The Celtics margin for error and victory is simply greater than that of the peaking Mavs.\n\nAdvertisementDan Shaughnessy\n\nMavericks in 7. Please don't be offended. It's Jayson Tatum's time. It's Jaylen Brown's time. The Celtics have the best roster, won the most games, and are 12-2 in the playoffs. But I still don't trust them and have nightmares about Kyrie Irving winning it here.\n\nKhari Thompson\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics have too much depth on both ends of the floor for Dallas to match. All five starters, plus Al Horford, have shown that they can take over a game offensively. They've rolled through the first three rounds without Kristaps Porzingis. Jayson Tatum's 3-point shot isn't falling, but his game is so well-rounded that it hasn't mattered much. Stopping Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving will be a tall task, but there's arguably no team better equipped to contain them than the Celtics, who have one of the league's best defensive backcourts in Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\nAdvertisementGary Washburn\n\nCeltics in 6. The Celtics have a deeper team, have had more than a week to prepare and appear ready for this moment. There are no excuses. They are healthy with Kristaps Porzingis returning, rested, and motivated. The Mavericks will be their biggest challenge and it will take more than this team has ever given to win a playoff series, but they are capable and it's their time.\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreFrom Mandatory Credit: David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports / David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports\n\nJayson Tatum sat on the Boston Celtics bench alone, distraught with a towel over his head as the Celtics were about to fall in Game 6 of the 2022 NBA Finals. The superstar did not perform up to standard, with the Celtics losing in a learning curve to the experienced Golden State Warriors.\n\nTwo years later with much more battles and reps under his belt along with his growth and improvement, Tatum is motivated for his second chance to prove himself on the game's biggest stage.\n\n\"I would say part of my motivation is I just love to win,\" Tatum said. \"Understanding the moment that I know how hard it is to get to the Finals. You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going. We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments. We didn't make it to the Finals. This year, put things in perspective. I think you can see in our excitement when we won the conference. Obviously, that's not the end all, be all, but it really is tough to get to this moment.\"\n\nThe way last season ended in the East Finals is a primary fuel added to the fire of the new-look Celtics and their title quest. Tatum has averaged 29.6 points, 10.3 rebounds, and 6.4 assists in his last eight games.\n\n\"I think right now just staying present in the moment. I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that. {"uri": "8163924625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:03:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:03:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:02:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5543327/2024/06/06/mavericks-celtics-nba-finals-game-1-odds-picks/", "title": "Mavericks at Celtics NBA Finals Game 1 odds, expert picks: Boston is a strong favorite", "body": "The Boston Celtics were expected to go to the NBA Finals. The Celtics had the best regular-season record in the league and were a clear favorite to win the Eastern Conference side of the playoffs when the postseason began. The Dallas Mavericks were not expected to be here.\n\nNow, the two teams meet in Game 1 on Thursday. Boston is a significant favorite for both the opening game and the series.\n\nIt's a matchup of teams featuring star duos. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown were drafted by the Celtics with the third pick in consecutive years (Brown in 2016, Tatum in 2017) and have been leading the team for several years. Luka Don\u010di\u0107 joined Dallas as the third pick in 2018, but only late last season got united with Kyrie Irving. That Dallas duo has started to click with the Mavs going on a 16-2 run late in the regular season before both sat out the final two games of the regular season. Dallas entered the postseason as the No. 5 seed in the Western Conference but has been playing much better than that for three months now.\n\nThe way these two teams have been playing this postseason makes it seem like this series should be competitive, but the odds are saying otherwise. The odds are implying a nearly 70 percent chance for Boston to win the series. The most likely series outcome in the odds is Boston in five games, which is +300 on BetMGM.\n\nBoston hasn't been tested this postseason. The Celtics are 12-2 in the playoffs and swept the Eastern Conference finals, although Indiana blew late leads in three of the four games in that series. Boston also played multiple games in every series with the opposing team missing arguably its best player. The Celtics have mostly cruised through the playoffs, but a healthy Dallas team should be a significant step up in competition.\n\nDallas has also avoided major drama this postseason. The Mavs beat Minnesota in five games in the Western Conference finals and won the first two rounds in six games. Dallas did this while also starting every series on the road.\n\nThese teams met twice in the regular season with Boston winning both games. Tatum averaged 35.5 points while Don\u010di\u0107 averaged 35 points per game. Buckle up.\n\nAny title is usually legacy-defining, but that might be especially true in this series. Tatum and Brown have not yet won a title despite being among the main contenders for the last few years. Boston made the NBA Finals two years ago but lost to Golden State in six games. Can they prove to be winners, or will this year end in another near-miss?\n\nDon\u010di\u0107 is taking part in his first NBA Finals. No one is doubting the ability of the Slovenian, who is arguably the best guard in the league, but he still has to win a title at some point to be among the true greats of the sport. He hasn't had a strong supporting cast for much of his young career, but with Irving on board, the Mavs are in the Finals. Irving already won with LeBron James in Cleveland in 2016 and was crucial in upsetting Golden State that year. If he wins with another team, he will cement his legacy as a winning player.\n\nFor all the talk of the stars, will any supporting cast members stand out in this series? P.J. Washington has had some standout games this playoffs for Dallas, mostly in the second round against Oklahoma City, and Derrick White had some heaters for Boston. Will those two play decisive roles in any games this series or will it all be about the star duos?\n\nCeltics vs. Mavericks: How this intriguing NBA Finals matchup will be won on the court\n\nHow Luka Don\u010di\u0107, Kyrie Irving are successfully attacking defenses in the pick-and-roll\n\nYes, Celtics had the easiest path to the NBA Finals, but how much does it matter?\n\nHow Kristaps
