"dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Professional", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Professional", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan_Pages", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Fan Pages", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Coaching", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Coaching", "wgt": 17}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/History", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Science", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Basketball/Science", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://cebudailynews.inquirer.net/files/2024/06/063_2076861394-scaled.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-29", "textStart": 3436, "textEnd": 3444}], "sentiment": 0.3019607843137255, "wgt": 181, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8163445365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:00:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:00:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:00:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/fantasy-basketball-roundtable-2024-nba-171221494.html", "title": "Fantasy Basketball Roundtable: 2024 NBA Finals Preview", "body": "The 2023-24 NBA season tipped off way back in October, and after a thrilling 82-game regular season and an even more exciting postseason, we've reached the pinnacle.\n\nGame 1 of the 2024 NBA Finals tips off Thursday as the Western Conference champion Dallas Mavericks travel to TD Garden to face the Eastern Conference champion Boston Celtics.\n\nThe fantasy hoops season is far in the rearview mirror, but that doesn't mean the Rotoworld crew is sitting around and twiddling their thumbs. Raphielle Johnson, Noah Rubin, Zak Hanshew, and Ameer Tyree offered their thoughts on what's sure to be a thrilling conclusion to the NBA season.\n\nQ: Who are you picking to win and why?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: I'm taking the Celtics in six games. They've been the best team in the NBA all season long, and during the conference finals, they displayed solid growth regarding how they close games offensively. The addition of Jrue Holiday and his defensive impact will help the Celtics attack the Doncic/Irving tandem, and they have options that the teams Dallas eliminated to reach this point lacked. Also, the time off should help Kristaps Porzingis; he's reportedly on track to be available for Game 1, which will give Boston a welcome boost in the frontcourt.\n\nNoah Rubin: Celtics in five. Full disclosure, I'll be rooting for Dallas to win and for the series to go seven games. However, this Boston team just feels inevitable. While they haven't faced much healthy competition yet this postseason, they were able to make quick work of every team they have played. The moves they made this summer gave them the best top six in the league, and it has shown all year. The extra rest has given time for Kristaps Porzingis to heal up, and with both teams pretty healthy, it will come down to talent. Simply put, the Celtics are the better team on paper, and I think their defense is set up perfectly to try and slow down Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving. Boston has won their last ten games against Kyrie, including their sweep of the Nets in 2022. I don't expect the Celtics to dominate every game, but this team has been the title favorite all year for a reason.\n\nZak Hanshew: I'm going Dallas in six. Boston comfortably led the NBA in games won this season, and the team has arguably the most talented starting five from top to bottom. This isn't a Tuesday in March... this is the NBA Finals. Imagine it's a two-point game with three minutes to play. Which Celtic is taking over? Will it be Jayson Tatum, who's having one of his worst playoff runs in recent memory? Will it be Jaylen Brown, who won the Eastern Conference Finals MVP award? Will it be Derrick White or Jrue Holiday, who can get hot at times? Maybe Kristaps Porzingis gets hot in his first game back. There are no questions when we look at the Mavericks. Dallas has a killer who wants the ball in his hands at the end of the game and is not afraid of the brightest lights. I'm picking the team with the best player on the court in Luka Doncic. Don't forget about Kyrie Irving, another one of the best closers in the Association who has already proven himself when he hit the go-ahead triple in Game 7 of the 2016 Finals in Golden State.\n\nAmeer Tyree: The Celtics should get the job done this time around. I'm picking the Celtics to win in six games. They were far and away the best team at home in 2023-24, are set to get Kristaps Porzingis back, and have had plenty of time to rest and prepare for the Mavericks. Boston has more offensive options and a more capable defense, so I'm backing them to take care of business. They've long been considered the most well-rounded team in basketball and should benefit from having an abundance of youth and big-time playoff game experience. Boston added a player with championship pedigree in Jrue Holiday and its perimeter defense is built to slow down the Mavericks' guard-centered offense.\n\nQ: Who is your Finals MVP and why?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: Jayson Tatum. There was some controversy regarding the Eastern Conference Finals MVP; I personally did not have a problem with Jaylen Brown winning it. Tatum wasn't his most efficient self against the Pacers, but he still produced solid numbers. I expect him to be better against the Mavericks, and a Boston championship would likely net him the Bill Russell Most Valuable Player award.\n\nNoah Rubin: Jayson Tatum. Even if Luka Doncic averages 40/10/10, the best player on the winning team is going to get this award. Jaylen Brown won the Eastern Conference Finals MVP despite Tatum having more points, rebounds and assists in the series. Not to say that the voters got it wrong, but I don't expect that result to repeat if Tatum has better numbers once again. Tatum wasn't great the last time they made the Finals, so I expect him to be much better this time around.\n\nZak Hanshew: I'm picking Dallas because they have the best player in the series and a man who should have received more love as the league's MVP. Of course, I'm picking Luka Doncic to win Finals MVP.\n\nAmeer Tyree: Jayson Tatum. Jayson Tatum has been overshadowed by Jaylen Brown at times. He's the best player on the best team at the end of the day, though. Luka Doncic might end up taking and making more shots, but Boston is built to win the series and winning team always has a player named MVP.\n\nQ: Who will be the X factor of the series?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: I'm going with Al Horford. Even though Kristaps Porzingis is expected back for Game 1, Horford's presence within the rotation will remain important. The veteran center is better equipped to punish Dallas' bigs offensively than Rudy Gobert, as evidenced by the seven 3-pointers Horford made in Game 3 of the conference Finals. Against Indiana, he averaged 12.8 points, 7.3 rebounds, 1.5 assists, 1.0 steals, 1.8 blocks, and 2.8 3-pointers in 35 minutes, shooting 46.2% from the field and 80.0% from the foul line. Horford's play/production has improved by the round, out of necessity due to the Porzingis injury, but it's a clear sign that he still has plenty to give. If he can continue on that path, Boston will be well-positioned to win the title.\n\nNoah Rubin: Kristaps Porzingis. One advantage that Dallas can exploit is forcing Porzingis to switch onto Luka and Kyrie. Doncic obviously had a number of big shots over Rudy Gobert in the conference finals, and Boston will need to avoid that matchup as much as possible. Porzingis needs to be able to hold his own in those situations and force Daniel Gafford to guard him on the perimeter, which will open up driving lines for their star scorers. However, things will get difficult for the Celtics if the Mavs are able to take advantage of Porzingis as a defender, since everyone else can be effective when switched onto Luka or Kyrie.\n\nZak Hanshew: Dereck Lively II immediately springs to mind here following an impressive rookie campaign and even more impressive postseason performance. The X factor here, however, is Kyrie Irving. Despite boasting a number of quality defenders, Boston will have its hands full with Luka Doncic, and the team will have to settle for slowing him down or wearing him out rather than completely neutralizing him. In two matchups with the Celtics in the regular season, Luka averaged 35.0 points, 15.0 rebounds and 12.0 assists on 47.3% shooting. Irving, on the other hand, averaged just 21.0 points, 5.0 rebounds and 2.5 assists on just 41.8% shooting. This year's playoffs did a phenomenal job in showing how important role players are, but both Luka AND Kyrie will need to be elite to slay the Eastern Conference's 65-win juggernaut. Irving is not liked in Boston, so there will be an added element of vitriol when he faces his former team in Boston.\n\nAmeer Tyree: Derrick White has been as hot as any Celtic on offense at times this postseason while also being a defensive linchpin. If his shotmaking pop early in this series he could be the player who makes Boston overwhelming. Especially because he'll likely end up getting a Kyrie Irving matchup assignment.\n\nQ: Which team/player is under the most pressure?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: Tatum, Brown, and the Celtics. We've seen these two stars come up short multiple times in their respective careers. While Tatum is still 26 and Brown 27, patience isn't exactly a strength of most fans and analysts. Add in the fact that the Celtics rolled through the regular season and the playoffs, and they're no denying who will be under the most pressure in this series.\n\nNoah Rubin: Celtics/Jayson Tatum. Boston has made the Eastern Conference Finals six times in the past eight seasons and in five of Tatum's seven years in the league. That is an impressive feat, but this is only their second appearance in the NBA Finals during that stretch. After losing to the Heat in the conference finals last year, they reloaded by adding Porzingis and Holiday, and White has been incredible this season. They've even had players like Payton Pritchard step up this year in an expanded role. This is a stacked team that was built to win the championship, and it would be a disappointment if they didn't get it done. On the other side, this is the Mavs first trip to the NBA Finals without Dirk Nowitzki. Dallas wasn't even in the Play-In Tournament last year, and now they're four wins away from a ring. Doncic will eventually have pressure on him to win a ring every year, but it's only his first appearance. Boston has to get it done this year, or the narratives will get ugly.\n\nZak Hanshew: I've got to concur with Raph, here. Boston continues to win in the regular season and in the playoffs, but the core of Tatum and Brown has yet to bring home any hardware. This is arguably the most talented roster the duo has ever played with, and if they can't get it done after going 12-2 in the Eastern Conference, this season will be seen as a massive failure. Tatum's name is often mentioned when NBA fans and analysts try to name the top-5 or top-10 players in the league, though he's gotten a reputation as someone who wilts in big games. Can he overcome that reputation and change the narrative on what's been an otherwise phenomenally successful career to date?\n\nAmeer Tyree: Jayson Tatum is the player facing the most pressure. The young star is 0-1 in the NBA Finals and has benefited from amazing team structure for years.\n\nQ: What does this mean for X player legacy?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: Luka Doncic will be the new face of the NBA if the Mavericks win the title. He's never been \"disrespected\" in the conversations regarding the league's best players, but maybe his name should be mentioned more with regard to who will lead the league in the post-LeBron/Curry/KD years. Doncic has been playing at a high level since his early teenage years at Real Madrid, and he didn't skip a beat once he arrived in Dallas. However, the difference now is that he has a team that's built to win a championship. Get it done now, and this may signal the beginning of the \"Doncic Era\" in the NBA.\n\nNoah Rubin: Al Horford is a Hall of Famer with a ring. This take feels a little bold to me, which is why I like it. Horford won two rings in college at Florida and has made the All-Star Game five times as a pro. He also has one All-NBA third team, one All-Defensive second team and made the All-Rookie first team. Add in another ring to his resume, and the case gets stronger. Entering this series, Basketball Reference has him at a 12.2% chance to make the Hall of Fame, so a ring would give him a fighting chance. He isn't a lock to make it, but I think he has a strong case with a ring, especially if he continues to play past this season.\n\nZak Hanshew: Kyrie Irving is a top-5 PG of all time. Magic Johnson and Steph Curry are cemented among the top-5 at the position, and guys like John Stockton, Allen Iverson and Oscar Robertson often make their way into the discussion. Irving is regarded as arguably the best ball handler ever, but he can etch his name into another all-time list with four more wins. With a second Finals victory for a second team and a strong Finals performance, it will be tough to exclude Irving from the top-5 PG conversation.\n\nAmeer Tyree: Tatum wants to take another step and become an undisputed top-5 player. The discussion could shift from him being a promising, young superstar to a disappointment with another championship loss.\n\nQ: Which of these guys (if any) can boost/diminish his 2024-25 fantasy stock with a big/poor performance?\n\nRaphielle Johnson: A player who could potentially boost his 2024-25 fantasy stock in this series is PJ Washington. Based on his Yahoo ADP (128.1), he wasn't a player most managers expected to see produce a top-100 season. However, he was a top 100 player after being traded to Dallas, finishing just outside of that threshold in season-long value. Playing off of Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving did result in a slight decrease in Washington's scoring, but the rebounds, steals, and blocks all increased.\n\nNoah Rubin: Daniel Gafford/Dereck Lively II. They both have helped their stock already, and now they'll have one more series for us to evaluate. Will one of them seize control of the starting center minutes? Will one of them falter, forcing the other to play more minutes? Will they both play well enough to provide value in a minutes split. This four-game series shouldn't be the only factor ahead of drafts next season, but if one of them plays noticeably better, the rotation could swing in favor of either big heading into next season.\n\nZak Hanshew: It's got to be PJ Washington. At this point, fantasy managers know what they'll get from Dereck Lively II and Daniel Gafford. Both guys will be great rebounders and blockers with the occasional scoring outburst when the lobs are plentiful. Can Washington consistently be the guy we hoped he would be for Charlotte? Can he score and rebound at a high level while hitting threes and making a concerted effort on defense?\n\nAmeer Tyree: PJ Washington's long-range shooting was huge in the Western Conference Finals and he's effectively working as his team's third option on offense. An impressive NBA Finals performance could help him lock in a significant role in 2024-25 after falling by the wayside in his last run with the Hornets.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "2024-06-379915934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:44:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:44:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:17:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/nba-finals-tickets-how-much-does-cost-attend-celtics-vs-mavericks", "title": "NBA Finals tickets: How much does it cost to attend Celtics vs. Mavericks?", "body": "The NBA Finals between the Celtics and Mavericks are right around the corner, and basketball fans won't want to miss any of the action. Some fans will want to watch in person, so how much are tickets?\n\nFans have seen a lot of the Boston Celtics in the NBA Finals, as the team has 22 previous appearances in the NBA's championship series. The team made it to the final stage of the postseason as recently as 2022. On the other hand, the Celtics' Finals opponent, the Dallas Mavericks, have only made the Finals twice before.\n\nThe matchup is an intriguing one, and all basketball fans will have their eyes on the action, especially considering all of the storylines that make this series interesting. While plenty of fans will watch on TV, some fans will want to get a better view of the action and watch the games in person. In this article, we will look at how much tickets will cost for the 2024 NBA Finals.\n\nWhen and where are the NBA Finals?\n\nThe Boston Celtics have been the best team throughout the season, and they finished with the best record in the league. Because of that, they will have home-court advantage in the NBA Finals. That means Games 1, 2, 5, and 7 will be at their home, the TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. The Mavericks will host Games 3, 4, and 6 at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas.\n\nGame 1: Dallas Mavericks @ Boston Celtics on Thursday, June 6 at 8:30 p.m. ET - ABC\n\nGame 2: Dallas Mavericks @ Boston Celtics on Sunday, June 9 at 8 p.m. ET - ABC\n\nGame 3: Boston Celtics @ Dallas Mavericks on Wednesday, June 12 at 8:30 p.m. ET - ABC\n\nGame 4: Boston Celtics @ Dallas Mavericks on Friday, June 14 at 8:30 p.m. ET - ABC\n\nGame 5: Dallas Mavericks @ Boston Celtics on Monday, June 17 at TBD - ABC\n\nGame 6: Boston Celtics @ Dallas Mavericks on Thursday, June 20 at TBD - ABC\n\nGame 7: Dallas Mavericks @ Boston Celtics on Sunday, June 23 at TBD - ABC\n\nHow much are tickets to the NBA Finals?\n\nNBA Finals tickets are available on Vividseats. Ticket prices for Game 1 start at $574 and are as expensive as $5,957. The average price is about $700-800. Additionally, you can get VIP tickets that surpass $6,000. Games 2 tickets go up in price, as the least amount of money it will cost to get in is $675, while top-end expensive tickets are over $9,000. The average price is about $100 more expensive than it was in Game 1, too.\n\nAs the series makes its way to Dallas, it will only cost more to watch the Finals in person. Game 3 tickets are at least $680, and they can cost up to over $10,000, with the most expensive tickets being listed at $29,736. Game 4 is the first game where the series could be closed out, so prices skyrocket then, too. The cheapest tickets are $778, while luxurious tickets will cost over $10,000.\n\nThe series will go back to Boston for Game 5, and once again, tickets get more expensive. The lowest you can pay to watch Game 5 is $864, and it'll likely cost you over $1,000 to watch the game. Of course, the series might not go this far, but prices really become unreasonable in Game 6. The cheapest tickets for that game are listed at $1,295, and it may cost you over $2,000 just to get average seats. As of right now, Game 7 tickets aren't quite as unreasonable, and you should be able to get in for less than $2,000, although prices will surely increase if the series does extend that far.\n\nThe NBA Finals first took place in 1947, back when the league was known as the BAA. Three years later, the league rebranded to the NBA, and we have seen plenty of teams advance to the league's biggest stage since. Even so, arguably no team has had more NBA Finals success than the Celtics. Their 17 championships are tied for the most in league history, and now they have a chance to take sole possession of first place in that regard. Boston has only lost the NBA Finals five times, too.\n\nThe Mavericks, on the other hand, will become the fourth team with exactly three Finals appearances. They lost it all back in 2006 with Dirk Nowitzki leading the way before the Hall of Famer led the team back in 2011, where they won one of the most iconic series in league history.\n\nThe 2024 NBA Finals are set up to be memorable. The Celtics have made the Conference Finals in six of the last eight years, but they haven't been able to bring home the Larry O'Brien Trophy during that time.\n\nMeanwhile, Luka Doncic has taken Nowitzki's place as Dallas' European megastar, and he will be desperate to get the championship that Nowitzki wasn't able to get until later in his career.\n\nAdditionally, Kristaps Porzingis is a former Maverick who was cast out by Dallas, while Kyrie Irving is a former Celtic who didn't end on good terms with his team in Boston. There are revenge storylines left and right, and the stakes are at an all-time high. You won't want to miss any of the action, and buying NBA Finals tickets and watching the game in person can be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity if it is feasible.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8163319686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:15:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:15:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:14:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/sports/mavericks/2024/06/05/which-players-will-step-up-for-mavs-celtics-writers-discuss-names-to-watch-in-nba-finals/", "title": "Which players will step up for Mavs, Celtics? Writers discuss names to watch in NBA Finals", "body": "Ahead of the NBA Finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, columnists and beat writers from The Dallas Morning News and The Boston Globe collaborated to answer several questions and predict an outcome for the series, which starts Thursday in Boston.\n\nHere are the players they said need to step up for either the Mavericks or the Celtics to win the series.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMike Curtis: P.J. Washington is going to be the X-factor for the Mavericks. He's shown throughout the postseason that he's capable of stepping up as that third scoring option behind Doncic and Irving. He'll receive plenty of looks from the 3-point line, especially from the corner. It's up to him to knock them down. His defense on Tatum and Brown could be even more valuable to Dallas and might prove the difference in the series if he can make it difficult for either Celtics star.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTim Cowlishaw: This will be an enormous series for Derrick Jones Jr. The Mavericks didn't know they were getting a full-time starter when they signed him away from Chicago. But the former dunk champion has been a top-level defender and will undoubtedly guard Tatum plenty in the coming series.\n\nMavericks\n\nBe the smartest Mavericks fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nTatum is a streaky shooter, and when he's at his best, Boston probably has too many weapons for the Mavs to contend with. But if Jones does his usual job of making Tatum work, that puts added pressure on Brown and Derrick White and others to carry the load.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShawn McFarland: P.J. Washington. He averaged 12.2 points and 6.4 rebounds in the Western Conference finals and cracked double digits in each game, and he's grown into the third option behind Doncic and Irving. We've seen him change the momentum, flow and outcome of individual playoff games, and assuming the Celtics -- with a top-ranked defense led by Jrue Holiday, White, Brown and co. -- throw the kitchen sink at Dallas' superstar backcourt, Washington's impact on offense and defense is necessary. He and Jones could see a lot of time on Tatum (6-8) and Brown (6-6), and his perimeter shooting can help stretch the floor versus a defense without too many holes.\n\nKevin Sherrington: Dereck Lively II was the Mavs' unsung hero of the last two rounds because of his ability to limit teams' offense in the paint. But how much difference can he make against the Celtics, especially if Porzingis reclaims the minutes Al Horford picked up in his absence? Washington and Jones will have their hands full guarding Tatum and Brown, meaning they may not have a lot left for offense. Goes without saying that Doncic and Irving need to outdo Tatum and Brown, so how's this for a wild card: Jaden Hardy. He's got a shooter's conscience, meaning none at all. If he can provide a consistent offensive spark, the Mavs can score with Boston.\n\nBrad Townsend: Washington. At this point, the Mavericks know the baseline of what they can expect from key non-Doncic/Irving players such as Washington, Jones, Josh Green, Maxi Kleber and even Lively. And they know they'll get stellar defense from Washington. But what will he give Dallas offensively? The Celtics have so many offensive weapons that it's imperative for the Mavericks to counter with a reliable No. 3 scorer.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDallas doesn't necessarily need the 17.7-point, 8.3-rebound Washington we saw against Oklahoma City in the second round, though that Washington obviously would be welcomed. But in this series the Mavericks need more scoring from Washington than his 10.8-point average in the first round and 12.2-point average against Minnesota in the WCF.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChad Finn: Honestly, it's just a matter of the Celtics' best players playing up to their ability. The Celtics have a remarkably well-rounded team, and Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have never trusted their colleagues more. The Celtics could be in trouble if Tatum or Brown underperforms or tries to do too much, but I don't anticipate that. I will say this: I think Jrue Holiday will be the one to make the play or plays that clinch this series.\n\nAdam Himmelsbach: The beauty of this Celtics team is that they are so talented at the top that they are generally able to withstand at least one poor performance by any player. So they don't necessarily need one specific player to step up. But keep an eye on Sam Hauser, who was one of the best 3-point shooters in the NBA during the regular season but has largely disappeared during these playoffs.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGary Washburn: This needs to be a Jayson Tatum series and that does not necessarily mean scoring. Tatum needs to rebound, be a playmaker, and play strong defense. The Mavericks don't have a player who can consistently guard him one-on-one and he needs to take advantage of any matchup, but don't get caught up in him matching Doncic basket for basket. He must be best all-around player in this series, prove he's Top 5-Tatum, and make his teammates better.\n\nRelated StoriesView MoreCeltics stars Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown feel better equipped for 2nd chance in NBA Finals10 things to know about ex-Mavericks forward Kristaps Porzingis for the NBA Finals Who will win NBA Finals? {"uri": "8165011040", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:07:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:07:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:06:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/06/the-reasons-the-dallas-mavericks-will-and-wont-win-the-nba-finals", "title": "The reasons the Dallas Mavericks will (and won't!) win the NBA Finals", "body": "The Dallas Mavericks are back in the NBA Finals for the third time in nearly 20 years and may have more on the horizon.\n\nBut before we discuss what's to come next for this Dallas team, we've got to talk about the opportunity right in front of it. The franchise could win its second NBA championship this summer with four wins over the Boston Celtics over these next couple of weeks\n\nIt'll be an uphill battle, though. The Celtics have been the best team in the NBA all season long. And, while the Mavericks have been incredible during this postseason run, overcoming the Celtics' talent won't be easy.\n\nThere's a path to victory here, though. Let's talk a bit about it.\n\nWhy the Mavericks will win\n\nFirst: Dallas arguably has the best player in the series in Luka Doncic.\n\nThis is why so many people have faith in the Dallas Mavericks. It's not that the Celtics aren't the NBA's best team or that there's widespread disbelief in Boston. It's just that Luka Doncic is that good. There's an argument to be made that he should've been MVP this season.\n\nThough the Mavericks didn't beat the Celtics in the regular season this year, he still had his way with Boston, scoring 35 points through the two games while averaging 15 rebounds and 12 assists. I don't know if we see those gaudy Luka numbers in this series, but if we do? That certainly bodes well for Dallas.\n\nSecond: Kristaps Porzingis might not be 100 percent healthy\n\nKristaps Porzingis' health hasn't mattered much this postseason. He's been out since the end of April and Boston has still managed to dispatch their opponents easily.\n\nThe Celtics' big man is back for this series. He says he's healthy, but that slight hesitation in saying he's no longer playing with pain raises antennas a bit.\n\nLuka and Kyrie Irving are going to test that calf. We'll see just how he's feeling in these Finals.\n\nThird: Luka and Kyrie Irving as a combination have been incredible in the playoffs\n\nAs far as duos go, Doncic and Irving have been at the top of the top so far in these playoffs. The 595 minutes they've played together in the postseason are the most any combination of players has played so far this season. Those two have a 9.1 net rating in those minutes together. That's extremely good.\n\nFinding ways to get those two playing in sync against Boston could tilt the series in Dallas' way.\n\nWhy the Mavericks won't win\n\nFirst: The Celtics' \"others\" are better than the Mavericks'\n\nDallas has the best player in this series. There's certainly an argument to be made that they've got the best duo in the series, too, though Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are incredible.\n\nBut there's no question that the rest of the Celtics' supporting cast is much better than what Dallas offers. Boston has two guards on the NBA's All-Defense team, a big man in Porzingis who could've been an All-Star if he had a healthier season, and a rotation filled with players who know their roles and play them well.\n\nThe Mavericks' role players have stepped up well in these playoffs. Maybe they will again, but Boston has them beat.\n\nSecond: Boston's defense has been impenetrable during these playoffs\n\nThe Celtics' 108.7 defensive rating in these playoffs is the third-best in these playoffs so far and the second-best out of any team that has played at least 10 games in these playoffs behind Oklahoma City (104.5).\n\nThe Mavericks might have the best player in this series, but he'll see many different matchups throughout this series. Boston is good enough to keep him in check.\n\nThird: The Celtics have matchups to hunt offensively against Dallas\n\nWhen you think about this series from a matchup standpoint, you've got to think about who is guarding who.\n\nWhere are you placing your weakest defenders against Boston? Who is Kyrie Irving going to guard? Where will Luka Doncic Play? Dereck Lively II and Daniel Gafford will have to play from the outside with Boston's big shooters stretching the floor. Can they handle that?\n\nThe more I think about it, the fewer answers I come up with. Dallas could try a zone or two -- that's not beyond the realm of possibility for this team. But doing that against a team that fires off 40 3-pointers a game is dangerous.\n\nDallas will have a hard time finding the answers defensively in this one.", "source": {"uri": "ftw.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "For The Win"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mike_d_sykes@ftw.usatoday.com", "name": "Mike D. This year, the Celtics were powered by major offseason acquisitions in Jrue Holiday and Kristaps Porzingis. They received good news on the injury front as Porzingis is expected to be ready for Game 1. As the Celtics come into the NBA Finals against the Dallas Mavericks, they face pressure of being the favorite, a feeling known all too well by Los Angeles Lakers star and former rival LeBron James.\n\nOn a recent episode of LeBron James' and JJ Redick's podcast, 'Mind the Game,' James spoke about the pressures that come with being considered the favorite in the NBA Finals.\n\n\"I know what Boston is going through, you know being a favorite and having the weight on their shoulders, and you know like you said the expectation because they've been there so many times it's like okay how many times you're going to climb this mountain to where now you keep sliding back down it and not actually getting to the top and going back down the other way,\" James said. \"So they're definitely feeling it but you know up until this point listen, it don't matter who is put in front of you, we're all NBA players and they're taking care of business right now.\"\n\nLeBron James has reached the NBA Finals ten times in his career. He's won four championships during those appearances. When he was playing for the Miami Heat, his teams were definitely favorites heading into each Finals series.\n\nCeltics have been the NBA's elite team this season\n\nThe Celtics came into the NBA playoffs as the favorite to win the title. They finished the regular season with a record of 64-18 and homecourt advantage throughout the entire postseason. Throughout the playoffs so far, they've looked like a team on a mission.\n\nSure they may have faced teams with a few injury woes, but as LeBron James said, they're all NBA players and the Celtics are taking care of business no matter who is opposite them.\n\nThe Celtics defeated the Heat in five games in the first round, beat the Cleveland Cavaliers in five games in the second round and swept the Indiana Pacers, 4-0, in the Eastern Conference Finals. Now the Celtics prepare for the Mavericks. {"uri": "8163993957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:06:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:06:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:05:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.nine.com.au/sport/basketball/national-basketball-association/nba-finals-2024-dates-schedule-celtics-mavericks-teams-everything-to-know-ultimate-guide-20240606-p5jju9.html", "title": "Aussie duo's rise to the NBA's biggest stage", "body": "The Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals on Friday AEST, with some of the biggest names on the international stage to decide who this year's champion will be.\n\nThe Celtics enter the Finals with home-court advantage after finishing the regular season 64-18, the best in the Eastern Conference and overall in the NBA.\n\nDallas finished with a 50-32 record, the fifth best in the Western Conference.\n\nUltimately the series will come down to either Boston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown or Dallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving.\n\nIn Brown and Tatum, Celtics' most tenured and scrutinised stars on their roster - it is a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nThey've also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw long-time emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favour of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nDoncic and Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nHere's everything you need to know.\n\nAll NBA Finals games in Australia will air on ESPN starting Friday June 7.\n\nThe Boston Celtics have a chance to be the standalone leader with 18 NBA championships if they can win. The 17 titles are tied with the Los Angeles Lakers for most in NBA history.\n\nBefore this season, the Celtics' last Finals appearance was in 2022, where they lost to the Golden State Warriors. Their most recent championship was in 2008.\n\nThe Dallas Mavericks have three NBA Finals appearances. Before this season, their most recent appearance -- and only championship -- was in 2011 when they defeated the Miami Heat. The Mavs reached the 2006 NBA Finals, losing to the Heat.\n\nThere's been a lot of the pressure on Tatum and Brown the past two seasons but that has been somewhat reduced by the presence of offseason acquisitions of Holiday and Porzingis, as well as the consistency of a bench led by veteran Al Horford.\n\nAs a result, Tatum and Brown have seen their overall production increase.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown has also seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nBut it's been tweaks to their overall mental approaches to this season that have stood out.\n\nFor a chunk of his career Brown acknowledged he was at times a victim of consuming much of the negative perception people have had about him.\n\nThat's changed this season, which he played under his most unrelenting spotlight yet as the league's first $450 million player.\n\n\"You get to a point where it's, like, you get scrutinised enough for a large part of your career, it becomes normal. Then it just rolls off you,\" Brown said. \"I don't know if Jayson feels the same way. It's kind of been that my whole career in a sense. Just being booed when you were drafted to saying you were overpaid, saying you were overpaid again. It's been that the whole journey for me.\"\n\nTatum, too, has let go of the mental blocks he believes weighed him down. That includes reluctantly accepting the disappointments he's endured along the way.\n\n\"I hate that I had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" he said. \"But I'm a firm believer in everything happens for a reason. There's a lesson to be learned in every situation. I do. I do feel a lot different this time, this go-around, two years later. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done.\"\n\nDoncic could become the first player to win a scoring title and a championship in the same season since Shaquille O'Neal in 2000, and a title surely would only add to the argument that Doncic -- who leads all players in this postseason in points, rebounds and assists -- may be the best player in the game right now.\n\nDoncic is averaging 28.7 points per game in his six regular seasons; only Michael Jordan and Wilt Chamberlain -- both at 30.1 -- have a higher career average. He's the only player in NBA history to have averages of at least eight assists and eight rebounds per game. He's one of two players with at least 10,000 points, 3,000 rebounds and 3,000 assists through his first 400 career games; Oscar Robertson is the other.\n\nDoncic wants no part of talk that winning is easy. He may make it look easy -- he had a league-best 73-point game this season, 13 different games of scoring at least 40 points in the regular season, and that number could have been even higher considering he scored exactly 39 points on eight other occasions.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nAustralia's Josh Green and Dante Exum are expected to play roles off the bench in the Mavericks rotation as they look to become the next stars Down Under to become NBA champions.\n\nBoomers Green and Exum saw plenty of court time during the playoffs and have become key role players for the Mavericks.\n\nIt's been a wonderful resurgence for Exum, a former No.4 pick, who found himself out of the NBA due to a bad run with injuries. He returned with Barcelona in Euro basket, which paved the way for his return to the NBA.\n\nEvery season since being drafted by the Mavericks in 2020, Green's game has evolved to complement Doncic.\n\nIt's led to the Sydneysider playing a meaningful role on the Mavericks when it matters most, playing 17.8 minutes a game over these playoffs, averaging 4.8 points, 2.5 rebounds, and 1.2 assists a contest, while shooting 35.4 per cent from beyond the arc.\n\n\"Honestly, it's a tough adjustment for anyone,\" Green told ESPN. \"But, I think for me personally, I want to win first.\n\n\"It took time to get used to it, and it took time for me to realise what I need to do to be out on the court. You can tell it's appreciated from guys like Kyrie and Luka. They know the work that the role players put in.\n\n\"They know that it's not like the role players can't do more; but we have Luka and Kyrie and there's certain things that we need to do in order for our team to win, and we're willing to sacrifice for the team.\n\n\"That's why we're in the Finals. Our goal is to keep being a winning team, and that means buying into your role.\"\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nJoe Mazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nThe Boston Celtics are the overwhelming favourites.\n\nSportsbet has the Celtics paying $1.40 to win the series, with Dallas at $2.75.", "source": {"uri": "nine.com.au", They are 12-2 in 14 postseason games, defeating the No. 8 Miami Heat, without Jimmy Butler, in five games, the fifth-seeded Cleveland Cavaliers in five games and the sixth-seeded Indiana Pacers in four.\n\nDallas has had a much tougher road, beating the No. 4 L.A. Clippers and No. 1 Oklahoma City Thunder in six games each. In the Western Conference Finals, they beat the No. 3 Minnesota Timberwolves in five games, who had just beaten the reigning champs in the second round.\n\nThe Celtics will host Games 1 and 2 on Thursday at 8:30 p.m. ET and Sunday at 8 p.m. The series then moves to Dallas for Games 3 and 4 on Wednesday and Friday at 8:30 p.m. before games 5, 6, and 7, if necessary, alternate between the two sites.\n\nGame 5 would be June 17 at 8:30 p.m., Game 6 would be three days later at the same time, and Game 7 is currently slated for June 23 at 8 p.m.\n\nThe Celtics have been in the finals more recently than Dallas, making it two years ago but losing to the Golden State Warriors. However, Boston last won it all the way back in 2008. Dallas, famously, beat the Miami Heat in their first year of their Big Three in 2011, and have not made the finals since.\n\nThis is Boston's 23rd Finals appearance in franchise history. With a win, Boston would break its tie with the Los Angeles Lakers for the most NBA titles, with 18. Jayson Tatum and Luka Doncic enter NBA Finals as favourites", "body": "The NBA Finals are here as the Boston Celtics take on the Dallas Mavericks, in pursuit of the Larry O'Brien trophy.\n\nThe Celtics finished with the best record in the regular season (64-18), and breezed through the Eastern Conference with a 12-2 record, led by Jayson Tatum and ECF MVP Jaylen Brown.\n\nMeanwhile, the Mavericks find themselves in their first NBA Finals since 2011, led by Western Conference Finals MVP Luka Doncic and his backcourt mate Kyrie Irving.\n\nMORE: Why Celtics need a healthy Kristaps Porzingis to beat Mavericks\n\nWith the superstars at the forefront of the series, the Finals will ultimately come down to which duo steps up on the biggest stage, with Doncic the only one from the four-man group making his Finals debut.\n\nThe bookmakers have earmarked the Celtics as favourites to win the Finals, with Jayson Tatum the front-runner for Finals MVP.\n\nHere's a look at the complete odds for the Bill Russell NBA Finals Most Valuable Player award.\n\nOdds courtesy of TAB\n\nTatum enters the Finals with the shortest odds at $1.75 for Finals MVP as the best player on the top-rated team, but throughout this postseason, Jaylen Brown has been the Celtics' best performer.\n\nComing off an Eastern Conference Finals MVP, Brown has averaged 25.0 points, 6.1 rebounds, 2.6 assists and 1.1 steals on .488/.363/.722 shooting splits, and with the 3-time All-Star likely to take on a larger share of the defensive assignment on Luka Doncic, his impact on the series could prove to be the difference-maker for Boston. At $6.00, Brown presents great value.\n\nMORE: Jayson Tatum gets candid about Kyrie Irving's disappointing Celtics run\n\nTatum's case for Finals MVP rests in him being the clear No. 1 option on offence, and while he routinely attracts the opposition team's best defender, he has still been productive this postseason with averages of 26.0 points, 10.4 rebounds, 5.9 assists and 1.1 steals on .443/.290/.845 shooting splits.\n\nIf Dallas is to pull off the upset and win the title, it will most likely mean Luka Doncic has gone absolutely berserk in the Finals -- a scenario that could well play out given he leads the Mavs in total points, rebounds and assists this postseason.\n\nSure, the superstars will have their say, but in Boston's case, there's one player looming as a wildcard for Finals MVP: Derrick White.\n\nThrough 14 postseason games, White is averaging 17.8 points, 4.6 assists, 4.1 rebounds and 1.3 blocks on .471/.407/.893 shooting splits, while playing elite defence on the other end of the court.\n\nHe leads the Celtics in 3-point percentage and has proven he can blow games open when he's knocking down triples, with Boston 8-0 when he hits at least three.\n\n\"When you talk about his ability to shoot the three, again he's one that a lot of times goes under the radar, but when he's able to knock down threes and he gets a lot of looks at them, it takes their offence to another level,\" Mavs head coach Jason Kidd said of White.\n\n\"They got a lot of lasers out there, we gotta be able to guard the three but White is the one that we are concerned about.\"\n\nMORE: Revisiting the trade that sent Kyrie Irving from Brooklyn to Dallas\n\nMeanwhile, Kyrie Irving presents an interesting pick for bettors at $17, with the 32-year-old one of just three players alongside Boston's Jrue Holiday and Dallas' Markieff Morris with championship experience.\n\nIrving's ability to create shots for himself in tight spaces and bail the Mavs out in the fourth {"uri": "8164900153", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:52:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:52:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:50:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/the-nba-finals-record-of-every-player-who-will-play-in-the-2024-finals/article_3819939a-af89-5907-a866-ce324cb833d1.html", "title": "The NBA Finals Record Of Every Player Who Will Play In The 2024 Finals", "body": "The 2024 NBA Finals have arrived, with the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics ready to compete for the championship title. This highly anticipated series showcases players who have accumulated substantial experience in the NBA Finals throughout their careers. From seasoned veterans to emerging stars, these athletes have made significant contributions to their teams' successes on the biggest stage. In this article, we will take an in-depth look at the NBA Finals records of key players from both teams.\n\nBy examining their career Finals records, we aim to highlight the pivotal moments and significant contributions that have paved the way for their current success. Whether it's Luka Doncic's first trip or Jayson Tatum's chance for redemption, these players have demonstrated their ability to excel when it matters most to lead their teams to this stage.\n\nPlayers Who Never Played In The NBA Finals\n\nDallas Mavericks: Luka Doncic, PJ Washington, Daniel Gafford, Dereck Lively II, Josh Green, Jaden Hardy, Maxi Kleber, Dante Exum, Dwight Powell, AJ Lawson, Tim Hardaway Jr.\n\nBoston Celtics: Kristaps Porzingis, Xavier Tillman, Oshae Brissett, Svi Mykhailiuk, Neemias Queta, Jaden Springer, Jordan Walsh\n\nFor the Dallas Mavericks, the 2024 NBA Finals mark a new chapter, as the majority of their roster is experiencing this stage for the first time. Players like Luka Doncic, PJ Washington, and Tim Hardaway Jr. are making their Finals debuts, bringing excitement and a fresh perspective to the team. This newfound opportunity provides a platform for these players to showcase their talent and resilience on the biggest stage of their careers.\n\nOn the other hand, the Boston Celtics bring a mix of seasoned experience and fresh faces. Having reached the NBA Finals in 2022, the Celtics are no strangers to this level of competition. While players like Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been here before and know what it takes to compete at this level, the roster also includes new additions such as Kristaps Porzingis and Oshae Brissett, who are eager to make their mark. This blend of experience and new energy positions the Celtics as a well-rounded and formidable opponent in this year's Finals.\n\nPlayers Who Played In The NBA Finals Before1. Kyrie Irving - 1-2 In Series (5-8 Game-Record)\n\nKyrie Irving brings extensive NBA Finals experience to the Dallas Mavericks, having played in three Finals series with the Cleveland Cavaliers. His Finals journey began in 2015, although it was cut short by injury after Game 1. In 2016, Irving delivered one of the most memorable performances in Finals history. He averaged 27.1 points, 3.9 assists, and 3.9 rebounds per game, highlighted by his game-winning three-pointer in Game 7, where he scored 26 points. This shot helped the Cavaliers complete their historic comeback from a 3-1 deficit to defeat the Golden State Warriors.\n\nIn the 2017 Finals, Irving continued to excel, averaging 29.4 points, 4.4 assists, and 4.0 rebounds per game, although the Cavaliers ultimately lost to the Warriors in five games. His 40-point performance in Game 4 was a standout, showcasing his scoring ability and resilience.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Irving has been pivotal for the Mavericks, averaging 22.8 points, 5.2 assists, and 3.9 rebounds per game in 17 games. His leadership and experience have been crucial, especially in guiding younger players making their Finals debut. Notable performances this postseason include a 36-point outburst in Game 5 of the Western Conference Finals against the Minnesota Timberwolves, where he also added 5 assists and 4 rebounds, leading Dallas to a decisive victory.\n\nIrving's ability to take over games in critical moments has been a driving force for the Mavericks throughout the postseason. As they head into the Finals, his extensive experience and proven track record in clutch situations make him a vital asset for Dallas as they compete for the championship.\n\n2. Jrue Holiday - 1-0 In Series (4-2 Game-Record)\n\nJrue Holiday played a pivotal role in the Milwaukee Bucks' 2021 NBA Finals victory over the Phoenix Suns. In that series, Holiday's performance was crucial on both ends of the floor. He averaged 16.7 points, 9.3 assists, and 6.2 rebounds per game, providing the Bucks with much-needed playmaking and defensive prowess. His standout moment came in Game 5, where he recorded 27 points, 13 assists, and three steals, including a game-saving steal and alley-oop assist to Giannis Antetokounmpo that sealed the victory.\n\nDuring the 2024 playoffs, Holiday has been a steady presence for the Boston Celtics, averaging 12.7 points, 5.6 rebounds, and 4.6 assists in 14 games. His leadership and experience have been instrumental in guiding a team that combines seasoned veterans with young talents. Notable performances include a 22-point, 8-rebound game against the Philadelphia 76ers in the Eastern Conference Semifinals, where his defense and playmaking were key to the Celtics' success.\n\nHoliday's ability to perform in high-pressure situations has been crucial for Boston. His past Finals experience is expected to play a significant role as the Celtics compete for another championship, providing stability and clutch play when it matters most.\n\n3. Al Horford - 0-1 In Series (2-4 Game-Record)\n\nAl Horford's NBA Finals experience came with the Boston Celtics in 2022, where they faced the Golden State Warriors. In that series, Horford played a significant role, averaging 12.5 points, 8.5 rebounds, and 3.0 assists per game. His veteran presence and leadership were crucial for the Celtics, especially in Game 1, where he scored 26 points, including six three-pointers, to help Boston secure a victory.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Horford has continued to be a reliable contributor for the Celtics. He has averaged 9.9 points, 7.3 rebounds, and 1.9 assists per game in 14 games, providing steady defense and crucial plays in key moments. His experience and calm under pressure have been vital for a Celtics team looking to leverage their past Finals experience to push for another championship.\n\nHorford's ability to stretch the floor with his shooting and his defensive versatility make him an indispensable part of the Celtics' lineup. As Boston heads into the Finals, Horford's past experience and steady play will be essential in their quest for the title.\n\n4. Jaylen Brown - 0-1 In Series (2-4 Game-Record)\n\nJaylen Brown's NBA Finals experience comes from the Boston Celtics' 2022 matchup against the Golden State Warriors. In that series, Brown was a standout performer, averaging 23.5 points, 7.3 rebounds, and 3.7 assists per game over six games. His contributions were vital in several games, particularly in Game 3, where he scored 27 points and grabbed 9 rebounds, helping the Celtics secure a crucial win.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Brown has been exceptional, averaging 25.0 points, 6.1 rebounds, and 2.6 assists per game. One of his standout performances came in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers. In that game, Brown hit a clutch three-pointer to send the game into overtime, finishing with 26 points, 7 rebounds, and 5 assists. His consistent high-level play earned him the Eastern Conference Finals MVP award, underscoring his importance to the team's success.\n\nBrown's experience and performance in the Finals are crucial for the Celtics as they prepare for another shot at the championship. His ability to score efficiently, defend multiple positions, and perform under pressure makes him a key player in Boston's quest for the title.\n\n5. Jayson Tatum - 0-1 In Series (2-4 Game-Record)\n\nJayson Tatum's NBA Finals experience is rooted in the Boston Celtics' 2022 series against the Golden State Warriors. During that series, Tatum averaged 21.5 points, 7.0 assists, and 6.8 rebounds per game over six games. His performances included notable games like Game 3, where he scored 26 points and added 6 rebounds and 9 assists, and Game 5, where he posted 27 points, 10 rebounds, and 4 assists. Despite his efforts, the Celtics ultimately fell to the Warriors in six games.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Tatum has continued to be a critical player for the Celtics. He has averaged 26.0 points, 10.4 rebounds, and 5.9 assists per game in 14 games. His leadership and scoring have been pivotal, especially in high-pressure situations. Notable performances include a 36-point, 12-rebound game in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers, and a 26-point, 13-rebound, and 8-assist game in Game 4, where his contributions helped Boston secure a sweep of the series.\n\nTatum's combination of scoring, playmaking, and defensive abilities makes him a key figure for Boston as they prepare for another chance at the championship. His experience from the 2022 Finals and his outstanding 2024 playoff run position him as a crucial player in the Celtics' quest for the title.\n\nRelated: A Timeline Of How The Dallas Mavericks Built A Powerful Team With Luka And Kyrie\n\n6. Derrick White - 0-1 In Series (2-4 Game-Record)\n\nDerrick White played a notable role in the Boston Celtics' 2022 NBA Finals run against the Golden State Warriors. Throughout the series, White averaged 9.8 points, 2.2 assists, and 1.5 rebounds per game over six games. One of his standout performances came in Game 1, where he scored 21 points, shooting 6-of-11 from the field, including 5-of-8 from three-point range, helping the Celtics secure an early lead in the series.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, White has been essential for the Celtics. He has averaged 17.8 points, 4.6 assists, and 4.1 rebounds per game in 14 games. A notable performance in the Eastern Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers included Game 2, where he scored 23 points, making 4-of-8 three-pointers and contributing significantly to the Celtics' victory.\n\nWhite's ability to perform under pressure and his versatility as a guard make him a crucial asset for Boston as they head into the Finals. His experience from the 2022 Finals and his solid 2024 playoff performances position him as a key contributor in the Celtics' quest for the championship.\n\n7. Payton Pritchard - 0-1 In Series (2-4 Game-Record)\n\nPayton Pritchard's NBA Finals experience comes from the Boston Celtics' 2022 series against the Golden State Warriors. In that series, Pritchard averaged 2.7 points, 2.2 rebounds, and 1.0 assists per game over six games. His contributions were primarily focused on providing energy and solid defense off the bench, although he had moments where his shooting helped the team.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Pritchard has been a more significant contributor for the Celtics. He has averaged 7.5 points, 2.3 assists, and 2.1 rebounds per game in 14 games. A standout performance in the Eastern Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers included Game 3, where he scored 12 points, hitting key three-pointers that helped maintain Boston's lead.\n\nPritchard's ability to provide scoring and playmaking off the bench makes him a valuable asset for the Celtics as they prepare for the Finals. His experience from the 2022 Finals and his increased role in the 2024 playoffs position him as a crucial player in Boston's pursuit of the championship.\n\n8. Markieff Morris - 1-0 In Series (4-2 Game-Record)\n\nMarkieff Morris was a significant contributor during the Los Angeles Lakers' 2020 NBA Finals victory over the Miami Heat. In that series, Morris averaged 7.5 points, 3.3 rebounds, and 1.2 assists per game over six games. His most notable performance came in Game 3, where he scored 19 points and grabbed 6 rebounds, hitting five three-pointers to help the Lakers secure a crucial win.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Morris has not yet appeared in any games for the Dallas Mavericks. Despite his lack of playing time, his experience and leadership are valuable assets for the team as they aim for the championship.\n\n9. Sam Hauser - 0-1 In Series (2-3 Game-Record)\n\nSam Hauser made his NBA Finals debut in 2022 with the Boston Celtics during his rookie season. In that series, he averaged 0.6 points and 0.4 assists in 5 games, finishing with a 2-4 record for the Celtics against the Warriors. Despite his limited role, the experience was valuable.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Hauser has stepped up, averaging 4.4 points, 1.9 rebounds, and 0.6 assists per game in 14 games. One notable performance came in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference Finals against the Indiana Pacers, where he scored 10 points, hitting crucial three-pointers that helped secure the win. Hauser's shooting and floor-spacing abilities make him a valuable asset as the Celtics prepare for the Finals, providing depth and scoring off the bench.\n\n10. Derrick Jones Jr. - 0-1 In Series (0-4 Game-Record)\n\nDerrick Jones Jr. played in the 2020 NBA Finals with the Miami Heat, where he averaged 0.5 points and 0.3 rebounds in 4 games. His role was limited, but his athleticism and defensive capabilities were key components of the Heat's rotation.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Jones Jr. has been a significant contributor for the Dallas Mavericks, averaging 9.8 points, 3.6 rebounds, and 1.4 assists in 17 games. His ability to defend multiple positions and provide energy off the bench has been vital for the Mavericks, adding depth to their playoff rotation.\n\n11. Luke Kornet - 0-1 In Series (0-3 Game-Record)\n\nLuke Kornet played in the 2022 NBA Finals with the Boston Celtics, appearing in three games. In that series, he averaged 1.7 points, 0.7 rebounds, and 0.3 assists per game. Although his role was limited, his presence provided valuable bench depth.\n\nIn the 2024 playoffs, Kornet has been more active, averaging 3.9 rebounds, 3.7 points, and 0.5 assists in 10 games. His contributions off the bench have helped bolster the Celtics' frontcourt as they prepare for another championship run.\n\nRelated: 2024 NBA Finals: Celtics vs. Mavericks (Analysis, Comparison, {"uri": "8164879258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:37:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:37:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:36:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/jrue-hoilday-on-tatum-brown-pressure-in-nba-finals/", "title": "'Really Impressive' How Tatum and Brown Handle Pressure in Boston", "body": "Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown enter the 2024 NBA Finals with the pressure to prove that they can carry the Boston Celtics to an NBA championship.\n\nHighlights Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown stay cool under pressure, drawing strength from Celtics legends. The duo accepts the weight of representing the historic Celtics organization in the NBA Finals. High expectations and pressure on Tatum and Brown will test their resolve in the Finals.\n\nIt takes a lot of composure for NBA players with the responsibility of carrying their team, and the adversity that these players face can be overwhelming. It's a gift and a curse to be a superstar in the NBA. When all is well and the team is winning, the fans are ecstatic, the organization is satisfied, and the player receives praise from the media. When things take a turn for the worse, the situation can be ugly. Players have been scrutinized, mocked, and torn apart by the media if they fail to meet expectations.\n\nSuperstar players have to be mentally strong and must have the ability to bounce back after tough outings. Teams become dependent on these superstars to be able to be a voice of reason in the locker room, to be a leader on the floor all while producing at an elite level. There is an abundance of pressure that comes along with trying to navigate through a vaunted regular season schedule, not to mention how much more challenging it can be to perform well on the game's biggest stage.\n\nThe dynamic duo of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown knows all too well about playing under pressure. These two players have been criticized daily and are always the topic of conversation whenever the Boston Celtics lose. As they prepare to make their second NBA Finals appearance, will the Celtic duo feel less pressure this time around?\n\nThe Celtics Understand What's At Stake In the 2024 NBA Finals Tatum and Brown may feel pressure trying to live up to the Celtics All-Time greats\n\nTatum and Brown have always handled being under pressure like seasoned veterans. You hardly ever see them get frustrated, and that credit should be given to the veterans that they have played with, particularly Al Horford and Kyrie Irving during his tenure when he was with the Celtics. Having that veteran presence brings a sense of calm, peace, and serenity in stressful situations, and gives the superstar duo someone to lean on if they ever need guidance or advice.\n\nThere has always been pressure for just putting on the Celtics jersey. Those players are not only representing themselves but the many legends who came before them. A reporter asked Tatum whether the team faced a different level of pressure due to the Celtics' historic past.\n\n\"We only hang championship banners. Seventeen of them. Some of the greatest players ever to play this game have worn this uniform, and all of us are honored to even follow in their footsteps. The way they paved for us in order to live out our dreams.\" -Jayson Tatum\n\nTatum, Brown, and the rest of the Celtics understand the significance of putting on that Celtics green as they understand the fact that this is bigger than any individual success. One day, Tatum's and Brown's jerseys should hang in the TD Garden rafters along with the rest of the Celtics legends, but the pressure to even live up to that is enormous. What they don't want is to be remembered as that group of Celtics who made it to the end and couldn't finish the job.\n\nWe are living in an era where a dynamic duo that has played in five Eastern Conference Finals and what will be two NBA Finals once the series begins before they both turned 30 is being viewed as a failure. Critics view this iteration of the Celtics as failure because of how stacked the roster has been over the past few seasons.\n\nEven Though the Pressure Mounts, Tatum and Brown Don't Appear to be Affected The past experiences and letdowns have prepared the duo for this moment\n\nEvery time the Celtics advance deep into the postseason, the goalpost gets moved and expectations become higher. Tatum and Brown will either falter from the pressure or they will overcome and embrace this challenge. If they have learned anything from their Finals appearance in 2022, it's to never allow the moment to overtake you and to remember that its still basketball at the end of the day.\n\nTake away the crucial mistakes and the costly turnovers from that series, and we may be having another conversation. No other duo has faced more pressure to succeed over the past couple of seasons as the Celtics were poised and ready to make a run at NBA history. During the team's media availability, a reporter asked Celtics guard Jrue Holiday about how Tatum and Brown handle the pressure of carrying the team so well and what he does to try and help alleviate some of that pressure.\n\n\"The pressure that JB and JT have to take on is something different. I've told them this before, that it's really impressive how they handle themselves, how they stay professional, how they still come out every game and do what they do.\" -Jrue Holiday\n\nThe Celtics rewarded Brown with the richest deal in NBA history by giving him a 5-year supermax extension worth up to $303.7 million. If the Celtics lose against the Dallas Mavericks in the Finals, the media will more than likely bring up the fact that the player with the largest contract in league history couldn't get the job done, and will question if he was even worth the money if he can't deliver on the biggest stage. A lot of players disappear when they get that big contract, but Brown has been the total opposite. He got his money and has been spectacular this postseason as his performance has improved.\n\nJaylen Brown's Playoff Stats 2023\n\nYear\n\nPPG\n\nRPG\n\nAPG\n\n3PT%\n\n2023\n\n22.7\n\n5.6\n\n3.4\n\n35.4\n\n2024\n\n25.0\n\n6.1\n\n2.6\n\n36.8%\n\nTatum also reflected on his experiences from the loss they suffered in the 2022 Finals during the team's media availability. The fact of the matter isn't that they lost on the biggest stage, but the lessons and knowledge that was gained in the process.\n\n\"I hate that I had to go through it. I wish we would have won. I'm a firm believer that everything happens for a reason. There is a lesson to be learned in every situation and I do feel a lot different this time around.\" -Tatum\n\nRelated Jrue Holiday 'Can't Wait' for Kristaps Porzingis' Return for NBA Finals The {"uri": "8161946807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "00:08:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T00:08:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T00:07:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/boston-celtics-nba-finals-history-record-titles-finals-mvps-appearances-game-7s", "title": "Boston Celtics NBA Finals history: record, titles, Finals MVPs, appearances, Game 7s", "body": "For the 23rd time in its history, the Boston Celtics are in the NBA Finals -- the place their fans, and the franchise itself, expect to be.\n\nThe Celtics are one of the grand and most historic franchises in the NBA, a history littered with the great names of the game: Bill Russell, Bob Cousy, Larry Bird, John Havlicek, Dave Cowens, Kevin McHale, Paul Pierce -- and that's just the tip of the iceberg.\n\nLet's look at the Boston Celtics NBA Finals history.\n\nBoston has 17 NBA titles, tied for the most in league history with its rivals, the Los Angeles Lakers. If Boston can beat Dallas this year, it will put the Celtics alone in first place and ahead of their West Coast nemesis.\n\nFive times. That includes their most recent trip to the NBA Finals in 2022 when Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown learned some hard lessons in their first trip to the league's biggest stage, falling at the hands of the more experienced Stephen Curry and the Golden State Warriors.\n\nBoston last won a title in 2008, when Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce and Ray Allen -- along with young upstart point guard Rajon Rondo -- knocked off the Kobe Bryant Lakers in six games.\n\nBoston was in the NBA Finals just two years ago, 2022, but lost to the Golden State Warriors. That was a very different Boston team. While Tatum and Brown were still the leaders, that roster leaned on players no longer with the team, including Marcus Smart, Robert Williams (who was battling knee issues even then), and Grant Williams.\n\nZero. That's the next step in Tatum's legacy, as great a player as he has been -- five-time All-Star, four-times All-NBA, 2022 Eastern Conference Finals MVP -- in Boston legacies are measured in rings. If Tatum wants to ascend to become one of the Celtics' all-time greats, he needs a title (or titles). That can start this year.\n\nFive Celtics have been named NBA Finals MVP. Larry Bird did it twice in the 1980s (1984 and 1986) and has the most of any Boston player. Other Celtics who have been voted NBA Finals MVP are John Havlicek (1974), Jo Jo White (1976), Cedric Maxwell (1981), and Paul Pierce (2008).\n\nBill Russell's name is not on that list because the NBA Finals award did not exist until 1969, the final season of Russell's 13-year Hall of Fame playing career. The Celtics did make the Finals in 1969, and the Celtics won the title that season, but the Finals MVP went to the Lakers' Jerry West, the only time in NBA history the award winner was on the losing team in the series. If the Finals MVP award existed prior to 1969, Russell would have a trophy case full of them.\n\nYes, and that doesn't even tell the story of the Celtics' dominance from the late 1950s through the 1960s.\n\nBoston won 11 titles in 13 seasons during the Bill Russell era, starting in the 1957 Finals and running through Russell's final season in 1969. Those teams were stacked with talent, including Russell, Cousy at the point,Tommy Heinsohn, Sam Jones, K.C.
