{"uri": "8164430995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:06:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:06:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:06:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/06/sports/nba-finals-celtics-mavericks-storylines/", "title": "An NBA Finals roundtable: Biggest story lines, players to watch, and who has the coaching edge - The Boston Globe", "body": "Despite a historic season, he finished third in voting for the regular-season MVP award. He now has a chance to win a Finals MVP -- which he'd probably appreciate more.\n\nTim Cowlishaw, Dallas Morning News: I don't know how Luka Doncic isn't the biggest story line in everything he does. He already has set regular-season statistical standards, and he has been dominant in the playoffs. In the conference finals, he badly outplayed Minnesota's Anthony Edwards, and few players have enjoyed hitting big shots or winning on the road stage quite like Luka.\n\nWell, a Finals in the Garden against the team with 17 championship banners is about as large as it's going to get. The accolades keep pouring in from national TV analysts, coaches, players. This series isn't quite Luka vs. the Celtics, but it's close to that, and he loves it. The extra days off in the Finals will allow Jason Kidd to play Luka close to 48 minutes a night.\n\nShawn McFarland, Dallas Morning News: The impact a title could have on each team's star(s). Just consider the company of 1A players who have led teams to recent titles that either Doncic or Jayson Tatum could join: Nikola Jokic, Steph Curry, Giannis Antetokounmpo, LeBron James, and Kawhi Leonard.\n\nA Dallas win would cement Doncic and Dirk Nowitzki as the only two superstars to lead the Mavericks to a championship. An 18th banner for Boston would officially ensure that the Tatum-Jaylen Brown era is successful beyond deep-yet-ringless playoff runs, and it'd squash any leftover narrative that the two can't coexist. The NBA is a star-driven league, and this series has massive ramifications for those on both sides.\n\nKevin Sherrington, Dallas Morning News: Kristaps Porzingis's return to Dallas will undoubtedly become a subtext, especially after Chandler Parsons's contention that Doncic didn't like playing next to him and that there's a \"beef\" there. Luka says there's nothing there.\n\nUnless KP goes off against the Mavs, the dominant story line will be whether Luka carries the Mavs to a title. Boston has a better team, or at least more star-caliber players, but, all apologies to Tatum, none so bright as Luka. If he doesn't play at a superstar level in the Finals, it won't be because he shrank from the spotlight. He might be the most unflappable player in the league, if not all sports.\n\nBrad Townsend, Dallas Morning News: It's Porzingis because there are so many layers to his expected return to the court. How rusty will he be? How quickly will he and his teammates reacclimate to one another? There's no worse time than the NBA Finals for Porzingis and the Celtics to confront these unknowns and have, in effect, a breaking-in period.\n\nLet's say the transition goes smoothly and the Celtics win the first two games in Boston, then Porzingis faces the hurdle of playing his first game in Dallas since the Mavericks traded him to Washington in February 2022.\n\nChad Finn, Boston Globe: I think the most overlooked story line in all of the analysis about this series is how the Mavericks intend to defend the Celtics. Dallas's defense has been terrific pretty much since the trade deadline, but it has also been lucky (catching an Oklahoma City team that went frigid from 3). Doncic and Irving are average defenders at best, and the Celtics are going to expose weaknesses that have been hidden so far.\n\nAdam Himmelsbach, Boston Globe: This is an obvious one, but it's the health of Celtics center Kristaps Porzingis, who is expected to return for Game 1 after being sidelined since suffering a calf sprain against the Heat on April 28.\n\nWhen Porzingis was asked Tuesday whether he is running without pain, he had a long, long pause before finally answering yes. Maybe this was just a smokescreen, or maybe there is something there. The Celtics will welcome 3-point shooting to space the floor, along with his rim protection against the Mavericks' array of high-flying finishers.\n\nGary Washburn, Boston Globe: How the Celtics defend Luka Doncic and approach one of the league's most talented and ball-dominant players. Do they allow Doncic to score but try to shut down his options for distributing the ball? Doncic has arguably been the best player in the playoffs and the Celtics have to devise a plan to slow him down so he doesn't turn into a scorer and distributor. If Doncic takes full control of this series, hits shots, gets to the free throw line and is allowed to toss easy lobs to the Dallas big men, it could be a long series for the Celtics.\n\nCurtis: P.J. Washington is going to be the X-factor for the Mavericks. He's shown throughout the postseason that he's capable of stepping up as that third scoring option behind Doncic and Irving. He'll receive plenty of looks from the 3-point line, especially from the corner. It's up to him to knock them down. His defense on Tatum and Brown could be even more valuable to Dallas and might prove the difference in the series if he can make it difficult for either Celtics star.\n\nCowlishaw: This will be an enormous series for Derrick Jones Jr. The Mavericks didn't know they were getting a full-time starter when they signed him away from Chicago. But the former dunk champion has been a top-level defender and will undoubtedly guard Tatum plenty.\n\nTatum is a streaky shooter, and when he's at his best, Boston probably has too many weapons for the Mavs to contend with. But if Jones does his usual job of making Tatum work, that puts added pressure on Brown and Derrick White and others to carry the load.\n\nMcFarland: P.J. Washington. He averaged 12.2 points and 6.4 rebounds in the Western Conference finals and cracked double digits in each game, and he's grown into the third option behind Doncic and Irving. We've seen him change the momentum, flow, and outcome of individual playoff games, and assuming the Celtics -- with a top-ranked defense led by Jrue Holiday, White, Brown & Co. -- throw the kitchen sink at Dallas's superstar backcourt, Washington's impact on offense and defense is necessary. He and Jones could see a lot of time on Tatum (6-8) and Brown (6-6), and his perimeter shooting can help stretch the floor versus a defense without many holes.\n\nSherrington: Dereck Lively II was the Mavs' unsung hero of the last two rounds because of his ability to limit teams' offense in the paint. But how much difference can he make against the Celtics, especially if Porzingis reclaims the minutes Al Horford picked up in his absence?\n\nWashington and Jones will have their hands full guarding Tatum and Brown, meaning they may not have a lot left for offense. Goes without saying that Doncic and Irving need to outdo Tatum and Brown, so how's this for a wild card: Jaden Hardy. He's got a shooter's conscience, meaning none at all. If he can provide a consistent offensive spark, the Mavs can score with Boston.\n\nTownsend: Washington. At this point, the Mavericks know the baseline of what they can expect from key non-Doncic/Irving players such as Washington, Jones, Josh Green, Maxi Kleber, and even Lively. And they know they'll get stellar defense from Washington. But what will he give Dallas offensively? The Celtics have so many offensive weapons that it's imperative for the Mavericks to counter with a reliable No. 3 scorer.\n\nDallas doesn't necessarily need the 17.7-point, 8.3-rebound Washington we saw against Oklahoma City in the second round, though that Washington obviously would be welcomed. But in this series the Mavericks need more scoring from Washington than his 10.8-point average in the first round and 12.2-point average against Minnesota in the WCF.\n\nFinn: Honestly, it's just a matter of the Celtics' best players playing up to their ability. The Celtics have a remarkably well-rounded team, and Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have never trusted their colleagues more. The Celtics could be in trouble if Tatum or Brown underperforms or tries to do too much, but I don't anticipate that. I will say this: I think Jrue Holiday will be the one to make the play or plays that clinch this series.\n\nHimmelsbach: The beauty of this Celtics team is that they are so talented at the top that they are generally able to withstand at least one poor performance by any player. So they don't necessarily need one specific player to step up. But keep an eye on Sam Hauser, who was one of the best 3-point shooters in the NBA during the regular season but has largely disappeared during these playoffs.\n\nWashburn: This needs to be a Jayson Tatum series, and that does not necessarily mean scoring. Tatum needs to rebound, be a playmaker, and play strong defense. The Mavericks don't have a player who can consistently guard him one-on-one, and he needs to take advantage of any matchup, but don't get caught up in him matching Doncic basket for basket. He must be the best all-around player in this series, prove he's top-five Tatum, and make his teammates better.\n\nCurtis: Coaching is one of the most underappreciated aspects of the playoffs. Adjustments could be the difference between a sweep, a competitive series, or ultimately a championship. Kidd has shown the ability to make several quick adjustments throughout the playoffs, whether it's a personnel change, such as giving Hardy more opportunities off the bench, or challenging a crucial late-game whistle that works in Dallas's favor.\n\nMazzulla, 35, is the youngest coach to reach the Finals since Bill Russell in 1969, but his Celtics didn't go through as much adversity in the previous three rounds as Dallas has. I'll give Kidd the edge here.\n\nCowlishaw: I don't know that there's a particular coaching edge in the series. Both have spent time being criticized in their own markets the last two years -- Mazzulla for being quiet or soft and emphasizing threes at all costs (who doesn't?), and Kidd for his team's uneven play and terrible defense a year ago when Dallas missed the play-in games.\n\nBut Kidd has been a recent assistant in the Finals (LA) and took the Mavs to the conference finals two years ago while Mazzulla has done the same the last two seasons in Boston. Kidd has been known to be reluctant to use timeouts to quiet home crowds when the opponent is making a run. That will be something to watch in Boston.\n\nMcFarland: Mazzulla. Kidd might have an experience edge in the postseason given his track record (titles as a player and assistant coach), and he's pushed the correct buttons more often than not this spring, but Mazzulla's winning percentage (.738) since becoming head coach last season is hard to overlook. His .676 postseason winning percentage trumps Kidd's .508, albeit in a smaller sample size.\n\nMazzulla has grown into his role considerably since last year's Eastern Conference finals loss to the Miami Heat, and he had to knock out Erik Spoelstra and Rick Carlisle to reach this year's Finals.\n\nSherrington: Neither Kidd nor Mazzulla has gotten the credit each deserves for getting their teams to the Finals. Just because both have stars doesn't mean it's easy. Mazzulla will feel more pressure because of the weight of Celtics history and their standing this season as the league's best team, at least by record.\n\nKidd knows what it takes to win a title because he's done it as a player and as an assistant. He conceded this week that it's \"a lot harder\" as a coach than as a player, but he's rounding into the job.\n\nBoston is great, but the Mavs have come a long way since the trade deadline. Kidd deserves a lot of the credit for that, and the nod here.\n\nTownsend: Kidd. He's been a head coach, off and on, since 2014. He's been on the NBA Finals stage three times as a player and once as a Lakers assistant in 2020, albeit in the Disney World bubble.\n\nSure, Mazzulla was an assistant when the Celtics lost to Golden State in the '22 Finals. But he's 35 and in his second season as head coach. Losing to No. 8 seed Miami in last season's Eastern Conference finals was deemed a failure and had media and fans wondering whether Mazzulla was suited for the job.\n\nBoston's 64-win regular season and 12-2 run through the playoffs has more than proved Mazzulla's head coaching ability, but the pressure to win this championship, which would be Boston's first since 2008, is immense.\n\nThis coaching matchup reminds me a lot of the 2011 Finals, when veteran Carlisle and his staff clearly made better chess moves than 40-year-old Spoelstra and his staff. That was Spoelstra's third season as head coach and first Finals.\n\nCertainly Spoelstra, with titles the next two seasons, has proved he's one of the best coaches of this generation, but back in '11? Carlisle was the better Finals coach.\n\nFinn: Kidd has never been considered a great tactician, with the Mavs or in previous stops, but he has gotten the most out of this team. Mazzulla made huge progress in his second season -- thank goodness he finally uses his timeouts -- and strategically, he might actually be a little better than Kidd, especially with Sam Cassell and Charles Lee at his side.\n\nHimmelsbach: Jason Kidd has played in the NBA Finals, and Mazzulla never even played in the NBA. But that doesn't really matter now. I'm not sure that either has an edge, really. Both have pushed all the right buttons during these playoffs. Over the course of the season, the Celtics became increasingly comfortable with Mazzulla's philosophy and general approach, and it showed.\n\nWashburn: This is dead even. While Kidd has the experience, the Mavericks struggled at times this season and he has been heavily criticized. Mazzulla won the coaching matchup in the Indiana series against Rick Carlisle and the Celtics were able to win close games.\n\nMazzulla has to devise a way to limit Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving. Kidd has galvanized what was a flawed roster after trades to get Daniel Gafford and P.J. Washington to turn the Mavericks into a better defensive club, but Mazzulla outcoached Kidd in both matchups during the regular season. He has a chance to win the rematch.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Can Boston, who had the No. 1 net rating in the regular season - and so far in the playoffs - show why it's the favorite on Thursday?\n\nHere's our full betting preview with the latest odds, key players to watch and a best bet for Game 1:\n\nLuka Doncic: The 2023-24 regular season MVP finalist leads the playoffs in total points, rebounds, assists, steals and 3-pointers made, recording six triple-doubles in 17 games. Luka really came on in the Western Conference Finals, scoring 32 or more points in all four of Dallas' wins, and he is going to be the main focus for Boston's defense in Game 1.\n\nJayson Tatum: Jayson Tatum has not shot the ball well in the postseason - 44.2 percent from the field, 29.0 percent from 3 - but he's made an impact elsewhere averaging over 10 rebounds and five assists per game. Tatum didn't play his best in his first NBA Finals appearance in 2022, but the Celtics star has a better team around him - and that experience to lean on - in this series.\n\nBoston deserves a little more respect for its run to the Finals, even if it faced a few banged-up teams along the way.\n\nThe C's needed just 14 games to get through the East, winning in blowouts against Miami and Cleveland as well as taking three games against the Indiana Pacers where the Pacers had a 90 percent win probability or higher in the fourth quarter of three of the four games.\n\nAn interesting trend for Game 1 of the NBA Finals surfaced this week, showing that since 2005, the favorite is 16-3 ATS in Game 1.\n\nI think that bodes well for a Boston team that covered in two of its three Game 1s so far this postseason and was 37-4 straight up at home in the regular season. The C's also posted a 26-21-2 against the spread record as home favorites this season, winning those games by an average margin of victory of 14.4 points.\n\nI have a lot of respect for the run Dallas made, but Jason Kidd's team has struggled in Game 1s since he took over, going 1-5 straight up and losing four of those five games by seven or more points.\n\nI'm worried about Dallas' role players and whether or not they'll make enough shots for key defenders like Derrick Jones Jr. and PJ Washington to stay on the floor for the majority of the game. Boston's most recent title came in 2008.\n\nThe Mavericks won their only NBA title in 2011 after reaching the 2006 final, losing to Miami.\n\nIrving will be the emotional heart of the series after his Boston stay and a playoff return with Brooklyn that went poorly.\n\n\"I'm better at consolidating the emotions now,\" Irving said. \"You call it animosity. We call it hate. We call it, 'It's going to be hell in Boston.'\"\n\n\"The last time in Boston (in the playoffs with Brooklyn), I don't think that was the best... everyone saw me flip off the birds and kind of lose my (cool) a little bit.\n\n\"I wasn't my best self at that time. I've been able to grow since then... I'm looking forward to it. I'll take the brunt of it, all the yells and all the remarks.\n\n- 'No stopping them' - More from this section Microsoft to invest $3.2 bn in AI in Sweden Cucumbers Are Recalled in 14 States Middle Class Americans Struggle Financially Amid High Costs\n\n\"That wasn't a great reflection of who I am and how I like to compete on a high level.\"\n\nHe's on a high now, averaging 22.8 points in the playoffs as Slovenian guard Doncic, who averaged 33 points in the regular season, averages 28.8 points, 9.6 rebounds and 8.8 assists in the playoffs.\n\nBoston counters with two of the NBA's top defensive guards in Jrue Holiday and Derrick White.\n\n\"There's really no stopping them. You just try to make it difficult for them,\" White said. \"They're going to take tough shots and they're going to make tough shots. Just trust that over 48 minutes what we're doing is going to work.\"\n\nTatum averages 26.0 points and 10.4 rebounds in the playoffs with Brown averages 25.0 points with White and Holiday providing strong support and the team leading the NBA in 3-point shots and baskets. The Celtics are 9-0 when hitting 14 or more three-pointers.\n\n\"Boston shoots the three at a high rate,\" Mavs coach Jason Kidd said. \"They have a lot of talented players. They've been here before, they have the experience. They're well-coached. This is another great test.\"\n\nDallas center Dereck Lively isn't sweating the experience factor.\n\n\"They have a lot of tradition, but that doesn't matter. What matters is who's going to go harder on the court,\" Lively said. \"It's going to be a dogfight out there, but we're going to keep swinging and see what happens.\"\n\nBoston, which defeated the Mavericks in both meetings this season, expects to have Latvian center Kristaps Porzingis back from a right calf strain suffered on April 29 in the first round against Miami that benched him for 10 games.\n\n\"He has been working extremely hard just to get back and to help us in any way he can,\" White said.\n\n\"When KP is at his best, he has been tremendous for us,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-29", "textStart": 3654, "textEnd": {"uri": "8163773113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:57:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:57:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:56:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.boston.com/sports/boston-celtics/2024/06/05/kristaps-porzingis-return-and-7-other-takeaways-from-nba-finals-media-day/", "title": "Kristaps Porzingis' return and 7 other takeaways from NBA Finals Media Day", "body": "\"Unless they change the light bulbs in the arenas, they won't be any brighter than they were the last series.\"\n\nWith the tip-off to the 2024 NBA Finals just a little over 24 hours away, the Celtics and Mavericks took part in the league's annual Media Day on Wednesday afternoon at TD Garden.\n\nNBA Finals Media Day is often mayhem -- with hundreds of reporters, TV cameras, and other personalities swarming both rosters over two-plus hours.\n\nWednesday's session was an eventful one, with both the Celtics and Mavericks diving into what should be a fascinating matchup with a title on the line.\n\nHere are eight takeaways from the 2024 NBA Finals Media Day:\n\nAt long last, the Boston Celtics are fully healthy with the NBA Finals right around the corner.\n\nBoston had no players listed on their injury report Wednesday evening, signaling that Kristaps Porzingis is slated to make his return to the court after missing the last 10 games with a calf strain.\n\n\"I will play tomorrow,\" Porzingis declared ahead of Boston's practice on the parquet floor.\n\nThe Celtics' big man has not played since April 29, with his return against the Mavericks giving Boston an elite rim protector who also elevates his team's offensive capabilities thanks to his ability to score in the post, hit midrange jumpers and make teams pay beyond the arc.\n\n\"He's obviously a very big part of what we do,\" Al Horford said. \"Just everything that he brings on the floor. He's a threat offensively. As we know, he shoots it, he can post, he protects the rim for us. It's just a really good thing for us to be able to have him back.\"\n\nEven though Porzingis seems to have the green light for Game 1, it remains to be seen just how healthy he is -- given the wide variance of recovery times with calf injuries.\n\n\"It's tough to say. I haven't played. I haven't played for a while,\" Porzingis said. \"Tomorrow will be my real, like, first real minutes in a while, you know? I did as much as I could to prepare for this moment, but there's nothing like game minutes and game experience that I'm going to get tomorrow.\n\n\"It will be tough to jump into the Finals like this. I did everything I could to prepare for it and we'll see tomorrow night.\"\n\nThis is not the first NBA Finals rodeo for several key cogs on the Celtics' roster. While Jrue Holiday won a ring with the Bucks in 2021, Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, Horford, Derrick White, and more Celtics players were on Boston's roster in 2022 when the team came up short against the Warriors in the NBA Finals.\n\nDespite the lessons learned from that 2022 run, Tatum still doesn't harp on the experience.\n\n\"I hate that I had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" Tatum said. \"But I'm a firm believer that everything happens for a reason. There's a lesson to be learned in every situation. I do feel a lot different this time, this go-around, two years later. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done.\"\n\nIt's only been two years since the Celtics came up just short of a championship, but Brown stressed that plenty has happened since then.\n\n\"We got a different team. We got a different coach, too, as well. We had Ime Udoka; now we have Joe Mazzulla,\" Brown said. \"We had Marcus Smart, Rob Williams; we have Jrue Holiday, Kristaps Porzingis. Different team, different coach two years later makes a pretty big difference.\"\n\nWhile some players might want to burn the tape after falling in the NBA Finals, Brown stressed that he has rewatched film from that six-game series several times -- as well as other shortcomings for Boston in recent memory.\n\n\"I've watched it a few times now, maybe four or five times. As well as last year's conference finals (against the Heat),\" Brown said. \"I think you can always learn from anything really. But just being able to watch those moments and learn from them, how to manage your emotions, like, what you would have did differently potentially.\n\n\"I don't think that's bad to look at and acknowledge and be aware of. So I would say a few times at least I've watched the Finals, the whole thing, all the way through.\"\n\nJoe Mazzulla's blunt and candid comments during press conferences have often drawn attention, with the second-year head coach's emphasis on staying in the moment often leading to him not taking the bait on questions from the media.\n\nThat trend continued on Wednesday, especially when asked about the \"bright lights\" that come with playing in the NBA Finals.\n\n\"Yeah, I mean, unless they change the light bulbs in the arenas, they won't be any brighter than they were the last series,\" Mazzulla said. \"It's just sticking to the details, the things that matter, the truth.\n\n\"The truth of the matter is if you don't box out, if you don't sprint back in transition, if you don't pass the ball in a two-on-one, if you don't take away the other team's tendencies, if you don't know who you're guarding, don't recognize the spacing, if you don't talk, if you don't play hard, you're not going to win.\"\n\nAs for any talk of this Finals showdown with the Mavericks being the end to this \"journey\" that has been the 2023-24 season?\n\n\"I would say this is not the end of the journey,\" Mazzulla said. \"The journey is for however long you're alive. This is just one piece to that. Regardless of what happens you got to wake up the next day and do your job. The journey will forever be there.\n\n\"You're just ready for it. You do everything within your control to prepare for it, mentally, physically, emotionally, spiritually. Tomorrow you just get after it. The game, the environment will tell us what we need to focus on, what we need to get better on and what we need to do. The most important thing is staying even keel and staying with poise. I think that's something our team has done a good job of doing all year.\"\n\nKyrie Irving is far from the only Mavericks player expecting boos and jeers on Thursday night at TD Garden.\n\n\"It's hard to play in this place,\" Luka Doncic said Wednesday. \"The crowd is amazing for their team. All I got to say is we got to stay together. It's us against them. We got to stay together. But it's going to be really hard to play in this crowd.\"\n\nGranted, Doncic is no stranger to hostile crowds -- and dishing it back with his play on the court.\n\nThe 25-year-old guard led the league in scoring this season with 33.9 points per game, while also averaging 9.2 rebounds and 9.8 assists. He has thrived at TD Garden in his career, averaging 32.2 points in his six games on the parquet floor.\n\nBut the most hostile crowd he's ever faced was not in an NBA setting.\n\n\"It was (the) quarterfinals of EuroLeague against Panathinaikos in Panathinaikos,\" Doncic said. \"The crowd went crazy. They started winning 20-0. Imagine that.\"\n\nEven though Irving still holds court as one of the most hated figures in Boston sports history, the sentiment hasn't been shared by some of his former Celtics teammates.\n\nDespite Irving making several critical comments about Boston's young core during his final season with the team, Brown noted on Wednesday that he's happy to see Irving thriving with a new team in Dallas.\n\n\"I think it was great,\" Brown said. \"Definitely learned a lot from Kyrie while he was here. It's been great to see his journey, see where he's at, all the stuff he's going through, stuff like that, to be where he's at it's amazing, it's dope to see.\"\n\nOf course, those positive words will ring hollow once Game 1 actually begins.\n\n\"How to stop him? That's a great player over there, so it's going to be a full-team effort,\" Brown said. \"Him and Luka. Making sure we're alert, making sure we're back in transition, and do the best we can.\"\n\nIrving's history with the Celtics is a popular storyline leading into the NBA Finals. But Porzingis is also set to face off against his former team in the Mavericks.\n\nPorzingis was one of the featured players on the Mavericks from 2019-22, with his size and scoring ability making him an intriguing option to pair alongside Doncic. But their time together did not work out, with former NBA player Chandler Parsons declaring earlier this week that Doncic \"did not like playing with\" Porzingis.\n\nBoth Porzingis and Doncic didn't feed into the narrative when asked about it on Wednesday.\n\n\"It's always been good,\" Porzingis said of his relationship with Doncic. \"He's one of the best players in the league, in the world. It'll be a tough challenge for us to try to stop him. But just following his career. When he came in the league, he already made a huge impact.\n\n\"I had the opportunity to play with him for a couple years and get to know him. Just knowing what type of person he is, the type of player he is, just his mindset. He's a special, special player. We have a big challenge ahead of us competing against somebody like that.\"\n\n\"I don't know why it didn't work out,\" Doncic added. \"We were still both young. We tried to make it work, but it just didn't work. So, moved on.\"\n\nBoth Mazzulla and Brown had plenty of good things to say about Brad Stevens, who has made the successful transition from Boston's head coach to the team's president of basketball operations.\n\n\"Everybody in the organization is a leader in their own way,\" Mazzulla acknowledged. \"Everybody sets the temperature when they come in. Brad giving me my start, hiring me, empowering me from day one as an assistant, giving me some of the opportunities that he has. But also the way he carries himself.\n\n\"I've always had a lot of respect for how he went about coaching, how he kept family balance number one. How he treated people, number one. That was always more important than whether there was a success or a failure. I think he spearheads the leadership, the temperature of the building, just as everybody else does.\"\n\nAfter making the switch to the front office, Stevens has orchestrated several key trades and roster moves that have put Boston just four wins away from a title -- including three deals that brought back White, Holiday, and Porzingis.\n\n\"I think Brad has been great in his role as GM. He was a great coach,' Brown said. \"I think he just continued that by just being a great GM, being able to put the right pieces together and things like that.\n\n\"Just happy for him. His schedule has been able to settle down, probably putting a little bit less stress on him than we did when he was coaching us. But, no, Brad has been great since he's been a part of the Boston organization. He's helped bring this organization back in terms of winning. He's now been able to move into that GM position and put the right pieces together to get us back to the Finals.\"\n\nTatum was candid when asked about whether or not the 17 championship banners hanging above TD Garden present any added pressure to this current Celtics squad.\n\n\"I mean, you know the answer to that. Of course, right? We only hang NBA championship banners, right? 17 of them,\" Tatum said. \"Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. All of us are honored to follow in their footsteps, the way they paved for us to live out our dream.\n\n\"Essentially, yeah, if you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. That's what we try to play for every single season. The expectations are obviously different here. It takes special players to be here and to be a part of an environment like that.\"\n\nThe Celtics will get their chance to earn an 18th banner starting on Thursday night.\n\n\"I would just like to add to it,\" Holiday said. \"I think to be a part of history would be cool, especially a history that the Celtics have and everything that comes with it. Again, I would say that I probably don't take a bulk of the pressure because we have Jayson and Jaylen on our team.\n\n\"But to add to that is I feel like a part of the reason why I was brought here, the part of reason why I wanted to come.\"", "source": {"uri": "boston.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Boston"}, "authors": [{"uri": "conor_ryan@boston.com", "name": "Conor Ryan", "type": {"uri": "8162361763", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "07:10:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T07:10:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T07:09:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/jun/05/celtics-star-forward-tandem-feels-better-tooled/", "title": "Celtics' star forward tandem feels better tooled for Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- For almost the entirety of their time together in Boston, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been linked.\n\nThey were drafted by the Celtics third overall in consecutive years.\n\nThey possess similar skillsets -- two explosive and skilled wing players with an ability to score from nearly every spot on the court.\n\nAnd they both have been central to the success of a Celtics team that has reached the NBA Finals for the second time in three seasons. It helped Brown earn the NBA's first $300 million contract last summer. Tatum is expected to get one this offseason.\n\nThe team has branded the All-Stars as \"The Jays\" in a marketing campaign shown during games that pitted them against one another in mini competitions.\n\nIt has created natural comparisons between them along the way, fostering an atmosphere in which fans and sports pundits alike have tried to parse out which one of them is better, whose spot is most untouchable on the roster and which of them is more pivotal to the Celtics' success as they prepare to lead the team's attempt at an 18th NBA title.\n\nIt reached a new level last week during a segment on ESPN's \"Get Up\" in which panelists debated whether the 26-year-old Tatum expressed excitement or disappointment while watching the 27-year-old Brown garner Eastern Conference finals MVP honors.\n\n\"I think it's unfair to both of them,\" Celtics Coach Joe Mazzulla said of what he viewed as an attempt to manufacture friction between the two stars.\n\nBut even as Tatum and Brown have distinguished themselves as the most important players on Boston's roster and the keys to the Celtics' fate in their NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, Mazzulla has hope that people will start viewing them differently.\n\nTatum and Brown, along with Al Horford, are the only returning starters from the 2021-22 team that lost to the Golden State Warriors in six games in the Finals after holding a 2-1 series lead.\n\nWhile Horford has taken on mostly a reserve role this season, backing up Kristaps Porzingis, Tatum and Brown have taken their play up a notch.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n\"Obviously, we've been there before, we came up short,\" Tatum said. \"You don't always get a second chance, so really just looking at it as a second chance and trying to simplify things as much as we can.\"\n\nMazzulla believes the reason the relationship between Brown and Tatum is so often talked about is rooted in outside disbelief that their dynamic doesn't breed any rivalry between them.\n\n\"At the end of the day, like, those two guys, their relationship is their relationship,\" Mazzulla said. \"They love each other. They push each other every single day in practice. They communicate with each other, but they go about it differently.\"\n\nBoston Celtics guard Jaylen Brown (7) is congratulated by forward Jayson Tatum (0) after a after a 3-point basket during the second half of Game 4 of an NBA basketball second-round playoff series against the Cleveland Cavaliers, Monday, May 13, 2024, in Cleveland. (AP Photo/David Dermer)\n\nIndiana Pacers forward Pascal Siakam (43) goes up for a shot against Boston Celtics guard Jaylen Brown (7), forward Jayson Tatum (0) and center Al Horford (42) during the first quarter of Game 1 of the NBA Eastern Conference basketball finals, Tuesday, May 21, 2024, in Boston. (AP Photo/Michael Dwyer)", "source": {"uri": "nwaonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Northwest Arkansas Democrat Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_draft", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NBA draft"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jayson_Tatum", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jayson Tatum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_playoffs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NBA playoffs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaylen_Brown", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jaylen Brown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Conference_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, {"uri": "8164977094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:43:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:43:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:42:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/06/sports/garden-party-game-1-is-finally-here/", "title": "Garden Party: Game 1 is finally here - The Boston Globe", "body": "After a long, long wait, Game 1 of the NBA Finals tips off tonight at TD Garden.\n\nWe'll finally get some answers to the questions we've been asking since this series was set: Can the Celtics stop Luka Doncic? Will Kristaps Porzingis's calf hold up? Is the city of Boston still that mad at Kyrie Irving? Will Al Horford spontaneously crumble in a cloud of dust now that he's 38 years old like he's been snapped away by Thanos?\n\nIt's an absolutely fascinating championship series, and it all gets rolling tonight.\n\nChad Finn: Celtics in 6. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving will not steal the series, because the Celtics are the better team.\n\nAdam Himmelsbach: Celtics in 5. I think this is the first time I've ever picked the Celtics to win a title.\n\nChristopher L. Gasper: Celtics in 6. The Celtics' margin for error and victory is simply greater than that of the peaking Mavericks.\n\nDan Shaughnessy: Mavericks in 7. Please don't be offended. It's Jayson Tatum's time. It's Jaylen Brown's time. The Celtics have the best roster, won the most games, and are 12-2 in the playoffs. But I still don't trust them and have nightmares about Kyrie Irving winning it here.\n\nKhari Thompson: Celtics in 6. The Celtics have too much depth on both ends of the floor for Dallas to match.\n\nGary Washburn: Celtics in 6. The Celtics have a deeper team, have had more than a week to prepare, and appear ready for this moment. There are no excuses.\n\nMike Curtis: Mavericks in 6. I don't foresee many blowouts, and I think almost every game will go the distance.\n\nTim Cowlishaw: Mavericks in 5. Boston has been just as good as Dallas (maybe better) at closing out games, but I'll still take Doncic with the ball in his hands for the final shot over Tatum, Brown, and the rest. Sometimes teams just get on a roll, and Dallas is on one.\n\nShawn McFarland: Celtics in 7. Don't be surprised if Dallas takes one of the first two road games, though, to create a pivotal stretch at American Airlines Center.\n\nKevin Sherrington: Mavericks in 7. I don't think the Mavericks will beat the Celtics, but I'm tired of being wrong.\n\nBrad Townsend: Mavericks in 6. Boston was the best team over the course of the season, but Dallas has been the best team of the past 2\u00bd months.\n\nYou want Boston? You got Boston.That's the message the Celtics are sending tonight with their in-arena giveaway shirts. And better yet: The order of the shirts will spell out some cool messages in the stands \ud83d\udc40\n\nOther highlights from tonight's festivities at the Garden:\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 Canal Street will be open to pedestrians starting around noonish. The Celtics will have their entertainment teams and a DJ spinning outside the Garden before the game.\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 The Celtics are wearing their white association jerseys. They're 3-1 in those duds.\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 For halftime ... folks, we're in for a treat. Red Panda is in the house. A living legend.\n\n\ud83c\udfc0 Don't have tickets? No worries: Matt Juul and Kara Baskin rounded up the best watch parties and sports bars to watch the game with other Cs fans.\n\nDoes your business have something exciting happening for the playoffs? Email us at gardenparty@globe.com \ud83c\udf89\n\nOne reason I hope the Lakers don't hire JJ Redick -- we'd probably lose his \"Mind the Game\" podcast with LeBron James, which has been full of fascinating conversations on the inner workings of basketball.\n\nIn this week's episode, James and Redick discussed how to defend Luka Doncic in the pick-and-roll, the biggest challenge the Celtics face in the NBA Finals -- few teams use the action more than Dallas, and even fewer players are more deadly in the pick-and-roll than Doncic.\n\nRedick asked James which of the main defensive options against the pick-and-roll -- blitzing, switching, and playing drop coverage -- was most effective. James correctly identified blitzing as the best option, and switching as the worst (as the Timberwolves found out the hard way in the Western Conference finals).\n\nWhen opponents blitz Doncic on the pick-and-roll, sending a hard double-team at him, the Mavericks posted 0.97 points per possession this season (as a frame of reference, the most effective Celtic as a pick-and-roll ballhandler this season was Jayson Tatum, at 0.95 points per possession). That number has dipped to 0.67 when teams blitz Doncic in the playoffs.\n\nWhen opponents play drop coverage, having whoever isn't guarding the ballhander (often a big man) drop into the paint to stop the roll, that number is around 1.10. And when teams switch the pick-and-roll, Doncic and the Mavericks put up 1.15 points per possession.\n\nThis leads to quite the conundrum for Joe Mazzulla. The most effective defense against a Doncic pick-and-roll is a blitz, which the Celtics rarely do. The least effective is a switch, which is Boston's preferred defense, as we saw with Al Horford having to defend Darius Garland and Andrew Nembhard out on the perimeter early in the playoffs.\n\nWill the Celtics stray away from their identity? That can be a dangerous thing to do; but leaving Horford or Kristaps Porzingis on an island with Doncic in this series could be lethal.\n\nGasper: Brad Stevens doesn't seek credit, but he's a big reason the Celtics are here\n\nLast offseason, there were no promises or proclamations of improvement from the Celtics, no mantras like \"full throttle,\" \"ready to burn some cash,\" or the latest Boston sports Pledge of Improvement via Bruins general manager Don Sweeney: \"We're going to be aggressive to be able to complement what we currently have.\" No, the Celtics are in the NBA Finals, four wins away from Banner No. 18, largely because last offseason Brad Stevens and his front office acted with a boldness our other local teams only offer as PR palaver.\n\n'Bro, where does that accent come from?': Talking all things Boston in Dallas ahead of the NBA Finals.\n\nAsking Texans what they think of Boston can be a humbling experience for native New Englander Danny McDonald.\n\nThe self-proclaimed hub of the universe, the Athens of America, is reduced to a ubiquitous coffee chain, cans of baked beans, an FBI snitch, assorted Afflecks, and a retired quarterback who grew up in Northern California. Worse yet are the shrugs, the blank space that Boston evokes for some.\n\n\"Bro, where does that accent come from?\" asked Will Cody, a 38-year-old bartender at the Press Box Grill in downtown Dallas. \"I've never been there, I really don't know anything about Boston.\"\n\nOn the cusp of the NBA Finals, which will pit the Dallas Mavericks against the Boston Celtics starting Thursday, the indignities don't end there.\n\nDoris Burke has come a long way from her days at Providence. Now, she's on the cusp of history.\n\nA standout basketball player at Providence College who still calls Rhode Island home, the Hall-of-Fame broadcaster never lost her point guard's eye for details, writes Aidan Ryan. People close to Burke say that shows up in the trust she builds with coaches and players, and her ability to communicate even the smallest details to millions of viewers.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8165121012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:27:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:27:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:26:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/things-boston-celtics-must-do-to-win-2024-nba-finals/", "title": "5 Things the Boston Celtics Must Do to Win the 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "A lot is at stake for the Celtics to win the 2024 NBA Finals, having a lot to prove with Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown as their star duo.\n\nHighlights Jayson Tatum must excel in his second Finals with increased scoring to combat Dallas' threats. Porzingis' return to form is crucial for Boston; adds value with defense and spacing. Bench production is key for the Celtics, esp. Hauser, Kornet, Brissett, and Tillman. GIVEMESPORT VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nThe 2024 NBA Finals is about to get underway when the Boston Celtics host the Dallas Mavericks to begin Game 1 of the highly anticipated matchup.\n\nThis is especially a big challenge for the Celtics, seeking their 18th championship in franchise history and their first since 2008.\n\nBoston went 64-18 in the regular season, showcasing themselves as one of the best offensive and defensive teams in the league. They kept that up in the playoffs, going 12-2 against Miami, Cleveland, and Indiana en route to their second NBA Finals appearance in the last three seasons.\n\nWith Dallas posing a huge threat, particularly with the dynamic scoring duo of Luka Don\u010di\u0107 and Kyrie Irving, the Celtics must do everything they can to achieve their goal of bringing the Larry O'Brien trophy back to Beantown.\n\nHere are five things they must do to take down the Mavericks in this series:\n\n1 Tatum Must Perform Big In His Second NBA Finals Tatum struggled in his Finals debut in 2022\n\nWhen the Celtics lost the 2022 Finals against Golden State, a lot of criticism went Jayson Tatum's way due to his shooting and scoring struggles inside the arc.\n\nIn that series, he averaged 21.5 points, seven assists, and 6.8 rebounds. He was all-around with his impact as he shot an amazing 45.5 percent from beyond the arc, but he was 36.7 percent from the field overall. When three-pointers are removed, he was 31.6 percent.\n\nIt was concerning because his scoring went down after each series that year. He went from averaging 29.5 points against Brooklyn to 21.5 against the Warriors, an eight-point decrease for a player known for being able to score the ball at will.\n\nThis postseason has seen a different version of Tatum. While maintaining his willingness to keep his teammates involved, his production has gone up following each series. He went from putting up 21.8 points against Miami in the first round to a whopping 30.3 points against Indiana in the Eastern Conference Finals, a big increase of 8.5 points.\n\nBoston will need all the scoring they can get from their franchise star to win this series, and with the way he has been playing as the playoffs go on, they might do just that.\n\n2 Have Porzingis Return To Form KP missed much of the postseason with injury\n\nBoston breezed through the East despite being without one of their key players in Kristaps Porzingis, who left during Game 4 of the first round against Miami due to a calf injury.\n\nThe good news for the Celtics is that Porzingis will be back on the court to begin the NBA Finals against Dallas.\n\nHaving him return provides Boston with a lot of advantages. He allows them to space out the floor with his efficient ability to make three-pointers, not to mention that he can be a lob threat when needed.\n\nHis defense is also valuable, with his shot-blocking and rim protection being a potential factor in preventing Dallas' offense from flourishing. It will also help keep his teammate Al Horford fresh, who had to play more minutes due to his absence.\n\nBefore he went to the sidelines, Porzingis was averaging 12.3 points, five rebounds, 1.8 assists, 1.5 blocks, and 1.3 steals on 38.9 percent shooting from the field and 40 percent from downtown.\n\nA small sample size to take into account since it only involves the first round, but Boston will need Porzingis to come through with big plays when they are in need of a mismatch to keep Dallas' defense on their heels.\n\n3 Bench Must Produce Assistance from Horford, Pritchard, and Hauser will be needed\n\nThe starting rotation of Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, Jaylen Brown, Tatum, and Porzingis will certainly have a heavy workload of minutes to start out the series against Dallas. Once it progresses, however, the Celtics will look to their bench for potential sparks.\n\nThe significant performers have been mainly Horford and Payton Pritchard, the former who stepped up in Porzingis' absence and the latter for being active with his production via three-point shooting and aggressiveness in getting to the basket.\n\nBoston needs Sam Hauser to bounce back from his shooting woes. Making 38.6 percent of his shots from the field and 33.3 percent of his attempts from three this postseason, he is coming off a brutal offensive showing in the East Finals, where he went 2-of-16 overall and 1-of-14 from downtown. Having him return to sharpshooting form will do wonders for the team's bench.\n\nIt would also be beneficial to keep an eye on Luke Kornet, Oshae Brissett, and Xavier Tillman throughout the series. They have shown, at the very least, that they can provide energy on both sides of the court, resulting in huge runs that prove difficult for opponents to come back from. Production from them would be the cherry on top of what is already a potent offense from the Celtics.\n\n4 Knock Down Three-Pointers Consistently The team averages 14.6 triples per game in the playoffs\n\nThree-point shooting has been the Celtics' signature for the past two seasons under head coach Joe Mazzulla. This playoff run has seen it be taken to a new level.\n\nBoston is making 14.6 of their 39.8 attempts from beyond the arc. While it may not be the 16.5 three-pointers they knocked down per game during the regular season, they still remain a deadly threat from deep as Dallas might have a hard time cooling them off.\n\nWhite and Tatum have the most attempts on the team, making their triples at a 35.3 percent clip. Brown, Holiday, Porzingis, Horford, and Pritchard follow suit as their ability to convert triples down the stretch will be crucial to them securing wins throughout the series.\n\n5 Slow Down Luka and Kyrie The duo scores 51.6 points per game this postseason\n\nThe biggest defensive challenge for Boston will be figuring out how to keep Luka Don\u010di\u0107 and Kyrie Irving in check.\n\nThe star duo has done a tremendous job in getting Dallas back to the NBA Finals for the first time since their title run in 2011.\n\nDon\u010di\u0107 has been on a scorching tear throughout this playoff run, averaging 28.8 points, 9.6 rebounds, 8.8 assists, and a 1.6 steals as a triple-double threat. Leading the team in shot attempts with 22.3 per game, getting the ball out of his hands should be one of Boston's top priorities on defense.\n\nAs for Irving, he is putting up 22.8 points, 5.2 assists, 3.9 rebounds, and 1.2 steals as an excellent second option behind Don\u010di\u0107. Facing his former team in the NBA Finals, it will be interesting to see how Boston limits his impact while making sure Don\u010di\u0107 is not getting to his spots with ease. Holiday, White, Brown, and Tatum will have their hands full whenever they switch onto these two stars.\n\nForcing PJ Washington, Derrick Jones Jr., Josh Green, Maxi Kleber, Daniel Gafford, and Dereck Lively to shoot the ball instead of Don\u010di\u0107 and Irving could be key to the Celtics' defensive game plan. How it will play out once the ball is tipped off to begin the series remains to be seen, but it will be interesting nonetheless.\n\nRelated Top 5 NBA Finals Debut Performances All-Time Many NBA Mandatory Credit: David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAfter an improbable run to the Western Conference title as the #5 seed, the Dallas Mavericks (62-37, 32-18 away, 58-41 ATS) face the Eastern Conference #1 seed Boston Celtics (76-20, 43-6 home, 49-43- 4 ATS) in the 2024 NBA Finals starting with Game 1 on Thursday, June 6, at 8:40 pm ET.\n\nThe Mavericks vs Celtics odds heavily favor Boston holding serve at home in Game 1.\n\nDallas Mavericks vs Boston Celtics Odds\n\nThe Celtics are currently 6.5-point favorites for Game 1 and -230 on the moneyline. The Mavs come back at +190 to win while the game total is sitting at 214.5.\n\nDallas is 9-8 over/under in the postseason and has hit the over in five of its past six games. Boston is 8-6 O/U in the postseason and has also gone over in five of its last six.\n\nOdds as of June 5 at DraftKings. Claim a bonus through the best NBA betting apps for the 2024 finals.\n\nThe Mavericks won three straight series without home-court advantage en route to the Western Conference championship, downing the #4 LA Clippers in six games, the #1 OKC Thunder in six as well, and the #3 Minnesota Timberwolves in five. Dallas is 11-6 against the spread in the playoffs to date.\n\nBoston hardly broke a sweat on its path to the NBA finals. After dusting aside the #8 Miami Heat and #4 Cleveland Cavaliers in five games each, the Celtics swept the #6 Indiana Pacers in the East finals, benefitting from an injury to Indiana's All-Star point guard Tyrese Haliburton.\n\nDallas vs Boston Game 1 Injury Reports\n\nAfter a ten-day hiatus, the Boston Celtics enter the 2024 NBA Finals fully healthy. Center Kristaps Porzingis missed the last ten games with a calf injury but the 7'1 center is no longer on the injury report ahead of Game 1 against the Mavericks.\n\nOn the Dallas side, Luka Doncic (knee/ankle) remains on the injury report, listed as probable. But take that with a grain of salt. Doncic has been listed as\"probable\" for the majority of the Mavs playoff games. He hasn't missed any time and has averaged 28.8 PPG, 9.6 RPG, and 8.8 APG in 41.5 minutes per night (all team-highs).\n\nMaxi Kleber (4.4 PPG, 3.3 APG, 34.8 3P%) missed the entirety of Dallas' six-game victory over OKC in the second round and the first three games against Minnesota in the West finals, but he returned in Games 4 and 5, scoring five points in 21 minutes over the pair of games. He's no longer on the Dallas injury report heading into the Boston series.\n\nAfter averaging 32.4 PPG in the five-game series win over the T-wolves, Luka Doncic is listed with a game-high point total of 31.5 on Thursday. Tatum has the highest total for the Celtics, per usual, at 26.5.\n\nMavericks vs Celtics Predictions for Game 1\n\nBoston wasn't seriously pushed in any of its first three series but it's sweep of the Pacers was arguably the least convincing sweep in NBA history. Three of the four games were decided by five points or fewer, and the Pacers led in the fourth quarter in three of the four (including nine-point fourth-quarter leads in both Games 3 and 4). If Haliburton had been healthy, the Eastern Conference Finals might have played out very differently.\n\nThere's no denying that the analytics - regular season and postseason - say Boston is the better team. They had an NBA-best in Net Rating of +11.7 in the regular season and once again lead in that category in the playoffs at +10.8. But the Mavericks have made huge strides in the postseason and, with Doncic rested and ready, I expect Dallas to push the Celtics every bit as hard - make that harder - than the Pacers did. {"uri": "8164997555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:58:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:58:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:57:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/boston-celtics-dallas-mavericks-game-1-odds-predictions/", "title": "Boston Celtics vs. Dallas Mavericks Game 1 Odds and Predictions", "body": "The Celtics host the Mavericks in Game 1 of the 2024 NBA Finals. GMS breaks down which team has the edge going into the series opener.\n\nHighlights The Boston Celtics hold the edge in Game 1 as favorites over the Dallas Mavericks. The 'over' is the smart choice for the 214.5 points total. Luka Don\u010di\u0107 is predicted to score over 31.5 points.\n\nThe 2023-24 NBA playoff action continues as we move on to the NBA Finals, where the Boston Celtics will face the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nHere is a look at which squad has the edge in this matchup and why.\n\nCeltics vs. Mavericks Game 1 Info\n\nWhen\n\nThurs. June 6\n\nWhere\n\nTD Garden\n\nTime\n\n8:30 PM EST\n\nLocation\n\nBoston, MA\n\nTV\n\nABC\n\nCeltics vs. Mavericks - How We Got Here & Betting Trends Boston is the favorite heading into Game 1\n\nThe Boston Celtics are just two years removed from their last Finals appearance. In 2022, they fell to the Golden State Warriors in six games. Last season, they were just one win away from consecutive appearances despite falling behind 0-3 to the Miami Heat in the conference finals.\n\nThis season, Boston was one of the prohibitive favorites to come out of the Eastern Conference, and they certainly lived up to those lofty expectations. They finished the season with the league's best record at 64-18. Despite dropping a pair of Game 2s in the first two rounds of the postseason, the Celtics have produced 12 wins in their 14 postseason games, including a 4-0 sweep over the Indiana Pacers in the previous round.\n\nLooking back at the team's previous Finals appearance, Boston forward Jayson Tatum offered this perspective:\n\n\"It was a lesson to be learned. I told myself that if I ever got the opportunity again to make it to the Finals, that (I'd) never take it for granted. Obviously, we're here now and thankful to be here. I'm excited to get ready to play and have fun.\" - Jayson Tatum\n\nOn the other side of the equation, the Dallas Mavericks have also had an impressive postseason run. In the first round of the playoffs, they defeated the L.A. Clippers in six games -- the first time they had managed to get by the Clippers in three tries. Next, their opponent was the top-seeded Oklahoma City Thunder. The teams split the first four contests before Dallas closed out the series in six games.\n\nThe conference finals matchup would pit the Mavericks against the third-seeded Minnesota Timberwolves - a team that had not been this far in the playoffs since 2004, and their inexperience was evident. The Mavericks took the first three games of the series before Minnesota finally broke through with a win in Game 4. However, the Mavericks left little doubt that they were the better team, as they closed out the series with an emphatic 124-103 victory in Game 5.\n\nThe Mavericks' last trip to the Finals occurred in 2011. Ironically, head coach Jason Kidd was the starting point guard for that squad, which defeated the Miami Heat in six games to claim the franchise's only NBA championship.\n\nKidd helped guide the Mavericks to an upset as a player. Can he pull off the feat once again from the sidelines?\n\nNow that we have set the stage for this matchup, let's examine the betting trends for both sides.\n\nCeltics vs. Mavericks Picks GIVEMESPORT presents our picks with analysis Spread\n\nOn the heels of going 12-2 through their first 14 playoff games, the Celtics come into this matchup as a 6.5-point favorite (per Lineups.com). Here is a look at how both ball clubs have fared against the spread this season.\n\nThe Mavericks have covered the spread four times in their last five outings. Dallas is 1-5 ATS in its last six matchups against Boston. The Mavericks are 5-0 ATS in their last five road games. In their last seven matchups against Eastern Conference opponents, Dallas is 6-1 against the spread. The Celtics have failed to cover the spread five times in their last six games. Boston is 4-1 ATS in its last five games against teams in the Southwest Division. In their last six Thursday night games, the Celtics are 2-4 against the spread. Prediction: Boston Celtics (-6.5) Over/Under\n\nThe projected over/under total for this matchup opened at 214.5 points (per BleacherNation.com). Here is why going with the \"over\" is the smart choice.\n\nThe OVER total holds a 5-1 record in the Mavericks' last six contests. In Dallas's last five games as the underdog, the OVER total is 4-1. The OVER total has emerged victorious five times in the Celtics' last six games. In Boston's last seven home games, the OVER total cashed in six times. Boston and Dallas have averaged a combined 238.5 points per game, which is 24 points more than the 214.5 over/under. Prediction: OVER 214.5 points Player Prop Bets\n\nLuka Don\u010di\u0107 leads the team in multiple categories, including scoring, rebounding, assists, and steals. It is also worth noting that he is putting up solid numbers despite playing with an assortment of injuries. With that in mind, he is the key player to watch for the road team. Doncic currently has -110 odds of scoring more than 31.5 points and -110 odds of finishing with less than 31.5 points (via DraftKings).\n\nDo Doncic's numbers favorably compare to the estimated points total for this matchup? Let's look at the tale of the tape to find out.\n\nDoncic is averaging 32.9 points per contest across 87 regular season and playoff games. In two games against the Mavericks this season, he has averaged 35.0 points per contest. During the postseason, Doncic is averaging 28.8 points per outing. Doncic has suited up against Eastern Conference teams 28 times this season. In those contests, he is averaging 34.9 points per outing. In nine matchups against teams in the Atlantic Division, the Mavericks guard is averaging 34.6 points per game. Over his last 10 outings, Doncic has averaged 29.1 points, 10.5 rebounds, and 8.4 assists per contest, exceeding the points total for this matchup four times during that stretch.\n\nPrediction: Luka Don\u010di\u0107 OVER 31.5 points\n\nOn the other hand, Jayson Tatum is one of the key players to watch for the home team. He currently has -131 odds of scoring more than 26.5 points and -104 odds of finishing with less than 26.5 points (via Caesars Sportsbook).\n\nHere is a look at how his numbers stack up against the projected points total for this matchup.\n\nTatum is averaging 26.7 points per contest during the regular season and playoffs. In two matchups against Dallas this season, he has averaged 35.5 points per contest. During the postseason, Tatum is averaging 26.0 points per outing. Tatum has played against Western Conference opponents 28 times this season (including the playoffs). In those contests, he is averaging 26.6 points per outing. In 23 matchups against teams in the Southwest Division, the Celtics forward is averaging 27.0 points per game. Over his last 10 outings, Tatum has averaged 27.1 points, 10.5 rebounds, and 5.9 assists per contest, exceeding the points total for this matchup four times during that stretch.\n\nPrediction: Jayson {"uri": "8161953730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "00:18:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T00:18:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T00:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://nesn.com/2024/06/four-random-predictions-ahead-of-celtics-mavericks-nba-finals/", "title": "Four Random Predictions Ahead Of Celtics-Mavericks NBA Finals", "body": "The Boston Celtics are entering an unexpected, but no less intriguing, NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, sitting four wins shy of ending a 16-year-long championship drought and seizing Banner 18.\n\nIt's been two years since the last time the Celtics booked a trip to the Finals, and with the aching memories of watching the Golden State Warriors pop champagne and shower in confetti at TD Garden, Boston's got plenty of motivation. The roster is new and improved, has experience from top to bottom, and hasn't tripped amid a favorable postseason path no matter what's been thrown at the Celtics up to this point.\n\nHere are four predictions before the Celtics and Mavericks meet for Game 1:\n\n1. Jayson Tatum's breakout series arrives at perfect time for Boston\n\nThe naysayers have had a field day watching Tatum's postseason struggles, but under the brightest lights, more than due, the 26-year-old will deliver.\n\nEntering Tatum's second-career trip to the Finals, and after coming up short of an MVP honor in the conference finals, the five-time All-Star is averaging 26 points while shooting 29% from 3-point range. Taking advantage of the double-team coverages thrown his way, Tatum played facilitator, but it didn't help Boston when it encountered its few dicey moments this postseason.\n\nBy this point, Tatum understands the only way to silence the outside doubters will be to unleash a night similar to his Game 7 versus the 76ers in last season's semifinal round. He might not outperform everyone else throughout the series from start to finish, however, being the most effective player will push him toward a Finals MVP candidacy.\n\n2. Boston won't restrain Luke Donic and it won't matter\n\nOne of the (many) leading questions following the Celtics in the Finals is how they'll guard Doncic, who's averaged 28.8 points this postseason.\n\nDoncic's emergence has been a sight to behold. With limited athleticism, the prodigal son of Dallas has the IQ, skill, and shooting ability that's thrown Doncic into (very) premature Hall of Fame discussion without having won a title -- and it's completely warranted too.\n\nSo... where does that leave Boston?\n\nWell, the Celtics don't need to shut down Donic to win the Finals and outplay the Mavericks. It's already hard, and sometimes impossible enough, but the talent gap between Boston and Dallas -- especially if Kristaps Porzingis returns -- should put the Celtics well above Doncic. The danger zone comes in tight late-game situations where, as we know, Doncic relishes in taking the final shot -- likely a step-back three -- in the dire moments.\n\nGive the Mavericks an offensive output like the Celtics did on March 1 (138 points) and Boston should be just fine.\n\n3. Joe Mazzulla's learning lessons won't be preached, they'll be applied\n\nOne of the several constants of a Mazzulla-coached team is the bright side approach to the inexcusable.\n\nLearning lessons is what the second-year head coach routinely chalks up the team's uncharacteristic off-nights to, but with a need for four wins in at least seven games, there's no room for any of that. By this point, lessons should be learned, notes should be studied, and with the exam on Boston's desk, the Celtics need to Ace their final test.\n\nWith a proven winner in Jrue Holiday and a hungry star duo in Tatum and Brown, plus the versatility in Porzingis, Derrick White, and Al Horford, Boston has the mix to get the job done. Having not lost more than twice consecutively -- a trend that carried its way into the playoffs -- the Celtics have shown their urgency to respond to defeats so there's no reason to suggest they'll be incapable of continuing to do so if necessary.\n\n4. The Kyrie Irving hatred (while played out) will reach new heights\n\nIt's old, it's unnecessary, but it's an inevitable storyline, therefore, after booing Caleb Martin, Max Strus, and Aaron Nesmith, Irving is up next.\n\nThe final villain standing in Boston's way of Banner 18, the ex-Celtics guard of two seasons, Irving, shouldn't expect a welcome back from the TD Garden crowd come Thursday night. Instead, the 32-year-old veteran should prepare for an outpour of boos whenever the ball ends up in his hands, even though it's now been five years and the Celtics have proven to be better off following the Boston-Irving breakup.\n\nWhat's a Finals series without some sort of theatrics, right?", "source": {"uri": "nesn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NESN"}, "authors": [{"uri":
