{"uri": "8164350712", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:19:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:19:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:18:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.wbur.org/news/2024/06/06/boston-celtics-nba-championshups-garden-gary-washburn", "title": "'Their best chance to win': Celtics open NBA finals at home", "body": "The Boston Celtics host the Dallas Mavericks at the TD Garden Thursday night in the first game of the NBA Finals.\n\nBoston is favored to win, and start the finals with the home court advantage.\n\nFor a preview of the championship series, WBUR's Morning Edition host Rupa Shenoy spoke with Boston Globe basketball reporter Gary Washburn.\n\nHighlights from this interview have been lightly edited for clarity.\n\nOn key players to watch\"\n\n\"It's going to be a star-studded series. The Dallas Mavericks have two stars that are very well-known -- Luka Don\u010di\u0107, a 25-year-old standout from Slovenia, who is one of the best players in the league and also Kyrie Irving, the former Celtic who has resurrected his career in Dallas -- in addition to the [Celtics] superstars, Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum.\"\n\nOn whether Tatum and Brown will be able to deliver:\n\n\"I'm expecting for them to give their absolute best effort. This is their best chance to win a championship in the seven years they've been together. They're favored in this series and they'll have to play their best basketball, so they'll have to play better than they played throughout the playoffs. And they played well throughout the playoffs. So they're going to need everything that's in them to win this series. And I think they have enough talent to do it. It's going to be a very competitive series because Dallas is also a very good team.\"\n\nOn Joe Mazzulla's first finals as coach:\n\n\"He is going to implement whatever game plan he can to slow down Luka Don\u010di\u0107. He's the head of the snake. He's their best player. He is the reason that they're here. And so he has to implement defenses to slow him down. And he also has to make Luca play on both sides of the ball, which means play defense and exert effort and energy there too.\n\n\"So his plan should be to try to slow down the combination of Don\u010di\u0107 and Kyrie Irving. You're not going to stop them, they're too talented, but you want to slow them down and make them less efficient.\"\n\nOn what makes this series different than the Celtics' 2022 finals loss against Golden State:\n\n\"They have the additions of Jrue Holiday, who was an NBA champion three years ago, then with the Milwaukee Bucks. And Kristaps Porzi\u0146\u0123is is a center who kind of unlocks their offense because he's so versatile. And I just think experience also helps.\n\n\"This team had a chance to win that championship two years ago and kind of fell apart at a key stretch, and Golden State was much more experienced. They had won three previous championships and they did not panic when the Celtics seemingly panicked. So I think experience will make a difference here.\n\n\"The Celtics have been here before. They know the routine, so they should be more familiar with the process than the Mavericks, most of whom have not played NBA Finals.\"\n\nOn former Celtics player Kyrie Irving's tension with Boston fans:\n\n\"I don't think it'll be a factor in the game. I think the crowd will get into it. I think they'll try to get into his head, the Boston fans, in terms of the chanting and trying to distract him a little bit. He did not have a smooth tenure in Boston. He had a very tumultuous time here. He made some promises that he didn't live up to. So the Boston fans will remember that and it will remind them of that.\"\n\nOn whether the team has shown they can bring home a victory:\n\n\"Yeah, they've lived up to everything so far. They've checked all the boxes. They had the best record in the NBA, they are 12-2 in the playoffs so far, No. 1 seed. So they're here and now it's time to really, really step your game up and make sure that you take home the banner because they are their favorite and the pressure is on them.\"", "source": {"uri": It's clear that Brown has carried a chip on his shoulder for the entirety of the 2023-24 campaign, which he will be looking to cap off with an NBA Championship.\n\nDuring the ages-long break between Game 4 of the Eastern Conference Finals and Game 1 of the NBA Finals, the Celtics released episode 3 of their \"All In Celtics\" docuseries.\n\nBrown was interviewed as part of the episode and was talked about some of the lack of respect he's felt.\n\n\"For various reasons, I feel like I don't get the credit or respect that I've earned,\" Brown said. \"I'm at the point of my life where I just don't give a f---... So, the ones who with me, let's rock and roll, and the ones who aren't can kiss my a--.\"\n\nThe 27-year-old has put together several attention-grabbing performances throughout Boston's run to the NBA Finals. {"uri": "8163631650", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:02:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:02:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:01:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nba/news/celtics-mavs-prediction-odds-advice-player-prop-bets-game-1/e9b111319d9ef6a4826b5e80", "title": "Celtics vs. Mavs prediction: Odds, betting advice, player prop bets for Game 1 on Thursday, June 6", "body": "Hoops fans, it has finally arrived: the NBA Finals between the Celtics and Mavericks tip off Thursday night (8:30 p.m. ET, ABC, Sling). Boston opens the series as a -225 favorite to win it all and a 6.5-point favorite to win Game 1, but savvy bettors will be fading both those bets and opting instead for higher-value wagers and player props.\n\nWhile this may not be the Finals matchup NBA fans expected two months ago, it's impossible to argue against the Celts and Mavs being the best two teams of the postseason. The superstar duos of Jayson Tatum-Jaylen Brown and Luka Doncic-Kyrie Irving have been complemented perfectly by their supporting casts, and this should be the most entertaining series of the playoffs.\n\nMORE FINALS BETTING:\n\nSteph Noh's pick | Sloan Piva's pick | Finals MVP betting prediction\n\nThese are exciting times for fans and bettors alike -- especially after such a lengthy break between the conference championships and the NBA Finals -- but bettors must avoid firing off bets without researching stat and betting trends. It's the casuals who blindly bet the favorite on the spread and smash the OVER who get hurt early in the Finals, while the sharps (and the sportsbooks) laugh all the way to the bank.\n\nLet's get to the best bets and top props for Game 1 of the 2024 NBA Finals between the Celtics and Mavericks, including the best spread, over/under, and player prop wagers from BetMGM.\n\nDallas has arguably exerted much more energy than Boston so far this postseason, and the Celtics have enjoyed a decent rest advantage over their Finals foes. Boston will also have the energy boost that comes with a championship-round opener at TD Garden, one of the more raucous arenas in sports.\n\nOh, and starting center Kristaps Porzingis is back from his month-long absence due to a heel injury -- so the starting five and the Al Horford-led bench should both get a bump in offensive production. That's fantastic news for a Celtics team that has already sat atop the NBA in first-quarter scoring (31.4) since the start of the 2023-24 season.\n\nDallas smashed Minnesota in the mouth in the first quarter of the series-clinching Game 5 of the Western Conference Finals. But before that game, the Mavs had been outscored by the Wolves in the first frame by a collective score of 120-106. That's a +14 first-quarter scoring margin and an average plus-minus of +3.5.\n\nBoston turns up at this time of year. But the Green-teamers have been pretty solid all season, helping their squad go 37-4 in the regular season and 7-2 in the playoffs. With public enemy No. 1 Kyrie Irving coming back to face the fans he once pledged his allegiance to -- only to leave and return with sage and logo foot-stomps -- the tension will be palpable in this one and the passion should transmit to the players. Bet the Celtics to cover the 2.5-point first-quarter spread.\n\nFIRST QUARTER PREDICTION: Celtics 29, Mavs 25 -- Boston wins the first quarter (-185) and covers the -2.5 spread (-105), and the frame finishes UNDER the projected total of 55.5 (-110).\n\nPeople love betting the OVER, especially in the playoffs and Finals. It's more fun to root for points than it is to root for defensive stops, so sportsbooks tend to bump the projected totals up for Game 1 because they can always get away with it. As of Wednesday, a whopping 90 percent of BetMGM Game 1 over/under bettors had put their money on the OVER of 214.5.\n\nDon't follow the sheep, people. The Celtics have been one of the best defenses in the Association the entire season, and the Mavs turned into an elite defensive unit once they acquired Daniel Gafford and P.J. Washington at the deadline -- and Derrick Jones Jr. turned into Superman. Sure, these squads also have premier scorers -- but they also probably have some rust to kick off after many days of rest leading up to this game (never mind the nerves associated with the Finals).\n\nIf you're a little nervous about betting the UNDER, utilize the value opportunity and bet the UNDER on the alternate total of 216.5. That way, you buy an extra two points and still get in at just -130, which is very little juice considering the number you're getting.\n\nThe Celtics have held opponents to 102 points or fewer in nine of their 14 games this postseason. The Mavs held opponents to 103 or fewer in eight of their 17. Act on the UNDER now, because this might be the highest the over/under projection will be the entire championship series.\n\nFINAL SCORE PREDICTION: Celtics 108, Mavs 103 -- Boston wins (-250) but Dallas covers the +6.5 spread (-105), and the game finishes UNDER the alternate projected total of 216.5 points (-130).\n\nOne of the most underrated scorers and impact players on the Celtics, Derrick White has consistently come through in big moments for Boston. He hit what ultimately ended up being the game-winner of the fourth and final game of the Celtics-Pacers Eastern Conference Finals, and he should be a huge part of Game 1 if Dallas tries to blitz Tatum and Brown.\n\nJoe Mazzulla's squad also benefits from having Porzingis back, meaning the floor will be spaced that much better for Boston's perimeter shooters. White has already hit three-plus three-pointers in eight of the Celts' 14 postseason games so far, and he's averaging 3.4 per game in the 2024 NBA Playoffs. {"uri": "8163750498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:27:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:27:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:25:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://nesn.com/2024/06/luka-doncic-or-jayson-tatum-ranking-top-10-players-in-nba-finals/", "title": "Luka Doncic Or Jayson Tatum? Ranking Top 10 Players In NBA Finals", "body": "The Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks didn't get to the NBA Finals by accident.\n\nThe Celtics enter the series with a 76-20 combined record from the regular season and playoffs while the Mavericks toppled three higher seeds in the Los Angeles Clippers, Oklahoma City Thunder and Minnesota Timberwolves to get to this point.\n\nBoth teams are two of the more talented squads in the league with plenty of fire power and depth. But which team has more talent? It seems like it should be the Celtics, which doesn't guarantee them a title.\n\nThere will be plenty of highly skilled players on the floor when the Finals commence Thursday night at TD Garden, so we ranked the top 10 players who could play a big role in the series:\n\n10. Daniel Gafford\n\nDerrick Lively II could be in this spot, but Gafford took it due to his elite rim protection. He came over to the Mavericks in a midseason trade from the Washington Wizards and became Dallas' main shot-blocking presence. The 6-foot-10 center totaled 2.6 blocks per game in the Western Conference finals and in Game 2, he turned in a 16-point, five-block performance on the road.\n\n9. Al Horford\n\nHorford, 38, is the wily old veteran at this stage of his career as he looks for his first ring. Horford can still provide enough versatility on the defensive end and is a reliable enough 3-point shooter. He knocked down a career-high seven triples in a Game 3 win over the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference finals.\n\n8. P.J. Washington\n\nAnother trade deadline pick up by the Mavericks who has made his mark. Washington is Dallas' third-leading scorer in the playoffs at 13.6 points per game and can make an impact on both ends of the floor.\n\n7. Kristaps Porzingis\n\nPorzingis would be higher on this list if he hadn't sat out the last five weeks due to a calf injury. He's not even sure what he can provide in the Finals, but when he's at his best, he's a pick-and-pop assassin and top-tier rim protector.\n\n6. Derrick White\n\nWhite can do everything for the Celtics as he went from an undrafted guard to the precipice of stardom. He's scoring 17.8 points per game in the playoffs and hitting 3-pointers at a 40.7% clip. And don't forget he's one of the best defensive guards in the NBA and is a real threat to block anyone's shot.\n\n5. Jrue Holiday\n\nHoliday and White do very similar things on the court, but it just feels like Holiday has a couple of more intangibles than White to take this spot. Holiday took his game to another level in the postseason by making several clutch plays and could be the X-factor for the Celtics in this series.\n\n4. Kyrie Irving\n\nThere might not be another player in the NBA who has the array of offensive moves that Irving does. He's a deadly shooter, too, as he's sunk 42.1% of his 3-point attempts during the playoffs.\n\n3. Jaylen Brown\n\nBrown is a better all-around player than Irving, which is why the Celtics star gets this spot. Brown is averaging 25 points and is shooting an eye-popping 61.5% from inside the arc in the playoffs. Brown has also delivered in the biggest moments, too, which shouldn't go unrecognized.\n\n2. Jayson Tatum\n\nThere's a reason why Tatum has finished in the top six in MVP voting each of the last three seasons. The 6-foot-8 forward is a high-volume scorer, a strong rebounder and has developed into an adept playmaker. Tatum's long-range shooting has been off in the postseason, but if he finds it, he has the chance to take over the series and claim Finals MVP honors.\n\n1. Luka Doncic\n\nThis might be tough for Celtics fans to swallow, but Doncic is the best player in the series. He's averaging close to a triple-double in the postseason with 28.8 points, 9.6 rebounds and 8.8 assists. Doncic has an unorthodox style, but he gets the job done repeatedly and can make an impact on any play when he touches the ball.", "source": {"uri": "nesn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NESN"}, {"uri": "8163267455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:36:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:36:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:35:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/nba-finals-records-leading-scorers-top-performances-highest-single-game-scoring-triple-doubles", "title": "NBA Finals records: Leading scorers, top performances, highest single-game scoring, triple doubles", "body": "The 2024 NBA Finals feature plenty of star talent between the Dallas Mavericks' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving as well as the Boston Celtics' Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, among other big names. Given the stakes, the finals have always been a setting where elite performances become iconic, and this year's stars have their work cut out for them if they are to match the achievements of legends past.\n\nRead on to learn more about the players who have left the greatest mark on the NBA's biggest stage - the greatest winners, performers and record-holders in the league's history.\n\nBoston Celtics legend Bill Russell boasts the most NBA championships of any player in the league's history with a staggering 11 titles. He racked up so many rings that two had to go on the same finger.\n\nRussell was the leader of the Celtics' dynasty in the 1950s and 1960s, which saw Boston win 11 of 13 titles between 1957 and 1969. Naturally, his teammates make up much of the top of the list for most NBA titles; Sam Jones ranks second all-time with 10, and then four more Celtics - John Havlicek, Tom Heinsohn, K.C. Jones and Tom Sanders - are tied at eight.\n\nThe first non-Celtic on the list is Robert Horry, who won seven titles during his years with the Houston Rockets, Los Angeles Lakers and San Antonio Spurs in the 1990s and 2000s. Naturally, he is tied with another member of Boston's golden era in Frank Ramsey.\n\nThe story for NBA Finals appearances is similar, at least at the very top. Russell leads the way with 12, with Sam Jones right behind at 11.\n\nThis is where the influx of Los Angeles Lakers comes in. LeBron James and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar - not so coincidentally, the league's two all-time leading scorers - have both made 10 finals appearances. Magic Johnson and Jerry West, along with Heinsohn, are up next with nine.\n\nLakers great Elgin Baylor holds the record for highest-scoring finals game after he scored 61 in Game 5 of the 1962 NBA Finals against the Celtics. Los Angeles needed just about every point, too, as it defeated Boston 126-121 at the Boston Garden to take a 3-2 series lead. The Celtics would win the final two games of the series, though, to earn their fifth championship.\n\nMichael Jordan and Rick Barry each scored 55 to slot in for second. Jordan's came in the Chicago Bulls' 111-105 win over the Phoenix Suns in the 1993 NBA Finals, giving Chicago a 3-1 lead it would not relinquish. Barry hit his number in the San Francisco Warriors' 130-124 victory against the Philadelphia 76ers in Game 3 of the 1967 NBA Finals, but Wilt Chamberlain and the 76ers ultimately won that series.\n\nOnly four other players have reached 50 or more points in an NBA Finals game: West (53 in Game 1 of the 1969 NBA Finals); James (51 in Game 1 of the 2018 NBA Finals); Giannis Antetokounmpo (50 in Game 6 of the 2021 NBA Finals); and Bob Pettit (50 in Game 6 of the 1958 NBA Finals).\n\nThe aforementioned Barry holds the highest career NBA Finals scoring average; he put up 36.3 points per game over that 1967 loss to the 76ers and the Warriors' 1975 sweep of the Washington Bullets.\n\nAllen Iverson and Antetokounmpo are not far behind, with averages of 35.6 and 35.2, respectively, in their lone finals appearances. Antetokounmpo was the only one of the two to take a trophy from his finals run, though.\n\nOnly four other players average 30-plus points per game in their finals career. Jordan (33.6 points per game in 35 finals games) and West (30.5 points per game in 55 finals games) are the players with the longest sustained scoring success of the group. Kevin Durant and Nikola Jokic just top the 30-point mark at 30.3 and 30.2, respectively.\n\nIn a strange twist of fate, none of the top three player scoring performances in Game 7 of an NBA Finals have resulted in victory. It does make a bit more sense when you hear all three came against Russell's Celtics.\n\nWest holds the high-water mark with 42 in Game 7 of the 1969 NBA Finals, which Boston won 108-106 for Russell's 11 and final championship. Baylor put the finishing touches on a stunning 1962 finals performance with 41 in Game 7, but the Celtics escaped with a 110-107 victory. Pettit's 39 in the final matchup of the 1957 finals were not enough, as the Celtics escaped 125-123 for Russell's first ring.\n\nThat 1957 series conclusion also saw Heinsohn go for 37 in the win, tied with James' performance in 2013 for fourth-highest Game 7 scoring output by a player and the most in a victory.\n\nThe raw totals here are dominated by two legends who wore purple and gold. James has 11 triple-doubles in 55 finals games to top the list. Johnson is not too far behind at eight in 50 finals games.\n\nDraymond Green is up next with three in 33 finals games. Also of note: Jokic had two over the five games of the 2023 NBA Finals, giving him easily the best ratio of triple-doubles to finals games.", "source": {"uri": "nbcsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Russell", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Bill Russell"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NBA Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Lakers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sam_Jones_(basketball,_born_1933)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Sam Jones (basketball, born 1933)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jayson_Tatum", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jayson Tatum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaylen_Brown", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jaylen Brown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Horry", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Robert Horry"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giannis_Antetokounmpo", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Giannis Antetokounmpo"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satch_Sanders", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Satch Sanders"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Heinsohn", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Tom Heinsohn"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Havlicek", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "John Havlicek"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._C._Jones", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "K. "https://nbcsports.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/fed919f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3841x2161+0+594/resize/1440x810!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnbc-sports-production-nbc-sports.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F12%2Fd1%2F9061aa2a45bb8952adfc07b42fd5%2Fhttps-delivery-gettyimages.com%2Fdownloads%2F1237697008", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3098039215686275, "wgt": 161, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8162187988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "04:55:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T04:55:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T04:54:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/celtics-mavericks-biggest-questions-nba-finals", "title": "READ", "body": "BOSTON - Questions about the 2024 NBA Finals have been coming since this matchup between Boston and Dallas was locked in last week. Answers, real answers, will only reveal themselves on the court in the weeks ahead.\n\nHere are 10, however, to serve as placeholders for what we'll learn about the Celtics, the Mavericks and their dueling pursuit of legacies and hardware, which begins Thursday with Game 1 (8:30 ET, ABC).\n\n1. Do playground-style rankings mean anything?\n\nFor some reason, this is an increasingly popular exercise for studio shows and media outlets looking to fill time while everyone waits for the league's championship series to start. It's like the briefly-used All-Star player draft, that mechanism that traumatized so many kids who were picked last - and might have ticked off Denver's three-time Kia NBA MVP Nikola Jokic went it happened to him.\n\nMaybe it's a clumsy and thoroughly unscientific way of gauging the teams' relative strengths, based on how many of their players are taken in the first X number of picks. A run through the Celtics and Mavericks rosters this year might go like this:\n\nAnd so on. Which doesn't tell us much about how they'll compete off each other, share responsibilities, fight through cold stretches, etc. It certainly wasn't helpful the last time Dallas got to this round, when the 2011 Miami Heat had three of the top four talents in the Finals, including prime LeBron James, and still lost. So the answer is no.\n\n2. Do Tatum and Brown get along and, if not, will that derail Boston?\n\nThis is a gossipy question straight out of a high school cafeteria, sillier than the far more meaty \"Does Kyrie Irving regret stomping on the Boston logo with mascot Lucky at TD Garden court three years ago?\"\n\nThe Celtics' set of wings have achieved so much together, combining for five conference finals, two trips to the Finals and eight All-Star selections in their seven years as teammates. Brown became the highest-paid player in the NBA last summer and Tatum is poised to top him with his next deal. Together they drain the options and energy right out of opposing defenses, and they have led Boston to a 76-20 record since the season began in October.\n\nIt's not ideal to answer a question with a question, but it is effective: Are you best friends with everyone you work with? Does it stop any of you from doing your best job?\n\n3. What does this series mean to the coaches?\n\nThere's a trivia aspect to Boston's Joe Mazzulla and Dallas' Jason Kidd working the sidelines in the first Finals to feature two black head coaches since 1975, when Golden State's Al Attles matched wits with Washington's K.C. Jones.\n\nThat doesn't mean as much as what getting here, and for one of them winning here, says. Mazzulla had a bumpy first season when abruptly thrust into Ime Udoka's vacated role in 2022-23. Kidd is on his third team in eight seasons as a head coach.\n\nBoth have learned while sticking to their beliefs and systems. Mazzulla's use of a deep roster and his connection with newcomer Holiday this season have stood out. Kidd adapted to midseason acquisitions, leaned on defense and managed the sizeable egos of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne of the coaches will win. Both have been validated.\n\n4. Who guards Luka?\n\nTV graphics will line up five players per side, by position, and imply that's how they'll battle all series. Real NBA competition is far from that, of course.\n\nHoliday and White will get isolated on Doncic at times, with Holiday's strength a better fit for the matchup. But pick-and-rolls and switching means plenty of Boston players will get turns in the tank. The guy best equipped at this point might be Brown, who seemed to roll up his sleeves for the challenge when the teams played March 1 (a 138-110 Celtics victory).\n\nTeam defense matters, too, which in this case means taking away Doncic's lob targets Lively and Daniel Gafford as much as possible. Not that turning the Slovenian multi-threat into a shooter/scorer is any sort of goal.\n\n5. So what about Kyrie going back to Boston?\n\nIrving's two unsatisfying seasons with the Celtics (2017-2019) will provide a backdrop to this series, with fans in Boston still cranky about the point guard's lack of commitment and leadership. He left for Brooklyn after pledging to re-sign with the Celtics and has taken his lumps at TD Garden ever since.\n\nWe'll focus on the sideshow it provides, but this won't have much to do with any outcomes. The fans won't be poking any bear, not with Irving as the most Finals-experienced player in this series, and presumably he already will be maxed out on motivation and focus.\n\n6. Will Kristaps Porzingis play for Boston?\n\nA good answer is \"yes,\" and a better answer as far as the Celtics are concerned is \"right away.\" There were reports that the 7-foot center will open the series with everyone else in Game 1, which would be his first game action since April 29.\n\nThat was Game 4 against Miami, in which Porzingis suffered a strained right calf. That suggests a lot of rust, but it also has provided him with nearly seven weeks of rest and rehab on an injury that spooks NBA medical staffs these days. It was, after all, the immediate precursor for Kevin Durant that led to his torn Achilles tendon in the 2019 Finals.\n\nIt seems unlikely Porzingis will play without a minutes restriction, and the Celtics' 9-1 flow since he went down could get disrupted. But they welcome him back, particularly his pick-and-pop spacing and his presence defensively in the paint.\n\n7. Who are the X-factors for each team?\n\nWhite for the Celtics, P.J. Williams for the Mavericks. White can earn redemption for a disappointing experience in the 2022 Finals. That's when he scored 21 points in the opening victory, then managed just 38 points and a minus-87 in the final five games against Golden State. That was his first postseason with Boston; now he's established and often their most quietly valuable playoff performer.\n\nWashington will have to blink through the bright lights, because all 17 of his playoff appearances have come this spring. But he has scored in double figures in 15 of them, with the size (6-foot-7, 230 pounds) to get physical with the Boston wings.\n\n8. How did Dallas nail this Doncic-Irving pairing?\n\nFor a sport played with just one ball, teaming two of the NBA's most ball-dominant guards struck many as sheer folly. Irving showed up in February 2023 dragging his unreliable reputation and obstinate off-court history with him. That made the trade look like a big-name grab to prove the franchise wasn't hanging Doncic out there by himself.\n\nBut Irving began to thrive away from Brooklyn and COVID-19. He seemed more willing to show his love for the game and, most important, he and Doncic talked, built mutual respect and made room for each other.\n\nNow he appears to be in better shape physically and emotionally. He shows more energy defensively than in the past. And he and Doncic are the same handful for opponents that Irving and past star teammates have been for their own organizations.\n\n9. Would Boston's 'easy' road toward a title taint it?\n\nIt's true that each of the Celtics' foes in the East's three previous rounds played without stars for all or some of the games. Miami was without Jimmy Buter, Cleveland lost Donovan Mitchell for the final two contests and Indiana's Tyrese Haliburton missed two in the conference finals.\n\nBig deal. If the Celtics snag the Larry O'Brien Championship Trophy this year, time will erase any asterisks. Do we really know off the top of our heads which NBA championships have been won thanks to missing stars?\n\nAnd if the Celtics don't win, that outcome will mar and largely define their season, but who was or wasn't around to face them in the playoffs won't much matter. Which leads to the next question:\n\n10. Is this championship or bust for Boston?\n\nIn a word, yes. Six trips to the East finals in eight years, with a Final appearance in 2022 against Golden State to whet appetites for this one is some serious door-knocking. Tatum (26) and Brown (27) still are young as the two pillars of this team, and there would be nothing wrong tactically with running it back.\n\nBut the belief might not be there, for the fans and perhaps even for the players. Al Horford at 38 could be crushed, and losing to this insta-contender from Dallas wouldn't be as palatable as, say, losing to defending champion Denver might have been.\n\nThe views on this page do not necessarily reflect the views of the NBA, its clubs or Warner Bros. {"uri": "8163664907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:48:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:48:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:37:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13499601/Redemption-minded-Celtics-set-match-opportunistic-Mavericks-NBA-Finals.html", "title": "Redemption-minded Celtics set to match up with opportunistic...", "body": "BOSTON (AP) - As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston\u00b4s Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics\u00b4 most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you\u00b4re young, if you\u00b4ve been once, you\u00b4ll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I\u00b4m not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nDallas\u00b4 Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nDallas Mavericks head coach Jason Kidd watches play during Game 1 of the NBA basketball Western Conference finals against the Minnesota Timberwolves, Wednesday, May 22, 2024, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn\u00b4t make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I\u00b4ve always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I\u00b4m just very real, very honest. That\u00b4s what\u00b4s helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he\u00b4s the one that\u00b4s been in the Finals. He\u00b4s the one that won in the Finals. He\u00b4s the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey\u00b4ll matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favorite to raise the franchise\u00b4s 18th championship banner entering the postseason.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nThey\u00b4ve also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw longtime emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favor of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We\u00b4ve been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nCOACHING PERSPECTIVES\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It\u00b4s fun. That\u00b4s what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka\u00b4s staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It\u00b4s no different.\"\n\nFRIENDS AND COMPETITORS\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston\u00b4s home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nCeltics fans haven\u00b4t held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn\u00b4s first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\n\"They\u00b4ve gotten tremendously better. They\u00b4ve led their team to this point. So I\u00b4m proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I\u00b4m looking forward to the competition because this is what we\u00b4ve all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-380204583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:40:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:40:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:19:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://nytlicensing.com/stories/yeT30QnQ", "title": "Celtics, back in NBA Finals after 2022 defeat, aim to show they learned from loss", "body": "BOSTON - There was a championship celebrated on the parquet court inside TD Garden just two years ago.\n\nOnly, it wasn't the Boston Celtics doing the celebrating, but the Golden State Warriors - who defeated the C's in six games to settle the 2022 NBA Finals.\n\n\"I hate that I had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" Celtics star Jayson Tatum said Wednesday, on the eve of the 2024 finals.\n\nBoston is back in business, getting set to host the Dallas Mavericks at 5:30 p.m. Thursday in Game 1, two years after the Tatum-Jaylen Brown nucleus fell on its face in the duo's first finals together.\n\nThe Celtics are not exactly the same team they were in the 2022 finals, but most of the important pieces are still intact, with Tatum and Brown leading the way. As Boston and the Mavericks addressed reporters during finals media day Wednesday at TD Garden, the Celtics' recent finals experience - and the benefit it could provide them over the next three weeks - was a main topic of discussion.\n\nMost of the Celtics who will take the floor Thursday have been in the finals before, hoping that the pain they experienced at the hands of the Warriors was needed so that they can win this time.\n\n\"I'm a firm believer in everything happens for a reason,\" said Tatum, who averaged 26.9 points this season and is scoring 26.0 points per game in the playoffs. \"There's a lesson to be learned in every situation. I do feel a lot different this time, this go-around, two years later. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done.\"\n\nThe Celtics and Lakers are tied for the most championships in NBA history (17), but Boston's last finals triumph was in 2008, when Tatum was 10 years old. Brown, who has one more year of NBA service than Tatum, has been a part of six Celtics teams to reach the conference finals in eight years. Only twice has the duo gotten to the finals.\n\nDerrick White played serious minutes for Boston's last finals team, as did Al Horford and Payton Pritchard. Joe Mazzulla was an assistant coach for Boston in 2022. Brad Stevens was in his first season as team executive, having been elevated from his post as head coach.\n\nAfter falling in Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals last May, Stevens added Jrue Holiday - a champion in 2021 with the Milwaukee Bucks - and former Dallas center Kristaps Porzi\u0146\u0123is over the offseason. Together, this group blew the rest of the NBA away to the tune of 64 regular-season wins, the most in the league.\n\nThough they might disagree with this assessment, the Celtics have largely gone untested in the playoffs, facing three opponents missing their best player for some or all of each series. For a team as good as Boston, with as much pedigree and experience as the Celtics have, the finals are a referendum on whether they \"work,\" and if Tatum and Brown can win the ultimate prize together.\n\n\"I think it's a fair question. I think it's fair to say that it does affect you being embraced versus being scrutinized,\" said Brown, who was voted MVP for the Celtics' Eastern Conference finals win over Indiana.\n\n\"You get to a point where it's like you get scrutinized enough for a large part of your career, it becomes normal,\" Brown continued. \"Then it just rolls off you. For me, at least, I can say - I don't know if Jayson feels the same way - it's kind of been that (way) my whole career in a sense.\"\n\nThe Mavericks entered the postseason as the No. 5 seed in the West, and as a group this is the farthest Dallas has been in the playoffs. Luka Don\u010di\u0107 dragged the Mavs to the Western Conference finals in 2022, where they were easily dismissed by those same Warriors who bested Boston in the finals.\n\nDallas coach Jason Kidd won a championship as a player with the Mavs in 2011 - the last time the franchise reached the championship round - and collected a ring as an assistant coach with the Lakers in 2020. Kyrie Irving, one of two Mavs stars, won in 2016 with Cleveland.\n\nBut in both Kidd and Irving's case, as players, they lost in the finals before they could win one.\n\n\"Yeah, I think you do have to experience it,\" Kidd said. \"I think that's the nicer way to accept losing, is that you have to go through it. It's a graceful way to accept losing. But you do have to, again, go through defeat to understand that bad taste, how do you feel, how does it make you feel, to work on your game, to get better.\n\n\"Jayson and Brown have gone through defeat,\" Kidd continued. \"We also lost to the Warriors, too, that year. The Warriors are really good. ... That tandem (Tatum and Brown), they're playing at an extremely high level and we got our work cut out.\n\n\"But they've been here. Some of us for the Mavs have been here, some of us haven't. We're going to embrace that and find a way to hopefully win a series.\"", "source": {"uri": "nytlicensing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Spokesman.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8163128633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:02:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:02:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:02:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://hardwoodhoudini.com/posts/former-boston-celtics-fan-favorite-tabs-luka-kyrie-two-best-players-finals", "title": "Former Boston Celtics fan favorite tabs Luka and Kyrie the two best players in Finals", "body": "Oklahoma City Thunder v Dallas Mavericks - Game Four / Tim Heitman/GettyImages\n\nIt's about that time. The NBA Finals are on the verge of beginning! The Celtics and Mavericks will square off on June 6th in Game 1. Surprisingly, Isaiah Thomas, a former fan favorite who used to wear the coveted green and white jersey, believes that the team from Dallas has the best players heading into the series.\n\n\"Dallas,\" Thomas said when asked which team has the best player in the Finals (h/t Sports Illustrated). \"They got two of the best ever. Obviously Jayson Tatum and those guys are really good. Jaylen Brown is really good. But Luka and Kyrie are something we haven't seen. They are the best duo (in the Finals). They don't just have the best player.\"\n\nThis take is 100% subjective, and everyone is entitled to their own opinion, even if they go against their former team. However, this is why basketball and sports in general are heavily tuned in -- the controversy makes things enticing. But like always, none of it matters one bit; it's all going to be determined by the players involved.\n\nFor starters, Jayson Tatum -- five-time All-Star and someone who is looking to avenge their 2022 NBA Finals loss to the Golden State Warriors. That one is a gimme.\n\nWho else?\n\nJaylen Brown, a three-time All-Star who normally gets overshadowed by Tatum's success, is starting to prove his worth to everyone. After the Celtics swept over the Indiana Pacers, Brown was named the NBA Eastern Conference Finals MVP.\n\nIt's awesome to watch Brown's growth, and it's making the doubters think twice.\n\nThomas' take states that the Mavericks have \"two of the best ever,\" but he must remember that basketball is a five-person sport, not just two.\n\nBesides Tatum and Brown, Joe Mazzulla has Derrick White, Kristaps Porzingis, Al Horford, and NBA champion Jrue Holiday. In comparison to rookie Derrick Lively, Daniel Gafford, P.J. Washington, and Derrick Jones Jr.\n\nWhat's the difference between those two groups? Experience. That's so crucial and is a huge factor in deciding if a team will hang another banner in their respective arenas.\n\nRegardless of what the former Boston Celtics fan favorite said, it will not change the fact that the two teams will duke it out on their own terms.\n\nThat's where we'll really find out who has the best players.", "source": {"uri": "hardwoodhoudini.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8164325262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:05:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:05:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:03:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/06/sports/celtics-fan-guide/", "title": "If you're just tuning into the Celtics, here's how to get caught up before the NBA Finals tip off - The Boston Globe", "body": "If you're tuning in to see if they can finally raise Banner 18, here's what you need to know.\n\n\u25aa You've probably heard the Celtics were good this year, and they were. Historically good, actually. They won 64 games in the regular season, 14 more than any other team in the Eastern Conference. They set a franchise record for points scored in a season, won their first 20 games at home, and either set or tied NBA records for 50-point wins, 40-point wins, and 30-point wins in a season.\n\nBottom line: The Celtics crushed everybody all season, and that continued into the playoffs, as they lost just two games (one each to the Heat and Cavaliers) on their way to the Finals.\n\n\u25aa There are six guys on the team you should know about. You probably already know Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, he star 1-2 punch at the top. Tatum made another All-NBA first team -- named one of the five best players in basketball, more or less -- and Brown has been brilliant in the playoffs, averaging 29.8 points per game to win Eastern Conference finals MVP as the Celtics swept the Pacers.\n\nBehind them is the do-it-all, defense-first backcourt of Jrue Holiday and Derrick White, a pair of unselfish guards who were both named to the NBA's All-Defense second team. They both can provide scoring, too -- White in particular is liable for the occasional offensive takeover, hanging 38 points on the Heat in the first round -- but they make much of their hay on the other end.\n\nNow, if you haven't paid much attention over the last year, you might be thinking, \"Where the heck is Marcus Smart? Didn't everyone love him?\" They did, but building a juggernaut requires sacrifice. Rounding out the Celtics' starting five is 7-foot-2-inch center Kristaps Porzingis, whose size, shooting, and versatility brought a new dimension to this offense.\n\nThe Celtics swung a blockbuster trade for Porzingis last summer, parting with Smart, long the beating heart of the team and a huge fan favorite, to bring the lanky Latvian to Boston. Porzingis has missed much of this playoff run with a calf injury, but he's expected to return for Game 1 of the Finals, a big boost to the Celtics, who have been without their third-leading scorer since the first round.\n\nThe loss of Smart was softened by the acquisition of Holiday, who also came to Boston in an offseason trade. Holiday has been, more or less, a direct upgrade of Smart -- even better defensively, more efficient as a shooter and scorer, and far less likely to drive you insane with his shot selection.\n\nAnd finally, there's Al Horford, the eminently popular 38-year-old big man who has turned back the clock on multiple occasions this postseason starting in place of Porzingis. It's OK if you don't love Horford yet; you will.\n\nPayton Pritchard and Sam Hauser will provide some shooting and energy off the bench, but the championship hopes of the Celtics lie almost entirely with those six guys.\n\n\u25aa The Celtics are coached by 35-year-old Joe Mazzulla, the youngest coach in the NBA and the youngest to lead a team to the NBA Finals since Bill Russell in 1969. So, is he some sort of coaching wunderkind, a prodigious basketball mind with revolutionary ideas?\n\nWell, no, not really. Mazzulla is Mazzulla; his brand of coaching has more to do with letting his guys do what they do best and play their own game rather than complex scheming and tactics. You probably will see the Celtics give up a big run to Dallas and think Mazzulla is going to call a timeout to slow the momentum (he won't) or you may expect the Celtics to stop taking 3-pointers if they're shooting poorly (they won't). It's part of the experience.\n\nMazzulla is an intense character. He practices jiu-jitsu in his spare time. He once tried to block an opponent's shot after the buzzer (\"We want our opponents to constantly be uncomfortable,\" he said). He has claimed that he watches \"The Town,\" the Ben Affleck bank-heist flick set in Boston, four times a week.\n\n\u25aa That's most of what you need to know about the Celtics. The short version on the Mavericks: Their best player is Luka Doncic -- the best player on either team -- and he will have the ball for 80 percent of the game and spend the other 20 percent complaining to the referees. Their second-best player is Kyrie Irving (you might remember him), who almost certainly will get booed incessantly in Boston. It's all part of the fun.\n\nIt all kicks off Thursday night at TD Garden, where the Celtics lost the 2022 Finals in six games to Stephen Curry and the Warriors. But the Celtics have home-court advantage this time, plus an even better roster and more consistent stars.\n\nOne way or the other, it should be a fun series. And if the Celtics fall short again, you can always tell your coworkers you knew they shouldn't have traded Marcus Smart.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3254901960784313, "wgt": 160, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-380134750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:28:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:28:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:03:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/which-players-will-step-up-for-mavs-celtics-writers-discuss-names-to-watch-in-nba/article_48703ecf-b1f8-51db-9eae-05a3de68e0ae.html", "title": "Which players will step up for Mavs, Celtics? Writers discuss names to watch in NBA Finals.", "body": "Tim Cowlishaw, Kevin Sherrington, Mike Curtis, Brad Townsend and Shawn McFarland - The Dallas Morning News (TNS)\n\nAhead of the NBA Finals between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics, columnists and beat writers from The Dallas Morning News and The Boston Globe collaborated to answer several questions and predict an outcome for the series, which starts Thursday in Boston.\n\nHere are the players they said need to step up for either the Mavericks or the Celtics to win the series.\n\n-- Mike Curtis: P.J. Washington is going to be the X-factor for the Mavericks. He's shown throughout the postseason that he's capable of stepping up as that third scoring option behind Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving. He'll receive plenty of looks from the 3-point line, especially from the corner. It's up to him to knock them down. His defense on Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown could be even more valuable to Dallas and might prove the difference in the series if he can make it difficult for either Celtics star.\n\n-- Tim Cowlishaw: This will be an enormous series for Derrick Jones Jr. The Mavericks didn't know they were getting a full-time starter when they signed him away from Chicago. But the former dunk champion has been a top-level defender and will undoubtedly guard Tatum plenty in the coming series.\n\nTatum is a streaky shooter, and when he's at his best, Boston probably has too many weapons for the Mavs to contend with. But if Jones does his usual job of making Tatum work, that puts added pressure on Brown and Derrick White and others to carry the load.\n\n-- Shawn McFarland: P.J. Washington. He averaged 12.2 points and 6.4 rebounds in the Western Conference finals and cracked double digits in each game, and he's grown into the third option behind Doncic and Irving. We've seen him change the momentum, flow and outcome of individual playoff games, and assuming the Celtics -- with a top-ranked defense led by Jrue Holiday, White, Brown and co. -- throw the kitchen sink at Dallas' superstar backcourt, Washington's impact on offense and defense is necessary. He and Jones could see a lot of time on Tatum (6-8) and Brown (6-6), and his perimeter shooting can help stretch the floor versus a defense without too many holes.\n\n-- Kevin Sherrington: Dereck Lively II was the Mavs' unsung hero of the last two rounds because of his ability to limit teams' offense in the paint. But how much difference can he make against the Celtics, especially if Kristaps Porzingis reclaims the minutes Al Horford picked up in his absence? Washington and Jones will have their hands full guarding Tatum and Brown, meaning they may not have a lot left for offense. Goes without saying that Doncic and Irving need to outdo Tatum and Brown, so how's this for a wild card: Jaden Hardy. He's got a shooter's conscience, meaning none at all. If he can provide a consistent offensive spark, the Mavs can score with Boston.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n-- Brad Townsend: Washington. At this point, the Mavericks know the baseline of what they can expect from key non-Doncic/Irving players such as Washington, Jones, Josh Green, Maxi Kleber and even Lively. And they know they'll get stellar defense from Washington. But what will he give Dallas offensively? The Celtics have so many offensive weapons that it's imperative for the Mavericks to counter with a reliable No. 3 scorer.\n\nDallas doesn't necessarily need the 17.7-point, 8.3-rebound Washington we saw against Oklahoma City in the second round, though that Washington obviously would be welcomed. But in this series the Mavericks need more scoring from Washington than his 10.8-point average in the first round and 12.2-point average against Minnesota in the WCF.\n\n-- Chad Finn: Honestly, it's just a matter of the Celtics' best players playing up to their ability. The Celtics have a remarkably well-rounded team, and Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have never trusted their colleagues more. The Celtics could be in trouble if Tatum or Brown underperforms or tries to do too much, but I don't anticipate that. I will say this: I think Jrue Holiday will be the one to make the play or plays that clinch this series.\n\n-- Adam Himmelsbach: The beauty of this Celtics team is that they are so talented at the top that they are generally able to withstand at least one poor performance by any player. So they don't necessarily need one specific player to step up. But keep an eye on Sam Hauser, who was one of the best 3-point shooters in the NBA during the regular season but has largely disappeared during these playoffs.\n\n-- Gary Washburn: This needs to be a Jayson Tatum series and that does not necessarily mean scoring. Tatum needs to rebound, be a playmaker, and play strong defense. The Mavericks don't have a player who can consistently guard him one-on-one and he needs to take advantage of any matchup, but don't get caught up in him matching Doncic basket for basket. He must be best all-around player in this series, prove he's Top-5 Tatum, and make his teammates better.\n\n\u00a92024 The Dallas Morning News. Visit dallasnews.com. two teams before the gameplay gets tighter and tighter when getting closer to crowning a champion.\n\nWhether it's the Mavericks or Celtics, don't be shocked if one team jumps out to a large lead {"uri": "2024-06-378960932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "23:31:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T23:31:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T22:33:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/celtics-stars-tatum-and-brown-feel-better-equipped-to-tackle-2nd-chance-in-nba-finals/article_6e85d1cc-9091-52fc-94ce-7206a1f94ade.html", "title": "Celtics stars Tatum and Brown feel better equipped to tackle 2nd chance in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- For almost the entirety of their time together in Boston, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been linked.\n\nThey were drafted by the Celtics third overall in back-to-back years.\n\nThey possess similar skillsets -- two explosive and skilled wing players with an ability to score from nearly every spot on the court.\n\nAnd they both have been central to the success of a Celtics team that has reached the NBA Finals for the second time in three seasons. It helped Brown earn the NBA's first $300 million contract last summer. And, Tatum is expected to get one this offseason.\n\nThe team has branded the All-Stars as \"The Jays\" in a marketing campaign shown during games that pitted them against one another in mini competitions.\n\nIt has created natural comparisons between them along the way, fostering an atmosphere in which fans and sports pundits alike have tried to parse out which one of them is better, whose spot is most untouchable on the roster and which of them is more pivotal to the Celtics' success as they prepare to lead the team to the franchise's 18th NBA title.\n\nIt reached a new level last week during a segment on ESPN's \"Get Up\" in which panelists debated whether the 26-year-old Tatum expressed excitement or disappointment while watching the 27-year-old Brown garner Eastern Conference finals MVP honors.\n\n\"I think it's unfair to both of them,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said of what he viewed as an attempt to manufacture friction between the two stars.\n\nBut even as Tatum and Brown have distinguished themselves as the most important players on Boston's roster and the keys to the Celtics' fate in their NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, Mazzulla has hope that people will start viewing them differently.\n\n\"They're, like, two completely different people. They're two completely different players,\" Mazzulla said. \"They're great teammates, they love each other and they go about winning and they go about their process in a different way. Why they have to always be lumped together I think is unfair.\"\n\nTatum and Brown, along with Al Horford, are the only returning starters from the 2021-22 team that lost to the Golden State Warriors in six games in the Finals after holding a 2-1 series lead.\n\nWhile Horford has taken on mostly a reserve role this season, backing up 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis, Tatum and Brown have taken their play up a notch.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n\"Obviously, we've been there before, we came up short,\" Tatum said. \"You don't always get a second chance, so really just looking at it as a second chance and trying to simplify things as much as we can.\"\n\nAnd being each other's biggest cheerleaders, too.\n\nAfter Brown made a game-tying 3-pointer late in Game 1 of the conference finals matchup with Indiana to send the game to overtime in an eventual Celtics' victory, the highest praise came from Tatum.\n\n\"Big time players make big time plays,\" Tatum said of Brown.\n\nFor Brown, this season has been about focusing on the expectations he has for himself and not worrying about others' perception of him.\n\nInitially, when he was asked about not being included on either the All-NBA or All-Defensive teams, he shrugged it off, saying his attention was focused on getting back to the NBA Finals.\n\nAfter he was named conference finals MVP, he acknowledged it did offer at least some motivation, particularly on the defensive side of the ball which he said he put most of his work into this past offseason.\n\n\"As time has gone by and I got to this point, I stopped caring,\" Brown said. \"I don't care who sees what, as long as my city knows my value, my team knows my value, my family -- that's all I really care about.\"\n\nMazzulla believes the reason the relationship between Brown and Tatum is so often talked about is rooted in outside disbelief that their dynamic doesn't breed any rivalry between them.\n\n\"At the end of the day, like, those two guys, their relationship is their relationship,\" Mazzulla said. \"They love each other. They push each other every single day in practice. They communicate with each other, but they go about it differently. And, I think they both get it unfair being compared to each other. They're different. And we see other duos around the league don't have to go through that. ... It's because they've been so successful their entire careers, they've been able to for so long stay in success at a high level.\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA", "source": {"uri": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NBA Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 160, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8163116616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "14:54:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T14:54:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:54:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "http://www.bangordailynews.com/2024/06/05/sports/professional-basketball/feed-porzingis-and-4-more-celtics-keys-to-winning-the-nba-finals/", "title": "Feed Porzingis and 4 more Celtics keys to winning the NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- The Celtics are heavy favorites to win the NBA Finals.\n\nOne of the strongest in recent memory.\n\nThe most common projections have Boston beating Dallas in five or six games. But if recent Celtics history, and the star power of Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving have taught us anything, it's that these Finals are destined to be a long, tight series.\n\nAmid all the drama and scrutiny, here's how Boston can pull out Banner 18:\n\n1. Feed Porzingis\n\nThe Celtics' clearest matchup advantage lies with the murky status of Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nPorzingis is expected to play in these Finals, but it's unclear exactly when or how many minutes he will be allowed to play coming off a calf strain. Whenever the 7-footer hits the floor, the Celtics should waste no time finding him. He can post up or shoot over every Mavericks rotation regular, and threaten Dallas with pick-and-pop 3s like no opposing center has yet these playoffs.\n\nHe is the solution to the Mavericks' first-rate rim protection, and any switching defense Dallas might opt for against the Celtics' star wings.\n\nPorzingis went 4 of 8 on 3-pointers in their last matchup, a Boston rout on March 1 that started with him canning multiple 3s in the first quarter. Much has changed since then, including a Mavericks team that quickly coalesced into a legit championship contender. But the mismatch Porzingis presents remains, and the Celtics should exploit it whenever they can.\n\n2. Attack Doncic on defense\n\nA tactic as old as time: forcing the opponent's best offensive player to work overtime on defense.\n\nFatigue them, mentally and physically. Force them to chase, think and defend. One possession after another after another.\n\nDoncic, at 6-foot-7 and 230 pounds, is no stranger to this plan. He's also held his own in the playoffs defensively, despite dealing with various minor injuries. The Celtics are not armed with the type of player best-equipped to beat him -- lightning-quick ball-handlers who can shoot -- but they can force Doncic to switch onto Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown or chase Derrick White around screens.\n\nBoston should probably brace for a Doncic avalanche on offense. It's coming.\n\nDoncic might even win a game or two on his own. The 25-year-old star is that good, and the proof is in these playoffs, when he knocked off three of the West's top four seeds, all 50-win teams. Kyrie Irving, on the other hand, is a different story.\n\nOklahoma City successfully harassed the 32-year-old with athletic primary defenders, encroaching double teams and lots of defensive attention. Irving averaged fewer than 15 points per game entering the Mavs' clinching Game 6 win in that series and nearly seven assists. Irving yielded the ball to lesser teammates (P.J. Washington, Derrick Jones Jr. and Josh Green, to name a few), who punished OKC on open 3-point looks.\n\nIt was a pick-your-poison proposition the Thunder handled wisely. With extra pressure on Doncic and Irving, Dallas posted a 112 offensive rating in that series, a rating that would have ranked bottom-10 over the regular season. The pitfall OKC found -- missing its own 3-pointers -- is an area Boston should avoid, as the second-best shooting team in the league by effective field goal percentage.\n\nThough, there is a balance here. Blitzing Irving cannot lead to Doncic playing 4-on-3 behind that initial pressure. He will kill the Celtics. Boston should pressure Irving with the intent of guiding the ball to the Mavericks' wings and centers as best it can, the least dangerous place it could be with two stars on the floor.\n\nNot to mention, during the regular season, Dallas went just 6-5 in games Irving played at least 15 minutes and scored fewer than 20 points.\n\n4. Keep an eye on transition\n\nThe Celtics' transition defense has been excellent all season, with two notable Game 2 exceptions: in the first round versus Miami and second round against Cleveland.\n\nThey lost both of those nights, a function of inconsistent defensive focus and preposterously hot opponent shooting. Dallas may step into similar shooting luck one night against Boston, but the Celtics can't give up anything easy.\n\nThe Mavericks will run selectively, often with Doncic or Irving hitting hit-ahead passes before the defense knows what has happened. Dallas is adding 3.4 points per 100 possessions off fast breaks in the playoffs, fourth-highest in the postseason per Cleaning the Glass, while the Celtics are at 0.1. Those three to four points could be the difference in any game this series, especially if Boston is slow to get back on multiple possessions.\n\n5. Play with purpose\n\nThe Celtics have come too far to let go of the rope now.\n\nThey cannot suffer from their own aimlessness against Luka and Co. The Mavericks will punish them for a lack of focus, lazing into stepback 3s and allowing easy baskets. They don't boast the same firepower or depth, but they know who they are and how they want to win.\n\nKnowing their talent advantage pads their margin for error, the Celtics have known to play with their food. But now it's time to eat.\n\nBecause if the Celtics match the Mavs' purpose and deliberately attack their weaknesses -- allowing corner 3s and lack of playmaking outside of Doncic and Irving -- long enough, it should pay off in a title.\n\n\u00a92024 MediaNews Group, Inc. Visit at bostonherald.com. The Celtics enter the matchup both the heavy series (-225) and Game 1 (-6.5, -250) favorites, with Heavy's projections putting the Celtics' Game 1 win probability at 66%, with a spread of minus-5.\n\nThe Celtics haven't played since May 27th, when they eliminated the Indiana Pacers with a 105-102 win. On the other side, the Mavs have had less rest, securing their spot in the NBA Finals with a series-clinching 124-103 win over the Minnesota Timberwolves.\n\nLet's take a look at the best bets for player props on both sides.\n\nWhile there is a logical reason to think the Mavericks will want to get Kyrie Irving going early in Game 1, the Celtics will not want Irving to gain the emotional upper hand with a quick start.\n\nTraditionally, Doncic has been the one to control the offense early, as he's scored in the first three minutes in each of his last five contests. Doncic is second in the NBA Playoffs in first-quarter points, with an average of 9.6 over 17 games.\n\nKyrie Irving Made Threes - Over 2.5 (-111)\n\nThe Celtics have allowed 33.8% shooting from the 3-point line over the span of the 2023-24 NBA Playoffs, but that number deserves context. Over their 14 playoff games, the Celtics have allowed 12.4 3-point attempts that were \"open\" (nearest defender 4-to-6 feet), with their opponents making a paltry 28.2% of those attempts. It's not great defense as much as bad shotmaking.\n\nAfter starting the playoffs averaging 8.2 3-point attempts per game against the Los Angeles Clippers, Irving backed off in the first five games of the Oklahoma City Thunder series, shooting it from deep just 3.2 times per contest. Since then (six games), he's back to attempting 7.0 3-pointers per game, making an average of 2.7.\n\nPlayer to Record 1+ Points, Rebounds, Assists, Blocks and Steals - Kristaps Porzingis (-160)\n\nBefore leaving Game 4 of the Eastern Conference First Round against the Miami Heat, Porzingis was riding quite a streak, recording the following:\n\nThe two issues to watch for are whether Porzingis is healthy and ready to play quality minutes and whether he's able to secure a steal. Familiarity playing alongside Doncic in the past paired with having relatively fresh legs will play a role in getting that steal.\n\nPlayer to Record a Double Double - Jayson Tatum (-135)\n\nTo say that this is the biggest game in Tatum's career would be an understatement. He's going to come out aggressively and should pass the 10-point threshold quickly. The rebounds will take longer, though, over his last 14 games, he's averaging 10.4 rebounds. {"uri": "8159936130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "19:54:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T19:54:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T19:52:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/kevin-garnett-disagrees-the-celtics-had-an-easy-path-to-the-2024-nba-finals/article_f6f5922d-d340-55e4-a56a-c45877146bbd.html", "title": "Kevin Garnett Disagrees The Celtics Had An Easy Path To The 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "Kevin Garnett has taken issue with the narrative suggesting the Boston Celtics had an easy path to the 2024 NBA Finals. Despite their dominant 12-2 record in the Eastern Conference playoffs, critics argue that Boston's journey was made easier due to injuries to key players on opposing teams. Garnett, however, finds this perspective flawed and unfair.\n\n\"Their path is is their path... It's not on the f***ing Celtics team that guys are getting hurt, not playing, falling out of the lineup. First off, there's still other professionals that are coming in, playing hard as s**t and then still trying to win.\"\n\n\"And then two, they close out a game on the road? Man, I don't know what people want. People want this heartfelt drama and going down to seven games. Nah, that ain't the script here. Their script, they're damn near 17,16 games better than anybody in the East.\"\n\n\"They really steamroll your team if your best player ain't on your team. And it is what it is. And then too, you're down on the road 18, they think that you can just hit a button and all of a sudden you're tired.\"\n\n\"No, man, you gotta win on the road. And it's hard as sh** to win on the road. And it's even more hard to close out on the road. But for all this other s**t that they can't control and that's out of control, get the f**k out of here with that. This is where we are with it.\" (13:15)\n\nGarnett points out that the Celtics can't control the health of their opponents. Injuries are an unfortunate part of the game, but the Celtics still had to face professional athletes who were determined to compete and win.\n\nThe Hall of Famer dismisses the idea that Boston's success should be discounted because their opponents were missing star players. He believes the Celtics' dominance throughout the season and playoffs speaks for itself.\n\nTo Garnett's point, the Celtics finished the regular season with a 64-18 record, the best in the league by a significant margin. They were 41-11 against Eastern Conference teams, underscoring their superiority. During the playoffs, Boston maintained this high level of performance, showcasing their depth and resilience.\n\nThey swept the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference Finals, a series where the Pacers fought hard despite missing Tyrese Haliburton for two games.\n\nCritics have suggested that the Celtics' path was too easy, but Garnett argues that winning on the road and closing out games are incredibly challenging tasks, regardless of the opposition. He emphasizes that the Celtics not only had to overcome deficits but also had to deal with the pressure of performing away from home, which is no small feat in the playoffs.\n\nFurthermore, Garnett highlights the Celtics' comprehensive team effort. Boston was built to withstand adversity, with a deep roster capable of stepping up when needed. This resilience was evident throughout their playoff run, as different players took turns making significant contributions. The notion that their path was easy undermines the hard work and determination displayed by the entire team.\n\nIn the Eastern Conference Finals, the Celtics faced criticism for winning close games, but Garnett argues that these victories should be seen as a testament to their toughness and ability to execute under pressure. He believes that even with the injuries to their opponents, Boston's performance was impressive and deserving of respect.\n\nAs the Celtics prepare to face the Dallas Mavericks in the NBA Finals, Garnett's defense of his former team serves as a reminder of the unpredictability and challenges of the playoffs.\n\nThe path to a championship is never easy, and the Celtics have proven themselves to be a formidable team, ready to compete at the highest level. Garnett's passionate defense underscores the pride and belief he has in the Celtics, and he remains confident in their ability to win the title.\n\nThe Celtics Run Should Not Have Any Asterisk Next To It\n\nThe Celtics' run to the 2024 NBA Finals should not have any asterisk next to it. It's unfair to diminish their achievements because their opponents faced injuries. The Celtics maintained their intensity and focus, taking advantage of the opportunities presented to them without any intentional actions causing those injuries.\n\nIn the first round, the Celtics faced the Miami Heat, who were without Jimmy Butler and Terry Rozier. Despite these absences, the Celtics did not show any complacency, handling their business efficiently and defeating the Heat in five games. Their professional approach ensured they moved past the Heat with minimal fuss.\n\nThe second round saw the Celtics up against the Cleveland Cavaliers, who were missing key players Jarrett Allen and Donovan Mitchell due to injuries. Again, the Celtics showcased their dominance, taking care of the Cavaliers in five games. Injuries impacted the Cavaliers, but the Celtics' superior play ensured they capitalized on the situation effectively.\n\nIn the Eastern Conference Finals, the Celtics faced the Indiana Pacers. The Pacers were without Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games, but the Celtics still had to execute their game plan and perform at a high level to secure the sweep. Boston's ability to stay focused and maintain their performance levels was a testament to their championship-caliber mindset.\n\nIt's important to recognize that injuries are an unfortunate part of sports. The Celtics cannot be blamed for their opponents' misfortunes. They played who was in front of them and did so with a high degree of professionalism and skill. The narrative that their path was easier due to these injuries overlooks the fact that Boston was the best regular-season team in the league and played like it throughout the playoffs.\n\nHowever, there is one caveat: if the Celtics were to lose in the Finals and blame their lack of competition in earlier rounds for their defeat, that excuse would not hold weight. A true championship team prepares and adapts to any situation, regardless of the opposition. The Celtics' journey to the Finals has been impressive, and their focus should remain on finishing the job, not on the circumstances that led them there.\n\nThe Celtics' run to the Finals deserves full recognition and respect. They have proven themselves as a dominant force in the league, and any attempt to undermine their achievements with an asterisk is misguided and unjustified.\n\nRelated: 2024 NBA Finals: Celtics vs. Mavericks (Analysis, Comparison, Prediction)\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World.
