{"uri": "8163865626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:57:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:57:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:56:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/jayson-tatum-gets-real-on-nba-finals-pressure-the-expectations-are-different-here/article_4855d8e3-d533-57f7-a502-e11a7db43fdb.html", "title": "Jayson Tatum Gets Real On NBA Finals Pressure: \"The Expectations Are Different Here...\"", "body": "On the eve of the 2024 NBA Finals, Jayson Tatum was willing to acknowledge the pressure to help the Celtics win their 18th NBA championship. During the media press conference on Wednesday, the 26-year-old star broke down what it means to be on the cusp of history with such a historic franchise.\n\n\"If you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. The expectations are obviously different here,\" Tatum said, via ESPN's Tim Bontemps. \"It takes special players to be here and to be a part of an environment like that.\"\n\nThe Celtics and Lakers are currently tied at 17 championships apiece, but the Celtics have a chance to re-take their spot as the winningest team with a victory in this series. for Tatum, he's humbled to think about those who came before him.\n\n\"We only hang NBA championship banners, right? 17 of them,\" Tatum said. \"Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. All of us are honored to follow in their footsteps, the way they paved for us to live out our dream.\"\n\nSo far, Tatum (26 years old) and Brown (27 years old) have withstood all of the trade rumors over the years and they've put together one of the most impressive runs by any duo in modern NBA history -- even if it hasn't come with a title. If they lose now to the Mavericks, many believe changes will be warranted, but Jayson wants to put all of that aside to live fully in the moment.\n\n\"I don't think about the future or what this may mean for me down the road,\" Tatum said. \"As simple as it sounds, just try to stay present, stay in the moment, enjoy it, right? Keep talking about pressure, pressure, pressure... It's the NBA Finals. This s--- is supposed to be fun.\"\n\nWith season averages of 26.9 points, 8.1 rebounds, and 4.9 assists per game on 47.1% shooting, Tatum was an MVP frontrunner all season long and now it's time to back it up. After cruising through the regular season and then through the East playoffs, the Celtics are out of excuses and expectations couldn't be higher.\n\nJaylen Brown Says The Celtics Are Ready To Cement Their Legacy\n\nDespite their youth, the Celtics have been in this position before. Besides the 21 other times they've advanced to the final round, this particular group made a similar run back in 2022. In that series, against the Warriors, Tatum and Brown were ultimately defeated in six games against a more experienced and well-rounded roster.\n\nWith a chance to come out on the winning end this time, Jaylen Brown knows the importance of the moment ahead and he's ready to seize the moment and establish a lasting legacy with the franchise.\n\n\"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win,\" said Brown. \"I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nWith Game 1 set to kick off tomorrow, it won't be long now before we find out if the Celtics duo, who were both drafted 3rd overall, are for real or if they're just blowing smoke. Judging from how they've looked in the playoffs so far, they aren't messing around and they are determined to give the Mavericks everything they've got.\n\nRelated: Jayson Tatum Gets Real On His Run With Kyrie Irving: \"It's Not Just Talent That Takes You Over The Top...\"\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {"uri": "8161960864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "00:29:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T00:29:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T00:28:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/jayson-tatum-jaylen-brown-2nd-shot-nba-finals", "title": "Tatum, Brown eager for 2nd chance in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- For almost the entirety of their time together in Boston, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been linked.\n\nThey were drafted by the Celtics third overall in back-to-back years.\n\nThey possess similar skillsets -- two explosive and skilled wing players with an ability to score from nearly every spot on the court.\n\nAnd they both have been central to the success of a Celtics team that has reached the NBA Finals for the second time in three seasons. It helped Brown earn the NBA's first $300 million contract last summer. And, Tatum is expected to get one this offseason.\n\nThe team has branded the All-Stars as \"The Jays\" in a marketing campaign shown during games that pitted them against one another in mini competitions.\n\nIt has created natural comparisons between them along the way, fostering an atmosphere in which fans and sports pundits alike have tried to parse out which one of them is better, whose spot is most untouchable on the roster and which of them is more pivotal to the Celtics' success as they prepare to lead the team to the franchise's 18th NBA title.\n\nIt reached a new level last week during a segment on ESPN's \"Get Up\" in which panelists debated whether the 26-year-old Tatum expressed excitement or disappointment while watching the 27-year-old Brown garner Eastern Conference Finals MVP honors.\n\n\"I think it's unfair to both of them,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said of what he viewed as an attempt to manufacture friction between the two stars.\n\nBut even as Tatum and Brown have distinguished themselves as the most important players on Boston's roster and the keys to the Celtics' fate in their NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, Mazzulla has hope that people will start viewing them differently.\n\n\"They're, like, two completely different people. They're two completely different players,\" Mazzulla said. \"They're great teammates, they love each other and they go about winning and they go about their process in a different way. Why they have to always be lumped together I think is unfair.\"\n\nTatum and Brown, along with Al Horford, are the only returning starters from the 2021-22 team that lost to the Golden State Warriors in six games in the Finals after holding a 2-1 series lead.\n\nWhile Horford has taken on mostly a reserve role this season, backing up 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis, Tatum and Brown have taken their play up a notch.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n\"Obviously, we've been there before, we came up short,\" Tatum said. \"You don't always get a second chance, so really just looking at it as a second chance and trying to simplify things as much as we can.\"\n\nAnd being each other's biggest cheerleaders, too.\n\nAfter Brown made a game-tying 3-pointer late in Game 1 of the conference finals matchup with Indiana to send the game to overtime in an eventual Celtics' victory, the highest praise came from Tatum.\n\n\"Big time players make big time plays,\" Tatum said of Brown.\n\nFor Brown, this season has been about focusing on the expectations he has for himself and not worrying about others' perception of him.\n\nInitially, when he was asked about not being included on either the All-NBA or All-Defensive teams, he shrugged it off, saying his attention was focused on getting back to the NBA Finals.\n\nAfter he was named conference finals MVP, he acknowledged it did offer at least some motivation, particularly on the defensive side of the ball which he said he put most of his work into this past offseason.\n\n\"As time has gone by and I got to this point, I stopped caring,\" Brown said. \"I don't care who sees what, as long as my city knows my value, my team knows my value, my family -- that's all I really care about.\"\n\nMazzulla believes the reason the relationship between Brown and Tatum is so often talked about is rooted in outside disbelief that their dynamic doesn't breed any rivalry between them.\n\n\"At the end of the day, like, those two guys, their relationship is their relationship,\" Mazzulla said. \"They love each other. They push each other every single day in practice. They communicate with each other, but they go about it differently. And, I think they both get it unfair being compared to each other. They're different. And we see other duos around the league don't have to go through that. ... It's because they've been so successful their entire careers, they've been able to for so long stay in success at a high level.\"", "source": {"uri": "nba.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Dallas, meanwhile, will be looking for just its second championship ever, having last won in 2011 with Dirk Nowitzki.\n\nThis championship series will certainly be star-studded. Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown will be joined by a dynamic supporting cast that features former Mav Kristaps Porzingis as well as Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, and Al Horford. Joe Mazzulla's Celts have been one of the best teams on both sides of the floor all season long.\n\nBut Jason Kidd's Mavericks are no slouches. Luka Doncic has looked like the best player in the world this postseason, and running mate Kyrie Irving finally seems to be at peace and ready to take back over the league. Trade-deadline acquisitions P.J. Washington and Daniel Gafford have also been huge for Dallas, as has been the alley-oop duo of rookie Dereck Lively II and vastly-improved small forward Derrick Jones Jr.\n\nThis should be a fantastic series -- and needless to say, a lot will be riding on Game 1 at TD Garden in Boston on Thursday. Historically, teams that take a 1-0 series lead in the NBA Finals go on to win the championship over 70 percent of the time!\n\nInterested in catching Game 1 of the NBA Finals in Boston? {"uri": "8161722437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "19:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T19:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T19:58:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/06/nba-finals-2024-celtics-smart-decisions-jrue-holiday-kristaps-porzingis", "title": "3 brilliant decisions that got the Celtics to the 2024 NBA Finals", "body": "No team has been more successful in the Eastern Conference lately than the Boston Celtics. The winningest team in NBA history has played in six of the last eight Eastern Conference Finals. Boston's best player, Jayson Tatum, has already played in 19 playoff series and is still only 26 years old.\n\nAll of that makes it no surprise to see the Celtics in their second NBA Finals in three seasons. And this time, their appearance in the NBA's championship round is a little more tense on paper.\n\nREAD MORE: Ranking the 14 greatest NBA Finals of all time.\n\nThat's because these Celtics were built to win a title. They have two All-Stars (Tatum and Jaylen Brown) surrounded by a roster stacked with other All-Star-caliber players and difference-makers. They also hail from the East, which is inarguably the easier path to the Finals between the NBA's two conferences. If the Celtics don't win this title, it's hard to see this iteration of the team ever getting over the hump. Full stop.\n\nWith all of that said, we'll have plenty of time to dive deeper into these narratives in a few weeks. For now, it's worth revisiting the steps the Celtics took to build a juggernaut that qualified for this year's NBA Finals.\n\n1. Taking advantage of the Milwaukee Bucks' desperation for Damian Lillard\n\nThis time last year, it wasn't an abject certainty that Giannis Antetokounmpo would be a Buck for the duration of his entire NBA career. Well, actually, at this point in time, it still isn't. But it helps that Milwaukee traded for perennial All-Star Damian Lillard with the aim of giving Antetokounmpo a top-flight running mate.\n\nHowever, to acquire Lillard in a blockbuster trade with the Portland Trail Blazers, the Bucks had to give up some sizable assets. One of them was point guard Jrue Holiday, arguably the NBA's best point-of-attack defender. With rebuilding Portland having no need for an older veteran guard like Holiday, it quickly shipped him off to the win-now Celtics.\n\nNow, Holiday anchors a tenacious and elite Boston defense while usually making timely and smart plays on offense. This only happened because the Bucks were so eager for Lillard in the first place.\n\n2. Selling high on Marcus Smart when they still could\n\nFrom a glance, Smart might be one of the greatest Celtics of all time. The guard made three All-Defensive First Teams and was the 2022 Defensive Player of the Year during his career in green. He was once rightfully considered an important long-term core piece for Boston alongside Tatum and Brown.\n\nUntil he wasn't.\n\nAfter the Celtics' disappointing collapse in last year's Eastern Conference Finals, they decided to sell high on Smart. They offloaded the defense-first point guard in a three-team deal that helped completely remodel their starting lineup. In return, Boston received a much-needed floor-spacer in center Kristaps Porzingis, who gives the Celtics another top-flight three-point shooter and offensive player.\n\nWhile the Celtics are a deep and great team without Porzingis's services, he undoubtedly gives them another extremely dangerous element. This never happens without a tough and shrewd trade of Smart.\n\n3. Believing in Derrick White\n\nOnce upon a time, White was just another bog standard cog-in-the-machine for the San Antonio Spurs. By no means was he a bad player, but there was little chance the guard would ever really flourish once the Spurs entered an earnest rebuild. The Celtics thought as much because they wanted to capitalize on his potential.\n\nOnce San Antonio began trying to bottom out, Boston swooped in with a modest 2022 trade centered around White eventually shining in a winning environment. He's done that and then some ever since.\n\nIn two seasons with the Celtics, White has morphed into an elite high-volume three-point shooter. Mix that up with his All-NBA-caliber defense, and the Celtics have constructed one of the more useful \"winning\" backcourts in the NBA. White fits like a perfect puzzle piece with the Celtics' starters.\n\nEven despite their recent success, these Celtics are proof that NBA contenders should never be afraid to make bold or shrewd trades.\n\nSometimes, a few shake-ups are exactly what's necessary to compete for a title.\n\nMeet NBA Draft prospect Kyle Filipowski, the Duke star ready to reintroduce himself in the pros The latest 2024 NBA mock draft from CBS has Stephon Castle to the Rockets Clipped: See the cast of FX's new Clippers series compared to their real-life counterparts", "source": {"uri": "ftw.usatoday.com", {"uri": "2024-06-380194511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.recordherald.com/2024/06/05/redemption-minded-celtics-set-to-match-up-with-opportunistic-mavericks-in-nba-finals/", "title": "Redemption-minded Celtics set to match up with opportunistic Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey'll matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favorite to raise the franchise's 18th championship banner entering the postseason.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nThey've also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw longtime emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favor of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nCOACHING PERSPECTIVES\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nFRIENDS AND COMPETITORS\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston's home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nCeltics fans haven't held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn's first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\n\"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"", "source": {"uri": "recordherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Record Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_playoffs", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-06-380135499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:29:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:29:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:20:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/celtics-news-jayson-tatum-jaylen-brown-respond-harsh-criticism-before-nba-finals", "title": "Celtics' Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown respond to harsh criticism before NBA Finals", "body": "Brown, who's now a three-time All-Star and the longest-tenured player on the C's, has learned to block out all the noise.\n\n\"You get scrutinized enough for a large part of your career, it becomes normal,\" he said during a Wednesday afternoon press conference. \"Then it just rolls off you ... It's kind of been that my whole career in a sense. Just being booed when you were drafted to saying you were overpaid, saying you were overpaid again. It's been that the whole journey for me. It just becomes another headline.\"\n\nThe 27-year-old is preparing for his second NBA Finals appearance on Thursday, as the Celtics are set to play the Dallas Mavericks in the championship round. He's been a vocal leader for Boston this playoffs and has maintained an impressive intensity on both ends of the floor throughout the playoffs.\n\nTatum, his partner in crime, has also learned to ignore the constant chatter from the media and other outlets.\n\n\"It's my mom, my grandma, my family and friends. They're more bothered by it than me,\" he admitted when asked about the scrutiny he faces. \"Just a long break without NBA basketball, so [the media] had to overanalyze every little thing, have something to talk about. Did it get old? Yeah. But, you know, it's the Finals. They wouldn't talk about me if I wasn't good, so ... Try to take some positives out of it and change the channel.\"\n\nThe best way for the Celtics to silence the noise is simple: hang Banner No. 18 in the rafters. Tatum and Brown have been to four Eastern Conference Finals in the last five years and have become accustomed to lengthy playoff runs. However, neither star has been able to earn themselves a ring thus far, but doing so this June would likely hush a lot of doubters.\n\nIt won't be easy, though. Mavericks star Luka Doncic is eager for his first title as well, and ex-Celtic Kyrie Irving knows what it takes to win on the biggest stage.\n\n\"That's a great player over there, so it's going to be a full-team effort,\" Brown remarked when asked how the Celtics can slow down Irving. \"Him and Luka. Making sure we're alert, making sure we're back in transition, and do the best we can.\"\n\nWhy Jrue Holiday is so impressed by Tatum and Brown\n\nCeltics guard Jrue Holiday definitely qualifies as an NBA veteran. He's in his thirties and has been in the league since 2009.\n\nAs a result, he's seen plenty, yet even he's been shocked by the disrespect Tatum and Brown face.\n\n\"The pressure that J.B. and J.T. have to take on is something different,\" he told the media on Wednesday. \"I've told them this before, but it's really impressive how they handle themselves, how they stay professional, how they still come out every game and do what they do. Yeah, I think it's extremely impressive how they do that.\"\n\nHoliday acknowledged that he's witnessed other players, such as Milwaukee Bucks star Giannis Antetokounmpo, get dissected unfairly by the media. But, in his opinion, that still doesn't compare to what Tatum and Brown deal with.\n\n\"I would say that I probably don't take a bulk of the pressure because we have Jayson and Jaylen on our team,\" Holiday said.\n\nMedia condemnation aside, the Celtics are more concerned with taking down the Mavs. Despite this year being his first time playing for Boston, Holiday shares the hunger for a championship that Tatum, Brown, and the rest of the C's have displayed this season.\n\n\"I think this team really wants to win,\" the 2021 NBA champion said. \"I know they've been to the Eastern Conference Finals a million times. They've been to the Finals. They've been to the top, just didn't execute the way they wanted to. Now that we're here, we want to get the job done.\"", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "daniel_donabedian@clutchpoints.com", {"uri": "2024-06-379858421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:49:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:49:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:45:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/jaylen-brown-bold-predictions-celtics-vs-mavericks-nba-finals", "title": "Jaylen Brown bold predictions for Celtics vs. Mavericks NBA Finals", "body": "Jaylen Brown is in his eighth NBA season, and this will be his second trip to the NBA Finals. His first appearance was a disappointing one, but Brown's improvement has been immense over the past couple of seasons. As a three-time All Star and one-time second-team All-NBA selection, Brown is on the perfect track to capture his first NBA Championship.\n\nThe Boston Celtics will be led by Brown and Jayson Tatum as they are in pursuit of beating the Dallas Mavericks in the 2024 Finals. Brown earned the 2024 Eastern Conference Finals MVP, which was a brilliant feat for the budding star. With all the momentum and confidence on Brown's hands, playing on the court against the Mavericks to wrap up an impeccable campaign will be a fantastic sight for the Celtics fanbase.\n\nIt will be an arduous and grueling series for Brown, but here are a couple of predictions for his 2024 NBA Finals.\n\n*Watch NBA games LIVE with fuboTV (click for a free trial)*\n\nJaylen Brown limits Luka Doncic to less than 40% FG in at least two games\n\nIn the two regular season victories for Boston, Brown was the main man tasked in containing Luka Doncic. He still had an impressive showing against the Celtics, but Brown made him work for a plethora of possessions. The strength and basketball IQ of Doncic is spectacular, thus it makes Brown the best option to try and stay in front of him.\n\nThe Mavericks will have a bevy of schemes to force either Kristaps Porzingis or Al Horford defend Doncic in the perimeter, but the Celtics will have counters to limit these kind of situations. Boston is a squad that has the least tendency to blitz ball handlers on pick-and-roll situations, so let's see how they will contain Doncic. Several defensive options will be great for the Celtics, but it will be a high likelihood for Brown to be the main reason for Doncic's down games.\n\nBrown records 5+ assists for at least three games\n\nJaylen Brown has the reputation of being a ball-dominant individual or for some, he may even be a ball hog. For other NBA pundits, that is one primary reason on why the tandem of Brown and Tatum will not work, but they have proven to excel in their seven seasons together. In both contests against Dallas this year, Brown tallied nine combined assists, so there is an increased likelihood he will average around 3.5-4 APG in the finals.\n\nEven if he is not known as a tremendous playmaker, there will be a myriad of opportunities to dish it off to Derrick White or Jrue Holiday for wide-open corner threes. Moreover, Porzingis will be back and healthy for the finals, which will be a welcome sight for Brown because of the commendable chemistry they have built throughout the season.\n\nBrown scores 30+ points in at least three games\n\nSimilar to the assist totals, Brown's scoring production has been excellent against the Mavericks, and there is a legitimate chance that will continue. Their best perimeter defender will be guarding Tatum for the majority of the night, so Brown will get the second or third-best defender on the floor. In the two outings against the Mavericks this year, Brown eclipsed the 25-point plateau.\n\nElevating that to 30 points in the NBA Finals is a plausible scenario, and the Celtics will need an outstanding series for Brown if they want to win it all. A ton of three-pointers will be attempted in the next series, and that will bring a huge advantage to the offensive firepower of the Celtics.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8163529181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:17:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:17:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:17:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40285650/jayson-tatum-admits-nba-finals-pressure-wants-enjoy-it", "title": "Tatum admits Finals pressure, wants to 'enjoy it'", "body": "BOSTON -- Ahead of appearing in his second NBA Finals Thursday, Celtics star Jayson Tatum was asked if there's a different level of pressure playing for a franchise that is attempting to claim an NBA-record 18th championship banner this month.\n\nHe didn't hesitate in his answer.\n\n\"I mean, you know the answer to that,\" Tatum said during his media availability Wednesday as part of the league's media day. \"Of course.\n\n\"We only hang NBA championship banners, right? 17 of them. Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. All of us are honored to follow in their footsteps, the way they paved for us to live out our dream.\n\n\"Essentially, yeah, if you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. That's what we try to play for every single season. The expectations are obviously different here. It takes special players to be here and to be a part of an environment like that.\"\n\nTatum and the Celtics are more than familiar with the pressures that come with playing here - particularly after knocking on the door so often over the past several years. Since the start of the 2017 playoffs, the Celtics have reached the Eastern Conference finals six times, and are appearing in the league's championship round for a second time in three years.\n\nOver those eight years, Boston has played in more playoff games - 126 - than any other team in NBA history without winning a championship, all while playing for a franchise that's hoping to move past its forever rival, the Los Angeles Lakers, and back into pole position among all teams in terms of titles won.\n\nTatum, though, said he doesn't spend a lot of time thinking about the future, or what winning a title would mean to him.\n\n\"Yeah, honestly, I don't think about the future or what this may mean for me down the road,\" Tatum said. \"As simple as it sounds, just try to stay present, stay in the moment, enjoy it, right? Keep talking about pressure, pressure, pressure... It's the NBA Finals. This s--- is supposed to be fun.\n\n\"That's kind of where I'm at with it. I'm in the NBA Finals. I have a second opportunity to win a championship. I want to enjoy it. I want to enjoy the moment, enjoy it with my teammates and my family.\n\n\"So that's where my narrow focus is at: competing at a high level, finally getting to play tomorrow, just having fun. Just going out there and doing what I love to do.\"\n\nJoining Tatum and the rest of the Celtics on the court will be center Kristaps Porzingis, who confirmed Wednesday that he will make his return in Game 1 of the NBA Finals, more than five weeks after he suffered a calf strain in Game 4 of Boston's first round series victory over the Miami Heat.\n\nPorzingis, who has never played in a playoff game past the first round of the playoffs in his nine NBA seasons, admitted that he is still unsure what his conditioning level is heading into Game 1 after having such an extended layoff.\n\n\"Yeah, I think it's still kinda open,\" Porzingis said. \"It's still not super clear. I haven't had that much time. We'll see tomorrow night, and then go from there.\"\n\nAfter returning to practice Friday, Porzingis said he hasn't been doing too much strenuous work ahead of the Finals, and has had some Kiniseo tape on his lower right leg.\n\n\"I've been keeping it pretty light the last couple of days,\" Porzingis said. \"Just prepping my body, recovering as much as I can right before the game to be in the best shape possible for tomorrow. It's been pretty light. Today's gonna be another light day and, yeah, just prepping for tomorrow.\"\n\nThe Celtics have been preparing for this moment for years, after their many deep forays into the playoffs. They traded for Porzingis and Jrue Holiday last offseason, in the hopes of giving them more offensive versatility deep in the postseason. Boston then won 64 games in the regular season, and put up an equally dominant plus-11.7 net rating - with the gap between the Celtics and Oklahoma City Thunder in second the same as the one between Oklahoma City and the Indiana Pacers in 10th.\n\nThey then tore through the Eastern Conference with a 12-2 record, dispatching the Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers and Pacers in barely more than the minimum number of games required - helped, in part, by Jimmy Butler, Jarrett Allen, Donovan Mitchell and Tyrese Haliburton all missing time with injuries.\n\nNone of it will matter, though, if the Celtics can't finish the job and close the playoffs out with a victory over Dallas.\n\n\"I think this is a special group,\" Jaylen Brown said. \"I really do. The core group of it has been here for a few years now. We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time.\n\n\"I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": For the bulk of the season the Celtics were the class of the Eastern Conference, finishing with a 64-18 record -- the best in the NBA -- and 14 games ahead of the New York Knicks in the East.\n\nThat led many to wonder if the Celtics would be ready for the playoff run, and to many neutral observers, Boston's path to the Finals was a little easier than expected. Boston squared off with the Miami Heat in the first round, but without Jimmy Butler who was lost with an MCL sprain, Miami struggled against Boston.\n\nThen came the Cleveland Cavaliers, who began the series against the Celtics without rim protector Jarrett Allen, who missed the entire series with broken ribs. Add in a knee injury for Donovan Mitchell and you have a 4-1 series win for Boston, who moved on to face the Indiana Pacers in the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nWho were without Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games of that series, as the guard entered the Conference Finals with a groin injury that hampered him in the first two games, and saw him shut down for the final two.\n\nNow they'll take on the Dallas Mavericks, who stormed to the NBA Finals thanks to a tremendous playoff run from Kyrie Irving and Luka Don\u010di\u0107. Don\u010di\u0107 might be playing the best basketball on the planet right now, and in our ranking of the top 15 players in this series, he was a fairly easy choice for the top spot. He has averaged almost a triple-double in the playoffs, averaging 28.8 ppg, 9.6 rpg, and 8.8 apg over Dallas' 17 postseason games. With him, the Mavericks have the best player left standing, even if he is doing it on just one healthy leg as he deals with a knee sprain.\n\nThey also could pose some problems for the Celtics, given their length and athleticism. As outlined above Boston has seen a somewhat easier path to the Finals, but that will change starting Thursday night. Around Don\u010di\u0107 and Irving the Mavericks have players who can frustrate the Boston offense, including P.J. Washington and Derrick Jones Jr.\n\nWashington is big with a massive wingspan, and expect to see him on Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum for most of the series. Jones Jr. is one of the better athletes in the league, who can pose problems both near the rim and around the arc.\n\nDown low Dallas can turn to the combination of Dereck Lively II and Daniel Gafford. The rookie Lively is 7'1, has a massive wingspan, and has been Dallas' third best player on this run. Gafford is another springy rim protector who can disrupt shots and harrass Boston's scorers near the tin.\n\nThose players will need to step up if Dallas has a shot at pulling this off, but in the NBA Finals, anything can happen.\n\nIt all gets started this Thursday. {"uri": "8163007047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "13:45:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T13:45:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T13:44:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/10-nba-players-with-the-most-pressure-in-the-2024-finals/article_738fe8fe-1f4d-5298-aa43-d8cc5d21cae7.html", "title": "10 NBA Players With The Most Pressure In The 2024 Finals", "body": "The 2024 NBA Finals is scheduled for Thursday at 8 PM ET and we are anticipating the most competitive series in the playoffs so far. The Boston Celtics have been the favorite all year since Brad Stevens acquired Jrue Holiday and Kristaps Porzingis, and the Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown-led squad finished with the best record in the NBA (64-18). The Dallas Mavericks, despite doubts, have overcome the odds and made it to the Finals led by the superstar duo of Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving. With so much star power in the Finals, we have named the 10 players with the most pressure.\n\n1. Jayson Tatum\n\nPressure: Prove He Is Good Enough To Lead A Team To A Championship\n\nJayson Tatum's ascension to a top-5 player in the league has been remarkable, but his legacy hinges on his ability to lead the Boston Celtics to an NBA championship. Finishing 5th in MVP voting this year, Tatum has demonstrated his elite skill set and leadership on the court.\n\nWith the Celtics on the brink of capturing their record 18th championship, Tatum has the opportunity to etch his name alongside Celtics legends like Larry Bird, John Havlicek, and Paul Pierce. Winning the Finals MVP would further cement his status as one of the greats, especially if he can deliver when it matters most and make up for his subpar performance in the 2022 Finals when he averaged 21.5 points and 3.8 turnovers per game on 36.7% shooting from the field.\n\nHowever, the stakes are incredibly high. If Tatum fails to perform, the narrative surrounding his career could shift negatively. Critics and fans alike will question his ability to carry a team to the ultimate prize, potentially overshadowing his regular-season accolades and All-Star appearances.\n\nThe pressure is immense, as Tatum's legacy could take a significant hit if he doesn't rise to the occasion. For Tatum, this Finals is more than just about winning a title; it's about proving that he can be the cornerstone of a championship team.\n\n2. Jaylen Brown\n\nPressure: Quiet The Doubts About Him Being A Supermax Player\n\nJaylen Brown's supermax deal, the largest contract of all time, has placed a magnifying glass on his performance, especially in high-stakes games. As an All-Star and All-NBA talent, Brown has faced scrutiny over his ability to deliver in crucial moments.\n\nThis season, he has shown significant improvement, displaying strong handles and exuding confidence on the court. His impressive play earned him the Western Conference Finals MVP when he averaged 29.8 points per game, showcasing his growth and readiness to lead alongside Tatum.\n\nThe 2024 Finals present a pivotal moment for Brown to solidify his worth as a supermax player. A strong performance can silence doubters and validate his place as a key component of Boston's dynamic duo.\n\nConversely, if he falters, questions about his contract and ability to perform under pressure will resurface. This series is Brown's chance to rewrite the narrative from the 2022 Finals (23.5 PPG and 3.3 TOV on 43.1% shooting from the field) and prove that he can be a reliable leader on a championship team.\n\n3. Luka Doncic\n\nPressure: Show The World He Is As Impactful As Larry Bird\n\nLuka Doncic, often compared to Larry Bird, is now at a critical juncture in his career. At 25 years old, Doncic has already established himself as one of the most talented players in the league, but he has yet to secure an NBA title. Bird won his first championship at 24, and the pressure is on Doncic to deliver a similar impact. With an all-time great like Kyrie Irving by his side, Doncic has the support to make a deep playoff run, but the challenge of dethroning the Celtics looms large.\n\nWinning the NBA title and Finals MVP this year would not only validate Doncic's standing among the elite but also solidify his place in Mavericks history, potentially even surpassing Dirk Nowitzki. Achieving these milestones in the same year would elevate Doncic into the conversation of the top 50 players of all time, showcasing his extraordinary talent and competitive drive. This Finals is Doncic's chance to prove that he can lead his team to the ultimate victory and live up to the comparisons with Bird.\n\n4. Kyrie Irving\n\nPressure: Change His Legacy To Win Without LeBron James\n\nKyrie Irving's legacy has long been tied to his 2016 NBA title win alongside LeBron James, where he delivered a historic performance, including the game-winning shot in Game 7 over Stephen Curry. Since then, Irving has struggled to replicate that playoff success, with his teams failing to advance past the second round. Now, back in the Finals, Irving has a golden opportunity to reshape his legacy by winning a championship without LeBron, proving that he can lead a team to glory on his own terms.\n\nA second title would solidify Irving's status as one of the all-time great players, not just an all-time great point guard. It would validate his decision to forge his own path and showcase his ability to thrive under pressure. Failing to deliver, however, would reinforce the narrative that his success was largely dependent on LeBron, potentially diminishing his career achievements.\n\n5. Kristaps Porzingis\n\nPressure: Become The Missing Piece Of A Championship Puzzle\n\nKristaps Porzingis has experienced a rollercoaster career, from being a highly touted draft pick to dealing with significant injuries and a tumultuous exit from Dallas. Now with the Boston Celtics, Porzingis has a chance to reinvent himself and prove that he can be the missing piece in a championship-winning team. His unique combination of size, skill, and shooting ability makes him a valuable asset, and Boston's league-best record this season underscores the potential impact he can have.\n\nPorzingis hasn't played in the last two rounds of the playoffs due to injury, but his return for the Finals could be a game-changer. At 7'4\" with exceptional offensive skills, he has the ability to stretch the floor and create mismatches.\n\nA strong performance in the Finals would not only help Boston secure their 18th championship but also re-establish Porzingis as a star in the league. Conversely, if he underperforms, questions about his durability and consistency will continue to haunt him. This Finals is a pivotal moment for Porzingis to prove his worth and help Boston achieve their championship aspirations.\n\n6. Jrue Holiday\n\nPressure: Make His Hall Of Fame Case\n\nJrue Holiday has long been regarded as one of the best two-way guards in the NBA, known for his defensive prowess and clutch performances. Despite his impressive resume, which includes a 2021 NBA title with the Bucks, two All-Star selections, and six All-Defensive Team honors, Holiday's Hall of Fame case remains to be determined. Winning a second championship, especially as a key contributor to two different teams, would significantly bolster his candidacy.\n\nHoliday's impact on both ends of the floor cannot be overstated. His ability to guard multiple positions and contribute offensively makes him an invaluable asset for the Celtics. A standout performance in the Finals would further highlight his importance to winning teams and strengthen his Hall of Fame credentials.\n\n7. Derrick White\n\nPressure: Make Himself Untouchable On A Title-Contending Team\n\nSince joining the Boston Celtics, Derrick White has transformed into a crucial player, showcasing his defensive prowess and improving his offensive game. Learning under Gregg Popovich with the Spurs, White developed a strong foundation in winning basketball, which he has carried into his role with the Celtics. Making two All-Defensive Teams, he has proven his value as a two-way guard capable of making significant contributions on both ends of the floor.\n\nThe 2024 Finals present White with a chance to further cement his place in Boston's rotation and make himself untouchable on a title-contending team. His ability to impact the game defensively and provide timely scoring can be pivotal in a championship run. A strong performance in the Finals would solidify his reputation as an all-time great role player for the Celtics franchise, ensuring his place in their future plans.\n\n8. Al Horford\n\nPressure: Win One NBA Championship Before Eventual Retirement\n\nAl Horford's illustrious career includes five All-Star appearances, an All-NBA Third Team selection, and a spot on the All-Defensive Second Team. Despite his numerous individual accolades and a previous Finals appearance with the Celtics, Horford has yet to capture an NBA championship. At 38 years old, time is running out for the veteran big man to add a title to his resume, and this year's Finals may represent his best chance.\n\nWinning a championship would solidify Horford's legacy as an exceptional role player and leader in Boston's storied history. His experience, leadership, and defensive acumen have been invaluable to the Celtics' success, and a title would be the crowning achievement of his career. On the flip side, failing to win a championship could leave Horford's career feeling incomplete, despite his numerous accomplishments.\n\n9. P.J. Washington\n\nPressure: Confirm His Place Alongside Luka Doncic And Kyrie Irving As Third Option\n\nPJ Washington has stepped up significantly this postseason, averaging 13.6 points per game and making crucial shots for the Dallas Mavericks. As the team looks to build around Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving for the foreseeable future, Washington has the chance to solidify his role as the third option. His offensive aggression and ability to hit timely shots have been pivotal in the Mavericks' journey to the Finals.\n\nA strong performance in the Finals would confirm Washington's place alongside Doncic and Irving, ensuring his role as a key contributor moving forward. His ability to complement the star duo with his scoring and versatility can make him an indispensable part of the Mavericks' success. Conversely, an underwhelming showing could lead to doubts about his fit and future with the team.\n\n10. Daniel Gafford\n\nPressure: Take Over The Starting Center Role\n\nDaniel Gafford has quietly developed into a reliable player over the past three years, particularly shining since joining the Mavericks. Known for his athleticism, aggressiveness, and tenacity around the rim, Gafford has the potential to become the long-term solution at the center position for Dallas. His ability to rebound, defend, and finish at the rim makes him a valuable asset for the team.\n\nA strong showing in the Finals would bolster Gafford's case to take over the starting center role permanently. His performance on the biggest stage can showcase his growth and readiness to handle more responsibility. On the other hand, if he struggles, it may raise questions about his consistency and ability to perform under pressure. For Gafford, this series is a crucial opportunity to prove that he can be a cornerstone of the Mavericks' future and solidify his place in their lineup.\n\nRelated: 2024 NBA Finals: Celtics vs. Mavericks (Analysis, Comparison, Prediction)\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3176470588235294, "wgt": 157, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-380181143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:52:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:52:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-06-05/redemption-minded-celtics-set-to-match-up-with-opportunistic-mavericks-in-nba-finals", "title": "Redemption-Minded Celtics Set to Match up With Opportunistic Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey'll matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favorite to raise the franchise's 18th championship banner entering the postseason.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nThey've also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw longtime emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favor of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nCOACHING PERSPECTIVES\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nFRIENDS AND COMPETITORS\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston's home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nCeltics fans haven't held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn's first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\n\"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8163662851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:36:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:36:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:35:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/sport/518803/favoured-celtics-battle-doncic-and-the-mavericks-in-nba-finals", "title": "Favoured Celtics battle Doncic and the Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "A Celtics team desperate for championship glory face Luka Doncic and a Dallas Mavericks squad eager to play spoiler in an intriguing NBA Finals matchup that tips off Friday (NZ time) in Boston.\n\nLed by superstars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the sharpshooting Celtics have had a relatively easy road to the finals.\n\nComing out of the weaker Eastern Conference as the top seed, they breezed past the Jimmy Butler-less Miami Heat, dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers and swept the Indiana Pacers, who were without point guard Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games.\n\nThe Celtics have won 12 of their 14 playoff games and gone undefeated on the road but they know that none of that will matter if they fail to end a title drought that stretches back to 2008.\n\nThe mission is clear - hang that elusive 18th championship banner from the TD Garden rafters and put recent postseason disappointment, including falling to the Warriors in the 2022 finals and coming up short in the conference finals last year, firmly behind them.\n\nAnything less will be seen as a bitter disappointment.\n\n\"They were the best team in the regular season and they have been the best team in the playoffs,\" former player and current ESPN analyst J J Redick said on a call with reporters.\n\n\"I feel strongly that they are the favourites going into this series. At the same time, I wouldn't be surprised if Luka and Dallas and Kyrie (Irving) and (head coach Jason Kidd) made this a series and won... This is going to be a phenomenal series.\"\n\nStanding in Boston's way is a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin the Celtics' title aspirations.\n\nThat starts with Doncic, the 25-year-old Slovenian who is quickly becoming the face of the league.\n\nHe has been the best player in the playoffs and is the first to lead in points (489), rebounds (164) and assists (150) coming into a finals.\n\nBy his side is veteran point guard Irving who, after turbulent stints in Brooklyn and Boston, has looked more comfortable and confident on the court than he has in years.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that offensively they are as talented as any backcourt in NBA history,\" Redick said of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne big, 7-foot 2-inch (2.1 metres) question mark hanging over the series is the health of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis, the former Maverick who suffered a calf strain in the Heat series and has been sidelined since.\n\nThe Celtics are hopeful that their prized offseason acquisition, who averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks during the regular season, will be healthy enough to match up against the Mavs' breakout big men Daniel {"uri": "2024-06-379086359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "03:44:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T03:44:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T03:44:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://cebudailynews.inquirer.net/577016/celtics-tatum-brown-feel-better-equipped-to-tackle-2nd-chance-in-nba-finals", "title": "Celtics' Tatum, Brown feel better equipped to tackle 2nd chance in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON -- For almost the entirety of their time together in Boston, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been linked.\n\nThey were drafted by the Celtics third overall in back-to-back years.\n\nThey possess similar skillsets -- two explosive and skilled wing players with an ability to score from nearly every spot on the court.\n\nAnd they both have been central to the success of a Celtics team that has reached the NBA Finals for the second time in three seasons. It helped Brown earn the NBA's first $300 million contract last summer. And, Tatum is expected to get one this offseason.\n\nThe team has branded the All-Stars as \"The Jays\" in a marketing campaign shown during games that pitted them against one another in mini competitions.\n\nIt has created natural comparisons between them along the way, fostering an atmosphere in which fans and sports pundits alike have tried to parse out which one of them is better, whose spot is most untouchable on the roster and which of them is more pivotal to the Celtics' success as they prepare to lead the team to the franchise's 18th NBA title.\n\nIt reached a new level last week during a segment on ESPN's \"Get Up\" in which panelists debated whether the 26-year-old Tatum expressed excitement or disappointment while watching the 27-year-old Brown garner Eastern Conference finals MVP honors.\n\n\"I think it's unfair to both of them,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said of what he viewed as an attempt to manufacture friction between the two stars.\n\nBut even as Tatum and Brown have distinguished themselves as the most important players on Boston's roster and the keys to the Celtics' fate in their NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, Mazzulla has hope that people will start viewing them differently.\n\n\"They're, like, two completely different people. They're two completely different players,\" Mazzulla said. \"They're great teammates, they love each other and they go about winning and they go about their process in a different way. Why they have to always be lumped together I think is unfair.\"\n\nStepping up\n\nTatum and Brown, along with Al Horford, are the only returning starters from the 2021-22 team that lost to the Golden State Warriors in six games in the Finals after holding a 2-1 series lead.\n\nWhile Horford has taken on mostly a reserve role this season, backing up 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis, Tatum and Brown have taken their play up a notch.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n\"Obviously, we've been there before, we came up short,\" Tatum said.\n\nAnd being each other's biggest cheerleaders, too.\n\nAfter Brown made a game-tying 3-pointer late in Game 1 of the conference finals matchup with Indiana to send the game to overtime in an eventual Celtics' victory, the highest praise came from Tatum.\n\n\"Big time players make big time plays,\" Tatum said of Brown.\n\nMotivation\n\nFor Brown, this season has been about focusing on the expectations he has for himself and not worrying about others' perception of him.\n\nInitially, when he was asked about not being included on either the All-NBA or All-Defensive teams, he shrugged it off, saying his attention was focused on getting back to the NBA Finals.\n\nAfter he was named conference finals MVP, he acknowledged it did offer at least some motivation, particularly on the defensive side of the ball which he said he put most of his work into this past offseason.\n\n\"As time has gone by and I got to this point, I stopped caring,\" Brown said.\n\nMazzulla believes the reason the relationship between Brown and Tatum is so often talked about is rooted in outside disbelief that their dynamic doesn't breed any rivalry between them.\n\n\"At the end of the day, like, those two guys, their relationship is their relationship,\" Mazzulla said. \"They love each other. They push each other every single day in practice. They communicate with each other, but they go about it differently. And, I think they both get it unfair being compared to each other. They're different. And we see other duos around the league don't have to go through that. ... It's because they've been so successful their entire careers, they've been able to for so long stay in success at a high level.\"", "source": {"uri": "cebudailynews.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8164098335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:31:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:31:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:30:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/nba/mission-clear-favored-boston-celtics-against-upset-conscious-dallas-mavericks-2024-finals/", "title": "Mission clear for favored Celtics against upset-conscious Mavs", "body": "After a relatively easy road to the NBA Finals, the Celtics brace for a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin their title aspirations\n\nA Celtics team desperate for championship glory face Luka Doncic and a Dallas Mavericks squad eager to play spoiler in an intriguing NBA Finals matchup that tips off in Boston Thursday, June 6 (Friday, June 7, Manila time).\n\nLed by superstars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the sharpshooting Celtics have had a relatively easy road to the finals.\n\nComing out of the weaker Eastern Conference as the top seed, they breezed past the Jimmy Butler-less Miami Heat, dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers, and swept the Indiana Pacers, who were without point guard Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games.\n\nThe Celtics have won 12 of their 14 playoff games and gone undefeated on the road, but they know that none of that will matter if they fail to end a title drought that stretches back to 2008.\n\nThe mission is clear - hang that elusive 18th championship banner from the TD Garden rafters and put recent postseason disappointment, including falling to the Warriors in the 2022 finals and coming up short in the conference finals last year, firmly behind them.\n\nAnything less will be seen as a bitter disappointment.\n\n\"They were the best team in the regular season and they have been the best team in the playoffs,\" former player and current ESPN analyst JJ Redick said on a call with reporters.\n\n\"I feel strongly that they are the favorites going into this series. At the same time, I wouldn't be surprised if Luka and Dallas and Kyrie (Irving) and [head coach Jason Kidd] made this a series and won... This is going to be a phenomenal series.\"\n\nStanding in Boston's way is a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin the Celtics' title aspirations.\n\nThat starts with Doncic, the 25-year-old Slovenian who is quickly becoming the face of the league.\n\nHe has been the best player in the playoffs and is the first to lead in points (489), rebounds (164), and assists (150) coming into a finals.\n\nBy his side is veteran point guard Irving who, after turbulent stints in Brooklyn and Boston, has looked more comfortable and confident on the court than he has in years.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that offensively they are as talented as any backcourt in NBA history,\" Redick said of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne big, 7-foot 2-inch question mark hanging over the series is the health of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis, the former Maverick who suffered a calf strain in the Heat series and has been sidelined since.\n\nThe Celtics are hopeful that their prized offseason acquisition, who averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks during the regular season, will be healthy enough to match up against the Mavs' breakout big men Daniel Gafford and As such, Thomas likely sees the Mavericks as having a significant advantage heading into their series.\n\nTatum and Brown play both sides of the ball. They are not only elite scorers and playmakers but also defend at an elite level and can rebound with the best of them. That is why the Celtics are such a formidable opponent; you can't exploit them on either side of the floor.\n\nThe Celtics will enter the Finals as heavy favorites to win a championship, regardless of what Thomas thinks. {"uri": "8164055329", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:58:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:58:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:57:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/basketball/nba-finals-2023-24-tatum-brown-boston-celtics-title-chance-vs-dallas-mavericks-playoffs-news/article68258006.ece", "title": "NBA Finals 2023-24: Celtics' Tatum, Brown hungry for crown after 2022 failure", "body": "A historic championship legacy and a gut-wrenching 2022 finals loss have the Boston Celtics extra motivated to capture their its title since 2008 in this year's NBA Finals.\n\nThe Celtics will play host to the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday in the opener of the best-of-seven series, with stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown excited about their trophy chances after falling to Golden State in the 2022 finals.\n\n\"I hate that we had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" Tatum said Wednesday. \"But I'm a firm believer that everything happens for a reason. There's a lesson to be learned in every situation.\n\n\"I do feel a lot different this time. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done. I told myself if I ever got the opportunity again to make it to the finals, never take it for granted. We're here now and I'm excited to get ready to play and have fun.\"\n\nALSO READ | NBA Finals 2023-24: Doncic, Irving lead Mavericks to finals with poise, skill\n\nBrown said he has watched the 2022 finals several times to learn how to better manage his emotions and to make better decisions on the court.\n\n\"You learn and grow from your experiences,\" Brown said. \"Two years later makes a pretty big difference.\n\n\"This is a special group. The core group has been here for a few years now. We've been able to go through experiences, having success but not having success at the same time.\n\n\"The ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy as a team, but as of right now, that story is still kind of untold.\"\n\nAnother factor is that the Celtics seek an unprecedented 18th NBA crown, one more than the all-time record they share with the rival Los Angeles Lakers.\n\n\"Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. We're honored to follow in their footsteps. They paved the way for us to live out our dreams,\" said Tatum.\n\n\"If you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. It takes special players to be part of an environment like that.\"\n\nALSO READ | NBA Playoffs 2023-24, East Conference finals: Celtics rally late again to close out Pacers for 4-0 sweep\n\nOne of those is Jrue Holiday, who won a 2021 NBA title with Milwaukee and was obtained in a trade deal just before the season began.\n\n\"To be a part of history would be cool, the history the Celtics have,\" Holiday said. \"To add to that is part of the reason I was brought here -- and part of the reason I wanted to come.\"\n\n'The will to win'\n\nThe defensive standout sees something special in the Celtics, who led the NBA with 64 wins this season.\n\n\"The pressure JB (Jaylen Brown) and JT (Jayson Taytum) have to take on is something different,\" Holiday said. \"It's really impressive how they handle themselves.\n\n\"I know sometimes talent doesn't mesh together but this does. You saw it in the regular season. You've seen it in the playoffs. Any given night we sacrifice for each other. We're unselfish and I think that's what makes it go.\"\n\n\"And then it's just the will to win. They've been to the Eastern Conference finals a million times and they have been to the finals so they've been to the top, just didn't execute the way they wanted. Now that we're here, we want to get the job done.\"\n\nTatum appreciates the finals more after losing to Miami in seven games in last year's East finals.\n\n\"Last year we took that for granted and we didn't make it to the finals. (It) put things in prespective,\" Tatum said.\n\n\"You could see our excitement when we won the conference (this year). That's not the be-all, end-all but it really is tough to get to this moment.\n\n\"I'm staying in the moment. I'm not thinking of what this would mean to my legacy or anything like that. Excited to go out and get the job done.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarNBA Finals 2023-24: Celtics' Tatum, Brown hungry for crown after 2022 failure AFPSunil Chhetri farewell: A year-by-year breakdown of the
