{"uri": "8163267600", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:38:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:38:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:35:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/celtics-jayson-tatum-nba-finals-silence-critics/", "title": "Will Jayson Tatum Finally Silence His Critics in the NBA Finals?", "body": "Jayson Tatum gets his opportunity to earn his respect and get redemption for the criticism he has received throughout his career.\n\nHighlights Tatum's playoff experience is valuable; history shows he's ahead of the curve in pursuit of a title. Despite criticism, Tatum's actions speak volumes about how he understands team dynamics and leads by example. Tatum's ability to showcase leadership and adjust his style depending on the team's needs has benefited the Celtics.\n\nOver the past few seasons, the Boston Celtics have come very close to capturing their first NBA title since 2008. They have earned another chance to win the franchise's 18th championship as they prepare to take on the Dallas Mavericks in what should be an exciting and thrilling NBA Finals.\n\nThe Celtics last NBA Finals appearance came back in 2022, and after losing that series, there is much to be desired after coming so close for so many seasons. The Celtics have reached the Eastern Conference Finals six times since the 2016-17 season, and many critics believe that they should have won multiple titles within that span.\n\nWhenever NBA teams are expected to achieve greatness, and whenever players fail to meet lofty expectations, fingers begin being pointed at certain individuals and are often blamed for the team's failures. Celtics all-star forward Jayson Tatum has been a victim of criticism every time the team is eliminated from the postseason.\n\nSome of that criticism is warranted and fair, and some isn't, but that's what comes with being a superstar in today's NBA. Tatum now has another shot to change the narrative of how he can't get his team over the hump, and that he isn't good enough to be the leader of a title-contending team.\n\nTatum Is Ahead of the Curve According to History Due to past playoff failures, Tatum's experience will be invaluable in the Finals.\n\nThere are a few things that Tatum should be able to use to his advantage during this series. Many athletes tend to block out the noise around them when preparing for a championship. No television, no social media and no internet is the route that most players take when trying to remain focused and locked in.\n\nDespite what they say about Tatum, and even if he's tuning everything out, he still knows and understands that he will be the topic of many conversations based on his performance in the Finals.\n\nIf Tatum happens to rise above everyone's expectations, wins the NBA title, and takes home MVP honors in the process, there should be plenty of admissions about being wrong about him. The critics fail to realize that he has done everything other superstars around the league have already done.\n\nThe only thing missing from Tatum's resume is a championship, but he has a history of not completing the job in the postseason, which is a reputation he would rather not be remembered for. There are a lot of critics who want Tatum to prove that he is worth the hype, and they just want to see him elevate his game when it matters most.\n\nIf Tatum had led the Celtics to the title two years ago when he was 24 years old, it would have been a rare occasion (other than Magic Johnson, who won a title during his rookie season with the Los Angeles Lakers) for a player that young to be able to lead his team to a championship.\n\nHe has had unrealistic expectations placed on him, and until he wins a title, those expectations will remain with him. If we look at some of the superstars who won a title and at the age they won it, Tatum is not so far off.\n\nNBA Superstars Age at Time of First Title\n\nPlayer/Team\n\nSeasons\n\nAge\n\nMichael Jordan/CHI\n\n7\n\n28\n\nLeBron James/MIA\n\n9\n\n27\n\nKevin Durant/GSW\n\n10\n\n28\n\nSteph Curry/GSW\n\n7\n\n27\n\nShaquille O'Neal/LAL\n\n8\n\n28\n\nDirk Nowitzki/DAL\n\n13\n\n32\n\nTatum has been a fantastic performer in the postseason other than the NBA Finals, which they lost to the Golden State Warriors. Even though he's gotten deep into the playoffs almost every year of his career, it's scary to know that Tatum is just now entering his prime years.\n\nIf the Celtics win it all this time and get to taste that champagne and the sweet success of victory, the rest of the league could have trouble on their hands with this team for the next couple of years.\n\nTatum's Understanding That Team is Bigger Than Him Leads Celtics to Finals Although his ability to lead has been questioned, Tatum allows his actions to speak for him instead.\n\nThe narrative that Tatum chokes in big games was created by one horrible series against the Warriors on the biggest stage. Unlike many other talented young players, Tatum has not been afforded the luxury of low expectations. He has been blessed to be on a contending team almost every year of his career, and with that came unprecedented playoff success but also higher expectations and scrutiny whenever the Celtics lose.\n\nTatum often gets the most flagrant attention due to the reputation he's earned. Despite what negativity the media spews about him, Tatum has proved to be an elite player who will embarrass a team if he goes unaccounted for. He is double-teamed more often than the average superstar and faces more pressure at the rim.\n\nTatum's biggest flaw at times is when he tries to do too much when he doesn't have to by resorting to hero ball, resulting in stopping the ball movement at inopportune times within the game. That may result from Tatum trying too hard to prove the pundits wrong, but he is a much more efficient player whenever he takes advantage of the team he is surrounded by.\n\nAnother issue that Tatum is often criticized for is his lack of leadership. He will indeed disappear at times, but his leadership shouldn't be questioned. It's never been an issue within the Celtics organization, especially when you have a franchise player who leads the team on deep playoff runs consistently.\n\nAt the end of the day, basketball is a team sport and the Celtics are the best team in the NBA. If Tatum played on another team, it's obvious that his numbers would skyrocket, and he would be at the top of the conversation for league MVP after every season.\n\nThe Celtics are competing for a title, so they take a different approach from other teams. Tatum could be selfish to inflate his stats, but that wouldn't benefit the team by him achieving individual goals. Many talented players surround him, and he is playing with four other All-Star-caliber players.\n\nTatum has never had to carry a team like other stars in the same position have had to. That scenario works out perfectly for the Celtics because it gives Tatum a higher margin for error because even if he has an off night, his team can still pick up the slack and rise to the occasion.\n\nRelated Jayson Tatum's Defense for Celtics a Key to Storyline To Watch in NBA Finals Jayson Tatum's defense for the Boston Celtics may be flying a bit under the radar right now.", That's kind of cool to see because when you look at Kai and Luka, a lot of times they're not known as our defensive guys.\"\n\nIrving and Doncic scored 36 points apiece in the clincher against the Wolves, both shooting better than 50% and combining to make half their 3-pointers.\n\nThe Mavs didn't need double figures from anybody off the bench, and barely from the other starters.\n\nThey can make that formula work, with at least some help.\n\nP.J. Washington Jr. will draw the difficult defensive assignments against Boston co-stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. But the midseason acquisition needs to shoot closer to the 47% from 3-point range that he did in the second-round victory over top-seeded Oklahoma City than the 25% he shot against Minnesota.\n\nThe other defense-first starter and key figure in trying to slow Tatum and Brown, Derrick Jones Jr., could provide a boost by matching his 40% shooting from 3 in these playoffs.\n\nThen there's the rim-protecting, pick-and-rolling tandem of centers Daniel Gafford -- the other midseason trade pickup along with Washington -- and rookie Dereck Lively II.\n\nThose two give Dallas an edge over the Celtics, who have a more perimeter-oriented pairing in Kristaps Porzingis and the undersized Al Horford.\n\nBoston also isn't sure what it will get out of Porzingis with the 7-foot-2 Latvian sidelined since the first round by a calf injury.\n\nThe Celtics get the edge in late-playoff experience, but not by much.\n\nThey are on a three-year run of reaching the East finals and made the NBA Finals in 2022, losing to Golden State in six games after the Warriors beat Dallas in the West finals.\n\nIrving, however, has the most experience in the series on the NBA's biggest stage, with 13 games in the finals. He ranks eighth among players with at least 10 games with a scoring average of 27.7 points.\n\nDoncic doesn't figure to be spooked by his first NBA Finals. The 25-year-old was playing professionally in Spain a decade ago and was the title-winning EuroLeague MVP days before getting drafted third overall in 2018.\n\nHe also is the reason Slovenia reached That doesn't reflect Boston entering the championship stage as a -210 favorite on DraftKings Sportsbook.\n\nHowever, everyone agrees that the Finals won't be short. Each expert picked the series to go six or seven games.\n\nEvery Celtics backer identified Jayson Tatum as their Finals MVP. Seven people chose Luka Doncic, and two selected Kyrie Irving.\n\nDespite missing Kristaps Porzingis, Boston cruised through the Eastern Conference with little opposition. Facing the Miami Heat without Jimmy Butler, they notched all four wins by double-digits in a five-game set.\n\nThe No. 1 seed caught another break when Donovan Mitchell missed the final two games of their second-round series. Boston dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers in five, averaging a 15-point victory margin.\n\nThe Celtics cemented their second Eastern Conference crown in the last three years by sweeping the No. 6 seeded Indiana Pacers. Joe Mazzulla's squad took Game 1 in overtime and won the final two matchups by three points each.\n\nOn the other hand, the Mavericks faced a tougher path to the Finals. {"uri": "2024-06-380463907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:51:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:51:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:20:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/celtics-news-tom-brady-nba-finals-hype-video-will-have-fans-pitying-mavericks", "title": "Tom Brady's NBA Finals hype video will have Celtics fans pitying Mavericks", "body": "\"We Want Boston!\" are the chants that the Boston Celtics received heading into the NBA Finals. Other forms of vitriol were also hurled at the Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown-led squad. Some have said that their regular season did not matter while others have come to declare that their postseason run has been fraudulent due to the injuries in other teams. Time and again they have been able to suppress these criticisms. Now, they are just four wins against the Dallas Mavericks from reaching their 18th banner. No one else was fit to hype them up than New England Patriots legend Tom Brady.\n\nThe Celtics got Tom Brady to narrate their pre-NBA Finals hype video. It chronicles the journey that Joe Mazzulla's squad had to undergo. First was taking care of the Miami Heat despite the unfortunate injury to Kristaps Porzingis. Then, getting the work done against the Cleveland Cavaliers as Derrick White and Al Horford stepped up. After that, it was sweeping an Indiana Pacers squad that clawed their way up to the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nDespite all of this, there has still been a lot of disrespect coming towards the Celtics' way. Made-up narratives about how Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown are not meshing. The fact that the Mavericks are supposedly a better squad but are set to have the lowest regular season win total among champions if they do win the NBA Finals. All of that and more has been heard around the world despite the efforts that the Celtics have put in.\n\nTired of the Celtics disrespect?\n\nMaybe it's just the disrespect because the city that the Celtics are situated in is just too competitive. After all, Tom Brady and the Patriots experienced the exact same thing when they were ravaging the NFL. The Boston Red Sox also had to hear all of this talk and unsolicited criticism during their World Series runs. It might just come with the territory.\n\nBut, none of these are warranted and the Celtics are ready to show why. They are a 64-win regular season squad for a season and have not gotten a losing record in a span of 10 games throughout the past eight months. Their offense which is rated at 123.2 is the best in the league. Moreover, the defensive intensity that they also give out ranks them third in the league with a 111.6 rating.\n\nAs for individual performances, Jayson Tatum is top 10 in the postseason when it comes to points, rebounds, and assists. Jaylen Brown is just coming off a steaming hot performance that got him an Eastern Conference Finals Most Valuable Player trophy. Derrick White, Jrue Holiday, and Al Horford have all been able to sustain their energy from the start to the clutch. Meanwhile, Kristaps Porzingis is also poised to make a return.\n\nThere are big expectations for the Celtics but even meaner demons to exorcise. They have seven games against the Mavericks to dispel all of these negative and baseless notions. {"uri": "8161823499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "21:36:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T21:36:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T21:35:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.covers.com/nba/finals/5-series-bets-to-make-ahead-of-game-1-2024", "title": "NBA Finals Props: 5 Series Bets You Need to Make Ahead of Game 1", "body": "The NBA Finals series prices are arguably the sharpest numbers of the entire NBA season. The Game 1 spread favoring the Boston Celtics by 6.5 belongs in the same argument, no matter any Dallas Mavericks' objections.\n\nBut there are an abundance of other markets before this series begins, ones that fit into Mavs vs. Celtics predictions.\n\nTarget some of these NBA picks before the NBA Finals tip on Thursday, June 6, and they should make the entire series more entertaining.\n\nJayson Tatum on The Glass\n\nThe Boston Celtics may have two traditional -- well, traditional-ish -- big men in Al Horford and Kristaps Porzingis, but Jayson Tatum has always been their best rebounder. Start with the simple reality of the regular season: Tatum led Boston with 8.1 rebounds per game, nearly a board more per game than Porzingis and almost two compared to Horford.\n\nTatum emphasizes his all-around game in the postseason, averaging 10.4 rebounds, well ahead of Horford's 7.3. With Porzingis returning from a soleus strain, expectations of his leaping ability should be limited. So there is little worry Tatum will not lead the Celtics in rebounds.\n\nLooking at Dallas's postseason numbers, Tatum's only genuine worry should be Luka Doncic. Dereck Lively II is No. 2 among Mavericks on the glass through three rounds, grabbing 7.2 per game. Meanwhile, Doncic has hovered at 9.6.\n\nThose numbers alone should embolden a Tatum bet. In each of the last two postseasons -- 20 games last year, 14 thus far this year -- Tatum has averaged well more than 10 rebounds per game.\n\nAt -180, betting Tatum to grab more rebounds than Doncic (at DraftKings) may seem tempting, but the greater value can be found betting Tatum to lead the series in rebounds.\n\nEntering the Finals, Derrick White may be considered an X-Factor. By the end of it, he may be seen as the key to Boston's success.\n\nWith Porzingis sidelined for the bulk of three rounds, White's usage rate has ticked upward to 20.3%, compared to 18.7% in the regular season. That has not entirely been because of Porzingis's absence. Among genuine Celtics contributors, only Jaylen Brown's (+0.5%) and Al Horford's (+1.8%) usage rates have also gone up. Horford's is obviously tied to Porzingis's absence. Brown's small jump could be chalked up to sample size.\n\nWhite's, however, is rising to the playoff moment. In the regular season, he took 6.8 threes per game. In the last 11 games, he has taken 9 per game, making 40.4% of them.\n\nYet, Luka Doncic sits at +110 to lead the series in 3-pointers.\n\nWhite has been hitting more 3s per game than Doncic has. And he will be the loose piece of Boston's offense, quite possibly with Doncic defending him. If not Doncic, then Kyrie Irving. Meanwhile, Doncic will be going against Jayson Tatum, Jaylen Brown, or Jrue Holiday.\n\nNot to be dramatic, but this may be a legacy-making series for Kyrie Irving. Winning one NBA Finals was impressive, particularly given the game-winner he hit in Game 7. But Irving has been adrift since that 2016 glory, and LeBron James did most of the heavy lifting in that series.\n\nWinning another ring nearly a decade later, against a team that he had an ugly split with, would strengthen Irving's case as an on-court legend in the modern NBA rather than a locker-room cancer that blew up three franchises since his only championship.\n\nIrving deserves every ounce of criticism he gets, but when the games matter most, his game elevates. Three times in his last four postseasons, including this one, Irving has averaged more than five assists.\n\nAgainst Minnesota last round, Irving averaged 4.6 assists. The round before that, he hummed at 6.2 against the Thunder. On a per-game basis this postseason, Boston has given up more assists to opponents than either of those Western Conference defenses.\n\nThis bet does not offer a massive payday, but Irving will have the ball in his hands more than any Maverick not named Doncic. In years past, he has turned that into assists in the postseason.\n\nMaybe this is not the smartest bet. It will be the most fun. At this point, some fun is defensible.\n\nThere are two versions of this bet, and both of them look at Luka Doncic as bringing value.\n\nBetting on the more conservative approach, that there will be at least one overtime in this series, is betting on a close game to remain tense.\n\nYour instinct may be to look at Game 1's 6.5-point spread as a reason to scoff at this thought, but consider what the spread should be in Dallas in Games 3 and 4. The shift in the home venue alone should bring the spread within a bucket, if not to Boston by 1.5 or 2.\n\nBetting on at least one overtime does not sound as illogical now, does it?\n\nIf nothing else, you can cheer for more basketball, and with so little basketball left in this NBA season, we should all cheer for more basketball.", "source": {"uri": "covers.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8163236836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:14:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:14:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:13:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/nba/luka-doncic-kyrie-irving-look-to-topple-favoured-boston-celtics-as-nba-finals-open-on-tsn-1.2130567", "title": "Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving look to topple favoured Boston Celtics as NBA Finals open on TSN | TSN", "body": "Kyrie Irving scored nine points in the final 3 1/2 minutes of the first half, pushing the lead to 29 on the way to a gaping 36-point margin in the 124-103 victory in Game 5.\n\nWhen the co-stars of the Mavericks are playing that way, there might not be a team in the NBA that can beat them.\n\nDallas, the fifth seed in the West, will need more than one such game in the NBA Finals against the favored Boston Celtics, who had the league's best record by seven games and swept the two-game season series.\n\nWatch Game 1 of the NBA Finals LIVE Thursday night at 8:30 p.m. ET/5:30 p.m. PT on TSN4, TSN5, TSN.ca and the TSN App.\n\nThe Mavs -- this deep in the playoffs for the first time since winning the franchise's only championship in 2011 -- also will need the defensive intensity both offensive wizards have shown in these playoffs.\n\n\"It's a beautiful combination,\" coach Jason Kidd said. \"They're in competition right now of who's playing the best defense. That's kind of cool to see because when you look at Kai and Luka, a lot of times they're not known as our defensive guys.\"\n\nIrving and Doncic scored 36 points apiece in the clincher against the Wolves, both shooting better than 50% and combining to make half their 3-pointers.\n\nThe Mavs didn't need double figures from anybody off the bench, and barely from the other starters.\n\nThey can make that formula work, with at least some help.\n\nP.J. Washington Jr. will draw the difficult defensive assignments against Boston co-stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. But the midseason acquisition needs to shoot closer to the 47% from 3-point range that he did in the second-round victory over top-seeded Oklahoma City than the 25% he shot against Minnesota.\n\nThe other defense-first starter and key figure in trying to slow Tatum and Brown, Derrick Jones Jr., could provide a boost by matching his 40% shooting from 3 in these playoffs.\n\nThen there's the rim-protecting, pick-and-rolling tandem of centers Daniel Gafford -- the other midseason trade pickup along with Washington -- and rookie Dereck Lively II.\n\nThose two give Dallas an edge over the Celtics, who have a more perimeter-oriented pairing in Kristaps Porzingis and the undersized Al Horford.\n\nBoston also isn't sure what it will get out of Porzingis with the 7-foot-2 Latvian sidelined since the first round by a calf injury.\n\nThe Celtics get the edge in late-playoff experience, but not by much.\n\nThey are on a three-year run of reaching the East finals and made the NBA Finals in 2022, losing to Golden State in six games after the Warriors beat Dallas in the West finals.\n\nIrving, however, has the most experience in the series on the NBA's biggest stage, with 13 games in the finals. He ranks eighth among players with at least 10 games with a scoring average of 27.7 points.\n\nDoncic doesn't figure to be spooked by his first NBA Finals. The 25-year-old was playing professionally in Spain a decade ago and was the title-winning EuroLeague MVP days before getting drafted third overall in 2018.\n\nHe also is the reason Slovenia reached {"uri": "8164932517", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:13:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:13:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:12:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/06/nba-finals-live-stream-guide-how-to-watch-dallas-mavericks-vs-boston-celtics-without-cable.html", "title": "NBA Finals live stream guide: How to watch Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics without cable", "body": "HOW TO WATCH: Fans can watch the Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics NBA Finals series via free trials to DirecTV Stream and fuboTV. You can also watch via a subscription to Sling TV, which is offering $25 off any package for the first month or a three-month subscription for just $90.\n\nHere are the top three NBA Finals streaming options:\n\n1. DirecTV Stream (FREE TRIAL)\n\nDirecTV Stream is good option for NBA fans since it carries every channel. Fans can try it for free using this link.\n\n2. SlingTV\n\nSlingTV, which is offering $25 off any package for the first month or a three-month subscription for just $90, offers good value for NBA Fans. Sling's channel lineup includes ABC, but only in certain markets. So it might be more challenging to catch the game with Sling TV.\n\nBOSTON (AP) -- Jason Kidd won an NBA championship as a Dallas player in 2011. He now has a chance to win one as a Dallas coach, which would put him in a very small club.\n\nThere are only 14 people in NBA history to win rings as both a player and a head coach. That group: Rick Carlisle, Larry Costello, Billy Cunningham, Tom Heinsohn, Red Holzman, Phil Jackson, Buddy Jeannette, K.C. Jones, Steve Kerr, Tyronn Lue, Pat Riley, Bill Russell, George Senesky and Bill Sharman.\n\nKidd can join a group within that group, too. Of those 14, there are seven to win titles as a player and a coach with the same team -- those being Cunningham (Philadelphia), Heinsohn, Jones and Russell (Boston), Jeannette (Baltimore), Riley (Los Angeles Lakers) and Senesky (Philadelphia Warriors).\n\nDOMINANT CELTICS\n\nIf Boston wins these NBA Finals, an argument could be made that this was the most dominant team in Celtics history.\n\nBarring anything but a Dallas sweep, the 2023-24 Celtics will finish with either the second- or third-best winning percentage in team history. The 1985-86 Celtics were 82-18 (.820); the best this team can do is 80-20 (.800).\n\nBut where this team will almost certainly set itself apart in Celtics history is point differential. Again, barring something like Dallas winning four games in 30-point blowouts, Boston will finish with the highest differential over a total season in team history. These Celtics are outscoring teams by 11.2 points per game entering this series; the 1985-86 team outscored foes by 9.6 points per game.\n\nLUKA 3K\n\nThe longer this series goes, the better the chance that Dallas' Luka Doncic will become the 11th player in NBA history to score 3,000 points in a season -- including playoffs.\n\nDoncic is entering these NBA Finals with 2,859 points this season, so he needs 141 for 3,000.\n\nIt would be the 24th such season in NBA history if he gets there. Michael Jordan had 10 such seasons, Wilt Chamberlain had five and eight other players -- Bob McAdoo, Elgin Baylor, James Harden, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Kevin Durant, Kobe Bryant, Rick Barry and Shaquille O'Neal -- each did it once.\n\nLeBron James, the league's career scoring leader, got as close as one can to joining the 3,000-point club without ever hitting the milestone. In 2017-18, James finished with exactly 2,999 points.\n\nSIX IN SIX\n\nThis season will see a sixth team win in the last six seasons, after Denver in 2023, Golden State in 2022, Milwaukee in 2021, the Los Angeles Lakers in 2020 and Toronto in 2018.\n\nIt's the second time in NBA history there has been a six-different-champions-in-six-years stretch. The Lakers won in 1980, preceded by Seattle in 1979, Washington in 1978, Portland in 1977, Boston in 1976 and Golden State in 1975.\n\nTHE MONEY\n\nAt stake in this series: the NBA title, the Larry O'Brien Trophy, a pile of bejeweled rings and $4,856,937 in bonus money.\n\nThe NBA's playoff pool is a record $33,657,947 this season and gets distributed to each of the 16 playoff teams. The deeper in the playoffs you go, the more money you get, and there were some additional bonuses for the top regular-season records as well.\n\nBoston is already assured $7,202,498 from the pool, and the Celtics would see that figure rise to $12,059,435 if they win the NBA Finals.\n\nDallas has locked up no less than $5,899,422 in bonus money. The Mavericks would get a total of $10,756,359 if they win the title.\n\nThe bonus pool is typically split in some way among players and staff from the playoff teams.\n\nDIVISION CHAMPS, NBA CHAMPS\n\nOnce again, a division champion will win the NBA title.\n\nBoston won the Atlantic Division by 14 games, Dallas won the Southwest Division by one game. And that means this will be the 12th time in the last 13 seasons that a division champion will be the one that hoists the Larry O'Brien Trophy.\n\nThe exception: Golden State in 2022, when the Warriors beat Boston. Before that, the last team to not win their division but win the NBA title was Dallas in 2011.\n\nSTICK AROUND\n\nNBA teams that have a lead going into the fourth quarter have prevailed 84.1% of the time this season. But Dallas has a knack for rallying.\n\nThe Mavericks, including playoffs, have a league-best 14 wins this season when trailing after three quarters. The Celtics, also including the playoffs, have a league-high 69 wins when leading after three.\n\n5 SEED CURSE\n\nDallas is trying to do something that no team has done under the current playoff seeding format, which goes back 40 years.\n\nNo team seeded No. 5 in either conference has won the NBA title.\n\nOne lower-seeded team did; Houston was a No. 6 seed out of the West in 1995 when it won a title. But all the other teams that made the finals after earning a seed of only No. 5 or worse -- Miami in 2023, Miami in 2020 and New York in 1999 -- lost the title series.\n\nFOUR WITH 50\n\nDallas has a chance at doing something that no team has since 2001 -- beat four teams with at least 50 wins on its way to the NBA championship.\n\nThe Mavericks have beaten a 51-win team in the Los Angeles Clippers, a 57-win team in Oklahoma City and a 56-win team in Minnesota -- starting each of those series on the road. Boston won 64 games in the regular season.\n\nIn 2001, it was the Los Angeles Lakers who, as the No. 2 seed in the West, beat 50-win Portland, 55-win Sacramento and 58-win San Antonio on its way to the NBA Finals -- where they downed 56-win Philadelphia.\n\nSan Antonio nearly did it in 2014, beating three teams with 50 wins on its way to the title. But in the first round, the Spurs' opponent had only 49 wins; that opponent was the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nThe 2002 Lakers also beat three 50-win teams and one 49-win team on their way to that season's championship.", "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NJ.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirecTV_Stream", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, {"uri": "8162584924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "09:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T09:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T09:29:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/basketball-network-nba/bill-simmons-on-why-dallas-beating-boston-would-be-a-huge-upset-theres-three-giant/article_544e63e0-98ad-537f-b097-c40bc9873f07.html", "title": "Bill Simmons on why Dallas beating Boston would be a huge upset: \"There's three giant history red flags with the Mavericks\"", "body": "The Boston Celtics are betting favorites to beat the Dallas Mavericks in the 2024 NBA Finals. However, most fans are expecting a close series.\n\nThe Celtics dominated the 2023-24 regular season from start to finish. As the No.1 seed in the East, they dropped only two games entering the Finals. On the other hand, Dallas was the fifth seed in the West and had to steal home-court advantage to win all three series heading to Thursday's Game 1.\n\nYet because the Mavs, specifically their superstar duo of Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving, played so well in the Western Conference Finals, people are giving the Celtics only a slight edge.\n\nBut according to podcaster Bill Simmons, history says Luka and the Mavs are massive underdogs and would be unlikely champs.\n\n\"There's three giant red flags with the Mavericks thing, and yet I still feel like mentally I'm where you are, like you almost throw it out. It's this different Mavs team that seems like it came together the last six weeks, so ignore the history stuff and concentrate on the six weeks. I think it's the right answer,\" Simmons said.\n\nSimmons' three giant history red flags\n\nThe Mavericks beating the Celtics would be the third largest Finals betting upset since the NBA/ABA merger. Simmons said that at +184, the only bigger upsets in Finals history would be the 2004 Pistons over the Lakers (+500) and the 2019 Toronto Raptors over the Golden State Warriors (+230).\n\nBill also noted that only six teams have won the Larry O'Brien after missing the playoffs the previous year. The 2020 Los Angeles Lakers, who won in the Bubble, and the 2022 Golden State Warriors, who played against the core players of the 2024 Celtics, were the last teams to do it.\n\nThe Ringer founder added that if the Mavericks beat the Celtics, they will be the second-worst Finals winner by record since the first Magic/Bird season. That record belongs to the 1995 Houston Rockets, who were 47-35 during the regular season and 15-7 in the playoffs. The 2006 Miami Heat are next at 52-30/16-7 or 68-37 combined. Meanwhile, the 2024 Mavs have already lost 37 combined games this year (50-32/12-5).\n\nHistory favors Boston\n\nOn the other hand, Simmons says history favors Boston. In the last 50 years, only one team, the 2016 Golden State Warriors, which entered the NBA Finals with 20 total losses, has lost the series. Entering Game 1, the 2024 Celtics have lost 20 games -- 18 during the regular season and two so far in the postseason.\n\nDespite all those, the Dallas faithful remain confident that their dynamic duo can lead them to the promised land. And no matter what historical numbers Simmons pulls out, the teams will start the Finals on equal footing. From there, it could come down to which team is healthier and whose players will shine on the big stage.\n\nRelated: Shaq shares how he changed his approach to making \"Inside the NBA\" unique: \"TNT He also shot 35% from behind the arc.\n\nIn the postseason, he's only gotten better, with 25 points per game with 6.1 rebounds, although a lower assist stat. {"uri": "8164449107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:19:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:19:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:16:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13501351/Jason-Kidd-chance-join-small-club-NBA-Finals.html", "title": "Jason Kidd has a chance to join a very small club in these NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) - Jason Kidd won an NBA championship as a Dallas player in 2011. He now has a chance to win one as a Dallas coach, which would put him in a very small club.\n\nThere are only 14 people in NBA history to win rings as both a player and a head coach. That group: Rick Carlisle, Larry Costello, Billy Cunningham, Tom Heinsohn, Red Holzman, Phil Jackson, Buddy Jeannette, K.C. Jones, Steve Kerr, Tyronn Lue, Pat Riley, Bill Russell, George Senesky and Bill Sharman.\n\nKidd can join a group within that group, too. Of those 14, there are seven to win titles as a player and a coach with the same team - those being Cunningham (Philadelphia), Heinsohn, Jones and Russell (Boston), Jeannette (Baltimore), Riley (Los Angeles Lakers) and Senesky (Philadelphia Warriors).\n\nIf Boston wins these NBA Finals, an argument could be made that this was the most dominant team in Celtics history.\n\nBarring anything but a Dallas sweep, the 2023-24 Celtics will finish with either the second- or third-best winning percentage in team history. The 1985-86 Celtics were 82-18 (.820); the best this team can do is 80-20 (.800).\n\nBut where this team will almost certainly set itself apart in Celtics history is point differential. Again, barring something like Dallas winning four games in 30-point blowouts, Boston will finish with the highest differential over a total season in team history. These Celtics are outscoring teams by 11.2 points per game entering this series; the 1985-86 team outscored foes by 9.6 points per game.\n\nDallas Mavericks head coach Jason Kidd pauses on the sideline during the second half of Game 5 of the Western Conference finals in the NBA basketball playoffs against the Minnesota Timberwolves, Thursday, May 30, 2024, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nThe longer this series goes, the better the chance that Dallas' Luka Doncic will become the 11th player in NBA history to score 3,000 points in a season - including playoffs.\n\nDoncic is entering these NBA Finals with 2,859 points this season, so he needs 141 for 3,000.\n\nIt would be the 24th such season in NBA history if he gets there. Michael Jordan had 10 such seasons, Wilt Chamberlain had five and eight other players - Bob McAdoo, Elgin Baylor, James Harden, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Kevin Durant, Kobe Bryant, Rick Barry and Shaquille O\u00b4Neal - each did it once.\n\nLeBron James, the league's career scoring leader, got as close as one can to joining the 3,000-point club without ever hitting the milestone. In 2017-18, James finished with exactly 2,999 points.\n\nThis season will see a sixth team win in the last six seasons, after Denver in 2023, Golden State in 2022, Milwaukee in 2021, the Los Angeles Lakers in 2020 and Toronto in 2018.\n\nIt\u00b4s the second time in NBA history there has been a six-different-champions-in-six-years stretch. The Lakers won in 1980, preceded by Seattle in 1979, Washington in 1978, Portland in 1977, Boston in 1976 and Golden State in 1975.\n\nAt stake in this series: the NBA title, the Larry O\u00b4Brien Trophy, a pile of bejeweled rings and $4,856,937 in bonus money.\n\nThe NBA\u00b4s playoff pool is a record $33,657,947 this season and gets distributed to each of the 16 playoff teams. The deeper in the playoffs you go, the more money you get, and there were some additional bonuses for the top regular-season records as well.\n\nBoston is already assured $7,202,498 from the pool, and the Celtics would see that figure rise to $12,059,435 if they win the NBA Finals.\n\nDallas has locked up no less than $5,899,422 in bonus money. The Mavericks would get a total of $10,756,359 if they win the title.\n\nThe bonus pool is typically split in some way among players and staff from the playoff teams.\n\nOnce again, a division champion will win the NBA title.\n\nBoston won the Atlantic Division by 14 games, Dallas won the Southwest Division by one game. And that means this will be the 12th time in the last 13 seasons that a division champion will be the one that hoists the Larry O\u00b4Brien Trophy.\n\nThe exception: Golden State in 2022, when the Warriors beat Boston. Before that, the last team to not win their division but win the NBA title was Dallas in 2011.\n\nNBA teams that have a lead going into the fourth quarter have prevailed 84.1% of the time this season. But Dallas has a knack for rallying.\n\nThe Mavericks, including playoffs, have a league-best 14 wins this season when trailing after three quarters. The Celtics, also including the playoffs, have a league-high 69 wins when leading after three.\n\nDallas is trying to do something that no team has done under the current playoff seeding format, which goes back 40 years.\n\nNo team seeded No. 5 in either conference has won the NBA title.\n\nOne lower-seeded team did; Houston was a No. 6 seed out of the West in 1995 when it won a title. But all the other teams that made the finals after earning a seed of only No. 5 or worse - Miami in 2023, Miami in 2020 and New York in 1999 - lost the title series.\n\nDallas has a chance at doing something that no team has since 2001 - beat four teams with at least 50 wins on its way to the NBA championship.\n\nThe Mavericks have beaten a 51-win team in the Los Angeles Clippers, a 57-win team in Oklahoma City and a 56-win team in Minnesota - starting each of those series on the road. Boston won 64 games in the regular season.\n\nIn 2001, it was the Los Angeles Lakers who, as the No. 2 seed in the West, beat 50-win Portland, 55-win Sacramento and 58-win San Antonio on its way to the NBA Finals - where they downed 56-win Philadelphia.\n\nSan Antonio nearly did it in 2014, beating three teams with 50 wins on its way to the title. But in the first round, the Spurs\u00b4 opponent had only 49 wins; that opponent was the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nThe 2002 Lakers also beat three 50-win teams and one 49-win team on their way to that season\u00b4s championship.\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA\n\nDallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (77) celebrates his score as Minnesota Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards, left, looks on during the first half of Game 5 of the Western Conference finals in the NBA basketball playoffs, Thursday, May 30, 2024, in Minneapolis. {"uri": "8163720736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:50:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:50:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:49:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/basketball/article-redemption-minded-celtics-set-to-match-up-with-opportunistic-mavericks/", "title": "Redemption-minded Celtics set to match up with opportunistic Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nKELLY: Kyrie Irving is proof of the redemptive power of sport - but supporting that redemption is a different matter\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the post-season. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the post-season as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey'll matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favourite to raise the franchise's 18th championship banner entering the post-season.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nThey've also benefited from an off-season shakeup of its roster that saw long-time emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favour of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston's home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nCeltics fans haven't held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn's first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\n\"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": {"uri": "2024-06-378712273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:22:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:22:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:22:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://deadspin.com/dallas-mavericks-vs-boston-celtics-2024-nba-finals-best-prop-bets/", "title": "Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics 2024 NBA Finals Best Prop Bets & Picks | Deadspin.com", "body": "Exactly one week after the conclusion of the Western Conference finals and 10 days removed from the end of the Eastern Conference finals, basketball will finally be back.\n\nThe Mavericks and Celtics will square off in Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday, with both teams looking to take a step toward their first title in over a decade. Dallas' last championship came in 2011, while Boston hasn't gone all the way since 2008.\n\nSo, get out the wallet, because at best, you only have seven more NBA games to throw your money on.\n\nWhether you're trying to polish off a season of betting that paid for your kid's college tuition or chasing losses that will prevent that same kid from even going to college, here are three futures bets that you should take a look at for this year's Finals:\n\nJayson Tatum to win Finals MVP (-115 at DraftKings, -120 at FanDuel)\n\nJaylen Brown already completed his redemption arc, and now it's time for Tatum to do the same.\n\nAfter making just 7 of 43 3-pointers (16.3 percent) and committing 3.6 turnovers per game in the 2023 Eastern Conference finals, Brown was named MVP when the series rolled around this year by averaging 29.8 points on 51.7 percent shooting from the field.\n\nTatum was underwhelming -- to say the least -- when Boston went up against the Golden State Warriors in the Finals two years ago, canning just 36.7 percent of his shots from the floor. His 3-for-17 performance in Game 1 was enough to make anyone vehemently ill, and things really didn't get that much better from there.\n\nBut with Finals experience now under his belt and a great team around him, Tatum has no reason not to end up with this award when he returns to the league's biggest stage.\n\nKyrie Irving to hit most 3-pointers in series (+700 at DraftKings, +550 at FanDuel)\n\nWith the bad blood between Irving and his former team, if you don't bet on him in some capacity, you're doing something wrong.\n\nAnd yes, this wager is a bit of a long shot (no pun intended), but we love the value here considering Irving has made the third-most postseason treys among players still around. He trails only teammate Luka Doncic (57 3-pointers) and Boston guard Derrick White (48).\n\nIt's also worth noting that Irving is 0-10 in his past 10 games against the Celtics. He could very well be cursed, and the only way he shakes off that hex is by taking over games alongside Doncic.\n\nExpect Irving to do a lot of his damage from distance, especially if Boston big man Kristaps Porzingis (calf) returns from a 10-game absence to clog up the lane.\n\nOne or more games to reach overtime (+190 at FanDuel).\n\nLet's just pretend like Boston didn't beat Dallas to a pulp for a 138-110 victory back on March 1 in the most recent meeting between these teams.\n\nSurely the Mavericks will be more competitive with the world watching, right?\n\nWe think so, and the Celtics were tied for the fourth-most overtime games during the regular season with six. No Big Three. Instead, the Mavericks will square off against the #1 team in the league for the last eight months.\n\nThe Boston Celtics had the NBA's best record in the regular season and are the number one seed in the East.\n\nThe series will begin in Boston for Games 1 and 2. Here are three things to watch for heading into Game 1 of the NBA Finals:\n\n1. Celtics homecourt\n\nDuring the regular season, the C's went 37-4 at the TD Garden - the best home record in the NBA since 2016.\n\nIn the postseason, that home record has \"dipped\" to 6-2. Still, the Celtics are the best home team in basketball.\n\nThe Garden will be rowdy and loud. Far more than anything the Mavs experienced in Los Angeles, Oklahoma City, or Minnesota.\n\nThe Mavs want to get out to a fast start regardless, but it would be especially helpful in a raucous road environment.\n\n2. Road dogs\n\nIf there's a team equipped to handle the Boston crowd, it's the Mavericks.\n\nThe Mavs have gone 7-2 on the road in the NBA Playoffs including five straight victories away from home.\n\nLuka Doncic plays better when opposing fans chirp at him and he will surely get chirped in Beantown.\n\nThe Finals matchups feature the best home team versus the postseason's best road team.\n\nTwo of the most intriguing storylines heading into the Finals are former Celtic/now Maverick Kyrie Irving and former Maverick/current Celtic Kristaps Porzingis.\n\nCeltics fans are not fond of Kyrie, since his departure. And as much as Kyrie looks at peace in Dallas, you would imagine the competitive part of him would like to shut up the Boston crowd with his play.\n\nPorzingis draws less ire from MFFL's but his split from the Mavs was not a cheerful experience either.\n\nYou would presume he's motivated to show the Mavericks they messed up by trading him to the Washington Wizards in 2022.\n\nBoth players are in the Finals, though. So whatever ill will there may be, is no match for fate (or destiny).\n\nThe storylines are plentiful. The on-court matchups are compelling. {"uri": "8163721861", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:52:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:52:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/sport/basketball/redemption-seeking-celtics-face-mavericks-in-nba-finals-c-14927218", "title": "Redemption-seeking Celtics face Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "Redemption-seeking Celtics face Mavericks in NBA FinalsStaff WritersAPThu, 6 June 2024 7:48AM\n\nAs the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown see it as a chance at redemption after falling narrowly short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think you're young (and) if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said.\n\n\"We realised that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nDallas's Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see the Finals as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after the latter was traded from Brooklyn.\n\nAfter a slow start this season, the superstar pair found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting.\n\nHe won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said.\n\n\"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the post-season as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said.\n\n\"The way he connects us. Me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nAlongside the Mavericks' Australian pair Dante Exum and Josh Green, they will matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time,\" he said.\n\n\"To solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. That will add a lot to our legacy.\"\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks mentor Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows - losing in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets - as well as the highs of his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 and as an assistant on the Lakers' 2020 championship team.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said.\n\n\"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about - seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nAccording to Boston's Joe Mazzulla, it's the \"toughest team\" that will take the honours.\n\n\"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different,\" he said.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The West {"uri": "8162758565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "11:13:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T11:13:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T11:12:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/win-2024-nba-finals-mavericks-110524625.html", "title": "Who will win 2024 NBA Finals? Mavericks vs. Celtics picks, predictions and odds", "body": "The Mavericks beat the 51-win Los Angeles Clippers, 57-win Oklahoma City Thunder and 56-win Minnesota Timberwolves with Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving starring and a capable cast of know-their-role guys providing support, including trade-deadline acquisitions P.J. Washington from Charlotte and Daniel Gafford from Washington.\n\nSince the deadline the Mavs have been one of the best teams in the league, showing marked improvement offensively and defensively. They rely on Doncic's playmaking but they have other capable scorers, make enough 3s and love alley-oop lobs.\n\nBoston is a force. The Celtics possessed the NBA's best offense and No. 2 defense and had a league-best 64 victories. When Kristaps Porzingis is in the lineup, the Celtics have the best starting five in the league and are the best two-way team in the league. They have multiple scorers, led by Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum, and it's not unusual for a third player (Jrue Holiday, Derrick White, Porzingis) to score 20 in a game. Defensively, they have size, strength and length and two All-Defense selections in Holiday and White. They come at an opponent several different ways, and the pressure is constant.\n\nThe Celtics like their 3s, and they're proficient at making them. When 3s are going in and Brown and Tatum are both in the 20s, the Celtics are tough to beat.\n\nHere are USA TODAY Sports' NBA experts' picks and predictions for the 2024 Finals:\n\nThis potentially will come down to which duo plays better: Kyrie and Luka or Tatum and Brown? But the X-factor is Kristaps Porzingis. If he can give them anything after coming back from a 10-game absence because of a calf injury, the Celtics should hoist banner No. 18, because they are just too deep and too good.\n\nCeltics in six\n\nThe Celtics had a fairly uncontested route to the NBA Finals, facing the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers and Indiana Pacers, all of whom were missing major star power, including Jimmy Butler (Heat), Donovan Mitchell (Cavaliers), Jarrett Allen (Cavaliers) and Tyrese Haliburton (Pacers). But the Celtics will face a superstar pair in Doncic and Irving. The series will be a close one, but the Mavericks have the closers to get this done.\n\nMavericks in six\n\nI believe in underdogs - and particularly in Luka's ability to break hearts.\n\nMavericks in seven\n\nThe Celtics have too many offensive weapons and too many defensive options so unless their offense takes a dip for an extended time, the Celtics will win the title.\n\nGannett may earn revenue from sports betting operators for audience referrals to betting services. {"uri": "8162990816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "13:35:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T13:35:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T13:34:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13497621/NBA-Favored-Celtics-battle-Doncic-Mavs-NBA-Finals.html", "title": "NBA-Favored Celtics battle Doncic and the Mavs in NBA Finals", "body": "By Rory Carroll\n\nJune 5 (Reuters) - A Celtics team desperate for championship glory face Luka Doncic and a Dallas Mavericks squad eager to play spoiler in an intriguing NBA Finals matchup that tips off Thursday in Boston.\n\nLed by superstars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the sharpshooting Celtics have had a relatively easy road to the finals.\n\nComing out of the weaker Eastern Conference as the top seed, they breezed past the Jimmy Butler-less Miami Heat, dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers and swept the Indiana Pacers, who were without point guard Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games.\n\nThe Celtics have won 12 of their 14 playoff games and gone undefeated on the road but they know that none of that will matter if they fail to end a title drought that stretches back to 2008.\n\nThe mission is clear - hang that elusive 18th championship banner from the TD Garden rafters and put recent postseason disappointment, including falling to the Warriors in the 2022 finals and coming up short in the conference finals last year, firmly behind them.\n\nAnything less will be seen as a bitter disappointment.\n\n\"They were the best team in the regular season and they have been the best team in the playoffs,\" former player and current ESPN analyst JJ Redick said on a call with reporters.\n\n\"I feel strongly that they are the favorites going into this series. At the same time, I wouldn't be surprised if Luka and Dallas and Kyrie (Irving) and (head coach Jason Kidd) made this a series and won... This is going to be a phenomenal series.\"\n\nStanding in Boston's way is a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin the Celtics' title aspirations.\n\nThat starts with Doncic, the 25-year-old Slovenian who is quickly becoming the face of the league.\n\nHe has been the best player in the playoffs and is the first to lead in points (489), rebounds (164) and assists (150) coming into a finals.\n\nBy his side is veteran point guard Irving who, after turbulent stints in Brooklyn and Boston, has looked more comfortable and confident on the court than he has in years.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that offensively they are as talented as any backcourt in NBA history,\" Redick said of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne big, 7-foot 2-inch question mark hanging over the series is the health of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis, the former Maverick who suffered a calf strain in the Heat series and has been sidelined since.\n\nThe Celtics are hopeful that their prized offseason acquisition, who averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks during the regular season, will be healthy enough to match up against the Mavs' breakout big men Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II.\n\nGame One of the NBA Finals is Thursday in Boston.\n\n(Reporting by Rory Carroll in Los Angeles Editing by Toby Davis)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8165026822", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:23:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:23:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:16:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/06/07/sports/redemption-minded-celtics-face-opportunistic-mavericks/1950287", "title": "Redemption-minded Celtics face opportunistic Mavericks", "body": "BOSTON -- As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals on Thursday (Friday in Manila), the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown -- the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster -- see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nBackcourt partnership\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey'll match up with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favorite to raise the franchise's 18th championship banner entering the postseason.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzula.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThey've also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw longtime emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favor of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nCoaching perspective\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nFriends and competitors\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston's home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCeltics fans haven't held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn's first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\n\"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@manilatimes.net", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", {"uri": "8161989559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "01:14:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T01:14:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T01:14:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/celtics-stars-tatum-and-brown-feel-better-equipped-to-tackle-2nd-chance-in-nba-finals/article_2829301d-2b03-5e5f-afc4-b5568cab886d.html", "title": "Celtics stars Tatum and Brown feel better equipped to tackle 2nd chance in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- For almost the entirety of their time together in Boston, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown have been linked.\n\nThey were drafted by the Celtics third overall in back-to-back years.\n\nThey possess similar skillsets -- two explosive and skilled wing players with an ability to score from nearly every spot on the court.\n\nAnd they both have been central to the success of a Celtics team that has reached the NBA Finals for the second time in three seasons. It helped Brown earn the NBA's first $300 million contract last summer. And, Tatum is expected to get one this offseason.\n\nThe team has branded the All-Stars as \"The Jays\" in a marketing campaign shown during games that pitted them against one another in mini competitions.\n\nIt has created natural comparisons between them along the way, fostering an atmosphere in which fans and sports pundits alike have tried to parse out which one of them is better, whose spot is most untouchable on the roster and which of them is more pivotal to the Celtics' success as they prepare to lead the team to the franchise's 18th NBA title.\n\nIt reached a new level last week during a segment on ESPN's \"Get Up\" in which panelists debated whether the 26-year-old Tatum expressed excitement or disappointment while watching the 27-year-old Brown garner Eastern Conference finals MVP honors.\n\n\"I think it's unfair to both of them,\" Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla said of what he viewed as an attempt to manufacture friction between the two stars.\n\nBut even as Tatum and Brown have distinguished themselves as the most important players on Boston's roster and the keys to the Celtics' fate in their NBA Finals matchup with the Dallas Mavericks, Mazzulla has hope that people will start viewing them differently.\n\n\"They're, like, two completely different people. They're two completely different players,\" Mazzulla said. \"They're great teammates, they love each other and they go about winning and they go about their process in a different way. Why they have to always be lumped together I think is unfair.\"\n\nTatum and Brown, along with Al Horford, are the only returning starters from the 2021-22 team that lost to the Golden State Warriors in six games in the Finals after holding a 2-1 series lead.\n\nWhile Horford has taken on mostly a reserve role this season, backing up 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis, Tatum and Brown have taken their play up a notch.\n\nTatum's scoring numbers have remained steady from the regular season (26.9 per game) into the playoffs (26.0), while his rebounding has increased from 8.1 to 10.4 per game in the postseason. Brown, too, has seen jumps in those categories, going from 23.0 points and 5.5 rebounds per game to 25.0 points and 6.1 rebounds in the playoffs.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nTax bill stunner: $250K owed on former Sand Dunes Club properties on Sullivan's Island Commentary: 'Spartanburgers' baseball team name is a big swing and a miss Editorial: SC voters in 32 districts can put an end to Freedom Caucus chaos. Here's how. Over 20,000 people expected for Greenville's free Jazz Fest. Here's who you'll hear. A MAGA insurgency seized the Greenville GOP. Here's an inside look at the ensuing chaos. What's the latest with Malfunction Junction upgrades in Columbia? Driving through South Carolina? Make sure to stop at these hidden culinary landmarks Parts of South Carolina are sinking, and quickly. Can we slow it down? Brown's Court Bakery bread to resurface at a new Charleston caf\u00e9 Gamecock baseball hot board: Who replaces Mark Kingston?\n\nTatum believes they've both used lessons from the 2022 NBA Finals' loss, as well as last year's conference finals loss to Miami, to grow into players more equipped to accomplish their championship goal this time around.\n\n\"Obviously, we've been there before, we came up short,\" Tatum said. \"You don't always get a second chance, so really just looking at it as a second chance and trying to simplify things as much as we can.\"\n\nAnd being each other's biggest cheerleaders, too.\n\nAfter Brown made a game-tying 3-pointer late in Game 1 of the conference finals matchup with Indiana to send the game to overtime in an eventual Celtics' victory, the highest praise came from Tatum.\n\n\"Big time players make big time plays,\" Tatum said of Brown.\n\nFor Brown, this season has been about focusing on the expectations he has for himself and not worrying about others' perception of him.\n\nInitially, when he was asked about not being included on either the All-NBA or All-Defensive teams, he shrugged it off, saying his attention was focused on getting back to the NBA Finals.\n\nAfter he was named conference finals MVP, he acknowledged it did offer at least some motivation, particularly on the defensive side of the ball which he said he put most of his work into this past offseason.\n\n\"As time has gone by and I got to this point, I stopped caring,\" Brown said. \"I don't care who sees what, as long as my city knows my value, my team knows my value, my family -- that's all I really care about.\"\n\nMazzulla believes the reason the relationship between Brown and Tatum is so often talked about is rooted in outside disbelief that their dynamic doesn't breed any rivalry between them.\n\n\"At the end of the day, like, those two guys, their relationship is their relationship,\" Mazzulla said. \"They love each other. They push each other every single day in practice. They communicate with each other, but they go about it differently. And, I think they both get it unfair being compared to each other. They're different. And we see other duos around the league don't have to go through that. ... It's because they've been so successful their entire careers, they've been able to for so long stay in success at a high level.\"\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NBA {"uri": "8163144234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:11:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.nbcsports.com/nba/news/nba-finals-past-winners-list-every-nba-champion-by-year-finals-sweeps-most-finals-wins-and-losses", "title": "NBA Finals past winners list: Every NBA champion by year, Finals sweeps, most Finals wins and losses", "body": "When Game 1 of the 2024 NBA Finals between the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks tips off on Thursday, there'll be some history on the line -- beyond the obvious.\n\nThe Celtics will be trying to break their current tie with the rival Lakers atop the leaderboard for the most championships in NBA history. Those two teams dominate that board, with a sizable gap between them and the next-fullest trophy case.\n\nHere's a thorough history of all past NBA Finals winners, including how many titles the Celtics have won, when the Mavericks earned their lone ring and which teams are still searching for their first.\n\nThe Boston Celtics and Los Angeles Lakers have won the most NBA Finals, with 17 apiece.\n\nNext is the Golden State Warriors, whose four titles within the last decade brought their all-time total to seven -- counting their 1947 win during the era of the Basketball Association of America, which merged with the National Basketball League to become the NBA in 1949.\n\nAfter them are the Chicago Bulls, whose six championships came in the 1990s with Michael Jordan, and the San Antonio Spurs, who have won five -- all with Gregg Popovich at the helm.\n\nThe 2023-24 season will be the sixth straight season without a repeat NBA Finals winning team.\n\nSeveral times, actually. The first was in 1959, when the Celtics swept the Lakers (then the Minneapolis Lakers). The last was in 2018, when the Warriors swept the Cavaliers.\n\nThe Jordan-led Chicago Bulls three-peated twice in the same decade, winning from 1991-93 and again from 1996-98. If Jordan hadn't retired for the 1993-94 season and most of the next, perhaps it would've been an eight-peat.\n\nInstead, the only eight-peat in NBA history -- and probably the only one the league will ever see -- belongs to the Boston Celtics. They won the title every year from 1959-66.\n\nHowever, there were only eight (until 1961) or nine teams in the league during that Celtics run.\n\nThe Nuggets won their first championship last year, leaving 10 franchises that have yet to reach the mountaintop: Brooklyn Nets, Charlotte Hornets, Indiana Pacers, Los Angeles Clippers, Memphis Grizzlies, Minnesota Timberwolves, New Orleans Pelicans, Orlando Magic, Phoenix Suns and Utah Jazz.\n\nThat would be the Lakers, with 15.
