{"uri": "8163689753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:09:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:09:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:08:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/sports/basketball/redemption-minded-celtics-set-to-match-up-with-opportunistic-mavericks-in-nba-finals/article_4912657b-08d9-54d4-ac7a-676a95d48713.html", "title": "Redemption-minded Celtics set to match up with opportunistic Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "BOSTON (AP) -- As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown - the Celtics' most tenured and scrutinized stars on their roster - see it as a chance at redemption after falling just short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"You think that you're young, if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said. \"We realized that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAnd now?\n\n\"I'm not thinking about what it would mean for my legacy or anything like that,\" he said. \"Just excited to play some basketball ... and go out there and try to get the job done.\"\n\nDallas' Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see it as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after Irving was traded from Brooklyn following a tumultuous run of two-plus seasons with the Nets.\n\nBut the duo was still learning to play with each other during their truncated time together last season and didn't make it to the postseason. After a slow start this season, they found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting. He won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said. \"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too. Get it out your mind that this is about to be a clean sweep or everything is about to feel good throughout this journey and all that.\n\n\"I'm just very real, very honest. That's what's helped me grow as a leader.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the postseason as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said. \"The way he connects us. I think me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nThey'll matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings. That was exhibited during a 64-win regular season that established it as a favorite to raise the franchise's 18th championship banner entering the postseason.\n\nThrough the first three rounds, the Celtics have met the challenge, losing just two games along the way under the guidance of second-year coach Joe Mazzulla.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThey've also benefited from an offseason shakeup of its roster that saw longtime emotional leader Marcus Smart and former NBA Sixth Man of the Year Malcolm Brogdon traded in favor of 7-footer Kristaps Porzingis and Jrue Holiday, who won a championship with Milwaukee in 2021.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"I think this is a special group. I really do,\" Brown said. \"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time. I think to solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy. But as of right now, that story is kind of still untold.\"\n\nCOACHING PERSPECTIVES\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks coach Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows, such as losing back-to-back trips to the Finals in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets. He has also seen success, earning his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 at age 38 and one as an assistant on the Lakers 2020 championship team.\n\nThe biggest lesson he has taken away is to approach it like business and be ready to live with the results. That has been his message to his team throughout these playoffs.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said. \"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about, is seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nMazzulla was an assistant on Ime Udoka's staff in 2022. What he learned from that experience is that the details of winning never change, even on this stage.\n\n\"The toughest team will win,\" Mazzulla said. \"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. It's no different.\"\n\nFRIENDS AND COMPETITORS\n\nIrving is ready for what he expects to be an icy greeting from Boston's home crowd for Game 1 on Thursday.\n\nCeltics fans haven't held a high opinion of him since he ended two disappointing seasons in Boston by leaving for the Nets and joining Kevin Durant in free agency in 2019.\n\nHe then rankled the Boston faithful even more when he flipped his middle finger at fans after making a shot during Brooklyn's first round playoff series loss to the Celtics in 2022. But he said he is looking forward to matching up with \"brothers\" and former teammates Tatum and Brown.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"They've gotten tremendously better. They've led their team to this point. So I'm proud of them,\" Irving said. \"I'm looking forward to the competition because this is what we've all strived for since we were kids, basketball at this level playing against the best of the best.\"\n\n___\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/nba", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Here are three bets worth considering for Thursday night's series opener.\n\nThis one doesn't require much overthinking. We've been treated to an abundance of close playoff games in recent weeks -- well, at least out of the West -- but the Celtics are favored at -225 to win this series for a reason. They're the better team top to bottom, they were hardly tested throughout the Eastern Conference bracket and they've had a week for Tatum and Brown to rest and heal up.\n\nDon't get us wrong, Dallas is dangerous enough to make the series close. That's just unlikely to start in Game 1 in a raucous TD Garden. The Celtics swept the two-game season series with the Mavericks, including a 138-110 pounding at home in March. A Boston win by at least seven points isn't hard to see coming.\n\nBrown was hot and cold from the arc during the Eastern Conference Finals, but he didn't need to hit as many threes with the likes of Jrue Holiday, Derrick White and 76-year-old Al Horford stepping up from long range.\n\nThat said, there's something you should know about Brown's 3-point tendencies. He's made them at a far better clip at home than on the road this year. During the regular season, Brown knocked down 39.5 percent of his triples at TD Garden and just 31.6 percent away from home. He made at least three 3-pointers in five of his final seven regular-season home games, and he's hit that mark in four of eight playoff games at home. And packing the paint has been Dallas' specialty more than defending the perimeter.\n\nThanks to BetMGM's \"alternate player prop\" options, you can turn up the dial on Brown's over/under and bet on him to drain at least three from three.\n\nApart from the handful of hardcore, professional sports bettors among us, why are you placing wagers on sports if not to have a little fun? And what's more fun than rooting for one of the league's most electric players to rack up the rebounds and assists he needs for that elusive triple-double?\n\nExcept with Doncic, it's not elusive in the slightest. He's followed up his 21 triple-doubles in the regular season by notching six in the playoffs, including five in his last eight games. {"uri": "8163229113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:09:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:09:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:08:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://hardwoodhoudini.com/posts/longtime-boston-celtics-killer-luka-doncic-deliver-cs-ultimate-heartbreak-finals", "title": "Longtime Boston Celtics killer Luka Doncic can deliver Cs ultimate heartbreak in Finals", "body": "Dallas Mavericks star already has two game-winners against Celtics\n\nDespite just turning 25 years old this year, Dallas Mavericks' guard Luka Doncic has already dominated the league and caused headaches for majority of NBA teams headaches with his ability to control the game.\n\nThe Celtics are no strangers to Doncic's excellence on the court, although they have his number in recent years. Since coming into the league, Doncic is 5-6 versus the Celtics, averaging 29.9 points per game, 8.8 boards, and 7.5 assists. The Celtics have easily won the last four against them, keeping Doncic's +/- under -10 in each contest, but the painful losses are impossible to ignore.\n\nThe Cs have had strong defensive rosters in every matchup against Doncic, but have only kept him under 40% from the field in one game. Although this year's team can create the most problems for Doncic offensively, his step-back jumper, ability to draw contact and control over the game's pace makes him by far the biggest challenge the Celtics will face these playoffs.\n\nPrior to the Celtics' 4-game win streak against the Mavericks, it was Luka who had bested the Celtics in four straight games -- all of which in dramatic fashion. In February 2021, Luka nailed a ridiculous step-back with 0.1 seconds remaining on the clock, less than a minute after hitting another go-ahead step-back over former Celtics' big Daniel Theis identical to his game-winner over Rudy Gobert in game 4 of the Western Conference Finals. One month later, Doncic hit his seventh three of the game in crunch time before drawing a huge foul on Kemba Walker behind the arc and sinking three free throws to help close out another win. Both Celtics' stars, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown failed to answer, and the Celtics fell 113-108.\n\nThe following season, Luka hit one of the wildest shots of his career, another step-back game winner that this time swished through the net after the buzzer sounded. Like the other two losses, the Celtics fought back from a deficit and delivered strong fourth quarter performances -- a troubling area for them -- but still fell short to Doncic's greatness in the clutch.\n\nAnd in March 2022, the Celtics squandered a close home game, with Luka drilling a three to tie the game before finding Spencer Dinwiddie for the eventual game winner. Tatum notably struggled, especially down the stretch, perhaps giving him all the motivation he needed to make this their last loss versus the Mavericks.\n\nSo if the Celtics hold a positive record over Doncic, including four straight dominant showings, and he seemingly needs last-minute magic to pull off his wins against them, what does that mean for this seven-game series?\n\nThe Celtics have {"uri": "8163544610", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:33:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:33:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:33:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/celtics-hunger-for-nba-crown-after-2022-finals-failure/article_5217502e-0d4b-54df-8ad7-aa2984480fc7.html", "title": "Celtics hunger for NBA crown after 2022 finals failure", "body": "Boston Celtics star Jayson Tatum talks to reporters on the eve of the NBA Finals\n\nA historic championship legacy and a gut-wrenching 2022 finals loss have the Boston Celtics extra motivated to capture their first title since 2008 in this year's NBA Finals.\n\nThe Celtics will play host to the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday in the opener of the best-of-seven series, with stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown excited about their trophy chances after falling to Golden State in the 2022 finals.\n\n\"I hate that we had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" Tatum said Wednesday. \"But I'm a firm believer that everything happens for a reason. There's a lesson to be learned in every situation.\n\n\"I do feel a lot different this time. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done. I told myself if I ever got the opportunity again to make it to the finals, never take it for granted. We're here now and I'm excited to get ready to play and have fun.\"\n\nBrown said he has watched the 2022 finals several times to learn how to better manage his emotions and to make better decisions on the court.\n\n\"You learn and grow from your experiences,\" Brown said. \"Two years later makes a pretty big difference.\n\n\"This is a special group. The core group has been here for a few years now. We've been able to go through experiences, having success but not having success at the same time.\n\n\"The ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy as a team, but as of right now, that story is still kind of untold.\"\n\nAnother factor is that the Celtics seek an unprecedented 18th NBA crown, one more than the all-time record they share with the rival Los Angeles Lakers.\n\n\"Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. We're honored to follow in their footsteps. They paved the way for us to live out our dreams,\" said Tatum.\n\n\"If you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. It takes special players to be part of an environment like that.\"\n\nOne of those is Jrue Holiday, who won a 2021 NBA title with Milwaukee and was obtained in a trade deal just before the season began.\n\nMore from this section Georgia woman faces manslaughter, other charges in fatal Massapequa crash Boxer Huang Hsiao-wen Qualifies for Paris Olympics - TaiwanPlus News Louisiana approves surgical castration bill for sex crimes against children\n\n\"To be a part of history would be cool, the history the Celtics have,\" Holiday said. \"To add to that is part of the reason I was brought here -- and part of the reason I wanted to come.\"\n\n- 'The will to win' -\n\nThe defensive standout sees something special in the Celtics, who led the NBA with 64 wins this season.\n\n\"The pressure JB and JT have to take on is something different,\" Holiday said. \"It's really impressive how they handle themselves.\n\n\"I know sometimes talent doesn't mesh together but this does. You saw it in the regular season. You've seen it in the playoffs. Any given night we sacrifice for each other. we're unselfish and I think that's what makes it go.\"\n\n\"And then it's just the will to win. They've been to the Eastern Conference finals a million times and they have been to the finals so they've been to the top, just didn't execute the way they wanted.\n\n\"Now that we're here, we want to get the job done.\"\n\nTatum appreciates the finals more after losing to Miami in seven games in last year's East finals.\n\n\"Last year we took that for granted and we didn't make it to the finals. Put things in prespective,\" Tatum said.\n\n\"You could see our excitement when we won the conference (this year). That's not the be-all, end-all but it really is tough to get to this moment.\n\n\"I'm staying in the moment. I'm not thinking of what this would mean to my legacy or anything like that. {"uri": "8163226259", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:11:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:11:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:07:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13498377/Mavericks-topple-favored-Celtics-NBA-Finals-Luka-Doncic-Kyrie-Irving-shine-together.html", "title": "Mavericks can topple favored Celtics in NBA Finals if Luka Doncic...", "body": "DALLAS (AP) - Luka Doncic scored 12 points in the first 3 1/2 minutes of the first quarter in the Dallas Mavericks' clinching blowout of Minnesota in the Western Conference finals.\n\nKyrie Irving scored nine points in the final 3 1/2 minutes of the first half, pushing the lead to 29 on the way to a gaping 36-point margin in the 124-103 victory in Game 5.\n\nWhen the co-stars of the Mavericks are playing that way, there might not be a team in the NBA that can beat them.\n\nDallas, the fifth seed in the West, will need more than one such game in the NBA Finals against the favored Boston Celtics, who had the league's best record by seven games and swept the two-game season series.\n\nThe Mavs - this deep in the playoffs for the first time since winning the franchise's only championship in 2011 - also will need the defensive intensity both offensive wizards have shown in these playoffs.\n\n\"It\u00b4s a beautiful combination,\" coach Jason Kidd said. \"They\u00b4re in competition right now of who\u00b4s playing the best defense. That\u00b4s kind of cool to see because when you look at Kai and Luka, a lot of times they\u00b4re not known as our defensive guys.\"\n\nDallas Mavericks guard Luka Doncic (77) shakes hands with teammate Kyrie Irving (11) after their loss to the Minnesota Timberwolves in Game 4 of the NBA basketball Western Conference finals, Tuesday, May 28, 2024, in Dallas. (AP Photo/Gareth Patterson)\n\nIrving and Doncic scored 36 points apiece in the clincher against the Wolves, both shooting better than 50% and combining to make half their 3-pointers.\n\nThe Mavs didn't need double figures from anybody off the bench, and barely from the other starters.\n\nThey can make that formula work, with at least some help.\n\nP.J. Washington Jr. will draw the difficult defensive assignments against Boston co-stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. But the midseason acquisition needs to shoot closer to the 47% from 3-point range that he did in the second-round victory over top-seeded Oklahoma City than the 25% he shot against Minnesota.\n\nThe other defense-first starter and key figure in trying to slow Tatum and Brown, Derrick Jones Jr., could provide a boost by matching his 40% shooting from 3 in these playoffs.\n\nThen there's the rim-protecting, pick-and-rolling tandem of centers Daniel Gafford - the other midseason trade pickup along with Washington - and rookie Dereck Lively II.\n\nThose two give Dallas an edge over the Celtics, who have a more perimeter-oriented pairing in Kristaps Porzingis and the undersized Al Horford.\n\nBoston also isn't sure what it will get out of Porzingis with the 7-foot-2 Latvian sidelined since the first round by a calf injury.\n\nThe Celtics get the edge in late-playoff experience, but not by much.\n\nThey are on a three-year run of reaching the East finals and made the NBA Finals in 2022, losing to Golden State in six games after the Warriors beat Dallas in the West finals.\n\nIrving, however, has the most experience in the series on the NBA's biggest stage, with 13 games in the finals. He ranks eighth among players with at least 10 games with a scoring average of 27.7 points.\n\nDoncic doesn't figure to be spooked by his first NBA Finals. The 25-year-old was playing professionally in Spain a decade ago and was the title-winning EuroLeague MVP days before getting drafted third overall in 2018.\n\nHe also is the reason Slovenia reached the medal round as a first-time Olympic qualifier at the Tokyo Games three years ago.\n\nAP NBA: https://apnews.com/hub/NBA\n\nDallas Mavericks center Daniel Gafford (21) celebrates a Minnesota Timberwolves shot clock violation as Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kyle Anderson (1) pauses on the court during the first half of Game 5 of the Western Conference finals in the NBA basketball playoffs, Thursday, May 30, 2024, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Abbie Parr)\n\nDallas Mavericks forward P.J. {"uri": "8163177858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:34:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:34:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/basketball-network-nba/jason-kidd-says-derrick-white-is-the-one-player-the-mavs-are-concerned-about-it/article_a5fcc400-70da-58e6-8ee4-2236d318cc1f.html", "title": "Jason Kidd says Derrick White is the one player the Mavs are concerned about: \"It takes their offense to another level\"", "body": "When the Dallas Mavericks face the Boston Celtics in the 2024 NBA Finals, the focus of the Dallas defense will be stopping Boston's superstar duo of Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown.\n\nThe 'Jays,' as they are called, have emerged as one of the best duos in the NBA today. What makes their tandem more deadly is that there is no clear Batman and Robin, as either can be the #1 option on any given night. And not only do they excel on offense, but both are also excellent defenders.\n\nHowever, aside from Tatum and Brown, Mavericks head coach Jason Kidd is concerned about a third Celtic. During his recent appearance on the 'Stephen A. Smith Show,' Kidd revealed which player on Boston's roster he is worried about.\n\n\"The other gentleman that you know we're all concerned about here in Dallas is White,\" said Kidd.\n\nDerrick takes the C's offense to another level\n\nWhite has been the Celtics' third-best player in the current playoffs. The 6'4'' guard is averaging 17.8 points, 4.1 rebounds, 4.6 assists, and 1.3 blocks per game in 14 postseason games. He is considered one of the best defensive guards in the NBA and is coming off a second straight appearance in the NBA All-Defensive First team.\n\nNot only is Derrick a standout on defense, but he is also a knockdown three-point shooter. At 40.7%, White leads the team in three-point shooting percentage. The Celtics are 8-0 in the playoffs when he hits at least three three-pointers in a game. Boston has won by at least 12 points when he makes at least four triples in a game.\n\n\"When you talk about his ability to shoot the three, again he's one that a lot of times goes under the radar, but when he's able to knock down threes and he gets a lot of looks at them, it takes their offense to another level. They got a lot of lasers out there, we gotta be able to guard the three but White is the one that we are concerned about,\" added Kidd.\n\nReggie says Boston has an unfair backcourt duo\n\nCoach Kidd's concern is valid. As Indiana Pacers Hall of Famer recently said, the Celtics having both White and Jrue Holiday is an unfair advantage. According to Uncle Reg, Derrick and Jrue are the most important players for the current Boston team.\n\n\"Let me say this about the Boston Celtics. Jrue Holiday and Derrick White, it's almost unfair. Seriously, those two dudes do every single little thing that impacts winning,\" Reggie said on The Dan Patrick Show. \"They take their team's temperature, whatever their team will need that night. I know all the headlines go to Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown... But this team, the bread-and-butter, to me, is Holiday and White.\"\n\nNo one will argue that Jayson and Jaylen are the No.1 and No. 2 options for the Celtics and that the ranking is interchangeable. However, when you look at every playoff series, the stars on both teams always cancel each other out. The team with the role players who come up big always wins in the playoffs. Unfortunately for Kidd, that's White's specialty.\n\nRelated: Bill Simmons on why Dallas beating Boston would be a huge upset: \"There's three giant history red flags with the Mavericks\"", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": "shane_garry_acedera@postandcourier.com", "name": "Shane Garry Acedera", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason_Kidd", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jason Kidd"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Basketball_Association", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "National Basketball Association"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Dallas Mavericks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-point_field_goal", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Three-point field goal"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Boston"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Boston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallas", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Dallas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Dallas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jayson_Tatum", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jayson Tatum"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_playoffs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NBA playoffs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaylen_Brown", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Jaylen Brown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_A._Smith", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Stephen A. {"uri": "8164916049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:02:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:02:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:01:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/06/how-to-buy-dallas-mavericks-watch-party-tickets-for-game-1-of-the-nba-finals-at-american-airlines-center.html", "title": "How to buy Dallas Mavericks watch party tickets at American Airlines Center for Game 1 of the NBA Finals", "body": "The NBA Finals begins Thursday, June 6, 2024, with Game 1 between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics at TD Garden at 8:30 p.m. ET.\n\nIf you want to purchase tickets for the official Dallas Mavericks watch party at American Airlines Center, you can do so at Ticketmaster for $10 per person. Doors open at 6 p.m.\n\nHow to watch online: Fans can watch the game for FREE via a trial of DirecTV Stream or fuboTV.\n\nYou can also purchase a subscription to SlingTV, which is offering $25 off any package for the first month or a three-month subscription for just $90.\n\nLAS VEGAS (AP) -- The Celtics are prohibitive favorites to win Thursday's Game 1 of the NBA Finals and odds are on Boston to hoist what would be its record 18th championship banner.\n\nBut the money, at least at BetMGM Sportsbook, is pouring in on the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nSenior trader Halvor Egeland said Monday that 80% of the bets were coming on Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving and the Mavs to win their second NBA title. Boston is a -225 favorite to win it all, meaning someone would need to wager $225 to win $100.\n\nAs for the series opener, the Celtics are 6 1/2-point favorites, but 63% of the money has been on the Mavericks to cover the spread. Dallas is receiving 70% of the bets to win the game outright at +200.\n\n\"Pretty much, the public is just believing in the Mavericks,\" Egeland said.\n\nDespite that, the Celtics' odds have remained consistently solid not only at BetMGM but other sportsbooks as well. Even though Egeland said professional bettors are largely sitting out this series because they don't find much betting value, he said he didn't expect the lines to be significantly affected.\n\n\"We feel it's the correct betting line,\" Egeland said. \"If we were trading strictly off money, we would've moved it towards the Mavericks because it's all Mavericks money. But we're trying to get to a point where we're at like an equilibrium -- half the time (betting is) going to be on one side, half the time it's going to go on the other. We've landed at 6 1/2 and that's the strategy you take.\"\n\nEgeland said there's a reason the Celtics are favored.\n\n\"The Celtics had an 82-game season and they've been the best team all year,\" he said. \"I know they haven't had the toughest competition to get to the Finals, but like I said, they've had 82 games to prove themselves, and they've done nothing but show you that they're that good of a team.\"\n\nTHE PORZINGIS FACTOR\n\nPart of the reason for the opening-game spread, Egeland said, is the expected return of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis. He hasn't played since straining his left calf in Game 4 of the opening round against the Miami Heat.\n\nPorzingis not only would give the Celtics size if he is back, but the 7-footer is an effective 3-point shooter, creating a difficult matchup for the Mavs. He averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds during the regular season.\n\nEgeland said if the Celtics have to sit Porzingis yet again, they likely would drop to 4 1/2- or 5-point favorites.\n\n\"The team's been pretty good without him,\" DraftKings sportsbook operations director Johnny Avello said. \"So with him, it makes them even that much better. Will he be able to get back into the mix kind of quickly? I think so. This series could be a seven-game series, so any bodies you can get in there and contribute, they are welcome for both sides.\"\n\nRUST VS. REST\n\nBoth teams have received extended time off to prepare for this series after the Celtics swept the Indiana Pacers and the Mavericks eliminated the Minnesota Timberwolves in five games.\n\n\"I would say the Mavs had it a little bit harder than the Celts did, so maybe (the layoff) would affect the Celtics more since they didn't get pushed much,\" Avello said. \"The Mavs' 4-1 (series victory) wasn't really reflective of how that series went, although you consider the Celtics, too. They could've lost an early game (to Indiana). It certainly would've changed the complexion of that series.\"\n\nEgeland said the extra prep time should especially benefit Porzingis, but also noted that Doncic has been playing on a gimpy knee and ankle.\n\nM-V-P!\n\nJayson Tatum is a -120 favorite to be the Finals MVP at BetMGM, but Doncic is close behind at +200. DraftKings has Doncic at -205 and Tatum at +280, nearly a complete flip from late last week.\n\n\"He's taking more money,\" Avello said of Doncic before the odds changed.\n\nHOW LONG CAN IT GO?\n\nThe odds at BetMGM favor the series ending in anywhere between five and seven games, with the odds ranging from +200 to +225. A sweep is at +450.\n\nDraftKings is even more bullish on a long series, posting the chances of it going six or seven games at -150 compared to +125 to be shorter.\n\nThank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. {"uri": "8164026540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:33:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:33:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:33:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/sport/basketball/article/3265582/luka-doncic-dallas-mavericks-stand-way-boston-celtics-18th-title-nba-finals-begin", "title": "Doncic and his Mavs stand in the way of Celtics' 18th title as NBA Finals begin", "body": "Slovenian, who has been the playoffs\u2019 best player, is well equipped to foil the season\u2019s form team from winning their first title since 2008\n\nA Celtics team desperate for championship glory face Luka Doncic and a Dallas Mavericks squad eager to play spoiler in an intriguing NBA Finals match-up that tips off on Thursday in Boston.\n\nLed by superstars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the sharpshooting Celtics have had a relatively easy road to the finals.\n\nComing out of the weaker Eastern Conference as the top seed, they breezed past the Jimmy Butler-less Miami Heat, dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers and swept past the Indiana Pacers, who were without point guard Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games.\n\nThe Celtics have won 12 of their 14 playoff games and gone undefeated on the road but they know that none of that will matter if they fail to end a title drought that stretches back to 2008.\n\nThe mission is clear: hang that elusive 18th championship banner from the TD Garden rafters and put recent postseason disappointment, including falling to the Warriors in the 2022 finals and coming up short in the conference finals last year, firmly behind them.\n\nAnything less will be seen as a bitter disappointment.\n\n\u201cThey were the best team in the regular season and they have been the best team in the playoffs,\u201d former player and current ESPN analyst JJ Redick said on a call with reporters.\n\n\u201cI feel strongly that they are the favourites going into this series. At the same time, I wouldn\u2019t be surprised if Luka and Dallas and Kyrie (Irving) and (head coach Jason Kidd) made this a series and won \u2026 This is going to be a phenomenal series.\u201d\n\nStanding in Boston\u2019s way is a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin the Celtics\u2019 title aspirations.\n\nThat starts with Doncic, the 25-year-old Slovenian who is quickly becoming the face of the league.\n\nHe has been the best player in the playoffs and is the first to lead in points (489), rebounds (164) and assists (150) coming into a finals.\n\nBy his side is veteran point guard Irving who, after turbulent stints in Brooklyn and Boston, has looked more comfortable and confident on the court than he has in years.\n\n\u201cI think it\u2019s fair to say that offensively they are as talented as any backcourt in NBA history,\u201d Redick said of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne big, 7-foot 2-inch (2.18-metre) question mark hanging over the series is the health of Boston\u2019s Kristaps Porzingis, the former Maverick who suffered a calf strain in the Heat series and has been sidelined since.\n\nThe Celtics are hopeful that their prized off season acquisition, who averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks during the regular season, will be healthy enough to match up against the Mavs\u2019 breakout big men Daniel {"uri": "8164932515", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:13:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:13:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:12:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/06/what-channel-is-the-nba-finals-game-1-dallas-mavericks-vs-boston-celtics-game-on-today-6624-free-live-stream-time-tv-channel.html", "title": "What channel is the NBA Finals Game 1 Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics game on today (6/6/24)? | FREE LIVE STREAM, time, TV, channel", "body": "The NBA Finals begins Thursday, June 6, 2024, with Game 1 between the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics at TD Garden at 8:30 p.m.\n\nHow to watch: Fans can watch the game for FREE via a trial of DirecTV Stream or fuboTV.\n\nYou can also purchase a subscription to SlingTV, which is offering $25 off any package for the first month or a three-month subscription for just $90.\n\nLAS VEGAS (AP) -- The Celtics are prohibitive favorites to win Thursday's Game 1 of the NBA Finals and odds are on Boston to hoist what would be its record 18th championship banner.\n\nBut the money, at least at BetMGM Sportsbook, is pouring in on the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nSenior trader Halvor Egeland said Monday that 80% of the bets were coming on Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving and the Mavs to win their second NBA title. Boston is a -225 favorite to win it all, meaning someone would need to wager $225 to win $100.\n\nAs for the series opener, the Celtics are 6 1/2-point favorites, but 63% of the money has been on the Mavericks to cover the spread. Dallas is receiving 70% of the bets to win the game outright at +200.\n\n\"Pretty much, the public is just believing in the Mavericks,\" Egeland said.\n\nDespite that, the Celtics' odds have remained consistently solid not only at BetMGM but other sportsbooks as well. Even though Egeland said professional bettors are largely sitting out this series because they don't find much betting value, he said he didn't expect the lines to be significantly affected.\n\n\"We feel it's the correct betting line,\" Egeland said. \"If we were trading strictly off money, we would've moved it towards the Mavericks because it's all Mavericks money. But we're trying to get to a point where we're at like an equilibrium -- half the time (betting is) going to be on one side, half the time it's going to go on the other. We've landed at 6 1/2 and that's the strategy you take.\"\n\nEgeland said there's a reason the Celtics are favored.\n\n\"The Celtics had an 82-game season and they've been the best team all year,\" he said. \"I know they haven't had the toughest competition to get to the Finals, but like I said, they've had 82 games to prove themselves, and they've done nothing but show you that they're that good of a team.\"\n\nTHE PORZINGIS FACTOR\n\nPart of the reason for the opening-game spread, Egeland said, is the expected return of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis. He hasn't played since straining his left calf in Game 4 of the opening round against the Miami Heat.\n\nPorzingis not only would give the Celtics size if he is back, but the 7-footer is an effective 3-point shooter, creating a difficult matchup for the Mavs. He averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds during the regular season.\n\nEgeland said if the Celtics have to sit Porzingis yet again, they likely would drop to 4 1/2- or 5-point favorites.\n\n\"The team's been pretty good without him,\" DraftKings sportsbook operations director Johnny Avello said. \"So with him, it makes them even that much better. Will he be able to get back into the mix kind of quickly? I think so. This series could be a seven-game series, so any bodies you can get in there and contribute, they are welcome for both sides.\"\n\nRUST VS. REST\n\nBoth teams have received extended time off to prepare for this series after the Celtics swept the Indiana Pacers and the Mavericks eliminated the Minnesota Timberwolves in five games.\n\n\"I would say the Mavs had it a little bit harder than the Celts did, so maybe (the layoff) would affect the Celtics more since they didn't get pushed much,\" Avello said. \"The Mavs' 4-1 (series victory) wasn't really reflective of how that series went, although you consider the Celtics, too. They could've lost an early game (to Indiana). It certainly would've changed the complexion of that series.\"\n\nEgeland said the extra prep time should especially benefit Porzingis, but also noted that Doncic has been playing on a gimpy knee and ankle.\n\nM-V-P!\n\nJayson Tatum is a -120 favorite to be the Finals MVP at BetMGM, but Doncic is close behind at +200. DraftKings has Doncic at -205 and Tatum at +280, nearly a complete flip from late last week.\n\n\"He's taking more money,\" Avello said of Doncic before the odds changed.\n\nHOW LONG CAN IT GO?\n\nThe odds at BetMGM favor the series ending in anywhere between five and seven games, with the odds ranging from +200 to +225. A sweep is at +450.\n\nDraftKings is even more bullish on a long series, posting the chances of it going six or seven games at -150 compared to +125 to be shorter.\n\nThank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. {"uri": "8163721254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:50:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:50:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:50:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/sport/basketball/redemption-seeking-celtics-face-mavericks-in-nba-finals-c-14927215", "title": "Redemption-seeking Celtics face Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "As the Dallas Mavericks and Boston Celtics prepare to tip off the NBA Finals, the four biggest names in the series are looking at this moment through different lenses.\n\nBoston's Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown see it as a chance at redemption after falling narrowly short two seasons ago and then failing to return last year.\n\n\"You think you're young (and) if you've been once, you'll continue to keep going,\" Tatum said.\n\n\"We realised that last year. We kind of took it for granted at certain moments.\"\n\nDallas's Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving see the Finals as their first opportunity to make good on a partnership that began late last season after the latter was traded from Brooklyn.\n\nAfter a slow start this season, the superstar pair found cohesion after the All-Star break and emerged from a deep Western Conference field.\n\nFor Irving, it has been a reminder that success can be fleeting.\n\nHe won his lone championship with Cleveland in 2016 and has played with three teams over the past eight years. His time in Dallas has reinvigorated him.\n\n\"These young guys are very hungry. They want a championship. I want a championship,\" he said.\n\n\"So our feelings are very mutual. But I've always reminded them that this is a process. Failure is going to be part of this, too.\"\n\nDoncic credits the partnership with Irving for uncorking the potential of a team that entered the post-season as a fifth seed.\n\n\"His leadership is amazing,\" Doncic said.\n\n\"The way he connects us. Me and Kyrie are the leaders of this team, but he's the one that's been in the Finals. He's the one that won in the Finals. He's the one that is really leading it.\"\n\nAlongside the Mavericks' Australian pair Dante Exum and Josh Green, they will matchup with a Boston team playing like a group that has learned from its recent shortcomings.\n\nBrown said a core that features seven players from the 2022 team that lost in the Finals to Golden State, is up to the challenge.\n\n\"We've been able to go through the experiences of having success but not having success at the same time,\" he said.\n\n\"To solidify the ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. That will add a lot to our legacy.\"\n\nThis stage is nothing new to Mavericks mentor Jason Kidd, who is in the Finals for the fifth time as a player or coach.\n\nHe has experienced lows - losing in 2002 and 2003 as a player with the New Jersey Nets - as well as the highs of his lone title as a player with Dallas in 2011 and as an assistant on the Lakers' 2020 championship team.\n\n\"This is the best of the best at the highest level,\" Kidd said.\n\n\"It's fun. That's what the Finals are all about - seeing what team is going to step forward and take advantage of mistakes.\"\n\nAccording to Boston's Joe Mazzulla, it's the \"toughest team\" that will take the honours.\n\n\"The team that makes the most plays will win. The team that can execute the details at a high level will win. {"uri": "8162257160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "05:56:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T05:56:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T05:52:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/sports/national_sports/celtics-in-6-local-nba-scout-makes-case-for-banner-no-18/article_d1108428-227c-11ef-8be4-fb9bce5c83aa.html", "title": "'Celtics in 6': Local NBA scout makes case for Banner No. 18", "body": "Local NBA scout Jeff Nelson has pegged the Boston Celtics playoffs, series by series, almost to a \"T.\"\n\nHe had the first two series going five games and the Celtics sweeping the Pacers if they won Game 2. They did and they swept.\n\nNelson, who has watched nearly every Celtics game this season, is back for the NBA Finals, the Celtics versus the Dallas Mavericks.\n\n\"This is going to be their toughest series by far,\" said Nelson, who scouted games this past season for the Phoenix Suns. \"This is going to be a real series, with two elite teams with each team having stars.\n\n\"Obviously, there are a lot of factors, matchups, etc., but in the end it usually comes down the superstars,\" he said. \"I believe it will come down to which duo, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, and Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving. Whichever duo plays the best will win.\"\n\nThat being said, there is a lot to break down.\n\n\"The Celtics strength will be their ability to throw several players at Luka, like Jrue Holiday, Brown and Derrick White,\" said Nelson. \"At the other end, how does Dallas match up with Brown and Tatum. The Mavs have Derrick Jones, who is a great defender. How will they both the Celtics best two players.\"\n\nThe wild card in the series, said Nelson, is Kristaps Porzingis. He can be the X-factor.\n\n\"Will Porzingis be a luxury for the Celtics, playing part-time, or will he be a necessity?\" said Nelson. \"If he is healthy and playing big minutes, he can have a big impact if he's hitting three's from deep. It will make it harder for the Mavs to load up on Brown and Tatum.\"\n\nNelson expects White to be a key defender on Kyrie.\n\n\"I believe Dallas would love opportunity to have White on Kyrie,\" he said. \"White is a very good defender, but Kyrie can crush that matchup. He's playing with a lot of confidence right now. If White can contain Kyrie, that would be huge for the Celtics. But I see Kyrie winning that battle.\"\n\nAnother key for the Mavericks, if they are going to have success in the series, is rebounding.\n\n\"The Celtics sometimes have problems rebounding. That where (Dereck) Lively, (Daniel) Gafford and (P.J.) Washington could help the Mavs cause,\" said Nelson. \"Those three are very athletic and could cause the Celtics some problems.\"\n\nWhile the Celtics bench was not a big factor in their run to the finals, Nelson expects Payton Pritchard and Sam Hauser to up their games in this series.\n\n\"Pritchard doesn't always have to score to add value,\" said Nelson. \"He is a threat as a three-point shooter, but he adds energy off the bench. He seems to get a lot of big offensive rebounds.\n\n\"Hauser has had some time to find his game,\" said Nelson. \"I expect him to play better in this series, hit some open shots.\"\n\nNelson is not sure if there is a good plan to \"shut down\" Doncic.\n\n\"The Timberwolves tried eight different ways to guard him and none worked,\" said Nelson. \"They tried doubling. They tried straight up, one on one. They tried under screens. They tried drop coverage, allowing him to shoot from the logo ... and he did. and made almost every shot. I think you have to live with Luka getting his 40 points.\"\n\nNelson said the key for the Celtics is on the other end, making Doncic and Kyrie play defense.\n\n\"I think the Celtics can attack the Mavs in transition and be physical with them,\" said Nelson. \"I believe the Celtics would wear them out. The Timberwolves didn't really try that. You want to make their two stars play defense.\"\n\nA key for the Celtics, on offense, said Nelson, is to make the extra pass and shoot 3-pointers on transition, moving the ball.\n\n\"The Celtics would be playing into the Mavs hands if they do a lot of isolation, one on one stuff,\" said Nelson. \"The Celtics can slow down the Mavs transition game by scoring.\"\n\nOverall, Nelson sees a good, hard-fought, emotional series led by stars in the NBA.\n\n\"I'm sticking with the Celtics. They have had the better year all year,\" said Nelson. \"I think the national media's bashing of the Celtics is unfounded, that they don't 'trust' them, that 'Tatum and Brown don't like each other,' that 'Joe Mazzulla can't coach.'\n\n\"I think this is their year and now they have to prove it against a quality, quality team,\" said Nelson. \"I'm going to pick the Celtics in six.\"\n\nYou can {"uri": "2024-06-381032181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:02:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:02:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://celticswire.usatoday.com/lists/celtics-vs-mavs-game-1-nbafinals-prediction-preview-how-to-watch-stream-start-key-stats-6-6/", "title": "Celtics vs. Mavs, Game 1 NBAfinals: Prediction, preview, how to watch, stream, start, key stats (6/6)", "body": "The Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks will start their 2024 NBA Finals series at TD Garden this ocming Thursday (June 6) evening. In something of a changing of the guard, we will have two storied ball clubs with young stars vying for their first title and experienced vets who have been there before to help guide them there.\n\nLaden with multiple and often parallel narratives, from prodigal sons returning home to a potentially nascent rivalry for the ages in the works, there are plenty of things to watch in this series. The complexity and adaptability of both ball clubs hints that this will almost certainly be a longer series.\n\nBut for Game 1, we'll take the Celtics with Porzingis back in the fold.\n\nCeltics statistical leaders\n\nPoints: Jaylen Brown - 26.0 Rebounds: Jayson Tatum - 10.4 Assists: Jayson Tatum - 5.9 Blocks: Kristaps Porzingis - 1.5 Steals: Jrue Holiday - 1.3\n\nMavs statistical {"uri": "8163856332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:45:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:45:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:44:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://fanbuzz.com/nba/nba-2024-finals-storyline-and-players-to-watch/", "title": "2024 NBA Finals: Storyline And Players To Watch", "body": "The Boston Celtics are set to take on the Dallas Mavericks in the 2024 NBA Finals, which features a series of player rivalries. When comparing the two teams, the Celtics have 17 NBA titles in franchise history, while the Mavs are seeking their second-ever championship, as the last came in 2011 when Dirk Nowitzki helped lead the team to upset the Miami Heat (4-2). On the other hand, Boston is looking for their first ring since 2008, when Paul Pierce, Kevin Garnett, and Ray Allen defeated Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers (4-2).\n\nThe storyline for this series has a revenge undertone, considering there are two players who will be facing their old teams, as Kyrie used to play for the Celtics from 2017-19 and Porzingis is a former Mavericks player from 2019-22. With that being said, both players are difference makers for their new respective teams, and the fans and teammates of their past teams have undoubtedly not forgotten about them.\n\nThat is to say, Kyrie will most likely be more hated by the Boston fans than Porzingis upon his return to Dallas. Kyrie left in free agency to join the Nets after two seasons, while Porzingis was traded to the Washington Wizards ahead of the 2022 trade deadline.\n\nPorzingis made the following statement, \"It's going to be fun going up against my old team.\"\n\nThen Kyrie stated that he is not scared of the Celtics fans.\n\n\"There's no fear out here, man. It's basketball,\" Irving said. \"The fans are gonna say what they're gonna say.\"\n\nAs both players didn't fit with their previous teams, after finding their new homes, they have certainly flourished and will be counted on by their teammates in order to win their respective organizations a title.\n\nEspecially Kyrie who has by far the most playoff experience on a young Mavs team that has only made it passed the first round one time since their last '11 championship. Notably, this is Kyrie's fourth NBA championship appearance, as he memorably won the 2016 Finals with the Cleveland Cavaliers. To point out, Kyrie ranks eighth all-time for highest points per game in NBA Finals history (27.7 ppg).\n\nThen when looking at Kyrie's backcourt partner, Luka Doncic, the Slovenian is hoping to follow in his old teammate Nowitzki's footsteps, in bringing a championship to Dallas. Seemingly, Luka is the best player in the series, as he leads the Mavericks in almost every statistical category. To emphasize, the 25-year-old superstar had the highest usage rating (35.9%) out of any player this season and went on to win the 2023-24 NBA scoring title, averaging 33.9 points (48.7% FG; 38.2% 3P), 9.2 rebounds, and 9.8 assists.\n\nThe supporting cast for the Mavs features two pieces, Daniel Gafford and PJ Washington, both of which were acquired ahead of the NBA trade deadline. Gafford, the former Washington Wizards center, is averaging 9.2 points, 5.9 rebounds and 1.8 blocks (team-leader) in 21.8 minutes per game in the playoffs. Throughout the postseason, Washington, the former Charlotte Hornets player, is currently averaging 13.6 points, 6.7 rebounds in 36.5 minutes per game.\n\nThe Celtics' top scorers throughout the postseason have been Jayson Tatum (26.0 ppg; 44.2% FG) and Jaylen Brown (25.0 ppg; 54.1% FG), but the team has an arsenal of weapons surrounding the two co-stars. Meaning to say, Boston's supporting cast has a big three of their own that includes Derrick White (17.8 ppg), Jrue Holiday (12.7 ppg), and Porzingis (returning from calf injury), who can all impact the game on both the offense and defensive side of the ball.\n\nTatum, is leading his team in three major stat categories this postseason with 26.0 points, 10.4 rebounds, 5.9 assists. The 26-year-old will hope to improve on his 2022 Finals performance in which he averaged 21.5 ppg on 36.7% FG shooting.\n\nWhen looking at the underdogs and their chances, head coach Jason Kidd, who was on the 2011 Mavericks team that won the championship, said the team will rely on their star players.\n\n\"Some of us for the Mavs have been here, some of us haven't... We're going to embrace that and find a way to hopefully win a series.\"\n\nKyrie Irving, who is the veteran leader of the Mavs, will be going up against his one-time teammates in Tatum and Brown, and will without a doubt hear an array of boos as he goes back to play at Boston's TD Garden for Game 1 which will tip-off June 6 at 8:30 pm ET.", "source": {"uri": "fanbuzz.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8163608956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:35:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:35:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:34:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://nesn.com/2024/06/celtics-still-remember-pain-of-2022-nba-finals-you-can-always-learn/", "title": "Celtics Still Remember Pain Of 2022 NBA Finals: 'You Can Always Learn'", "body": "BOSTON -- After swallowing the disappointment of squandering a trip to the NBA Finals two years ago, the Celtics are entering a familiar stage this go-around against the Mavericks with redemption in mind.\n\nThe 64-win Celtics, cruising with a 12-2 postseason record, will host Dallas to begin the Finals on Thursday night. Although, even with a clean slate and improved roster working to Boston's advantage, those who experienced the anguish of watching TD Garden host a champagne/confetti-filled Warriors celebration in 2022, haven't forgotten the heartbreak and disappointment.\n\n\"I've watched (the 2022 Finals) a few times now, maybe four or five times. As well as last year's (Eastern) conference finals,\" Jaylen Brown revealed during Wednesday's Finals media day at TD Garden. \"I think you can always learn from anything really. But just being able to watch those moments and learn from them, how to manage your emotions, like, what you would have did differently potentially. I don't think that's bad to look at and acknowledge and be aware of.\"\n\nBoston held a 2-1 series lead over Golden State, closer than the team had been in raising Banner 18 in over a decade, but crumbled. The inexperience a jitters of performing on the highest stage against a dynasty sunk the Celtics and allowed the Warriors to put them away in six games.\n\nSince that series, it's felt like a long road to returning.\n\nThe chance at a second consecutive trip was there for the taking last season as Boston drew a favorable opponent in the No. 8 seed Heat in the conference finals. But, once again, the lack of urgency, hunger, and non-existent killer instinct backfired on the then-nonchalant Celtics, prompting some much-needed roster reconstruction during the offseason.\n\nMarcus Smart and Robert Williams III, who both partook in the 2022 Finals run, packed their bags and departed Boston as the team's sacrificial lambs.\n\n\"I give a lot of credit to that team, the Warriors,\" Tatum said when looking back. \"I think we understood what it took to get there. They understood what it took to get over the hump. That was really a special team that didn't make many mistakes, obviously well-coached.\"\n\nTatum added: \"I told myself that if I ever got the opportunity again to make it to the Finals, never take it for granted. Obviously, we're here now. Thankful to be here. I'm excited to get ready to play and have fun tomorrow.\"\n\nAt every opportunity leading up to the Finals, the Celtics have played the part of a team on the hunt for vengeance. They held on tight to their No. 1 seed after ripping it from the Sixers on Nov. 14, and didn't cough it up until the end of the regular season. Boston didn't lose more than twice consecutively, and that trend has extended to the postseason. Plus, the team did its job by surpassing everyone in the East while giving a then-injured Kristaps Porzingis time to recover from a strained calf injury.", "source": {"uri": "nesn.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8162071446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "03:00:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T03:00:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T02:59:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://nesn.com/2024/06/kyrie-irving-among-biggest-villains-to-face-celtics-in-nba-finals/", "title": "Kyrie Irving Among Biggest Villains To Face Celtics In NBA Finals", "body": "The Boston Celtics have come across their fair share of villainous players over the course of their illustrious history.\n\nKyrie Irving certainly fits into that category and will be public enemy No. 1 in Boston when he takes the floor at TD Garden with the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday night for Game 1 of the NBA Finals.\n\nHow Irving earned the villain status in the eyes of Celtics fans is well-documented. He announced his commitment to re-sign with the organization only to turn his back and flee in free agency. He then met the relentless boos of Celtics fans in his returns to Boston by flipping the bird and mocking them.\n\nBut Irving's actions aren't new to the Boston fan base. In fact, the talented guard is just the latest in a long list of villains to face the Celtics on the NBA's grandest stage.\n\nAnd while Irving might play the role of Celtics villain better than anyone, these players -- many of them who wore Los Angeles Lakers jerseys -- also stood out for drawing the ire of the fans in the Finals.\n\nDraymond Green\n\nThe Golden State Warriors forward knows how to rile up a fan base and he did that two years ago against the Celtics. Green became a target for Celtics fans when he got in a dust up with Jaylen Brown in Game 2.\n\nWhen the Warriors traveled to Boston as the series continued, Green got an earful from Celtics fans, including his name being included in expletive-filled chants. Green didn't back down after that and only seemed to be fueled by fans' hatred of him.\n\nGreen and the Warriors got the last laugh with Golden State securing an NBA title on the famed parquet floor in Game 6. Green, an able and willing trash talker, left Celtics fans know how he felt as a parting gift.\n\nRalph Sampson\n\nSampson became a mortal enemy in Game 5 of the 1986 Finals when he threw a right hook at Celtics guard Jerry Sichting. The fight was the definition of Sampson not picking on someone his own size. At 7-foot-4, the Hall of Fame center decided to go after the 6-foot-1 Sichting in the second quarter before taking on every other member of the Celtics on the floor at that moment.\n\n\"I don't know why he hit me. What could I do? I threw a couple of elbows, and then he was punching everybody,\" Sichting told reporters after the game, per The Los Angeles Times.\n\nThe Rockets went on to win the game even after Sampson was ejected -- Sichting remained in the game. Sampson got a nasty welcome back in Boston for Game 6 with fans in the stands hanging a Sampson mannequin by a noose.\n\nPat Riley\n\nRiley was the constant figure on the sidelines for the three legendary Finals battles between the Lakers and Celtics in the 1980s. He was one of the main faces of the Showtime Lakers with his slick back hair and fancy suits, which seemed to stand for everything the lunch-pail Celtics of that time were not.\n\nBoston's mystique seemed to get Riley, too. According to The Boston Globe's Dan Shaughnessy, Riley moved the Lakers to three different hotels during the 1984 series to get away from rowdy Boston fans.\n\nRiley's hatred for the Celtics seemed to ooze out of him even well after taking two out of those three Finals matchups. He exchanged heated words with then-Celtics president of basketball operations Danny Ainge in 2013 after Ainge complained about how LeBron James was officiated.\n\n\"Danny Ainge needs to shut the (expletive) up and manage his own team,\" Riley said in a statement, per ESPN. \"He was the biggest whiner going when he was playing and I know that because I coached against him.\"\n\nWilt Chamberlain\n\nIt was a clash of styles between Chamberlain's all-around individual greatness and Bill Russell's team-first mentality. Russell only lost one playoff series in his career against Chamberlain and beat Chamberlain twice in the Finals, including going out in style in 1969.\n\nIt was easy to root against Chamberlain, especially with him struggling continuously against the Celtics and Russell.\n\nThere's a reason the Finals MVP award is named after Russell and not Chamberlain.\n\nMetta World Peace\n\nThere had to be someone on this list from the two Finals showdown the Celtics had with the Lakers this century. Peace, formerly known as Ron Artest, fit the billing of the Lakers villain. His physical style of play, especially on the defensive end, seemed to always tip-toe staying on the line and had Celtics fans watching his every move.\n\nPrior to joining the Lakers, Peace had a run-in with Paul Pierce while a member of the Indiana Pacers. He tried to slow Pierce down by pulling down Pierce's shorts, but the tactic ultimately failed with Pierce hitting a 3-pointer on the play.\n\nIt always hurts that Peace, not Kobe Bryant, made the biggest shot of Game 7 of the 2010 Finals by sinking a 3-pointer with a minute left.\n\nMoses Malone\n\nMalone thought it was a wise decision to unleash some trash talk prior to Game 5 of the 1981 Finals. Bad decision.\n\n\"I could get four guys off the street in Petersburg (Virginia, Malone's hometown) and beat them,\" Malone said.\n\nThe Celtics responded by handling Malone and the Rockets as Boston won the next two games after Malone's remarks to close out the series. According to Celtics great Cedric Maxwell, he and his teammates taunted Malone on the floor for his comments, telling the Hall of Famer he \"better go get them other four guys, because they have to be better than the four you have right now.\"\n\nMalone really should have been more careful with what he said in that moment and it completely backfired on him.", "source": {"uri": "nesn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NESN"}, "authors": [{"uri": "greg_dudek@nesn.com", "name": "Greg Dudek", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://nesn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2024/06/Kyrie_Irving_cd21c0.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "2024-06-378823629", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "19:43:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T19:43:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T19:39:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.si.com/nba/jayson-tatum-and-jaylen-browns-relationship-is-fine-but-their-pairing-could-elevate-with-a-title", "title": "Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown's Relationship Is Fine, but Their Pairing Could Elevate With a Title", "body": "Jayson Tatum and guard Jaylen Brown are aiming for their first NBA championship. / David Butler II-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThere are no issues between Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown.\n\nPressure? Well ...\n\nLast week, the four-letter network made waves by reigniting a long-dormant debate about Tatum and Brown's relationship. Only there is no debate. Tatum and Brown are fine. Always have been. They have known each other since high school, when they competed at an Under Armour camp. They are, as Brown noted last week, \"polar opposites.\" But whenever the trade rumors swirled around Brown over the years, Tatum has backed him. When Tatum won a gold medal at the 2021 Olympics, Brown celebrated with him. In '22, while reporting a Sports Illustrated cover story on the Boston Celtics, I asked Tatum's longtime trainer, Drew Hanlen, if he had any thoughts on the Tatum-Brown relationship.\n\n\"Jayson brags about how good Jaylen is,\" Hanlen told me. \"How there aren't many players he would trade straight up for him. Any narrative that they didn't like each other, that they can't win together is totally made up.\"\n\nIndeed, they can win together. Boston has made six conference finals in the Tatum-Brown era. Two NBA Finals. Four seasons of 50-plus wins. In a league that covets elite two-way wings, the Celtics have a pair of them.\n\nStill, Boston's duo has reached a critical juncture. The 2022 Finals defeat was disappointing. But, in a way, excusable. The Golden State Warriors were elite. They had championship-level talent and years of experience with it. Did the Celtics gag away a potential 3-1 series lead in Game 4? Maybe. More accurate would be Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and the Warriors went out and took it.\n\n\"This time, this go-around is a lot different,\" Tatum said. \"You don't always get a second chance, so really just looking at it as a second chance and trying to simplify things as much as we can.\"\n\nAdded Al Horford, \"The first time [in 2022], it felt like a roller coaster, just a lot going on, increased coverage in media, all the responsibilities we had and everything that came with it. This time around, we all have an understanding. We know what things are like and I feel like we'll be able to manage it better.\"\n\nThis year, there are no Warriors. The Dallas Mavericks are good. They have Luka Doncic, a superstar. Kyrie Irving, a premiere wingman. P.J. Washington, Dereck Lively II and Derrick Jones Jr. can play. The defense has improved considerably since midseason acquisitions to acquire Washington and Daniel Gafford. While the Celtics were cruising through the Miami Heat, Cleveland Cavaliers and Indiana Pacers, the Mavericks were muscling out the Los Angeles Clippers, Oklahoma City Thunder and Minnesota Timberwolves.\n\nStill, the Celtics are heavy favorites. They are six deep with All-Star-level talent. Jrue Holiday and Derrick White are elite defenders. Kristaps Porzingis, who appears to be tracking toward a Game 1 return, is a terror on both ends of the floor. Horford, who celebrated his 38th birthday on Monday, is ageless.\n\nAnd they have Tatum and Brown. This has not been a flawless postseason run. There have been some clunkers. Tatum's 7-for-17 performance in a Game 2 loss to Cleveland. Brown's 0-for-6 three-point stat line in the same game. But the Celtics are 12-2 in the playoffs, with Tatum (26.0 points on 44.2% shooting) and Brown (25.0 points, 54.1% shooting) leading the way.\n\nNow, though, comes the real test. The scrutiny of Tatum and Brown's relationship is unfair. \"The whole thing about that really pisses me off,\" coach Joe Mazzulla said. Raising expectations for their play is not. Curry and Thompson won't be remembered for conference championships. Nikola Jokic and Jamal Murray aren't defined by 50-win seasons. If Tatum and Brown want to be regarded as an elite duo, they need to win a title.\n\nFor years, Tatum has been among the NBA's most scrutinized stars. He's a great scorer ... just not always in the clutch. He's a strong defender ... just not one of the best. Even as Tatum's game has grown -- in the post, at the rim, in his playmaking -- he's often viewed as a cut below the NBA's best.\n\nBrown, too. Brown signed the richest contract in NBA history last summer. He responded with a season (23.0 points, 5.5 rebounds, a career-best 3.6 assists) worthy of it. In Boston, Brown will always be the second star. But that doesn't mean he can't be one of the best wings in the game.\n\n\"As long as my team knows my value, my city knows my value, my family, that's all I really care about,\" Brown said. \"But I like to set my hat on just being a versatile two-way wing [who] can do both at any point in time.\"\n\nTatum and Brown understand the stakes. A series win springboards them into rarified air, a tandem with a title, and a chance to win more. A loss opens them up for criticism and more questions about whether the pairing really works.\n\n\"I think [it's unfair] being compared to each other,\" Mazzulla said. \"They're different. And you see other duos around the league don't have to go through that. And it's because of the platform that they have. It's because they've been so successful their entire careers. They've been able to long stand success at a high level.\"\n\nNow it's time to do it at the highest. Two years ago, in the immediate aftermath of a Game 6 loss, Tatum slumped in his locker. In TD Garden, the visiting locker room is directly across from the home one, making the roar of the Warriors' celebration unavoidable. Walking to his car that night, Tatum could hear the Champagne-soaked afterparty still raging. He vowed never to forget that feeling. He swore he would never let an opportunity like that slip away again. Two years later, Tatum, still alongside Brown, will get that chance.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports Illustrated"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_mannix@si.com", {"uri": "2024-06-380092634", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:25:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:25:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:16:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/celtics-hunger-for-nba-crown-after-2022-finals-failure/article_d6e0adde-bc58-5e6a-a1cd-0201f871b087.html", "title": "Celtics hunger for NBA crown after 2022 finals failure", "body": "Boston Celtics star Jayson Tatum talks to reporters on the eve of the NBA Finals\n\nA historic championship legacy and a gut-wrenching 2022 finals loss have the Boston Celtics extra motivated to capture their first title since 2008 in this year's NBA Finals.\n\nThe Celtics will play host to the Dallas Mavericks on Thursday in the opener of the best-of-seven series, with stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown excited about their trophy chances after falling to Golden State in the 2022 finals.\n\n\"I hate that we had to go through it. I wish we would have won,\" Tatum said Wednesday. \"But I'm a firm believer that everything happens for a reason. There's a lesson to be learned in every situation.\n\n\"I do feel a lot different this time. I'm excited for the opportunity for us to get the job done. I told myself if I ever got the opportunity again to make it to the finals, never take it for granted. We're here now and I'm excited to get ready to play and have fun.\"\n\nBrown said he has watched the 2022 finals several times to learn how to better manage his emotions and to make better decisions on the court.\n\n\"You learn and grow from your experiences,\" Brown said. \"Two years later makes a pretty big difference.\n\n\"This is a special group. The core group has been here for a few years now. We've been able to go through experiences, having success but not having success at the same time.\n\n\"The ultimate goal is to get over the hump and win. I think that will add a lot to our legacy as a team, but as of right now, that story is still kind of untold.\"\n\nAnother factor is that the Celtics seek an unprecedented 18th NBA crown, one more than the all-time record they share with the rival Los Angeles Lakers.\n\n\"Some of the greatest players to ever play this game wore this uniform. We're honored to follow in their footsteps. They paved the way for us to live out our dreams,\" said Tatum.\n\n\"If you want to be one of the greats to put on this uniform, every great before you won a championship. It takes special players to be part of an environment like that.\"\n\nOne of those is Jrue Holiday, who won a 2021 NBA title with Milwaukee and was obtained in a trade deal just before the season began.\n\n\"To be a part of history would be cool, the history the Celtics have,\" Holiday said. \"To add to that is part of the reason I was brought here -- and part of the reason I wanted to come.\"\n\n- 'The will to win' -\n\nThe defensive standout sees something special in the Celtics, who led the NBA with 64 wins this season.\n\n\"The pressure JB and JT have to take on is something different,\" Holiday said. \"It's really impressive how they handle themselves.\n\n\"I know sometimes talent doesn't mesh together but this does. You saw it in the regular season. You've seen it in the playoffs. Any given night we sacrifice for each other. we're unselfish and I think that's what makes it go.\"\n\n\"And then it's just the will to win. They've been to the Eastern Conference finals a million times and they have been to the finals so they've been to the top, just didn't execute the way they wanted.\n\n\"Now that we're here, we want to get the job done.\"\n\nTatum appreciates the finals more after losing to Miami in seven games in last year's East finals.\n\n\"Last year we took that for granted and we didn't make it to the finals. Put things in prespective,\" Tatum said.\n\n\"You could see our excitement when we won the conference (this year). That's not the be-all, end-all but it really is tough to get to this moment.\n\n\"I'm staying in the moment. I'm not thinking of what this would mean to my legacy or anything like that. Excited to go out and get the job done.\"\n\njs/bb\n\nMore from this section\n\nMontana US Sen. {"uri": "8162751819", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "11:10:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T11:10:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T11:08:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/06/05/finally-the-finals/", "title": "Finally, the Finals | Tessa Jazmines", "body": "On Friday morning, Game 1 of the National Basketball Association Finals will happen for us in this part of the world. And it's a finals series that has all of the ingredients of a blockbuster.\n\nThe Beast of the East meets the Best of the West and there has never been a dueling duo that is so much different and so much alike. Different because sixth place Dallas is going up against top-seed Boston in a storyline similar to rich, privileged kid meeting struggling, self-made man.\n\nBut not really, because before getting to wear an armor of seeming invincibility, Boston had shed tears and had its heart broken, too many times before. And Dallas had conquered the playoffs because it made the best roster-building decisions of its life since drafting Luka Doncic in 2018 by adding Kyrie Irving, Dereck Lively, Grant Williams and Derrick Jones, Jr.\n\nThe two teams are alike in more ways than one. Both have the stars, both have young coaches. Both have played the waiting game too long. The Dallas Mavericks last won their one and only NBA championship in 2011. The 17-going-on-18 Boston Celtics last wore a ring in 2008.\n\nNow the stars have aligned and the waters have parted and these two long-suffering teams are ready and eager to raise another banner to their rafters. It is time.\n\nWill the Boston Celtics continue their season-long dominance in the series? Will the Dallas Mavericks pull off a surprise and negate the luck of the Irish in this one?\n\nSo many factors to consider, but here's one. It's going to be a Battle of Best Duos. Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving versus The Jays of Jaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum. But wait, there's a third J named Jrue Holiday.\n\nAdmittedly, the two-headed monster that is Luka and Kyrie will be a problem for the Celtics. When they're on, they're on and both Luka and his new pardner always find a way to score, somehow or other.\n\nThe Mavs are also excellent rim protectors. And the Celtics are elite 3-point shooters. When the Celtics' threes come pouring in, the rim may lose its protection, and the Green cavalry can come charging in. Boston's offense is hard to stop when all five men are locked in. The dynamics in this aspect of the game will be an interesting thing to watch.\n\nGoing back to the Duo scenario, did you know that championships past have been won on the shoulders of star duos? Shaq and Kobe for the Lakers, LeBron and Dwayne Wade for Miami. Steph Curry and Klay Thompson for GSW. MJ and Scottie Pippen for the 90s Chicago Bulls.\n\nSo many things to watch out for in this kaleidoscopic match-up. Like who's good enough on the Celtics' side to guard Luka and Kyrie and keep their production low? What's the Mavs' formula for eluding or crushing the vaunted Celtics defense? In turn, what kind of defense will the Mavs concoct to stop the Celtics' fluid offense?\n\nSo many scenarios that are just as good to watch on the side. What will Kyrie's new adventure in the Garden be? Everybody seems to have grown up since the days when Uncle Drew burned sage, stomped on Lucky on the Celtics' logo and did a smooth but not so subtle raising of two dirty fingers behind the back of his head at the Garden crown. Kyrie has acknowledged that his past TD Garden moment was regrettable -- \"wasn't a great reflection of himself.\" But the Boston faithful don't forgive easy. And they never forget.\n\nBrian Martin of NBA.com says there are eight things that the Celtics have in common with other past champions. They are: a star duo, elite offense, elite defense, scoring more points than they allow their opponents, three-point shooting prowess, two all-defensive guards, 75+ wins and 20 or fewer losses in the season, and the privilege and luxury of being well-rested.\n\nLook, the 2023 Denver Nuggets had nine days off last year before they played their NBA finals series. As did the Golden State Warriors in 2017.\n\nThe Boston Celtics were 2-1 in the playoffs when they were on exactly 9 days of rest, all-time, says StatMuse.\n\nIf the stats hold true, we can all raise a cup of joe to the coach, Mazzula. And Boston's rafters will finally have that No. 18 hanging up there along with the rest.\n\nIn the end though, the basketball gods decide. Luka and Kyrie can ride off beaming into the sunset. Or the three Jays plus 'Old Man\" Al, Derrick White, the comebacking Kristaps Porzingis and the rest of the crew will be grinning from ear to ear.", "source": {"uri": "businessmirror.com.ph",
