{"uri": "8164632187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:06:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:06:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:06:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://hardwoodhoudini.com/posts/3-burning-questions-boston-celtics-finals", "title": "3 burning questions for the Boston Celtics ahead of the Finals", "body": "Boston Celtics v Indiana Pacers - Game Four / Justin Casterline/GettyImages\n\nQuestioning if Jayson Tatum will show up in these NBA Finals is entirely valid considering the stinker of a series he put up in 2022. In the 2022 NBA Finals against the Golden State Warriors, JT shrank under the pressure only averaging 21 points, seven assists, and seven rebounds on a measly 37% shooting from the field. These games were marked by either Tatum getting off to ridiculously slow starts or trying to do everything himself and forcing the issue. Neither version of the star forward will win a championship.\n\nJayson Tatum is having a tremendous playoff run thus far no matter what media pundits and casual fans will say to discredit his performance. Through all three rounds, he is leading the team in points, rebounds, and assists becoming the first player to do this since 2018 LeBron James. He is averaging 26 points, 10.4 rebounds, and 5.9 assists on 44% shooting. The only notable improvement comes from him needing to knock down the three more efficiently as 29% is not ideal. However, in turns of complete play, this has been his best playoff stint to date.\n\nWhen the lights are brightest will the wing fold or win gold?\n\nA story as old as time when the Boston Celtics played drop coverage against the Golden State Warriors back in 2022 and regretted it deeply because of how Stephen Curry dominated. In these playoffs, under Joe Mazzulla, the Celtics have kept playing drop coverage throughout to mixed success. He's been willing to live with getting burned in the mid-range by opposing teams, but there is a difference in the type of opponents now.\n\nRound one saw guards like Tyler Herro, and Delon Wright so it worked pretty well. Round two saw an injured Donovan Mitchell and the inconsistency of Darius Garland and Caris LeVert. The Eastern Conference Finals saw Tyrese Haliburton thrive before getting injured and Andrew Nembhard absolutely cook in those moments. The difference is on the other end, the Celtics were always able to dominate the perimeter with these teams and get timely stops when they needed to in order to win.\n\nAgainst the Dallas Mavericks, doing a drop coverage against two mid-range maestros would prove disastrous for the Boston Celtics. Kyrie Irving and Luka Doncic may very well be the most dangerous offensive backcourt the game has ever seen.\n\nIn the 2022 Finals, the Celtics bench went into ghost mode providing no depth on the biggest stage. Al Horford will supposably join and lead this second unit. Big Al is in year 17 and this may very well be his last chance to win a ring. The level of urgency for the big man means we are more than likely to count on a legacy game or two in the series. In six games of the 2022 NBA finals, Payton Pritchard averaged three points, two rebounds, and one assist on 30% shooting and did not score in the final three games he played in during the series. Sam Hauser was not a part of the rotation back then and is struggling to replicate his shooting prowess from the regular season.\n\nHauser was signed on to the C's bench to do two things: hit threes and play defense well enough to hold his own. There is no reason he is not fully capable of having a game where four or five threes are netted. We will dub it the Sam Hauser game, and hold it in the same lore as legendary performances of other role players such as Grant Williams, Kelly Olynyk, and Leon Powe.\n\nPritchard has been on a heater recently and should be a top-three bench player in the Finals. He has hit double-digit scoring marks in five of the Celtics 14 playoff games -- they are 4-1 when he scores 10 or more points. {"uri": "8161468979", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:29:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:29:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:27:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/top-performers-eastern-conference-finals/", "title": "Top 5 Performers of the 2024 NBA Eastern Conference Finals", "body": "The Eastern Conference Finals saw multiple players step up on both fronts, but which ones were the best?\n\nHighlights Jaylen Brown's clutch performance earned him the series MVP over Jayson Tatum. Both Tatum and Brown's offensive prowess overwhelmed the Indiana Pacers. Derrick White's defense and clutch three-point shooting were key for the Celtics' series win. GIVEMESPORT VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nThe final step prior to the NBA Finals is the Conference Finals. By the time the penultimate round of the NBA Playoffs rolls around, four teams (two in each conference) remain.\n\nBut upon the round's conclusion, the pain sets in for two teams as they realize they made it potentially within a game of reaching the NBA Finals, but ultimately lost. For the other team, euphoria sets in as they officially punch their ticket to the Finals, earning the right to take on the respective club in the mirroring conference that did the same.\n\nA team must possess no shortage of star power to even reach the Conference Finals, let alone win it. And in this year's Eastern Conference Finals, both the Boston Celtics -- the winner -- and the Indiana Pacers -- the loser -- that was surely the case.\n\nThe Celtics defeated the Pacers thanks to said talent, but if not for the Pacers' assortment of talent, they would not have reached this point. The following are the five best performers of the 2024 Eastern Conference Finals.\n\n1 Jaylen Brown Brown's elite performance earned him the series MVP\n\nThe current iteration of the Celtics has been, for the most part, headlined by Jayson Tatum, with Jaylen Brown serving as his 1A. When it mattered most in these playoffs, they both shone, but Brown took his clutch factor to another level, and that earned him the series MVP award over Tatum.\n\nIn the Eastern Conference Finals, which ended up being a four-game sweep, Brown averaged 29.8 points, 5 rebounds, and 3 assists per game. He shot 51.7 percent from the field and 37.0 percent from three-point range.\n\nJaylen Brown - 2024 ECF Stats\n\nPTS\n\n29.8\n\nREB\n\n5.0\n\nAST\n\n3.0\n\nFG%\n\n51.7\n\n3PT%\n\n37.0\n\nBut it was his performance in clutch moments that earned him the series MVP and made him the series' best performer, in addition to his otherworldly offensive stats. In Game 1, he would nail the corner three-point shot that sent the game to overtime, where the Celtics would eventually win it.\n\nThen he doubled down on his team's Game 1 win by putting up 40 points in Game 2, tied for his most ever in a playoff game. Tatum won the inaugural Larry Bird trophy for the Eastern Conference Finals MVP in 2022, and now, it was Brown's elite play that earned him the 2024 iteration of that award.\n\n2 Jayson Tatum Tatum put up offensive numbers that the Pacers could not counter\n\nWhere Brown was, Tatum was right by his side. It has been no secret that Tatum is the centerpiece of this current Celtics squad, which finished miles above any other team in the standings.\n\nBut in the Eastern Conference Finals, Tatum would be his usual self, which is all that is needed for him to automatically be one of the series' best performers. He meshed with Brown perfectly to dominate the Pacers on all ends of offense, averaging a double-double of 30.3 points and 10.3 rebounds per game.\n\nJayson Tatum - 2024 ECF Stats\n\nPTS\n\n30.3\n\nREB\n\n10.3\n\nAST\n\n6.3\n\nFG%\n\n46.3\n\n3PT%\n\n30.6\n\nIn addition to those stats, Tatum averaged 6.3 assists and 3.3 turnovers in the four-game sweep, while shooting 46.3 percent from the field and 30.6 percent from three-point range. Tatum's ability to come up when it matters most was on full display in this series, easily making him one of its top performers.\n\n3 Derrick White White's elite defense and ability to hit clutch threes meshed perfectly\n\nThe Celtics' primary gameplan has become the reliance on splash threes to blow opponents away, and Derrick White brought that ability in addition to elite defense in this series. The All-Defender shot 33.3 percent from the three point range this series, but it would be his huge corner three in Game 4 that would solidify the Celtics' comeback, win, and series sweep.\n\nWhite finished Game 4 with 16 points, which was his average for the series. He also notched five steals and three blocks in that game, becoming the first player to do so in a Conference Finals game since Scottie Pippen.\n\nOverall, White averaged 16.8 points, 4.8 rebounds, and 6.5 assists in the series, while shooting 43.4 percent from the field and the aforementioned 33.3 percent from three-point range. Those numbers, combined with his ability to put them up in clutch moments and towering defense, made White one of the best players in the series.\n\n4 Pascal Siakam Siakam stepped up in the absence of Tyrese Haliburton\n\nDespite the Pacers' series loss, which was a lot closer than a close glance would indicate, Pascal Siakam stepped up as the player they traded for at the Trade Deadline. Tyrese Haliburton, the main star of the team, got hurt after Game 2 and missed the rest of the series, and Siakam did his best to step up in Haliburton's absence.\n\nPascal Siakam - 2024 ECF Stats\n\nPTS\n\n23.3\n\nREB\n\n7.5\n\nAST\n\n4.5\n\nFG%\n\n55.3\n\nHe led the Pacers in offense this series, averaging 23.3 points, 7.5 rebounds, and 4.5 assists per game. He also shot 55.3 percent from the field, continuing the trend of the Pacers' elite shooting.\n\nWhile the series was a four-game sweep, each game was pretty close, with Boston making a late comeback in two instances. That is inexcusable if you're the Pacers, but Siakam did what he could to serve as an offensive threat for the Celtics in Haliburton's absence, earning him a spot on the list.\n\n5 Jrue Holiday Holiday rounded out a dynamic Celtics rotation that pounded the Pacers\n\nThe Celtics had it all in this series: a dynamic offense, pinpoint shooting, and towering defense. Jrue Holiday served as the Celtics' fourth-best player in the Eastern Conference Finals, but thanks to how talented Boston truly is, that still meant that he was one of the series' best performers.\n\nJrue Holiday - 2024 ECF Stats\n\nPTS\n\n18.5\n\nREB\n\n7.3\n\nAST\n\n5.8\n\nFG%\n\n58.7\n\n3PT%\n\n41.7\n\nThe Celtics traded for Holiday in the 2023 offseason with the hopes of bolstering their defense, and he has brought that in addition to offense. In the Eastern Conference Finals, Holiday averaged 18.5 points, 7.3 rebounds, and 5.8 assists per game, while shooting 58.7 percent from the field and 41.7 percent from three-point range.\n\nThose are not bad stats for a fourth player, and a defender at that, and it is why he was easily one of the best performers of the Eastern Conference Finals.\n\nRelated Top 5 Performers of the 2024 NBA Western Conference Finals The Western Conference Finals saw multiple players step up on both fronts, but which ones were the best?", "source": {"uri": "givemesport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8164900146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:54:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:54:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:50:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/nba-career-comparisons-luka-doncic-kyrie-irving-and-jayson-tatum/article_7ba3aa00-0a73-50a7-8e90-3b721b6382da.html", "title": "NBA Career Comparisons: Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving, And Jayson Tatum", "body": "Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving, and Jayson Tatum are three of the most prominent names in today's NBA, each leaving a significant mark on the game with their unique talents and achievements. As we delve into their careers, we will evaluate key metrics such as points per game, All-Star selections, MVP awards, and more to determine who stands out as the most impactful player. With Irving's championship experience, Doncic's rapid rise to stardom, and Tatum's consistent excellence, this comparison aims to highlight the strengths and accomplishments of each player, offering a detailed look at their contributions to the NBA. Join us as we break down their careers and see who comes out on top in this ultimate basketball showdown.\n\nBest Stats\n\n1. Luka Doncic - 28.7 PPG, 8.7 RPG, 8.3 APG, 1.2 SPG, 0.5 BPG (3 Points)\n\n2. Kyrie Irving - 23.6 PPG, 4.0 RPG, 5.7 APG, 1.3 SPG, 0.4 BPG (2 Points)\n\n3. Jayson Tatum - 23.1 PPG, 7.2 RPG, 3.5 APG, 1.1 SPG, 0.7 BPG (1 Point)\n\nLuka Doncic has played 6 seasons for the Dallas Mavericks, and his stats reflect his status as one of the most versatile players in the league. Averaging 28.7 points per game, Doncic is a scoring machine, capable of lighting up the scoreboard on any given night. His 8.7 rebounds per game highlight his ability to battle in the paint and secure crucial boards, while his 8.3 assists per game show his playmaking skills and vision on the court. Additionally, Doncic contributes on the defensive end with 1.2 steals per game, making him a formidable all-around player.\n\nKyrie Irving has consistently been one of the best point guards in the league, known for his incredible handles and scoring ability. He averages 23.6 points per game, showcasing his ability to score from all areas of the court. Irving also adds 4.0 rebounds and 5.7 assists per game, reflecting his capability to contribute in multiple facets of the game. His 1.3 steals per game underscore his defensive presence, even though his primary reputation lies in his offensive skills.\n\nJayson Tatum has emerged as a leading scorer for the Boston Celtics, averaging 23.1 points per game. His 7.2 rebounds per game demonstrate his ability to play physically and secure important rebounds. Tatum also averages 3.5 assists per game, showing his willingness to share the ball and create opportunities for his teammates. Defensively, Tatum contributes with 1.1 steals and 0.7 blocks per game, proving his effectiveness on both ends of the floor.\n\nMost NBA Championships\n\n1. Kyrie Irving - 1 Championship (3 Points)\n\nT2. Luka Doncic - 0 Championships (2 Points)\n\nT2. Jayson Tatum - 0 Championships (2 Points)\n\nIn the championships category, Kyrie Irving stands out as the only player among the trio with an NBA title. Irving won his championship with the Cleveland Cavaliers in 2016, playing a pivotal role in the team's success. His clutch performance, including the memorable game-winning shot in Game 7 of the Finals, cemented his legacy as a champion.\n\nLuka Doncic and Jayson Tatum are still on their quest for their first NBA championships. Both players have shown tremendous potential and have led their teams deep into the playoffs, but they have yet to capture the ultimate prize. Doncic's leadership and Tatum's scoring prowess make them strong contenders for future titles, but for now, Irving holds the edge with his championship pedigree.\n\nMost Finals MVP Awards\n\nT1. Luka Doncic - 0 Finals MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nT1. Kyrie Irving - 0 Finals MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nT1. Jayson Tatum - 0 Finals MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nKyrie Irving has played in three NBA Finals (2015, 2016, 2017) with the Cleveland Cavaliers. His most notable performance was in 2016, where he hit the game-winning shot in Game 7 to help secure the championship. Despite his impactful play, he did not win the Finals MVP.\n\nJayson Tatum reached the NBA Finals with the Boston Celtics in 2022. Though the Golden State Warriors defeated the Celtics, Tatum's strong performance highlighted his potential as a future Finals MVP contender.\n\nLuka Doncic has yet to appear in the NBA Finals. However, his playoff performances for the Dallas Mavericks suggest that he has the capability to lead his team to the Finals and compete for the MVP award.\n\nThis year, all three players will have a chance to compete for the Finals MVP in the Dallas Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics Finals matchup. Each star will be aiming for their first Finals MVP, adding extra excitement to this highly anticipated series.\n\nMost MVP Awards\n\nT1. Luka Doncic - 0 MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nT1. Kyrie Irving - 0 MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nT1. Jayson Tatum - 0 MVP Awards (3 Points)\n\nNone of these players have won an MVP award, but they've each come close. Luka Doncic was closest in the 2023-24 season, finishing 3rd in MVP voting. His outstanding performance that season, leading the Dallas Mavericks with his impressive all-around game, solidified his place among the league's elite.\n\nKyrie Irving has not been a finalist but had notable seasons where his scoring and playmaking garnered attention. His best finish in MVP voting was 9th place during the 2014-15 season, showcasing his impact when healthy and leading his team.\n\nJayson Tatum has not won an MVP but finished in the top 10 in voting multiple times, with his best position being 6th place in the 2021-22 season. His scoring, defense, and all-around play for the Boston Celtics have made him a consistent candidate for the award.\n\nRelated: 2024 NBA Finals: Celtics vs. Mavericks (Analysis, Comparison, Prediction)\n\nMost All-NBA Team Selections\n\n1. Luka Doncic - 5 All-NBA Selections (3 Points)\n\n2. Jayson Tatum - 4 All-NBA Selections (2 Points)\n\n3. Kyrie Irving - 3 All-NBA Selections (1 Point)\n\nLuka Doncic leads this category with 5 All-NBA selections, all of which are First Team honors. This consistent recognition highlights his dominant presence in the league and his status as one of the top players in the game.\n\nJayson Tatum follows with 4 All-NBA selections, including 3 First Team and 1 Third Team. His impressive scoring and all-around play for the Boston Celtics have earned him these accolades, showcasing his impact on the court.\n\nKyrie Irving has 3 All-NBA selections to his name, including 1 Second Team and 2 Third Team honors. Despite battling injuries at times, his exceptional talent and skill have still garnered him recognition as one of the league's best guards.\n\nMost All-Defensive Team Selections\n\nT1. Luka Doncic - 0 All-Defensive Team Selections (3 Points)\n\nT1. Kyrie Irving - 0 All-Defensive Team Selections (3 Points)\n\nT1. Jayson Tatum - 0 All-Defensive Team Selections (3 Points)\n\nIn the All-Defensive Team category, none of the players have secured a nomination yet, putting Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving, and Jayson Tatum on equal footing with 3 points each.\n\nWhile all three players have shown their defensive capabilities at various points in their careers, they have yet to be recognized with an All-Defensive Team selection. Each player has the potential to earn this honor as they continue to develop and refine their defensive skills. As their careers progress, it will be interesting to see if any of them can break into this elite category of defensive recognition.\n\nMost All-Star Selections\n\n1. Kyrie Irving - 8 All-Star Selections (3 Points)\n\nT2. Luka Doncic - 5 All-Star Selections (2 Points)\n\nT2. Jayson Tatum - 5 All-Star Selections (2 Points)\n\nKyrie Irving leads the pack with 8 All-Star selections, earned over his illustrious career. His first All-Star appearance came in the 2012-13 season, and since then, he has been a regular fixture in the event. Known for his incredible handles, clutch performances, and scoring prowess, Irving has been a fan favorite. His All-Star selections highlight his consistent impact and popularity in the league, with memorable moments such as his MVP performance in the 2014 All-Star Game.\n\nLuka Doncic has quickly earned 5 All-Star selections since entering the NBA, a testament to his rapid rise and immediate impact on the league. Doncic made his first All-Star appearance in the 2019-20 season and has been selected every year since. His versatile game, which includes scoring, rebounding, and playmaking, has captivated fans and made him a standout star. Doncic's All-Star selections reflect his status as one of the most exciting young talents in the NBA.\n\nJayson Tatum also boasts 5 All-Star selections, underscoring his role as a cornerstone for the Boston Celtics. Tatum's first All-Star appearance came in the 2019-20 season, and he has continued to be selected each subsequent year. His ability to score efficiently, coupled with his defensive skills and leadership on the court, has earned him recognition from fans, coaches, and peers alike. Tatum's consistent All-Star presence highlights his growing influence and success in the league.\n\nTotal Win Shares\n\n1. Kyrie Irving - 86.2 Win Shares (3 Points)\n\n2. Jayson Tatum - 55.9 Win Shares (2 Points)\n\n3. Luka Doncic - 51.2 Win Shares (1 Point)\n\nKyrie Irving leads this category with 86.2 total Win Shares. This metric highlights his significant impact on the court over his career, contributing to the success of the teams he has played for. Irving's ability to score efficiently, create plays, and perform in clutch situations has translated into substantial contributions to his team's wins.\n\nJayson Tatum follows with 55.9 Win Shares. Since joining the NBA, Tatum has consistently been a key player for the Boston Celtics. His scoring, rebounding, and defensive skills have been instrumental in the Celtics' performance, earning him a high Win Shares total. Tatum's all-around game and leadership have made him a cornerstone of his team's success.\n\nLuka Doncic has accumulated 51.2 Win Shares, reflecting his tremendous impact in a relatively short period. Doncic's ability to contribute across multiple statistical categories -- scoring, rebounding, and assisting -- has made him one of the most valuable players in the league. His performance has directly translated into wins for the Dallas Mavericks, showcasing his importance to the team's success.\n\nPER (Player Efficiency Rating)\n\n1. Luka Doncic - 25.7 PER (3 Points)\n\n2. Kyrie Irving - 22.3 PER (2 Points)\n\n3. Jayson Tatum - 20.1 PER (1 Point)\n\nLuka Doncic leads this category with a PER of 25.7, highlighting his efficiency and all-around impact on the game. Doncic's ability to contribute significantly in scoring, rebounding, and playmaking makes him one of the most efficient players in the league. His high PER reflects his versatility and dominance on the court, consistently performing at an elite level.\n\nKyrie Irving follows with a PER of 22.3, underscoring his scoring efficiency and playmaking abilities. Irving's ability to create his own shot, score from anywhere on the court, and facilitate for his teammates contributes to his strong PER. His efficient scoring and offensive prowess are key factors in his high rating.\n\nJayson Tatum has a PER of 20.1, reflecting his solid all-around game. Tatum's scoring ability, combined with his rebounding and defensive skills, makes him a highly effective player. His PER showcases his capability to contribute positively across various facets of the game, reinforcing his value to the Boston Celtics.\n\nWho Has Had The Greatest NBA Career Out Of Luka Doncic, Kyrie Irving, And Jayson Tatum?\n\nT1. Jayson Tatum - 19 Points\n\nIn this comparative analysis, Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving are tied for the most impactful NBA career so far, based on the points accumulated across various categories. Doncic's exceptional achievements in Best Stats, All-NBA selections, PER, and consistent All-Star selections highlight his rapid rise to stardom. His versatility, scoring ability, and playmaking skills make him one of the most dynamic players in the league.\n\nKyrie Irving showcases his dominance in categories such as NBA Championships, All-Star selections, and Win Shares. Irving's clutch performances and scoring prowess have left a significant mark on the league. His contributions to a championship team and his All-Star appearances reflect his high level of play and popularity.\n\nJayson Tatum, while excelling in several areas, particularly in All-NBA selections and his balanced contributions, comes in third in this overall comparison. Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nWhen the co-stars of the Mavericks are playing that way, there might not be a team in the NBA that can beat them.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDallas, the fifth seed in the West, will need more than one such game in the NBA Finals against the favored Boston Celtics, who had the league's best record by seven games and swept the two-game season series.\n\nThe Mavs -- this deep in the playoffs for the first time since winning the franchise's only championship in 2011 -- also will need the defensive intensity both offensive wizards have shown in these playoffs.\n\n\"It's a beautiful combination,\" coach Jason Kidd said. \"They're in competition right now of who's playing the best defense. That's kind of cool to see because when you look at Kai and Luka, a lot of times they're not known as our defensive guys.\"\n\nIrving and Doncic scored 36 points apiece in the clincher against the Wolves, both shooting better than 50% and combining to make half their 3-pointers.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Mavs didn't need double figures from anybody off the bench, and barely from the other starters.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThey can make that formula work, with at least some help.\n\nP.J. Washington Jr. will draw the difficult defensive assignments against Boston co-stars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. But the midseason acquisition needs to shoot closer to the 47% from 3-point range that he did in the second-round victory over top-seeded Oklahoma City than the 25% he shot against Minnesota.\n\nThe other defense-first starter and key figure in trying to slow Tatum and Brown, Derrick Jones Jr., could provide a boost by matching his 40% shooting from 3 in these playoffs.\n\nThen there's the rim-protecting, pick-and-rolling tandem of centers Daniel Gafford -- the other midseason trade pickup along with Washington -- and rookie Dereck Lively II.\n\nThose two give Dallas an edge over the Celtics, who have a more perimeter-oriented pairing in Kristaps Porzingis and the undersized Al Horford.\n\nBoston also isn't sure what it will get out of Porzingis with the 7-foot-2 Latvian sidelined since the first round by a calf injury.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Celtics get the edge in late-playoff experience, but not by much.\n\nThey are on a three-year run of reaching the East finals and made the NBA Finals in 2022, losing to Golden State in six games after the Warriors beat Dallas in the West finals.\n\nIrving, however, has the most experience in the series on the NBA's biggest stage, with 13 games in the finals. He ranks eighth among players with at least 10 games with a scoring average of 27.7 points.\n\nDoncic doesn't figure to be spooked by his first NBA Finals. The 25-year-old was playing professionally in Spain a decade ago and was the title-winning EuroLeague MVP days before getting drafted third overall in 2018.\n\nHe also is the reason Slovenia reached {"uri": "2024-06-379486777", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "10:33:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T10:33:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T10:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/sports/article288994554.html", "title": "Analysis: Mavs or Celtics? Who has the edge heading into the NBA Finals?", "body": "After a longer than expected break, the NBA Finals is finally on the verge of tipping off and the 2024 Finals could be the most high-profile finals since the Golden State Warriors run in the late 2010's.\n\nWhy? Because unlike last year's Finals between the Nuggets and Heat, there's a lot more starpower between both the Mavericks and Celtics.\n\nThe storylines are lot juicier, too, with Kyrie Irving and Boston big man Kristaps Porzingis facing their former teams on the biggest stage.\n\nThen there's the battle between Luka Doncic and Jayson Tatum, two of the game's brightest superstars who are entering their primes and trying to stake their claim as the best player in the world. On paper, both teams have reasons to feel confident, but who really has the edge?\n\nBreakdown: Just one of the many high-profile individual battles this series, Doncic and Holiday are two of the best at what they do. Doncic is arguably the most lethal scorer in the game and one of the best playoff performers the NBA has had despite him only being 25 years old. In four playoff runs, Doncic is averaging over 30 points per game and this postseason he's picked apart Minnesota's No. 1-rated defense, the No. 1 seed Oklahoma City Thunder and future Hall of Famers Paul George, Kawhi Leonard and James Harden.\n\nBelieve it or not Doncic's averages this postseason (28.8 points, 9.6 rebounds, 8.8 assists) are slightly below his standards. As crazy as it sounds, that's just how dominant Doncic has been in the postseason. On the flip side Holiday had a case as being the league's top perimeter defender for nearly half a decade with a length run of NBA All-Defense selections. One reason the Celtics are back in the finals is the fact they acquired Holiday from rival Milwaukee this off-season.\n\nHoliday was also a catalyst in the Bucks championship run in 2021. Holiday's numbers (12.7 points, 5.6 rebounds, 4.6 assist) are modest compared to Doncic's, but Holiday's the fourth or fifth option for the Celtics and is primarily there for his defense and intangibles, which he has plenty of. There's really no achetype to slow down Doncic, but Holiday might be the closet to it as he has a similar stature to OKC forward Lu Dort, the only defender that's been able to bother Doncic this postseason.\n\nHoliday has enough of an offensive game to where Doncic will have to be engaged defensively the entire series, but this is still the type of matchup Doncic lives for.\n\nBreakdown: Irving will have his hands full when he goes up against White, maybe the most underrated player in the NBA. Irving is a superstar talent that can heat up at any moment and is one of the best closers in the NBA when the fourth quarter arrives. Irving has been up and down throughout the playoffs as his scoring average has gone from 25.6 in the regular season to 22.8 in the postseason as defenses have thrown more double teams at him.\n\nWhite saw his numbers take a step up as his offensive usage increased with Porzingis out of the lineup most of the playoffs. White averaged 15.2 points in the regular and is up to 17.8 points while knocking down 40 percent of his 3-pointers. White has been selected All-Defense two straight seasons and will have a slight size advantage over Irving. Boston will try to use White to wear down Irving on defense as well by running him through screens to get him open looks from deep and White is capable of finishing in the paint.\n\nOn paper, most would say this matchup heavily favors Dallas, but it could be a lot closer than you think.\n\nWings\n\nJaylen Brown and Jayson Tatum vs. P.J. Washington and Derrick Jones Jr.\n\nBreakdown: Two superstar forwards vs. two forwards that just arrived in Dallas this past season. This is the matchup where the Finals could be won or lost for Dallas. Tatum and Brown have arguably been the best duo in the NBA since Tatum joined the franchise in 2017. Boston has had deep playoff run after deep playoff thanks to the brilliance of both. Tatum is a top-10 player in the league while Brown is one of the highest paid and a multi-time all-star.\n\nBoth have great size, athleticism and are three-level scoring threats. Tatum joined Doncic as one of the only players in NBA history to lead to their team in points, rebounds and assists in a playoff series. Tatum is averaging 26.0 points, 10.4 rebounds and 5.9 assists. Brown was voted MVP of the Eastern Conference finals and is averaging 25.0 abd 6.2 rebounds this postseason. Both are also upper echelon defenders on the wing and will likely guard Doncic and Irving at some point.\n\nOn the flip side Washington and Jones have fully embraced their roles this postseason. Washington's provided toughness, rebounding and spacing with his consistency knocking down corner 3s. The same can be said for White, who has guarded the opposing team's best perimeter scorers while also being a factor in transition and knocking 39.6 percent of his 3s. Jones will likely start on Brown with Washington getting a crack at Tatum.\n\nIf either is able to slow their matchup down, then it'll make things easier for Dallas.\n\nBigs\n\nKristaps Porzingis and Al Horford vs. Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II\n\nBreakdown: Lively and Gafford have also been a big reason the Mavericks have advanced this far in the playoffs. The pairing bullied Oklahoma City's smaller frontline and mostly outperformed Minnesota's expensive core of bigs in the Western Conference finals. Gafford is the older veteran that starts the game while Lively is the talented rookie that comes off the bench and has been able to be a sparkplug with his athleticism on both ends of the floor.\n\nBoth have thrived with Irving and Doncic as lob threats while also being quality rim protectors on defense. However, the Celtics frontline will test Dallas in a different way as both Horford and Porzingis do plenty of their damage away from the basket. Horford and Porzingis combine to average over 11 3-point attempts per game and knock roughly 37 percent. Porzingis can also do damage inside, but it's fair to wonder how he'll look after missing the last two rounds of the playoffs with a calf injury.\n\nIf Porzingis is healthy, the edge likely goes to Boston, but if he's rusty then this could be another series for Lively in particular to make an impact.\n\nBench\n\nLively, Maxi Kleber, Josh Green, Jaden Hardy, Tim Hardaway Jr., Dante Exum vs. Horford, Payton Pritchard, Sam Hauser\n\nBreakdown: The Mavericks have the edge with the reserves as Jason Kidd has been able to find valuable minutes from almost every member on the bench. Boston's bench will get a boost with Horford returning to the unit after starting for Porzingis, but Dallas' bench is still younger and more versatile. Hardy has found a groove as a secondary scorer and ballhandler while Green and Exum have provided some sparks on the wing.\n\nHardaway has yet to catch fire this postseason, but averaged 14.4 points per game during the regular season. While Dallas should confident in its reserve, it's important to remember that bench play will only impact the series so much. These are role players and the the trophy will ultimately be decided by which stars shine the brightest between Doncic, Tatum, Brown and Irving.", "source": {"uri": "kansascity.com", "dataType": "https://www.star-telegram.com/latest-news/1f2msb/picture289011314/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/USATSI_22663235.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2156862745098038, "wgt": 137, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8161258767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:08:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:08:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:07:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://celticswire.usatoday.com/lists/welcome-to-jayson-tatums-nba/", "title": "Welcome to Jayson Tatum's NBA", "body": "The stage is set for the 2024 NBA Finals, a clash between the Boston Celtics and the Dallas Mavericks. For Jayson Tatum, this series is a chance to win a first championship ring as a professional and deliver Boston a coveted 18th banner. And though it would be a massive step forward in his career, Tatum is already on a special trajectory regardless of the outcome.\n\nThe NBA's current guard is getting ready to exit stage left, and soon players like LeBron James, Steph Curry, and Kevin Durant will retire. Already debates concerning the next \"face of the league\" have swirled as people begin to imagine a new hierarchy of NBA stardom. Media and fans alike pore over advanced analytics and squeeze every data point to support their position with bared teeth and steely resolve. With the hot take economy churning like never before, every statistic, every award, and every game seems to be a referendum on a player's status in that pecking order.\n\nBut this sort of analysis misses the point of what it really means to be the brightest star in the NBA galaxy. Superstardom is about much more than personal accolades or getting buckets. Take a step back and it becomes clear. This is Jayson Tatum's league now.\n\nYes, to be the biggest name in the NBA, a player does have to be among the very best on the hardwood. The 26-year old Tatum is only now stepping into his prime, but has already authored a nearly unimpeachable resume.\n\nIn 2024 Tatum was named to the All-NBA First Team for a third consecutive season, and he's been an All-Star for five straight years. Since becoming the focal point of the Celtics scoring effort, he's been one of the NBA's most prolific offensive weapons in the league while becoming a very effective defender, too.\n\nSure, Tatum hasn't yet won an MVP award. But he has been firmly in the mix each of the past few years. In 2024 he finished fifth place in voting. He was thirrd in 2023 and sixth in 2022. Statistically only Nikola Jokic, Giannis Antetokounmpo, and Joel Embiid have been in the heart of the MVP conversation this decade as consistently as Tatum.\n\nRegardless of individual accolades, Tatum is one of the most productive stars in the league. This year he piloted his Celtics to 64 wins and a No. 1 seed, earning his fifth trip to the Eastern Conference finals in seven seasons as a pro. Thus far during the 2024 playoffs, he has led Boston in points, rebounds, and assists.\n\nTatum's high level of play is the engine behind his superstardom. Heading into the 2024 finals, he has played in 80 postseason games, the highest number of any NBA player this decade. Besides his teammate Jaylen Brown, the next closest player is Bam Adebayo of the Miami Heat with 69 games played.\n\nNot only has he already been to more conference finals than 11 NBA franchises, Tatum has never missed a playoff game in his career. Load management be damned, when you tune into a Celtics game, Tatum shows up as advertised.\n\nApr 11, 2024; Boston, Massachusetts, USA; Boston Celtics forward Jayson Tatum (0) signs an autograph for a fan prior to a game against the New York Knicks at TD Garden. Mandatory Credit: Bob DeChiara-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIf Tatum wins a title or MVP in the next few seasons, his status as generational star will only grow, although the debate around specific awards and accomplishments will continue. Even if he isn't the single best player in the league, his knack for success has allowed him to take the NBA centerstage again and again. It's a feedback loop, where winning begets more exposure.\n\nWhat this means is that Tatum is incredibly visible to even casual fans. And the league understands he is an attractive star. Boston has the 11th biggest market in the NBA, but has had more nationally televised regular season games than any team in the league in the last few years save the Golden State Warriors and the Los Angeles Lakers. Playing in a second finals in three seasons doesn't hurt either.\n\nTatum has proven himself to be one of the best players in the league, and he and the Celtics are consistently on national television as a result. This alone doesn't always lead to superstardom, however. Tim Duncan is a good example of a generational great who was indifferent to the spotlight. Some guys don't become cultural icons, even if they are the best players on the court. But Tatum has thrived under the bright lights and what comes with. Just ask the NBA's biggest partners.\n\nMarketability and visibility are the key to becoming the true face of a brand as big as the NBA, and Tatum is everywhere when it comes to league sponsorships. More importantly, these partners proactively try to work with the St. Louis native.\n\nAfter SoFi inked a deal to become the official banking service of the NBA, they specifically sought out Tatum as their chosen spokesperson. SoFi told CelticsWire they appreciated Tatum's style and charisma, and how easy he was to work with. He had a reputation as a reliable, effective star for promoting their brand.\n\nThis is a common theme among the NBA's biggest partners. For example, Tatum is one of five players who will be featured in an upcoming Netflix documentary about the Association. He recently graced the cover of NBA 2K's mobile edition, and he's reportedly already developing a third signature shoe with Jordan Brand. The league's most important corporate constituents love Tatum.\n\nPlayers Tatum's age jostling for the status as the NBA's biggest star have their own endorsement deals, too. Most professional athletes do, after all. But Tatum's portfolio of commercials and partnerships is hard to top, and it's difficult to find an area where Tatum hasn't proven to be a marketable star.\n\nImportantly, he isn't just an individual spokesperson. Brand's often put him alongside league's signature stars. Tatum is in commercials for Ruffles chips alongside LeBron James. He does Subway ads with Steph Curry. He helps sell Gatorade with Michael Jordan and Caitlin Clark.\n\nTatum also has appeal across sports leagues. Earlier this year Fanatics and Make-A-Wish paired Tatum with MLB star Aaron Judge and NFL legend Tom Brady. The company Tatum keeps when doing promotional work is unrivaled for his peer group, and another measure of how he is regarded by cultural tastemakers.\n\nThe NBA is an entertainment product at the end of the day. So it's not enough to just show up in a bunch of commercials. Consumers have to have a positive reaction to all of that visibility.\n\nOrdinary fans have indeed responded, and they themselves can't get enough of the former Duke Blue Devil. In 2024, Tatum was third in the entire NBA in jersey sales behind only James and Curry. He was third last year as well, and has been in the top five every season since 2020. Only James and Curry have sold as many or more jerseys than Tatum this decade.\n\nTatum has reach across the broader public, and with great effect. His winning ways have made him one of the most visible players on and off the court. And his personal charm and style have earned him serious exposure, at least to the American public.\n\nThere's an interesting bend to this debate around the next crop of NBA superstars and the possibility of a single \"face of the league.\" For the first time in NBA history, the top players are predominantly international.\n\nAlong with the aforementioned trio of Jokic, Embiid, and Antetokounmpo, it's fair to argue that Luka Doncic and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander are as good or better than Tatum on the court. Victor Wembanyama looks ready to join that conversation soon enough. Tatum is probably the best American-born basketball player, for whatever that's worth.\n\nTatum's star power here in the United States is rock solid, but perhaps his international contemperaries have greater pull overseas. During the upcoming 2024 Olympics in Paris, though, Tatum has a chance to win another gold medal with the entire world watching. Expect his sponsorship partners to ensure his stardom and global reach grow further in that time.\n\nTatum does keep a lower profile compared to other stars. He can be soft-spoken, even in public appearances. He openly admits that he considers himself a shy person.\n\nRegardless, there's a reason the television cameras love seeing him and his son \"Deuce\" prior to Celtics games, or Tatum is often seen embracing his mother afterward. There's an endearing element to Tatum's stardom that seems to connect with people. He's earnest and real, and that resonates with fans.\n\nSo, no. Being a dedicated father who loves to golf isn't the sexiest tagline for a superstar. And Tatum isn't as sharp-tongued as Jordan or Durant. His story isn't as sensationalized as James or Curry. Up-and-coming stars like Doncic or Anthony Edwards have better soundbites. Even Tatum's co-star in Boston Jaylen Brown is usually a better quote.\n\nAs an aside, Brown hasn't sought out the same types of partnerships or exposure as Tatum. He's spent more time and energy in different areas, and pitting the two against one one another isn't really the point. They have their unique niches in the NBA and in the culture. Tatum's more conventional approach to stardom has had broader appeal and reach, at least thus far in their careers, but they're a little apples and oranges in that regard.\n\nJust because Tatum doesn't always go viral after each press conference isn't a huge knock, however. Tatum is careful when speaking to the media. Within reason, he's good at controlling his own narrative, and his mild approach helps him maintain his public image.\n\nTatum has the perfect mix of ingredients to be the league's top superstar. He is one of the best players in the league and only getting better, with a Duke pedigree to boot. Basketball devotees have known his name for years now, and Tatum's resume is only getting stronger.\n\nHe's built the right partnerships, and he has a sterling reputation among advertisers and casual fans. The NBA is eager to elevate his star status further, and the league's most important partners seem to feel the same way.\n\nStardom is about so much more than counting stats and titles, even if rings are the ultimate currency within NBA circles. It's about connecting with casual fans and making a broader impact on the culture. It's about transcending the role of NBA player into a bigger touchstone across interests and communities. No one has hit that mark as well as Tatum.\n\nThe 2024 NBA Finals represent a huge pivot point for Tatum's career. Some of the most prevalent narratives in the league zeitgeist could rise or fall with the outcome of the series. A loud win will put to bed some of the biggest doubts tied to Tatum's name. Imagine if Tatum wins a title in a few weeks, though. He could follow that up by signing a historic contract extension and earning Olympic gold.\n\nA loss would end up being a major stain on Tatum's basketball resume. And the takes would rain down for weeks and months. But even if Tatum and the Celtics come up short, it won't matter. His role as the future center of the NBA landscape is secure.\n\nThis is Tatum's league now.", "source": {"uri": "celticswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Celtics Wire"}, "authors": "https://celticswire.usatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/39/2024/04/USATSI_22983808.jpg?w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623033", "eventUri": "eng-9623033", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-06-377613815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "20:01:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T20:01:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T20:01:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/sports/nba/nba-finals-single-game-record-holders-points-rebounds-more/3427438/", "title": "Single-game record holders for points, rebounds and more in the NBA Finals", "body": "Boston is tied with the Los Angeles Lakers for the most championships, and it will have a chance to regain the top spot for itself with its 2024 NBA Finals matchup against the Dallas Mavericks.\n\nWith so many trips between the Celtics and Lakers, it's no surprise that players from both squads also hold individual Finals records.\n\nHere are some of the individual, single-game Finals records entering this year's championship series:\n\nWho has scored the most points in an NBA Finals game?\n\nElgin Baylor never won a championship during his Hall of Fame playing career, but he still holds an NBA Finals record.\n\nThe Lakers forward erupted for 61 points in Game 5 of the 1962 Finals against the Celtics. He played all 48 minutes, shot 22-for-46 overall and made 17 of 19 free throw attempts in a 126-121 win. Though the Lakers wound up losing the series in seven games, Baylor holds the Finals record for most points in a series with 284.\n\nBaylor is one of just seven players to ever score 50 or more points in a Finals game. Giannis Antetokounmpo is the most recent star to reach that number, doing so in a series-clinching Game 6 win for the Milwaukee Bucks over the Phoenix Suns in 2021.\n\nWho has the most 3-pointers in an NBA Finals game?\n\nThe best 3-point shooter in NBA history is also the best 3-point shooter in NBA Finals history.\n\nSteph Curry holds the all-time and single-game records for most 3-point attempts and makes in the NBA Finals. He set the single-game marks in Game 2 of the 2018 Finals, where the Golden State Warriors guard went 9-for-17 from 3-point range in a 122-103 rout over the Cleveland Cavaliers.\n\nAlong with the nine 3-pointer game, Curry also drained seven 3s in six Finals contests, two of which came in the 2022 Finals against the Celtics.\n\nWho has the most rebounds in an NBA Finals game?\n\nJust like his team won most of their Finals matchups, Bill Russell edged Wilt Chamberlain for the most rebounds in an NBA Finals game.\n\nRussell has two Finals games with 40 rebounds. The first came in 1960 against the St. Louis Hawks and the second came against the Lakers in Game 7 of the 1962 Finals. By comparison, Chamberlain's highest rebounding total for a Finals game was 38, a number he reached twice.\n\nRussell and Chamberlain have an overwhelming presence in the Finals rebounding records. The two centers combined for 73 of the top 100 single-game rebounding outputs in Finals history: 48 from Russell and 25 from Chamberlain.\n\nWho has the most assists in an NBA Finals game?\n\nIt should come as no surprise that Magic Johnson's name is all over the NBA Finals assists records.\n\nThere have been just six times in Finals history that a player has tallied 19 or more assists in a game, and five of them came from Johnson. His highest total came in Game 3 of the 1984 Finals, where he dished out 21 assists in a 137-104 win over the Celtics.\n\nWho has the most turnovers in an NBA Finals game?\n\nAlong with the most assists in an NBA Finals game, Johnson also holds the record for most turnovers in a Finals game.\n\nJohnson turned it over 10 times against the Philadelphia 76ers in Game 5 of the 1980 Finals, which came during his rookie season. The Lakers star struggled with his turnovers and shooting, but he still picked up a triple-double in a 108-103 victory.\n\nJohnson also holds the second-highest mark for turnovers in a Finals game. He turned it over nine times in the Sixers' Game 4 clincher over the Lakers in the 1983 Finals.\n\nWho has the most steals in an NBA Finals game?\n\nSeven is a significant NBA Finals number for Robert Horry.\n\nFirst and foremost, Horry won seven championships in his career. The first two came with the Houston Rockets, the middle three came with the Lakers and the last two came with the San Antonio Spurs.\n\nOn top of that, Horry holds an NBA Finals record involving the number seven. He became the first and only player in league history to pick up seven steals in a Finals game, doing so in Game 2 of the 1995 Finals. The Rockets won that game 117-106 en route to a sweep over the Orlando Magic.\n\nWho has the most blocks in an NBA Finals game?\n\nThe 2009 Finals did not go Dwight Howard's way, but he still made some history during the series.\n\nThe Magic center set an NBA Finals record with nine blocks in a Game 4 loss to the Lakers. He also added 16 points and 21 rebounds, but Orlando fell 99-91 and lost the series in the following game.\n\nPrior to Howard's nine-block performance, five Hall of Famers shared the Finals record with eight blocks in a game: Tim Duncan, Shaquille O'Neal, Patrick Ewing, Hakeem Olajuwon and Bill Walton.", "source": {"uri": "nbclosangeles.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Southern {"uri": "8163354386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:43:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:43:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:43:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.thespread.com/nba-articles/how-to-watch-nba-finals-from-japan/", "title": "How To Watch NBA Finals From Japan?", "body": "This year's NBA Finals are about to begin. Just to quickly recap, it is the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks facing off, with the Celtics advancing to the finals for the first time since 2022 with a 12-2 post-season result. The Mavs, on the other hand, conquered the West and will be making their first Finals appearance since the 2010-11 season. And this will be their first time to face off on the court of the NBA Finals.\n\nIn the 23-24 season, the Celtics led by Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, won both head-to-head matchups between the two teams, which may give the Celtics the edge. The only thing standing in the way of these ace players is Luka Doncic, one of the biggest talents in NBA history, who has played remarkably well throughout the playoffs. The thrilling thing is that, in this final, both players will be in search of their first championship ring.\n\nIf you are reading this, we would assume that you are perhaps in Japan during the unmissable NBA Finals. But worry not. In this article, I would like to show you how to watch the NBA Finals while you are in Japan.\n\nMany sports fans can sometimes be passionate punters. If you bet on sports regularly, you probably know that some bookmakers offer live-streaming features.\n\nIn Japan, you can access many bookmakers, including global sites such as bet365 and 1xbet, as well as local sites specializing in the Japanese betting market. However, due to the licensing situation, we have to emphasize there is no guarantee that the NBA Finals will be streamed on bookmakers accessible in Japan.\n\nAlso, the fact that the NBA Finals are held at night time in the US, which falls in the morning through early afternoon in Japan time, makes this a non-preferred option. So what are other options?\n\nThe most reliable and basic way to watch the NBA Finals from Japan is Rakuten. Rakuten is almost like the Japanese version of Amazon of Japan (although Amazon does exist in Japan as well) and offers a platform called Rakuten TV that allows its subscribers to watch a variety of sports like the NBA and European soccer leagues.\n\nThe LEAGUE PASS is a monthly subscription that allows users to watch all NBA games live or on-demand for 4,500 JPY per month. The price is at the highest end of the other available options, but it is worth signing up for, especially if you have lived in Japan for a long time.\n\nWOWOW was Japan's first SVOD channel and now offers exclusively many international sports, movies, stage shows, music programs, and anime, as well as original drama productions.\n\nWhat is available here is live and on-demand coverage of all NBA Finals games. The price is much lower than Rakuten's, at 2,530 JPY per month. If you are interested in watching only the Finals, this option is highly recommended.\n\nABEMA is an online TV channel. There are regular programs that are available for free and premium programs that are accessible to viewers on a subscription basis.\n\nThey became famous as an international sports channel when they won the exclusive rights for FIFA World Cup 2022. Currently, Abema is partnering with the aforementioned WOWOW, to offer some of the sports programming available on WOWOW, including the NBA Finals, where you can watch the Finals games for less than half the price.\n\nHere we have provided some possible options for those who wish to watch the NBA Finals during their stay in Japan. {"uri": "8164146639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:06:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:06:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:06:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/au/nba/news/celtic-origin-boston-nickname-mascot-history/a595c9cd5cc66d4d874d6a88", "title": "What is a Celtic? Explaining the origin of Boston's nickname, NBA mascot history", "body": "No NBA team has won more championships. No NBA team has won more individual games. And no NBA team has played more games.\n\nBoston's basketball history is rich, and to many, the word, \"Celtics,\" just means basketball.\n\nBut while the Celtics and their name have been a part of the NBA for nearly 80 years, it's likely not everyone knows how the team got its name or its mascot.\n\nSporting News is taking a look back at the history of the Celtic name and mascot history in Boston.\n\nMORE: Jayson Tatum gets candid about Kyrie Irving's Celtics tenure\n\nTo many in the United States, the first thing that comes to mind when hearing \"Celtic\" is the basketball team. But that's not the case globally.\n\nCeltic, internationally, is more widely recognized as the descriptor of Celts, which are people who speak using the Celtic language. The Celtic people have lived across Europe throughout history, though today are best known as Irish, Scottish Gaelic and Welsh people. Many most strongly associated \"Celtics\" as Irish.\n\nWhen it comes to the team name, ironically, it comes from Boston's fiercest sports city rival: New York. The New York Celtics were started in 1914 but disbanded due to World Were I. They were reformed after World War I and called the Original Celtics. They played at Madison Square Garden, but were also largely a barnstorming team, playing up to 205 games nationally, per the Basketball Hall of Fame.\n\nMORE: Will Celtics follow LeBron James' example for defending Luka Doncic?\n\nThe Original Celtics stopped barnstorming in 1926 and joined the ABL in 1926, and won ABL titles in 1926 and 1927. They then returned to barnstorming in 1930 but stopped by 1941.\n\nWhen Walter Brown formed Boston's basketball team, he and Howie McHugh, who handled public relations, went through a range of nicknames, including the Whirlwinds, Unicorns and Olympics, per the Boston Irish Tourism Association. But Brown decided on the Celtics.\n\nThe reason was two-fold: first, the Original Celtics; second, Boston's Irish population.\n\n\"We'll put them in green uniforms and call them the Boston Celtics,\" Brown said, per the Boston Irish Tourism Association.\n\nIt didn't take long before the Celtics adopted a mascot, Lucky the Leprechaun.\n\nRed Auerbach, the coach of the Celtics, asked his brother to design a logo for Boston, per the Boston Irish Tourism Association. The mascot featured aspects of 1950s Irish Americans, which included a bowler hat, a pipe, shamrock clothing and holding a shillelagh.\n\nThe mascot has remained almost the same over the years. In early years, he was leaping in the air, but by 1968-69, he had moved down to a standing posture with his legs crossed and leaning on the shillelagh, per SportsLogos.net. Since then, a few minor color adjustments have been the extent of the changes.\n\nThe Celtics have won 17 championships, tied with the Lakers for the most in the NBA. Boston hasn't won a title since the 2007-08 championship but was the most dominant team of the 1950s and 1960s, winning 11 championships in 13 seasons between 1956-57 and 1968-69.\n\nHere's a look at every Celtics' NBA Finals appearance:\n\nGames 1, 2, 5 and 7 are scheduled to be played at TD Garden in Boston. Two of the biggest stars in the Finals have Chess.com bots and we're offering a limited-time only bot challenge starting on Thursday at 9:00 a.m. ET / 15:00 CEST / 6:30 p.m. IST.\n\nWill the Boston Celtics, led by Eastern Conference Finals MVP Jaylen Brown, win? Or will the Dallas Mavericks, anchored by Western Conference Finals MVP Luka Don\u010di\u0107, rise to the occasion?\n\nStarting on Thursday, Brown and Don\u010di\u0107's bots will have their own section on the bot page and both players' bots will be rated 1000. Their ratings will go up and down based on how many games the Chess.com community plays against each NBA superstar. Think the Celtics will win? Play as many games against Brown as possible.\n\nBoston has been the season favorite to win the NBA Finals, as they've held the best record in the league for a majority of the season. They last appeared in the Finals in 2022, where they lost to the Golden State Warriors. {"uri": "8164983920", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:48:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:48:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:47:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://heavy.com/sports/nba/boston-celtics/celtics-soft-patrick-beverley-weighs-in/", "title": "Are the Boston Celtics Soft? The Fiery Patrick Beverley Weighs In", "body": "Getty Veteran guard Patrick Beverley weighs in on whether or not the Boston Celtics are a \"soft\" team.\n\nThe Boston Celtics begin their quest to bring home Banner 18 on Thursday, June 6, when they host the Dallas Mavericks in Game 1 of the 2024 NBA Finals. The Celtics haven't won a championship since 2008.\n\nLed by Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the Celtics are the favorites in the series after finishing with the best record in the NBA. Despite cruising through the regular season and the playoffs, there always seems to be some doubt with this Celtics team. One of those doubts appears to be their toughness.\n\nVeteran NBA guard Patrick Beverley, who played with the Milwaukee Bucks this season, addressed the issue of Boston's toughness during a radio appearance on the \"Felger & Mazz\" show leading up to the Game 1 showdown with the Mavs.\n\nBeverley is known for his fiery play. A defensive menace, he's sometimes referred to as an agitator. He's comparable to Marcus Smart, the tenacious guard who left Boston after nine seasons. Smart was traded to the Memphis Grizzlies in a three-team deal that brough center Kristaps Porzingis to Boston.\n\nSmart was gritty. He was tough. Some believe when Smart left town, so did Boston's toughness.\n\nThat was brought up during Beverley's radio interview. He was flat-out asked if he thought the Celtics had a reputation for being \"soft.\"\n\n\"Not soft,\" Beverley said. \"Soft is a soft-ass word, so I'm not going to use soft. Do people kind of look at them and be like they haven't been challenged this year? Yes. That comes with everything. You still can't take anything away from them.\n\n\"Have they beaten some banged-up teams? Yes. Is it their fault? No. Have they been the most dominant team in the NBA? Yes. You can't use soft because of their domination throughout the season and postseason.\"\n\nTatum and Brown have both been named All-NBA in their careers and have played together for seven years but haven't been able to win a championship. They got to the NBA Finals in 2022, but they fell to the Golden State Warriors after both Tatum and Brown struggled in the series.\n\nTatum and Brown are one of the best tandems in the NBA. So is Dallas' duo of Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving.\n\nBeverley was asked who he thought was the best player in the series. He danced around the question, saying his idea of the best player are the scrappy guys, like Derrick Jones, Dereck Lively, Jrue Holiday, and Derrick White, who get things done without scoring 25 to 30 points.\n\n\"But if I have to take one (from each team), I'll take Luka Doncic, and I'll take Jaylen Brown,\" he said.\n\n\"You think Jaylen Brown is better than Jayson Tatum?\" host Mike Felger asked Beverley.\n\n\"Right now,\" Beverley said. \"I don't think he's better than him. He was just the Eastern Conference MVP, so you have to give it to him.\"\n\nWhen asked to give his prediction for the series, Beverley shifted quickly and said he'll continue to do so.\n\n\"I like Dallas, but I like Jrue Holiday a lot,\" he said. \"I like Jrue Holiday a lot. Mind you, when I give you this answer, my answer changes every day. Today, it's Boston. Tomorrow, it might be Boston. The next day it might be Dallas, but right now at this moment, it's Boston.\"", "source": {"uri": "heavy.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Heavy"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mike_thomas@heavy.com", {"uri": "8162336238", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "06:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T06:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T06:51:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://fun107.com/boston-celtics-name-origin/", "title": "How the Boston Celtics Got Their Name", "body": "The fact that the Boston Celtics are vying for another world championship banner to hoist to the rafters at the TD Garden should come as no surprise to New England sports fans and anyone else who occupies the six-state region.\n\nThe Celtics are tied with the Los Angeles Lakers for the most NBA championships with 17. They hold the record for the most recorded wins of any team in the NBA. The team has a storied history.\n\nThe Celtics compete in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference as part of the Atlantic Division. The team, one of the NBA's eight original teams, was founded on June 6, 1946 by Walter A. Brown, president of the Boston Garden-Arena Corporation.\n\nGame 1 of the NBA Finals between the Boston Celtics and Dallas Mavericks will occur on June 6, 2024, the 78th anniversary of the Celtic's founding.\n\nThe Celtics began in the Basketball Association of America (BAA) in the 1946-47 season. Their first coach was John \"Honey\" Russell. They finished fifth in the Eastern Division that first season with a 22-38 record.\n\nIn 1949, the National Basketball League merged with the BAA, forming the National Basketball Association.\n\nAccording to Study.com, \"Celtic refers to a group of languages that belong to a particular branch of the Indo-European language family.\"\n\nThe site says, \"It may also refer to the culture of the people who speak these languages\" and adds, \"Irish refers to one particular Celtic language and culture.\"\n\nMost know Boston has a large Irish population and a rich Irish culture and history. So it is not surprising the city has a professional sports franchise with an Irish connection.\n\nWhere did the name \"Boston Celtics\" come from, though?\n\nAccording to the Boston Irish Tourism Association (BITA), team owner Walter Brown and his \"public relations guy, Howie McHugh, were throwing out potential nicknames, including the Whirlwinds, Unicorns, and Olympics.\"\n\nBITA says, 'It was Brown who had the epiphany, saying, \"Wait, I've got it - the Celtics.\"\n\nThe Celtics were named after the 1920s Original Celtics basketball team based in New York City.\n\nThe Boston Celtics played home games at Boston Garden until it was demolished and replaced with the TD Garden.", "source": {"uri": "fun107.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FUN 107"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8165025836", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:16:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:16:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:15:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardhomonoff/2024/06/06/espn-disney-hoping-for-history-and-magic-from-nba-finals-2024/", "title": "ESPN, Disney Hoping For History And Magic From NBA Finals 2024", "body": "There's a massive buzz in sports media right now, including today's report from The Wall Street Journal that the NBA is closing in on a $76 billion package of new carriage rights agreements with NBC, Amazon, and ESPN, which would be a significant realignment for viewers and broadcasters. We've also got the impending launch of the new streaming bundle Venu Sports and the stunning growth of the WNBA and women's sports. On the unalloyed good news front (especially for Boston and Dallas folks), tonight marks a key moment in the U.S. sports media calendar - the start of the NBA Finals (with that term now a well-marketed capitalization!).\n\nFor ESPN, the immediate question is whether this NBA Finals will create what the network has branded as \"moments that matter\"? For fans of the NBA, sports and media in general, what is the alchemy that produces such moments? Here's one fan's take on the secret sauce ingredients for NBA Finals, some of which are in place this year.\n\nIconic Teams (Brands to us media types)\n\nThe presence of marquee franchises unequivocally raises the level of attention, drama, and historical significance in NBA Finals. For baseball it's the Yankees, Cubs, Dodgers and Red Sox (umm...not recently) and in basketball it really comes down to the Celtics and Lakers and maybe the Warriors now. We've got one of them this year as the Boston Celtics go for what would be a record 18 championship (a special number for many of us). There is a texture and historical narrative that that surrounds a Celtics or Lakers pursuit of a championship that can't be manufactured. It's the kind of stuff creative producers take to new heights.\n\nStars and Stories\n\nThe NBA has done a better job of marketing its stars than any other U.S. sports league (other than the NFL's Taylor Swift). The modern NBA came into being with the Larry Bird-Magic Johnson rivalry (and ultimate friendship) in the 1980s and has continued through Michael Jordan, LeBron James, Steph Curry and many more. This year features two of the most dynamic duos in the sport - Luka Doncic and Kyrie Irving from the Dallas Mavericks and Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown of the Celtics. When you add in the off the court drama in Kyrie's hate-hate relationship with seemingly the entire New England region (it's a long story), you've got elements of some elements of Greek tragedy (Better Help usage is going to skyrocket if the Celtics lose to Kyrie).\n\nBroadcast Personalities\n\nHey folks, it's entertainment, so it matters who's on the mic. Baseball was defined by Vin Scully and Jack Buck (\"I don't believe what I just saw!\") and in the 1980 U.S.-Soviet Union hockey game Al Michaels spontaneously scripted maybe the greatest sports line ever (\"Do you believe in miracles?\"). The NBA has benefitted from a series of well-known voices that have heightened the drama and \"bigness\" of moments for decades, including Brent Musberger at CBS covering Bird and Magic, Bob Costas at NBC in the Jordan years, the unmistakable Marv Albert, and now play-by-play man Mike Breen (with his signature call \"Bang!\"). Breen is still there, but today lacks the magic chemistry with his new partners J.J. Redick and Doris Burke that Albert had with Bill Walton and Breen himself developed with Jeff Van Gundy and Mark Jackson. It's not automatic.\n\nCompetition\n\nThere's not much ESPN can do about this one. Sports after all offers up the ultimate reality TV without a pre-set script. The quality and intensity of the competition between the teams has a lot to do with how fondly and strongly an NBA Finals is remembered. A long series is certainly a boon to the bottom line of the broadcaster and the teams filling arenas and tends to cement more longer-term memories. And sometimes individual moments resonate long beyond the overall games themselves. For New Yorkers, even for those not alive at the time, Marv Albert's reveal that \"Willis Reed is coming out of the tunnel!\" still delivers a chill down the spine. No pre-taped packages will work here - all you've got is hope is serendipity.\n\nSince you asked (I see you out there) - here's my own list of the top five NBA Finals (in chronological order) that have \"mattered\" most since the advent of the modern NBA over 40 years ago. Feel free to disagree.\n\n1984 - Celtics/Lakers\n\nSo many elements at play here. This was the first Bird-Magic NBA Finals, a renewal of the historic Celtics-Lakers rivalry that dominated the 1960s, and it went to seven hair-raising games. You still see Kevin McHale's clothesline take-down of the Lakers' Kurt Rambis show up on plenty of NBA highlight (or lowlight) reels. Although it may be hard to believe, this was also one of the first NBA Finals to be broadcast live nationally. As recently as Bird's first championship in 1981, several of the games were tape-delayed to air after the late local news - they weren't seen as likely to drive sufficient ratings in prime time!\n\n1998 - Chicago Bulls/Utah Jazz\n\nThis was the Bulls' sixth and final championship before Michael Jordan's retirement. It has been immortalized in the ESPN documentary series \"The Last Dance.\" It had big stars and one of those craved-for \"moments\" as Jordan hit the final jumper to win the game and championship by one point with five seconds left. As the late Jack Buck might have said \"I don't believe what I just saw!\".\n\n2002 - Lakers/New Jersey Nets\n\nStay with me on this one. This was a four-game sweep, and no one is really going to remember this Nets team (they don't even play in New Jersey anymore). But it was the first and only \"three-peat\" (three championships in a row) in the NBA since the Bill Russell Celtics in the 1960s. The Lakers featured massive stars in Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant as well as hall of fame coach Phil Jackson. The announcers included Marv Albert and the late great Bill Walton - gold at the mic.\n\n2008 - Celtics/Lakers\n\nI know, enough already with the Celtics and Lakers! But this was the first NBA Finals meetings between these two teams in over 20 years. There were stars galore, with Kobe in LA and Paul Pierce, Kevin Garnett, and Ray Allen for the Celtics. At the end was the enduring memory of the championship-starved Garnett screaming out \"Anything is possible!\" which became his signature rallying cry and the title of an acclaimed documentary several years ago.\n\n2016 - Cleveland Cavaliers/Golden State Warriors\n\nIt may be weird that I'm including a Finals where the dynastic Warriors lost, but this was a huge one. The LeBron James-led Cavs won the first professional championship for any Cleveland franchise since Jim Brown and the 1964 Browns. Kyrie Irving (there he is again) hit the famous last shot to win it in seven games. On a personal note, I watched this one live in the middle of the night (and early morning) at the Carlton Hotel in Cannes on the first night of Cannes Lions with a lot of unhappy Silicon Valley folks. Warning to Cannes attendees who are NBA fans - you may in for a couple of very late nights this year!", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_Finals", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NBA Finals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Celtics", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boston Celtics"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_journalism", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sports journalism"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Breen", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Mike Breen"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marv_Albert", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Marv Albert"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Jordan", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Michael Jordan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC", "type": {"uri": "8163267124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:36:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:36:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:35:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/othersport/arid-41410100.html", "title": "Favoured Boston Celtics battle Doncic and the Dallas Mavericks in NBA Finals", "body": "Led by superstars Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown, the sharpshooting Celtics have had a relatively easy road to the finals.\n\nComing out of the weaker Eastern Conference as the top seed, they breezed past the Jimmy Butler-less Miami Heat, dispatched the Cleveland Cavaliers and swept the Indiana Pacers, who were without point guard Tyrese Haliburton for the final two games.\n\nThe Celtics have won 12 of their 14 playoff games and gone undefeated on the road but they know that none of that will matter if they fail to end a title drought that stretches back to 2008.\n\nThe mission is clear - hang that elusive 18th championship banner from the TD Garden rafters and put recent postseason disappointment, including falling to the Warriors in the 2022 finals and coming up short in the conference finals last year, firmly behind them.\n\nAnything less will be seen as a bitter disappointment.\n\n\"They were the best team in the regular season and they have been the best team in the playoffs,\" former player and current ESPN analyst JJ Redick said on a call with reporters.\n\n\"I feel strongly that they are the favorites going into this series. At the same time, I wouldn't be surprised if Luka and Dallas and Kyrie (Irving) and (head coach Jason Kidd) made this a series and won... This is going to be a phenomenal series.\"\n\nStanding in Boston's way is a confident Mavs team under far less pressure and uniquely equipped to ruin the Celtics' title aspirations.\n\nThat starts with Doncic, the 25-year-old Slovenian who is quickly becoming the face of the league.\n\nHe has been the best player in the playoffs and is the first to lead in points (489), rebounds (164) and assists (150) coming into a finals.\n\nBy his side is veteran point guard Irving who, after turbulent stints in Brooklyn and Boston, has looked more comfortable and confident on the court than he has in years.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that offensively they are as talented as any backcourt in NBA history,\" Redick said of Doncic and Irving.\n\nOne big, 7-foot 2-inch question mark hanging over the series is the health of Boston's Kristaps Porzingis, the former Maverick who suffered a calf strain in the Heat series and has been sidelined since.\n\nThe Celtics are hopeful that their prized offseason acquisition, who averaged 20.1 points and 7.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks during the regular season, will be healthy enough to match up against the Mavs' breakout big men Daniel Gafford and Dereck Lively II.\n\nGame One of the NBA Finals is on Friday morning.
