{"uri": "8161723604", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "20:00:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T20:00:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T19:59:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3725490272045135, "url": "https://www.nba.com/news/nba-player-correspondent-program-prepares-players-for-next-stage-2024-finals", "title": "Player Correspondent Program at 2024 Finals", "body": "The NBA Player Correspondent Program provides players with the opportunity to get behind the mic at NBA events all year long.\n\nWhen Dallas Mavericks center Dereck Lively wasn't participating in Panini Rising Stars activities during All-Star Weekend in February, he could be seen walking around with a mic conducting player interviews. One of the players he interviewed was Boston Celtics star Jayson Tatum, who Lively and the Mavs will try to take down in Game 1 of the NBA Finals on Thursday (8:30 ET, ABC).\n\nLively was part of the NBA Player Correspondent Program, which gives players the opportunity to attend events such as All-Star Weekend, NBA Finals and NBA Draft, among others, to serve as media correspondents.\n\nOther notable past participants of the program include:\n\nNBA.com caught up with SVP of entertainment and player marketing, Michael Levine, who helps spearhead the program.\n\nEditor's Note: The following conversation has been condensed and edited.\n\nNBA.com: Since you helped create the NBA Player Correspondent Program, you're the perfect person to drop some knowledge on what it's all about. What do you hope the correspondents learn from participating in the program?\n\nLevine: The reality is that we want to work with our players in unique ways in which they can be perceived positively. We are giving them access to this type of platform, not only from a content standpoint, but from being on the NBA's biggest stage. This is where they aspire to be one day.\n\nThis program really gives players an opportunity to do four things. One, is to build their social profile. We want to keep the momentum from their season going, and get them back in the spotlight.\n\nTwo, we also want them to understand the business of the NBA, and specifically the NBA Entertainment side. So, they're seeing how we cover the Finals from a broadcasting perspective, photos perspective, original content, etc. I think when they go back to their markets, they then have a greater awareness of how things work. They leave with a better sense of how the NBA operates.\n\nThree, is relationship building. So getting to know the people, the league office, our broadcast partners, our global partners, will help all of us build this game. This knowledge then leads to a more trusting and cooperative relationship.\n\nLastly, seeing the NBA Finals, this is where they hope to be. So all those things went into play as we were developing it. And the program has just gotten bigger and bigger over the years.\n\nOff the top of your head, do you remember who was the first person in the program?\n\nIt was CJ McCollum in June of 2015. He actually did it that year and in 2016. In 2015, he stayed for two media days. He interviewed Tristan Thompson, Matthew Dellavedova, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green. The program has changed over the years, but that was the first media day. CJ majored in Journalism at Lehigh so getting into this space was an ideal opportunity for him.\n\nSome impressive names have come through the program since then. Vince Carter, Gary Payton, Donovan Mitchell, Myles Turner to name a few.\n\nWe've had veterans that were looking to get on air experience towards the end of their career, as they were exploring a potential post career in broadcasting. So, it was an opportunity for them to sort of get their feet wet. Channing Frye, Vince Carter, Caron Butler ... these are all guys that wanted to try to get into broadcasting. And we wanted to give them the stage and the opportunity as well.\n\nThere are five budding players for the first four games of the Finals. Game 1: Jabari Smith, Jr.; Game 2: The Thompson Twins; Game 3: Keyonte George; Game 4: Brandin Podziemski. What type of training will they get ahead of time?\n\nWe have calls and try to engage with them prior to being on site, to explain what they're going to be doing and cultivate a level of comfort. When they arrive on site, we have experts from our social media team that work directly with them as well.\n\nI wouldn't say there is a lot of training per se, because we want their personality to simply just come out and be showcased through this. While we do write up some questions, we also give them the opportunity to ask their own. We have even had several players pop into press conferences. So from a training perspective, there's not much [but] a little bit of guidance.\n\nHow does a player get chosen for the program?\n\nThere's not an exact science to it. The reality is that we look at players that have expressed an interest in working more closely with us off the court and who have achieved success on the court. That on court success is essential. So if you look at some of the players that we've worked with, they have had accolades on the court, which can in turn allow them some free time to devote to other opportunities off of it.\n\nDo you have a moment from the program that stands out to you?\n\nJaren Jackson Jr. was quite unique. He got to surprise his former teammate Marc Gasol which made a great social moment. Jaren brought his father, who obviously played in the NBA Finals. So, having Jackson Sr. see his son actually participate in this type of program was special. He got to embrace the fashion game and on top of that he got to interview Draymond Green, who was also a Michigan State alum.", "source": {"uri": "nba.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBA.com"}, {"uri": "8160086532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "22:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T22:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T22:31:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3568627536296844, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/most-durable-superstars-nba/", "title": "5 Most Durable Superstars in the NBA", "body": "In a league full of injured superstars, it's high time to praise the few who are always available.\n\nHighlights Nikola Joki\u0107 is the most durable superstar in the NBA, appearing in an average of 75 games per season. LeBron James has played a career-high 71 games in his age-39 season. Jayson Tatum's old-school approach and appearance in 73.3 regular season games reflect his elite durability. GIVEMESPORT VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nThe tagline for the 2024 NBA Playoffs might go something like, \"durability wins championships\". A historic number of superstars have gone down with injuries during these playoffs (if they were even available to begin with), altering the entire landscape of the NBA title race in the process.\n\nThough it's human nature to pessimistically focus on the \"what if\" potential of injury-riddled superstars like Joel Embiid, Kawhi Leonard, or Zion Williamson, the media doesn't seem to do enough championing superstars who do stay healthy.\n\nWith this in mind, here's a look at the most durable superstars in the NBA, including some honorable mentions.\n\nNikola Joki\u0107 The best player in the world is almost always on the court\n\nThe best player in the world is also the most durable. Nikola Joki\u0107 has played in 75 regular season games per season over his nine-year career in the NBA, winning an NBA championship and three NBA MVPs in the process.\n\nJoki\u0107 has also never missed a playoff game for the Denver Nuggets, who looked very poised to repeat as champions this season before running into a Minnesota Timberwolves defensive roster constructed literally for the sole purpose of neutralizing Joki\u0107.\n\nJoki\u0107's durability is even more impressive considering his size, as he's just short of 7-feet and around 285 pounds. Players the size of Joki\u0107 are normally prone to constant injuries, forcing them to miss significant time every season and be heavily load-managed (Embiid is a recent example).\n\nNikola Joki\u0107 - MVP Seasons Comparison\n\nCategory\n\n2020-21\n\n2021-22\n\n2023-24\n\nPTS\n\n26.4\n\n27.1\n\n26.4\n\nREB\n\n10.8\n\n13.8\n\n12.4\n\nAST\n\n8.3\n\n7.9\n\n9.0\n\nFG%\n\n56.6\n\n58.3\n\n58.3\n\n3PT%\n\n38.8\n\n33.7\n\n35.9\n\nJoki\u0107 has never required load management. He has appeared in less than 70 games only once in his career (69 games played in 2022-23), and he's appeared in 79-plus games on three separate occasions, including this past season.\n\nWith LeBron James presumably headed toward retirement in the next couple of years, Joki\u0107 and Tatum become the current models for superstar durability in the NBA.\n\nLeBron James James has largely missed injuries throughout his decades-long NBA career\n\nWho else could challenge for the top spot on this list but LeBron James, one of the most durable NBA players of all time? James' 1,492 total regular season games played (sixth all-time) is impressive enough, as are his 287 total playoff games played (first all-time), but most pertinent for this list is James' 71 regular season games played per season over a 21-year career.\n\nJames combines the \"man in the arena\" mentality exhibited by Jayson Tatum with the kind of supreme physicality shared by Anthony Edwards and Jaylen Brown. Essentially, James is a model of durability, both mentally and physically.\n\nNotably, James' durability has fallen below his career norm since he joined the Los Angeles Lakers, most certainly as a result of his age.\n\nLeBron James: Regular Season Games Played\n\nSeason\n\nGames Played\n\n2018-19\n\n55\n\n2019-20\n\n67\n\n2020-21\n\n45\n\n2021-22\n\n56\n\n2022-23\n\n55\n\n2023-24\n\n71\n\nJames' diminishing regular season appearances has as much to do with a shift in strategy as anything else, as James has prioritized having his body ready for the playoffs above all else. While such a strategy might disqualify another NBA player from appearing on this list (not to mention in the second position), James gets a pass due to being in his late 30s and having already proven throughout a lengthy career that he is durable when he needs to be.\n\nJames playing 71 games in his age-39 season (this past year) speaks directly to his continuing availability as one of the most durable players in the NBA.\n\nJayson Tatum Tatum is yet to miss the playoffs in his NBA career\n\nJayson Tatum famously doesn't believe in load management, and his availability certainly reflects this mindset. Tatum has appeared in 73.3 regular season games per season over his seven-year career with the Boston Celtics.\n\nOf the five players on this list, Tatum probably has the body that is least protected against injury, but his mentality more than makes up for it. He struggled with a debilitating wrist injury throughout the Celtics' 2022 title run but never missed a game (and later elected to forego offseason surgery).\n\nJayson Tatum - Regular Season vs Playoffs Comparison (Career)\n\nCategory\n\nRegular Season\n\nPlayoffs\n\nPTS\n\n23.1\n\n24.1\n\nREB\n\n7.2\n\n7.9\n\nAST\n\n3.5\n\n4.8\n\nFG%\n\n46.0\n\n44.3\n\n3PT%\n\n37.5\n\n34.9\n\nSimply put, Tatum loves playing basketball, and he takes an old-school approach to wanting to show up every night and give fans a special experience who have never seen him play. Tatum's elite durability, in tandem with Jaylen Brown's, is a huge reason why Brad Stevens and the Celtics franchise have invested all of their chips into this dynamic duo.\n\nGiven all of their athleticism, skill, and accolades, durability is criminally under-discussed when Tatum and Brown arise in NBA discussions. Celtics fans are truly lucky to have a superstar in Tatum who approaches every regular season opportunity with equal humility.\n\nGiannis Antetokounmpo Despite missing the postseason in 2024, Giannis has always been reliable\n\nFor years, Giannis Antetokounmpo's consistent availability during the regular season has been the driving force behind the Milwaukee Bucks continually securing top playoff seeding.\n\nOver his eleven-year career, Giannis has appeared in 72 regular season games per season for Milwaukee, including a three-year stretch between 2014 and 2017 in which Giannis logged 81, 80, and 80 games played in consecutive seasons. In addition to this run, Giannis has appeared in 70-plus games four other times.\n\nGiannis Antetokounmpo - 2023-24 Stats\n\nPTS\n\n30.4\n\nREB\n\n11.5\n\nAST\n\n6.5\n\nFG%\n\n61.1\n\n3PT%\n\n27.4\n\nGiannis' season-ending calf injury at the end of the 2023-34 campaign was all the more shocking, considering his historic durability. After four years before this season of not reaching the 70-game mark (63, 61, 67, and 63 games played, respectively), Giannis returned to elite availability in 2023-24 by appearing in 73 games.\n\nKnown as one of the hardest-playing NBA superstars, Giannis' durability is particularly remarkable. He has added a surprising amount of muscle to his 6-foot-11 frame since entering the league, which has contributed to his ability to bring it night after night throughout the grueling NBA schedule. It will be fascinating to see if Giannis can maintain elite availability late into his career the way that the players at the top of this have done, especially since history shows that such a feat is unlikely to happen.\n\nAnthony Edwards Edwards has emerged as a reliable superstar\n\nAnthony Edwards' limited time spent in the NBA (four seasons) is the only reason he is not higher on this list, since his elite durability has not been proven over as long a stretch as the four players above him.\n\nSo far, however, Edwards is tracking to be as durable as they come. In his four seasons in the league so far, Edwards has totaled regular season game appearances of 72, 72, 79, and 79, averaging 34.4 minutes per game along the way.\n\nAnthony Edwards - Offensive Progression\n\nCategory\n\n2020-21\n\n2021-22\n\n2022-23\n\n2023-24\n\nPTS\n\n19.3\n\n21.3\n\n24.6\n\n25.9\n\nFG%\n\n41.7\n\n44.1\n\n45.9\n\n46.1\n\nUSG%\n\n27.0\n\n26.4\n\n29.9\n\n32.3\n\nEdwards' durability doesn't come as a surprise to anyone aware of his competitive nature, not to mention his elite physique. Like Jaylen Brown, Edwards possesses the sort of body just as appropriate for heavyweight boxing or NFL football as it is advantageous in the NBA.\n\nEdwards' durability and attitude towards showing up every night is another point of comparison between Edwards and Michael Jordan, who, although many are unaware, played in all 82 games in nine of his NBA seasons, including Jordan's last season at age 39 playing for the Washington Wizards.\n\nRelated Keon Ellis' Rise Could Lead to Several Trades in the Off-Season The rising guard carved out a spot for himself in Sacramento's rotation throughout
